HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Publicis begins an extensive, and risky, reshuffling of accounts and people.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
IN one of the most sweeping post-acquisition reorganizations by an agency company, the Publicis Groupe in Paris is embarking on an ambitious -- and risky -- reshuffling of assets, accounts and employees that affects some of the biggest names in marketing like General Motors and Procter & Gamble.
 The reorganization, formally described yesterday after weeks of speculation, is centered on the elimination of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, a Madison Avenue mainstay that traces its roots to a shop founded in St. Louis in 1906. Publicis acquired D'Arcy last month along with other major agencies like Leo Burnett Worldwide when it completed a $3 billion takeover of the Bcom3 Group. 
 D'Arcy's clients, accounting for an estimated $9.4 billion in billings, and 6,000 employees in 72 countries will be reapportioned among three of the four largest Publicis agencies: Burnett, Publicis Worldwide and Saatchi & Saatchi Worldwide. In the United States, most D'Arcy operations will become part of the American operations of Publicis Worldwide. But some big clients like General Motors, with billings estimated at $400 million, and General Mills, an estimated $180 million, are being steered to Burnett or Saatchi & Saatchi.
"We want to make sure we are making the right decisions how best to serve our clients," Maurice Levy, chairman and chief executive at Publicis, said in a telephone interview from his Paris office.
"D'Arcy is in one of the down cycles an agency can face in its history," he added, referring to recent large account losses like Mars. "There is a view the D'Arcy brand is not as strong as the other ones. To make D'Arcy as competitive as Burnett or Publicis or Saatchi would require a lot of investment."
Publicis has grown into the world's fourth-largest agency company by deftly integrating a skein of acquisitions that included Saatchi & Saatchi, Fallon Worldwide and Hal Riney & Partners. For the most part, analysts say, Publicis avoided the disruptions, client defections and ego clashes that cost competitors like the Interpublic Group of Companies hundreds of millions of dollars in lost billings.
Still, there have been far more examples of failed reorganization attempts than success stories in the advertising world. And that means Publicis must tread gingerly in seemingly uncomplicated areas like staffing levels and office relocations, which could prompt top managers and clients to walk out the door.
"On paper, taking out administrative and other costs offers the possibility of savings, but you also have the possibility of disrupting the way people work," said Alan J. Gottesman, an analyst at West End Communications/Consulting in New York.
"Especially with what's going on in the economy, people are skittish," he added. "You have to reassure them there will be continuity or they feel their whole world is shaken up because what was important in the past is not anymore, and their future is dimmed."
That point of view was echoed by a D'Arcy client, James D. Speros, chief marketing officer for the United States at Ernst & Young in New York, which consolidated its account at D'Arcy in 1998.
"In the end, it's all about the people who work on your business," Mr. Speros said. "I have a great team on my account and I've been told they'll stay intact, so I'm thrilled."
By giving senior posts in the reconstituted agencies to top managers at D'Arcy, Mr. Levy hopes to elicit similar reactions from other big D'Arcy clients like Bristol-Myers Squibb ($150 million in billings, according to the trade publication Adweek), Capital One ($170 million), Heineken ($125 million), Philips ($250 million) and Procter ($450 million).
Susan Gianinno, 54, president and chief branding officer at D'Arcy in New York, is to become chairwoman and chief executive at Publicis Worldwide USA, which will now work for D'Arcy clients like Ernst & Young and Heineken. She will succeed Robert H. Bloom, chairman and chief executive, who has worked for Publicis since 1993 when his agency became the first to be acquired by Publicis in this country.
"I've been a part of these transactions several times," said Mr. Bloom, 68, who will serve as a consultant to Publicis, "and if the people respected and liked by clients continue to work on their business, it makes a difference."
Patrick Sherwood, 51, chief executive at D'Arcy North America in Troy, Mich., which has for decades handled the Cadillac and Pontiac accounts for General Motors, is to become president and chief executive of a new unit of Burnett. Gary Topolewski, 46, executive creative director at the Troy office, will be global chief creative officer at the unit. The unit, not yet named, is to be devoted exclusively to advertising, public relations, promotion and interactive marketing for G.M. D'Arcy and predecessor agencies have worked on and off for Cadillac since 1915 and continuously for Pontiac since 1935.
That shift will significantly bolster Burnett, which had been facing an end to its relationship with General Motors in 2004 when its Oldsmobile division is eliminated. The recent D'Arcy work for Cadillac -- complete with Led Zeppelin songs -- has been acclaimed for its ability to appeal to younger consumers, which G.M. and the agency had failed to achieve after years of failures and false starts.
Two other senior D'Arcy executives in New York are being named to new posts. Lee Garfinkel, 47, president and chief creative officer, will become worldwide creative director at Publicis Worldwide. And John Farrell, 45, president and chief executive, will serve as president and chief executive at the Specialized Agencies and Marketing Services division of Publicis.
"You have seen how we have been able to integrate Saatchi & Saatchi," Mr. Levy said, referring to the addition of that agency to the Publicis ranks in 2000, "and that is the model we want to follow."
"We want zero fallout among clients and minimum disruption of people," he added.
That is why some D'Arcy clients are being shifted to Burnett or Saatchi & Saatchi rather than Publicis Worldwide USA: the goal is to avoid potential conflicts or match them with an agency they already know. For example, Saatchi & Saatchi already handles General Mills' Big G cereals and Pillsbury brands.
As for layoffs, Mr. Levy said he could not determine that until Publicis executives sort through how the D'Arcy operations outside the United States are to be divided among Burnett, Publicis Worldwide and Saatchi & Saatchi.
The D'Arcy name joins a lengthy list of venerable Madison Avenue brands that were recently merged out of existence, including N. W. Ayer, Lintas and Needham Harper Worldwide.
D'Arcy was formed by mergers of numerous agencies that included D'Arcy Advertising, MacManus Inc. and Benton & Bowles. The D'Arcy parent, the MacManus Group, merged with the Burnett parent, the Leo Group, to form Bcom3. One of the most famous ads ever, a 1915 magazine ad for Cadillac called "The Penalty of Leadership," was written by Theodore F. MacManus.
The last line of that ad resonates today: "That which deserves to live -- lives."

HEADLINE: An Effort to Undo an Old Reservoir 

BYLINE:  By DEAN E. MURPHY 

DATELINE: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, Calif., Oct. 8 

 BODY:
An old black and white photograph hangs behind the bar at the Evergreen Lodge, a rustic roadside establishment just outside this park. It shows wildflowers dancing in the thick grass. A river glides between a pair of imposing granite walls.
 To visitors here, the scene from 1914 looks instantly familiar. 
 "People think it is Yosemite Valley," said Dan Braun, the lodge's proprietor. "But it is not. They have no idea that Hetch Hetchy looked like that, too." 
For most of the past century, the Hetch Hetchy Valley, 15 miles north of its more famous and bigger sibling within the park, has served as a 300-foot-deep bathtub holding melted snow from the High Sierra for people and businesses in San Francisco and its suburbs. Now a group of environmentalists wants to drain the eight-mile-long reservoir and restore the valley to what John Muir once described as a "grand landscape garden, one of nature's rarest and most precious mountain temples." 
The proposal has generated excitement among employees of the national park, consternation among San Francisco's water interests and political feuding between the environmentalists and City Hall. A citywide ballot measure in November calls for raising $1.6 billion to improve the Hetch Hetchy water delivery system, which several studies have shown to be outdated and vulnerable to a big earthquake, but environmentalists are opposing it. 
The environmentalists want to dismantle the 80-year-old O'Shaughnessy Dam on the Tuolumne River and release the 117 billion gallons of water held behind it in the Hetch Hetchy Valley. By doing so, more than 1,900 acres of submerged valley floor would be uncovered, an area that Muir liked to call the "Tuolumne Yosemite." 
"People say this is a radical idea, but wasn't it a radical idea to put a dam in a national park?" said Ron Good, executive director of Restore Hetch Hetchy, an organization formed to raise money and rally support for the restoration plan. "Imagine the opportunity we have to allow nature to recreate another Yosemite Valley."
To start, the environmentalists are thinking small and are not proposing any specific way of replacing the reservoir. Instead, they have asked San Francisco to help pay for a study to determine the cost of the proposal and to come up with alternatives -- perhaps building or expanding reservoirs or using aquifers. The study would also seek a replacement for the hydroelectric power generated by the system. Mr. Good and the other proponents say they do not want to take water or power away from San Francisco, but rather rework the network "so it is a win-win for everyone." 
So far the city has refused. But San Francisco's top water official, Patricia E. Martel, said the door was not entirely closed, even though she and many other officials consider the idea far-fetched and suspect it would cost billions of dollars.
Ms. Martel, who is general manager of the San Francisco Public Utilities Commission, said the agency would cooperate with a study that was paid for and undertaken by some other organization. She also said the general notion of replacing the reservoir would be explored in environmental reviews that would soon be needed as part of repairs and upgrades planned for the system.
"We are willing to cooperate with the environmental groups, but we are not willing to take the lead and say our mission is to restore Hetch Hetchy," Ms. Martel said. "We don't believe we have a requirement to fund that study."
In the old days, Hetch Hetchy -- it was named by the Ahwahneechee and Paiute Indians for the type of grass that once grew there -- was a breathtaking glacier-carved valley in a newly established national park, not unlike Yosemite along the Merced River. But Congress voted in 1913 to allow San Francisco, 160 miles to the west, to flood the valley in an effort to secure a reliable water supply. Richard W. Sellars, a longtime National Park Service historian, describes the decision as "the most famous and egregious invasion of a national park."
Muir was a fierce opponent of the reservoir, and was said to have died of a broken heart in 1914 after failing to block it. "Dam Hetch Hetchy!" he wrote in his book "The Yosemite." "As well dam for water-tanks the people's cathedrals and churches, for no holier temple has ever been consecrated by the heart of man."
Among Restore Hetch Hetchy's supporters is Donald P. Hodel, the former secretary of the interior under President Ronald Reagan, who floated a similar restoration proposal in the late 1980's. Though the dismantling of productive dams is not common practice, Mr. Hodel said he got the idea from Rocky Mountain National Park, where a damaged dam was taken down a decade ago. Since then, there have been other dismantlings of dams, especially ones that interfered with fisheries.
Like Muir before him, Mr. Hodel was silenced by powerful water interests. Mr. Hodel said he had little in common with the new group pushing for the Hetch Hetchy study, but he was willing to lend his name to the cause because he still believed in it. He also remained incensed at what he described as the duplicity of many San Franciscans. They are known to champion environmental causes, he said, but seem blind to the destructiveness of their own water policies.
"All of the arguments made against a study of Hetch Hetchy were about San Francisco's birthright to flood that valley -- that it is our vested economic right," Mr. Hodel said in telephone interview from Colorado, where he lives in semi-retirement. "Those are the same arguments made by slaveholders in opposition to abolition."
Mr. Hodel was especially critical of Senator Dianne Feinstein, who was instrumental in sinking his proposal when she was mayor of San Francisco and who remains a fierce opponent of any tinkering with the reservoir.
"You would think she would say, 'Let's look at the facts, let's look at the merits of this,' " he said. "But she had determined to her satisfaction that it would never work and it was unsuitable."
Ms. Feinstein said that whether mayor or senator, the idea of tearing down the O'Shaughnessy Dam looked the same to her. "It is foolish," she said.
"It makes no sense to destroy the source of the highest-quality drinking water around," Senator Feinstein said.
The Hetch Hetchy environmentalists said their overall strategy was to persuade and cajole, but they have gotten off to a rocky start with officials by taking a stance against the November ballot measure.
The measure, known as Proposition A, would allow the city to borrow $1.6 billion to help pay for about $3.6 billion in repairs and seismic improvements to the Hetch Hetchy water delivery system. That system brings water from the valley through 280 miles of pipes and 60 miles of tunnels to about 800,000 people in San Francisco and 1.6 million more in its suburbs.
The proposition is supported by the San Francisco water utility, Senator Feinstein, Mayor Willie L. Brown and a majority of the city's usually fractious Board of Supervisors. Ms. Martel, the utility's general manager, said large stretches of pipeline are more than 75 years old and desperately need to be replaced.
But A. Spreck Rosekrans, a senior analyst with Environmental Defense, one of the groups behind the effort to restore the Hetch Hetchy Valley, said that with billions of dollars in improvements ready to be spent, the moment was right to re-think the entire system.
Environmental Defense and the Planning and Conservation League wrote to city officials asking them to study the feasibility of restoring Hetch Hetchy Valley. When the officials balked, the groups vowed to fight Proposition A. Other influential environmental organizations, including the Sierra Club and the Natural Resources Defense Council, have joined in criticizing the proposition.
Win or lose on Proposition A, Mr. Rosekrans said the struggle for Hetch Hetchy had only begun. Because of the great interest in national parks around the country, and the particular popularity of Yosemite, Restore Hetch Hetchy is looking to support from outside California to counter and eventually overwhelm the local resistance.
In the meantime, Mr. Good lectures to civic and community groups and leads interpretive tours around the reservoir, where he suggests the submerged rocks "are holding their breath" and the Tuolumne River is "crying out for life again."
Standing atop the 312-foot-high concrete dam, water sprinkling from two eyelets behind him, Mr. Good quoted Muir as a source of the environmentalists' resolve:
"Imagine yourself in Hetch Hetchy on a sunny day in June, standing waist-deep in grass and flowers as I have often stood, while the great pines sway dreamily with scarcely perceptible motion."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ron Good, leader of Restore Hetch Hetchy, at the reservoir in Yosemite National Park that he wants to have drained. Officials are instead promoting a proposal to refurbish the pipes that send water to San Francisco. (Monica Almeida/The New York Times) Map of California highlights the Hetch Hetchy Reservoir: The Hetch Hetchy Reservoir holds 117 billion gallons of water.

HEADLINE: Brazil Raises A Key Rate By 3 Points 

BYLINE:  By SIMON ROMERO 

 BODY:
Brazil's central bank surprised investors yesterday and raised a crucial interest rate by three percentage points, continuing an aggressive effort to halt the decline in the value of the nation's currency.
 The bank's monetary policy committee raised overnight interest rates to a three-year high of 21 percent, from 18 percent, in a move aimed at keeping short-term investment in the country by offering higher returns on domestic bonds. The increase, the first in 15 months, came as tension builds ahead of the runoff election Oct. 27. 
 Brazil's currency, the real, which was down 3 percent earlier yesterday, recovered to close down half a percentage point at 3.82 to the dollar. On the Sao Paulo stock exchange, the main index fell 4.5 percent as concerns mounted over the effect of higher borrowing rates on the economy. 
Investors were initially critical of the central bank's decision, which was characterized as an unexpected move in the middle of the standoff between Brazil's government and financial institutions speculating about the direction of the real.
"Perhaps the central bank blinked," said Alexandre Schwartsman, head of economic research at Banco BBA Creditanstalt in Sao Paulo.
Mr. Schwartsman and other analysts criticized the rate increase, saying it came at a time when concern was growing over the effect of higher rates. Brazil has traditionally had some of the world's highest interest rates but when adjusted for inflation, rates had stabilized and begun to decline in recent years.
The government has kept rates high in a bid to stabilize markets, part of a policy supported by the International Monetary Fund, which recently offered to lend Brazil $30 billion. But the higher interest rates combined with the currency's slide have led to ballooning debt costs.
Differing from some of their counterparts in the United States, few investors in Brazil are worried about a default of domestic debt as long as the central bank is able to roll over bonds in the overnight market or redeem debt by printing money, measures that would inevitably fuel inflation. Still, analysts are worried about the costs of additional rate increases. Yesterday's increase, Mr. Schwartsman said, could cost the government in interest payments the equivalent of 1.8 percent of gross domestic product, limiting its ability to alleviate social tensions with public spending.
Analysts said yesterday that if the strategy of Arminio Fraga, the president of Brazil's central bank, is to work, rates should not remain high for long. Seeking to prevent wide swings in the currency, Mr. Fraga has become more assertive in recent days.
Last Friday, for example, the central bank made it more costly to bet against the real by increasing the amount of reais that banks must keep as reserves. That decision fueled a rally in the currency's value on Friday but by yesterday it was clear that traders were ready to test the real again.
"At least Fraga is sending a clear message that he has tools available with which to fight," said Ignacio Sosa, principal manager of OneWorld Investments, a hedge fund based in Boston.
The central bank said yesterday that it raised rates because of "worsening expectations for inflation" but it also mentioned the "pronounced depreciation of the currency." 
The real, which briefly fell to a low of 4 to the dollar last week, has declined 40 percent this year.
A weaker real has raised the cost of imported goods and contributed to a small increase in inflation. But the concerns over price increases are not responsible for most of the market's volatility. Instead, investors are nervously awaiting the outcome of the presidential runoff election.
Jose Serra, the candidate favored by supporters of Brazil's centrist government, continued to trail Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva of the left-leaning Workers Party, in polls released over the weekend.
Mr. da Silva has provided few details of his plans for crucial positions at the central bank and finance ministry aside from insisting that Mr. Fraga, a former associate of the financier George Soros, must go. 
Still, Mr. da Silva is thought to have warmed to the idea of granting greater independence to the central bank, according to a report over the weekend by a prominent columnist, Elio Gaspari. The move could bring calm to the markets if the appointee is agreeable to investors.
Several people have been mentioned, including Henri Philippe Reichstul, whose experience in the 1970's with a revolutionary group brings him respect with some factions of the Workers Party. Mr. Reichstul, an Oxford-educated economist, has since become one of Brazil's most respected business executives.
"A more independent central bank with the right person at its helm would be a striking example of the new government's wish for stability," said Murillo de Aragao, Brasilia-based political consultant with LatinSource, a consulting firm in New York.

HEADLINE: A Green Foothold in the Downtown Concrete; 
Apartment High-Rise Will Set an Environmental Benchmark Near Ground Zero

BYLINE:  By KIRK JOHNSON

 BODY:
In the nerdy world of green construction, 20 River Terrace was already an address with a big reputation -- even before everything changed.
 The building, begun early last year just a few blocks from the World Trade Center, was to be the world's most environmentally correct residential high-rise, its developers said -- an air-purified, solar-paneled monument to the marriage of mother earth and technological gee-whiz. 
 Now as construction resumes after a 10-month break during the cleanup of ground zero, the 27-story tower has become even more than the sum of its ambitions, builders and environmentalists say.
When the job started, Lower Manhattan was pretty much a finished product, and 20 River Terrace, for all its departures from the norm, was just another building. Now the city is gripped by a debate over what to rebuild at ground zero and what future to envision. 
Environmental awareness among residents, office workers and employers was sharply elevated by the dust from the twin towers' collapse and the lingering smoke from their ruins. A regional drought put new value on water conservation. And the linkage of Middle Eastern oil and the financing of terror gave solar power new life, environmentalists say, because using alternative fuels can now be considered an act of political defiance.
The biggest single element that has changed, development experts say, is that in Lower Manhattan, thinking beyond the old boundaries is now in fashion, and right there, on downtown's front porch, is Exhibit A of how to do it. 
"To have a sustainable building going up in an area that was a target of a terror attack is a very powerful thing," said Richard Florida, a professor of regional economic development at Carnegie Mellon University in Pittsburgh and an adviser to the Regional Plan Association, which is helping put together a new design for downtown. "I think there's a great possibility that this example will trigger things even more imaginative on the part of architects or designers."
Other planners and environmentalists say that 20 River Terrace and the set of environmental construction standards created by the Battery Park City Authority, which oversees the building project, are already leading the way. The construction resumed in July and completion is expected next spring. The authority, a state-chartered agency developing the landfill areas of Lower Manhattan (which were largely created by the excavation for the trade center in the late 1960's) had planned a series of green residential towers long before Sept. 11.
"The philosophy is that if you create a healthier building, you make people healthier," said Timothy S. Carey, the president and chief executive of the authority. 
No matter what philosophical effect 20 River Terrace has or does not have on downtown, developers say, it is also very much a prototype that must work on its own, in engineering and financial terms. Although New York is already home to what is considered the nation's first environmentally green high-rise office tower, the Conde Nast building at 4 Times Square in Midtown, apartment buildings have very different issues and patterns of use, from the peaks of power demand to the far higher volumes of water use. 
The skeleton of 20 River Terrace has twice as many water pipes and air ducts in its apartments as a conventional high-rise residential building. Each apartment will have its own dedicated air supply -- filtered and humidified -- and a separate water line just for flushing the toilets with treated waste water piped up from the treatment plant in the basement. There are also pipes leading to and from a 10,000-gallon rainwater collection tank that will be used to water the rooftop garden, which is intended to reduce the building's radiant heat and energy loss.
"The interesting thing is that it's forcing us to develop innovative ways of building in a sustainable fashion at appropriate costs," said Martin Dettling, a vice president at the Albanese Development Corporation and the project manager. "Our lenders want the building to be financially sustainable, too."
To meet the Battery Park guidelines and also qualify for a green building tax credit created by New York State earlier this year, 20 River Terrace must use 35 percent less energy than a similar-sized structure built under the standard construction codes. Building materials must follow a complex formula establishing their percentage of recycled content, and there must be affidavits and a paper trail to prove it. At least 40 percent of components must be manufactured no farther than 500 miles from the job site, to hold down air pollution from long-distance truck transportation.
Jumping through all those hoops at once required compromise and constant calculation, contractors said. How the solar-energy collectors on the building's exterior changed their color midway through the project tells that tale. 
The original design specified black photovoltaic panels -- running halfway up the tower's southwest side. The subcontractor found a Delaware supplier, within the 500-mile limit, who was making solar panels out of recycled silicon, using chips discarded by the computer industry. Using the Delaware supplier would thus get two benefits for one in meeting the rules -- more recycled content, close enough -- but there was a problem. The solar panels would have to be blue, not black. 
So the exterior design changed. Blue it was.
There were some culture clashes, too.
Anthony O. Pereira, a former organizer for Greenpeace who now develops alternative energy systems and whose business cards say they are printed with soy ink on recycled paper, vividly recalls making his first presentations to the general contractor, the Turner Corporation, a big, old-line firm that has been building New York skyscrapers for more than 100 years.
"The first few meetings were very intimidating," Mr. Pereira said, "but we decided that if we worked twice as hard, we could still earn their respect."
Other construction experts say Sept. 11 also raised the profile for green construction by illuminating how incredibly expensive it is to put in water and electricity and sewer systems once they have been destroyed.
"If you use less energy and less water and you're putting less water out as waste, then you don't have to think about the big things like putting more pipes in and more wires, and the political and economic implications of that are enormous," said William D. Browning, a senior consultant at the Rocky Mountain Institute, a nonprofit group in Snowmass, Colo., that works on resource efficiency issues.
Green buildings are designed to depend less on water and energy resources; 20 River Terrace, for example, will use a third less water than a typical tower of 293 apartments. It will also generate about 5 percent of its own electricity through solar collectors and use natural gas for its air-conditioning system, which, developers say, will help avoid summertime electricity price spikes.
Mr. Dettling, the project manager at 20 River Terrace, said that in watching the building rise, he is seeing another payoff as well: a growing expertise in how to make it all work. "First there's resistance to new things, then acceptance," he said. "Then competition kicks in, and you get innovation, efficiency and cost savings."

HEADLINE: Anaheim Journal; 
Angels-Crazy Suburb Longs for an Ending Right Out of Disney

BYLINE:  By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: ANAHEIM, Calif., Oct. 14 

 BODY:
The Anaheim Angels' success in the American League playoffs is not just a victory for a long-suffering baseball franchise. It is a vindication for the strip malls, the used-car lots, the smog-shrouded freeways, the housing tracts and the past-their-prime downtowns throughout Southern California.
 "This is a victory for the new suburbia, what could be called a post-suburban suburbia," said Joel Kotkin, a scholar of American urban life at Pepperdine University. "The success of the Angels represents a kind of coming of age for Orange County. It's Anaheim's revenge on all the sophisticates in New York and San Francisco and the West Side of L.A. who like to make fun of them." 
 City officials have begun planning a celebration if the team wins the World Series. But they have not decided whether to have a parade or simply stage the kind of rally that another suburban team, the New Jersey Devils, held in the parking lot of its arena when it twice won hockey's Stanley Cup. There is no Canyon of Heroes here, not even a Peachtree Street, to serve as a focus of city pride. City government buildings line Anaheim Boulevard, but that municipal complex quickly fades to warehouses, car lots and mini-marts.
The real heart of the city, the attraction that draws nearly 30 million visitors a year, is the Disney fantasia, which has grown beyond the original Disneyland to include a second park, Disney's California Adventure, and a new shopping and entertainment district called Downtown Disney.
John Nicoletti, Anaheim's chief public affairs officer, said Edison Field, where the Angels play, would certainly be a site for celebration if the team won the Series. But he said officials were also talking about taking advantage of the immaculate and tightly secured Disney entertainment complex, which has come to symbolize the city.
"Downtown Anaheim is Anaheim Boulevard and the Center Street Promenade," Mr. Nicoletti said, referring to the complex built a decade ago to replace the city's hollowed-out urban core. "And I hate to say this, but Downtown Disney is certainly a cultural hub as well. It is bordered by two theme parks and ESPN Zone, and it's a natural drawing place for people during a sports event."
It is also something of a natural fit for a celebration of the Angels since Disney owns the team, as well as the Anaheim Mighty Ducks of the National Hockey League.
Angels fans are delighted, and more than a little surprised, at their team's success. Like hopeful fans everywhere, they see destiny at work, for their ball club and for their city.
"Toward the end of the regular season, I said they're going all the way," said Juan Garcia-Alaniz, a salesman at Acapulco Auto Sales on Anaheim Boulevard a few blocks south of City Hall. "It's not that they're going to win it because they're good, but because they want it, and we need it." 
Anaheim is one of the oldest settlements in Orange County, established in the mid-1850's by German utopians who came to grow grapes. When the vineyards were wiped out by blight in the 1870's, the farmers switched to oranges, which became the basis of the area's economy for the next 75 years.
Today the orange groves are gone, along with virtually all other traces of the city's agricultural past. Anaheim is now, for good and ill, a microcosm of Southern California, home to 330,000 mostly working-class residents and hundreds of small retailers and manufacturers. Nearly half the population is Latino; an additional 13 percent is of Asian descent. More than 60 percent of the families live on $50,000 a year or less, struggling to afford houses and apartments that are mostly small and aging.
The Disney complex employs 20,000 people: costumed mice and chipmunks working in shifts, hotel chambermaids, security guards, shop clerks and busboys. Many earn less than $20,000 a year and are forced by high housing costs to double up with relatives, live in cheap motels or commute from cheaper suburbs farther inland. 
Nor has Anaheim escaped the rising crime rate afflicting much of Southern California. Roger A. Baker, the city's chief of police, said its crime rate was lower than that of any other American resort district. Still, after steadily falling rates in the 1990's, Anaheim is suffering a surge of serious felonies.
While Anaheim has become absorbed by the Orange County agglomeration around it, it has retained some of what made it distinctive: a collection of well-maintained Craftsman-style bungalows, 45 tidy city parks and the Disney-owned attractions and sports teams.
"It is a place that is becoming comfortable with itself," said Mr. Kotkin, of Pepperdine University. "This is not just typical boosterism, but the beginning of place-making where there was no place."
"This really has a lot to do with resurgence of the older suburbs," he added. "These places are the most interesting and diverse places in the country right now."

GRAPHIC: Photo: These days, a banner with the Angels' logo is prominently hung outside City Hall in Anaheim. (J. Emilio Flores for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Excerpts From Candidate's Old Columns 

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from columns written by Douglas R. Forrester for The West Windsor-Plainsboro Chronicle, a weekly newspaper.

D.W.I. Checks: Roadblocks to Freedom
 Some have claimed that these checkpoints are effective as deterrents and that is why there is a low incidence of arrests at these locations. I remember an old friend who hung garlic on his door posts to keep away vampires. It was difficult to argue against his statistics. I tried to suggest that, perhaps, the garlic had nothing to do with his success and that it may be attributable to other factors, like the low incidence of vampires in the area. He wouldn't listen; he would rather be safe than sorry. June 21, 1990 

Forgive Your Enemies
This season of Passover and Easter is the best of public reminders that forgiveness is not cheap. The Passover lamb and the man on the cross make the same point. The same person who begged divine forgiveness for his executioners was abused for amusement purposes by Roman captors in the hours before his death. They were no seconds to the Iraqis. I believe that we are better off remembering his concluding remarks: "Forgive them." March 21, 1991

Atlantic City's 'Mocking Grin'
I don't like Atlantic City. In fact, I don't know anyone who does. Government officials complain about the failure of the casinos to spur the city's redevelopment; casino officials quietly bemoan the lack of public leadership. . . . The sorry eyes of the elderly who trudge the boardwalk in pursuit of a life which has passed them by are most telling: Atlantic City isn't so much a city of dreams as it is a Cheshire cat smile, a mocking grin for those who believe that life in the fast lane brings prosperity. Never has a place fallen so short of its potential. May 16, 1991

Rifling Our Liberty
We should avoid any encroachment by the public sector into private matters which don't have a compelling public purpose. I believe the case against semiautomatic weaponry is hard to document, let alone prove. It is, unfortunately, a prime case of politicians offering emotional satisfaction because they cannot or will not offer any substantive relief from violent crime. Oct. 15, 1992

HEADLINE: THE 2002 CAMPAIGN: THE DEMOCRAT; 
McCall Charges Pataki Created A Fiscal 'Mess'

BYLINE:  By SHAILA K. DEWAN 

 BODY:
H. Carl McCall, the Democratic candidate for governor, said yesterday that Gov. George E. Pataki had mismanaged the state's response to the slumping economy, leaving Albany facing huge deficits and unable to take on bold new initiatives.
 Mr. McCall, the state comptroller, described a government tightly constrained. He said it would have to cut many expenses -- though he added that he hoped to be able to preserve and even increase spending on education -- because overburdened taxpayers should not be asked to pay more. 
 As a result, he said, a McCall administration would focus on streamlining and professionalizing government, using management techniques like evaluating agencies, and consulting panels of outside advisers. 
Ultimately, he said in a 90-minute interview with reporters and editors of The New York Times, only an improving economy would give the state the financial resources to finance existing programs and create new ones. He pledged to try to persuade businesses to take advantage of low costs in the state's depressed upstate region and relocate there.
For the moment, he said, budget constraints meant the state would be unable to give cash to New York City to help close the city's huge, looming deficits. What he can offer, he said, is "a sympathetic ear and a willingness to work" with city leaders. Excerpts, Page B6. 
The interview touched on issues ranging from the redevelopment of Lower Manhattan to casino gambling. Mr. McCall spoke with an insider's knowledge of state government, yet avoided specifics, saying the state's fiscal uncertainties made it difficult for him to commit to new programs, or to even say how he would change or cut existing programs.
Mr. McCall criticized Mr. Pataki repeatedly, saying the governor had stocked the state payroll with political supporters, failed to come up with a comprehensive economic development plan, placed the state heavily in debt and allowed needless waste in agency after agency. Furthermore, he said, the governor had concealed the state's true fiscal picture from the public and the Legislature.
"George Pataki's going to leave a real mess," Mr. McCall said.
He accused Mr. Pataki, who has served for two terms that included an economic boom, of squandering opportunities and the state's resources.
"Have they created the gap?" he asked. "Have they been responsible for the financial condition of the state? Not entirely, but they have not managed well, either."
He said Medicaid and transportation had been poorly managed, and that the governor had shown little concern over issues like education, particularly higher education.
Yet, he acknowledged, Mr. Pataki has had some success appealing to voters in New York City and the suburbs, and has been able to gain support from traditionally Democratic constituencies. He attributed this to Mr. Pataki's "ability to appear to -- becoming more moderate."
But, he said, "He has no real ideology whatsoever. He is a pragmatist and goes where he thinks people want to see him."
With three weeks to go before the election, Mr. McCall said, "What I'm trying to do is to get people to focus not on his presence but on his performance."
Mr. McCall said he would move aggressively to make sure that issues that are important to him -- like a gay rights bill and changes in the Rockefeller drug laws -- are pushed through the Legislature. He said he would do this by horse trading with Senate Republicans, and by "helping to get more Democrats and more progressive people elected to the Senate," an act that would break a longstanding, informal nonaggression pact between the political parties.
Mr. McCall said that he would not tolerate Albany's common practice of ratifying important legislation before the public and most members of the Legislature have had an opportunity to study it. He said he would even veto legislation if it were approved without comment or review.
Just the threat of a veto, he predicted, would help break the pattern of secrecy and the gridlock that has led to a record string of late budgets.
But Mr. McCall also spoke of political pragmatism. While he had originally opposed Mr. Pataki's effort to eliminate a commuter tax, he now says he will not try to reimpose the tax because suburbanites feel overburdened. He also said he supported an Assembly proposal to soften the Rockefeller drug laws although critics of the laws regard it as a weak compromise. "I want to start somewhere and that seems to be a reasonable starting point," he said.
He was cautious about proposing new state programs or initiatives. He said he could not commit to such programs until he could determine the true extent of the state's budget gap, which he estimated would exceed $5 billion.
He said that although he did not want to raise taxes, he could not promise that he would not have to.
"I start off with an intention not to raise taxes because people simply feel that they're terribly overburdened now with taxes," Mr. McCall said. "So I do not want to raise taxes.
"On the other hand, cutting expenses, we'll have to do that," he added.
Michael McKeon, a spokesman for the Pataki campaign, defended the governor's record on financial matters, saying the state had record surpluses and its highest credit rating in 23 years. 
"The experts from Wall Street took a look and said that we're on sound ground because of sound fiscal management," Mr. McKeon said.
At one point, Mr. McCall said that even the most popular programs, like spending on education and health care, might have to be cut. "Everything will have to be put on the table," he said. But he also said that savings could be found within the education budget, allowing the state to shift dollars to finance school policies he favors, like smaller class sizes.
"I'm not willing to say there is no money," he said. "Nor am I willing to say we're going to solve this overnight."
On education, he said he supported standardized testing. But he said he wanted the state to let alternative schools use their own methods of assessment.
This had been the practice until April 2001, when the State Board of Regents mandated testing for all students.
Concerning aid to New York City, which is facing a $5 billion deficit of its own, he said the state's ability to help was limited. "I don't think that the state government is going to be in a position to provide cash," he said.
"New York City will need help," he added. "New York City's major issue will be money. They are facing a very significant budget deficit. The mayor has acknowledged it. And I applaud the mayor for his efforts to come forward with specific proposals to close the gap. I will look at those proposals. I will try to be helpful. And those proposals that make sense, that will help the city, I will help the mayor gain approval of those proposals in Albany."
He said he was also concerned with economic conditions upstate. He said he would focus economic development on central and western New York and market those areas aggressively as inexpensive places to do business. He faulted the governor for ignoring the region's needs until after he had campaigned there in 2000 with Rick Lazio, who had been running for a United States Senate seat against Hillary Rodham Clinton, and had found widespread dissatisfaction over the state of the economy. 
"The governor's economic development program was a failure," Mr. McCall said. "It was driven by ad hoc attempts to provide grants and incentives to companies after they announced that they were leaving New York."
Mr. McCall repeatedly said he would "put professionals in charge" of various agencies under the governor's control, including the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation, which is charged with rebuilding the downtown area.
That effort, he said, has proceeded too slowly. He said he would make "whole-scale changes," but declined to say whom he would remove from or appoint to the development corporation board.
On casino gambling, Mr. McCall criticized the governor again for not having had a comprehensive plan.
"We've got to step back and look at the whole thing rather than doing it on an ad hoc basis, in the middle of the night agreeing we're going to have six casinos someplace," Mr. McCall said, referring to a casino deal that the Legislature passed shortly after Sept. 11, 2001. "Let's step back and let's have a policy that is driven by social, economic and other concerns. And we end up with something that makes sense for the state." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: H. Carl McCall, seen here in a January photograph, said Gov. George E. Pataki had mismanaged the state's response to a faltering economy. (Fred R. Conrad/The New York Times)(pg. B6)

HEADLINE: For New York Fans, It's More Like Mudville 

BYLINE:  By ANDY NEWMAN 

 BODY:
As Yogi Berra might have put it, it sure got late early for New York sports fans.
 It's only mid-October, a time when championships, or at least hopes for them, are usually ripening, and it already feels like this could be the longest, loneliest sports season in 15 years. 
 The Jets, who usually wait until December to break hearts, are a 1-4 disaster. And the Giants may be worse: 3-3, yes, but boring. 
The Knicks, who made a big point of laying down the law to one of their star players, now have to pick up the pieces of their season before they've even played an official game -- thanks to the broken kneecap of the power forward who was supposed to be the centerpiece of their resurgence.
The Yankees, of course, are history, with Derek Jeter trying to find a way for his $189 million contract to lighten what the back page of a newspaper called his profound depression over the sudden end of his autumn activity. And those other Giants, the deserters who split for the West Coast 45 short years ago, have now brought about -- horror of New York horrors -- an all-California World Series.
But in perhaps the most alarming measurement of the city's sense of sporting desolation, fans searching for a local winner may be forced to turn to a team whose middle name is Jersey.
"Everybody's sick," Jorge Goldburn, 40, said yesterday at the OTB parlor near Brooklyn's Borough Hall, as he waited for the next race at Belmont to start. "The only team doing anything at all right now is the Nets."
Of course, this is just sports. It's not like, say, the economy stuck in the tank, or the war on terror.
Sports is also full of long-shot surprises, so maybe the Rangers will somehow find their way to their second Stanley Cup since 1940.
But for New Yorkers, sports is an organizing obsession -- one that promotes conversation, provides relief, generates some collective if fleeting nourishment. And it must be said: it's been a long time since basic optimism seemed in such short supply.
"I'm not that old, but it's never been as bad as this," said Jay Brennan, 22, a truck driver who was surveying the bleak landscape of losing from the ESPN Zone sports entertainment complex in Times Square yesterday afternoon. "The Mets stink, the Yankees stink, the Knicks stink -- well, the season hasn't started yet, but they're already stinking. And the Jets -- geez, they're terrible. It seems like all of the New York teams have lost their heart."
One might have to reach back to the Koch administration -- from the fall of 1987 to the spring of 1988, to be precise, when the Yankees, Mets, Giants, Jets, Knicks and Rangers all missed the playoffs -- to find a season as cheerless as this one has the potential to be.
Most of the damage seemed to happen suddenly, in the course of a couple of October weekends. First, the Yankees folded like lawn chairs (or, maybe more accurately, Mets) at the feet of a perennial also-ran, the Anaheim Angels.
Then, on Saturday, the Knicks saw their prospects for success collapse when Antonio McDyess, acquired in a blockbuster off-season trade, broke his kneecap. Until then the team's preseason had been marked by the disciplining of Latrell Sprewell, who responded by sulking on his yacht in Milwaukee, of all places, nursing his pride as much as his broken pinky.
The next day, the spiritual anchor of the Giants' defense, the tackle Keith Hamilton, was helped off the field with that most symbolic of season-ending injuries, a torn Achilles' tendon.
Three games into their season, the Rangers, who haven't made the playoffs for five years running, already have an embarrassing 6-0 loss under their belts, and a 1-2 record. The Islanders, meanwhile, have lost both games they've played.
Of course, the perpetually porous Jets, for a change, did not lose on Sunday. On the other hand, they didn't play.
Throughout most of the 1990's, New York's all-around sporting prowess and postseason omnipresence seemed an integral part of the city's resurgence. The swagger of the Giuliani years derived in no small part from the spectacle of the mayor whooping it up in a Yankees cap.
So does the current losing streak mean the city is weakened?
Never, promised Dan Daly, behind the bar at the estimable Coogan's in Manhattan's Washington Heights. 
"It's coincidence," he said. "It's just kind of the ebb and flow. The consensus at the bar is that it's just the fortunes of what goes on in professional sports -- and poor judgment on the part of management."
Still, he conceded, "it is insane. Maybe the Giants might do something, but not this year. It's kind of wait till next year already."
There have been a few bright spots, to be sure. Last month the Staten Island Yankees, the Bronx Bombers' farm team, won the Class A Penn League championship for the second time in three years.
And here's good news for Knicks fans: season tickets, for which there is usually a long waiting list, are yours for the asking (and the $2,800). According to Ticketmaster, there are even $210 and $100 seats still available for the home opener, Nov. 2 against the Celtics.
Morris McWilliams, who managed the Harlem 12-year-olds to the Little League World Series in August, prescribed patience for fans and players alike.
"You've got to continue to persevere and hang in there," Mr. McWilliams said. "Hopefully things will turn themselves as time goes on."
Back at the OTB, a 58-year-old security guard named A. Gardner said that although he would not bet on any of the local teams -- "That would be stupid" -- he remained hopeful.
"Take the Knicks," he said. 'You can't go by the preseason. I'm not going to give up on them."
Then he turned his attention to what seemed like a surer thing.
"Come on 3," he shouted at the TV screen as the horses rounded a turn. "Get him 3. Get on that rail!"

GRAPHIC: Photo: Derek Jeter, Joe Torre and other Yankees players and coaches watched the Anaheim Angels celebrate after eliminating the Yankees from the post-season 10 days ago. New York teams have had disappointing seasons. (Barton Silverman/The New York Times)(pg. B7)

HEADLINE: Working to Put Blacks on France's Agenda 

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE

DATELINE: PARIS, Oct. 14 

 BODY:
"They say, France is one and indivisible," said Dogad Dogoui, with characteristic deadpan humor, as he poked at a lunch of fish recently. "I say, yes, and with lots of people who are invisible."
 After 17 years in France, Mr. Dogoui is still uncomfortable with the French treatment of blacks. 
 He is one of hundreds of thousands of nonwhite immigrants, mainly blacks and Arabs, whom France has absorbed over the years from its former colonies in Africa and the Caribbean. But French sensitivity to the Arabs in their midst, largely because of the potential for a spillover of violence from the Middle East, far outstrips that toward blacks here, he said. 
So last year, Mr. Dogoui, a stocky, cheerful man who earns a living advising foreign companies how to do business in France, founded a club for black business leaders. Now, he is spearheading a drive to involve more blacks in politics.
French attitudes toward blacks, he conceded, are ambiguous. The cradle of human rights, Paris raised a statue early in the last century to Toussaint-Louverture, the black Haitian liberator. For years, the French have regularly denounced American racism, and the road from Harlem to Paris was wide, inviting talented American blacks like the singer Josephine Baker, musicians like Sydney Bechet and writers like Richard Wright, Langston Hughes and James Baldwin.
Yet, today, blacks are not much on the French agenda, said Mr. Dogoui, 38, who migrated here from Abidjan, Ivory Coast. He thinks they should be.
"For 30 years France has been changing," he said. "But they don't open their eyes and see it."
Officially, blacks number about 1.5 million of a total population of 59 million. But the unofficial number is higher, Mr. Dogoui maintains, and more come daily.
In national elections this year, Christiane Taubira, a feisty economist from French Guiana, became the first black candidate for president, drawing 660,000 votes, or 2.3 percent of the total.
But in French politics, Mr. Dogoui said, "blacks arrange the chairs at conferences and clean up afterward." No black person sits in the National Assembly or in regional parliaments. In all of France, he said, there are only about 100 black City Council members. "That's ridiculous," he said, "What does that mean, among 36,000 towns and cities?"
The oldest of 12 children, Mr. Dogoui grew up in comfortable circumstances -- his father was deputy director of the port of Abidjan. At one time, he had wanted to emigrate to Quebec, but his father objected, saying the move would carry him too far from their close-knit family. He is now married to a French woman from Normandy; they have three children. In 1994, he became a French citizen.
After trying unsuccessfully to enroll in medical school, Mr. Dogoui studied psychology, but became drawn to public relations. He obtained his degree from the leading French school for public relations, making useful contacts while working as an intern in several government ministries. Earlier, he had attended a Catholic boarding school in Normandy, where he cut his teeth on politics, founding an African students association and organizing an African film festival.
As a student, Mr. Dogoui supplemented an allowance from his father by working with other black and Arab immigrants in a packaging plant in a Paris suburb. While there, he saw how long hours on the factory floor prevented the blacks from overseeing their children's education. But what particularly troubled him, he said, was how the workers clung to an immigrant mentality, happy to have escaped African poverty and content with the simplest of jobs.
"They forget that their kids are not immigrants," he said. 
They nevertheless showed enough concern to complain that the schools offered their children none of the extra help they needed or a place to study after hours. "It's not a financial question but a question of interest," Mr. Dogoui said. 
While white pupils are encouraged to continue studying, black children are steered toward vocational training. He heard, he said, of black students telling their teachers they wanted to study medicine, only to be laughed at.
"Black kids say, 'Why should I study journalism?' " he said. "There are no blacks on TV."
Mr. Dogoui likes to tell a story about his 10-year-old son, who returned recently from a trip to London, where he visited stores with nonwhite owners. "They're bosses there," the boy told his father, with an unmistakable note of wonder. 
During a layover recently at the Amsterdam airport, Mr. Dogoui sat in a lounge with other business people. One-third of them were black, he said, yet he was the only French person. The others were from North America, Britain and the Netherlands. France's largest corporations have no black directors or senior executives, he said, claiming competent blacks are unavailable. 
Yet, as a corporate consultant advising North American and Scandinavian companies how to do business with French companies, Mr. Dogoui has observed how savvy businesses use blacks to increase their effectiveness in dealing with nonwhite countries or customers. Finding competent black executives should be "a challenge for French companies," he said. But it isn't one that they seem particularly eager to confront. "Sometimes it's racism," he said, referring to French companies. "But sometimes they just don't get it." 
When asked whether the French people are racist, however, he reflected a moment before saying no.
Some blacks see the French as racists, he said, because they distrust all French society. "I chose to adapt," he said, attributing his success to his mastery of the French language, which he spoke at home in Abidjan, and to an ease accepting people of other cultures that he inherited from his father. 
At boarding school and in college, he said, he met French students who were curious about Africa and its art, literature and film. But the average French person, he said, shows little interest. 
France, he said, is "a strange country -- closed, traditional, even on the left."
One goal of the business club is to create an investment fund to finance black start-up companies. France has room for ethnic African and Caribbean restaurants, Mr. Dogoui said, as well as hairdressers and cosmetics. French advertising lacks blacks, he notes, both in the advertisements and the agencies, and has neither a major black newspaper nor magazine.
The goal of Mr. Dogoui's political movement is to discover talented blacks to run for office at all levels of government. He has no illusions about the difficulties they will face.
For example, when the new prime minister, Jean-Pierre Raffarin, assembled his cabinet last spring, black leaders including Mr. Dogoui asked him to name a black minister for African affairs. They were refused.
Blacks, he said, "are disappointed with the left," believing that the former Socialist prime minister, Lionel Jospin, did little for them. "And they mistrust the right."
He favors no particular faction. "My dream," he said, "is to have blacks some day on the left, on the right and in the center."
An optimist by nature, he fears nonetheless that, barring change, racial unrest could explode in France as it did in America in the 1960's. High-rise slums surrounding French cities are cauldrons of racial anger dominated by urban gangs. "And they are armed," he said.
"You have to give young people hope."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Dogad Dogoui's political movement aims to find talented blacks to run for office in France. (Owen Franken for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Cuomo and McCall Assail Pataki at Parade 

BYLINE:  By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

 BODY:
Andrew M. Cuomo returned to the campaign trail yesterday with his former Democratic Party rival, H. Carl McCall, to accuse Gov. George E. Pataki of dodging one-on-one debates and failing to specify plans for a third term.
 Speaking at a news conference before marching in the Columbus Day Parade, Mr. Cuomo and Mr. McCall both called Sunday's debate a "circus" that deprived potential voters a chance for a rigorous examination of either Mr. Pataki's or Mr. McCall's positions or record. The debate included seven candidates -- at least three from parties just hoping to get 50,000 votes so their party can hold onto a ballot line in future elections. 
 Mr. Cuomo, the former federal housing secretary who quit the Democratic primary a week before the vote, said Mr. Pataki would not debate Mr. McCall one on one because he could not account for what the Democrats called failures to improve education and the struggling upstate economy.
"His campaign has two disabilities," Mr. Cuomo said of Mr. Pataki. "First, he has no memory of the past. And second, he has no vision for the future."
Mr. Pataki, meanwhile, marching in the parade with Charles A. Gargano, his top economic development aide and chairman of the parade committee, ridiculed Mr. McCall for changing his position on debating. Mr. McCall had originally called for all candidates to participate and then demanded one-on-one debates with Mr. Pataki. On Sunday Mr. McCall said he would debate any candidate one on one.
"Carl McCall keeps changing his mind," Mr. Pataki said as he marched. "He started out saying he wanted all seven candidates, then he said he wanted three candidates, now he is saying he would take any two candidates. I think it's appropriate that anyone who the public has the right to vote for have the opportunity to be seen."
During the campaign Mr. McCall has laid out his own plans for education and the economy, though he has not said how he would find $8 billion to finance his education initiatives when the economy is weak and a huge budget deficit is expected.
Mr. Pataki has not offered any sweeping proposals for the next four years, suggesting instead that he planned to stay the course of his first two terms. When asked to respond to Democrats' complaints about his vision, he pointed to economic development projects that he has begun as well as to plans to convert Governors Island in New York Harbor into a college campus.
Mr. Cuomo, who quit campaigning a week before the Democratic primary in the face of Mr. McCall's strong showing in polls, pledged financial help for Mr. McCall's campaign, which is at a severe disadvantage to Mr. Pataki with three weeks left in the race.
Mr. McCall said Mr. Cuomo "has lived up to all the commitments he made to me, and I'm very pleased that he's done so."

HEADLINE: Before Congress Leaves 

 BODY:
With the country focused on Iraq, the Democrats keep complaining that they can't get any traction on economic issues despite widespread public concern about jobs, pensions and the sluggish economy in general. Here's a suggestion: In the few days remaining before Congress goes home to campaign, Democratic leaders should push as hard as they can for two measures that will bring economic benefits to the country and credit to those who secure their passage. Each will require some legislative gymnastics. Both could be successful. 
 The first and more important is to extend the temporary additional unemployment benefits program beyond its Dec. 31 expiration date, while at the same time restoring assistance to 1.3 million workers who have already exhausted or will soon exhaust their benefits. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton of New York is among several sponsors of a bill that would achieve both objectives. It carries a $17 billion price tag, which isn't cheap, but there is no quicker and fairer way to put money in the hands of consumers at just the moment when they and the economy as a whole most need a transfusion. 
 Even notoriously conservative House Republicans are beginning to see the light on the unemployment compensation issue. Bill Thomas, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, will shortly bring to the House floor a measure extending the jobless benefits program into next year. But unlike the Senate bill, it provides no help to those whose benefits have expired or will shortly run out. It also comes attached to a larger bill that would provide an estimated $60 billion in various tax breaks for investors over the next 10 years -- people least in need of an immediate transfusion. The Senate should insist on its version if the two bills reach a conference committee.
One other measure also deserves prompt approval. It would provide some $5 billion in fiscal relief to state governments facing their most severe fiscal crisis in decades. Without help, they will soon have to start cutting essential programs like Medicaid. There is no comparable House bill, but it should not be impossible to get the House to accept some version of this useful measure in the horse-trading that takes place in the final weeks of a legislative session.
Theoretically, of course, the unemployment insurance and state fiscal relief measures could be delayed until Congress returns for a lame-duck session after the elections. What might be convenient for Congress, however, will be inconvenient indeed for unemployed workers and hard-pressed states that need the money.

President Bush said that the bombing in Indonesia appeared to be the work of Al Qaeda and that the attack was part of a pattern of terrorist acts that included recent violence in Kuwait and Yemen. HEADLINE: In Senate Race, Textiles, Tobacco and Tart Words 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: RALEIGH, N.C., Oct. 14 

 BODY:
They held a debate between North Carolina's candidates for the United States Senate today, and nobody came. Nobody even knew where it was going to be, exactly, or on what day, or at what time.
 Nobody, that is, except the candidates, Elizabeth Dole and Erskine B. Bowles, the two television anchormen who moderated the lively 58-minute-long exchange and whoever else was in on the big secret. (Rumor had it there was actually a small audience of family members and friends.) 
 When it finally was shown tonight on videotape on 16 television stations across the state, it proved to have been a zesty match, focused on getting the economy moving again, particularly on aiding North Carolina's struggling tobacco farmers and textile industry.
Mr. Bowles, the former chief of staff to President Bill Clinton, attacked Mrs. Dole for opposing minimum-wage increases, paid family medical leave and civil rights legislation. Mrs. Dole, the former transportation secretary, Red Cross president and Republican presidential aspirant, chided Mr. Bowles for the tone of his campaign commercials and waved a blank sheet of paper she said constituted his plan to save Social Security.
Mrs. Dole pointedly linked Mr. Bowles to Senators Hillary Clinton, Edward M. Kennedy and the majority leader Tom Daschle, who make up the closest thing to an unholy trinity for conservative Southern voters. And Mr. Bowles boasted that he had lived his whole life in North Carolina and worked here too, except for those five years in Washington -- prompting Mrs. Dole to acknowledge, "You can't run the Red Cross from Salisbury," her birthplace south of Winston-Salem.
But for the most part, the encounter was far more civil than either candidate's television advertisements of late, which have nearly reached the saturation point since the long-delayed primary a month ago finally let loose the fall campaign.
Mrs. Dole repeated her pledge not to raise taxes, and Mr. Bowles again demurred, calling it a gimmick. He pledged instead to eliminate the estate tax permanently for family farmers and small businesses. He positioned his stance on broad-based tax cuts as a matter of choices, warning, "We are looking at deficits as far as the eye can see."
"I'm a true fiscal conservative," he said. "And if I'm presented with a choice between freezing the tax rate for the richest one percent of Americans and a prescription drug benefit, I'm going to freeze the tax rate."
Mrs. Dole pounced: "Now, Erskine is for, candidly, a tax increase," she translated, arguing that business executives and others have planned for their tax cuts and would feel a freeze as an increase.
The two also tussled over which of them would be the more forceful advocate for North Carolina's tobacco farmers, who are seeking buyouts in exchange for switching from quotas and price supports to a more market-driven system.
Mrs. Dole repeatedly claimed authorship of a bill to provide $8 a pound to tobacco farm owners and $4 a pound to growers, while Mr. Bowles, who said he supported similar legislation, insisted Mrs. Dole's bill was really written by the retiring Senator Jesse Helms, whose seat they are fighting to fill.
Mr. Bowles argued, too, that his role in reaching an agreement on a balanced budget while in the Clinton White House showed he was more capable of getting a tobacco buyout enacted. "You're going to have to get the Midwest, the dairy farmers from the Northeast and their senators, the health care groups -- just like I did in the balanced budget -- to get something done," he said.
That this debate ever happened, metaphysical questions aside, was a surprise that roiled North Carolina's news media, particularly a group of 25 television stations that had agreed to hold a live debate next Saturday, provided it was the first of the campaign. When two Raleigh-Durham network affiliates announced they would hold this debate, the other group canceled the Oct. 19 debate.
When it was all over, aides to the candidates revealed that the debate had been held in an auditorium at Meredith College here late this morning. As to the veil of mystery that had shrouded the event all weekend, the campaigns insisted it had just been a matter of scheduling. They were unable to agree on a night for a live, prime-time debate, and decided to tape it early in the day, they said. Why not let the public and other reporters attend the taping? "We wanted to maintain the integrity of the debate," said Mary Brown Brewer, Mrs. Dole's spokeswoman. 
Susan Lagana, Mr. Bowles's spokeswoman said, "We didn't want people listening to the TV or the radio and being told what to think before they saw the debate."
Just how many people saw it, of course, remains to be seen.

HEADLINE: Forrester on Defensive for Old Newspaper Columns 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI

DATELINE: PLAINSBORO, N.J., Oct. 14 

 BODY:
Douglas R. Forrester, New Jersey's Republican nominee for the United States Senate, found himself on the defensive today about several newspaper columns he wrote more than a decade ago opposing drunken-driving checkpoints, criticizing New Jersey's ban on assault weapons and saying that Atlantic City had "the subtle beauty of a streetwalker."
 In a 1991 column, Mr. Forrester, who has made his support for military action to oust Saddam Hussein a centerpiece of his Senate campaign, urged Americans to forgive the Iraqis who tortured American prisoners. 
 Between 1989 and 1993, Mr. Forrester wrote nearly 200 columns for the weekly local newspaper in his hometown, most of which mused on topics as innocuous as Mother's Day, ice cream or the time Mr. Forrester was forced to kill a shrew in his bathtub. 
A handful of the columns featured Mr. Forrester espousing provocative opinions on more substantive political issues. In October 1992, after New Jersey passed the nation's first assault weapons ban, Mr. Forrester wrote that the case for banning semiautomatic weapons was "hard to document, let alone prove" and he derided the law as political pandering.
In 1990, he said he opposed checkpoints for drunken driving as a "gross violation of proper governmental boundaries." In May 1991, he described a visit to Atlantic City that he said left him depressed and "feeling that I had cavorted in the unclean waters of a toddler's wading pool."
During his nine months on the campaign trail, Mr. Forrester has never mentioned his tenure as an unpaid columnist for the defunct West Windsor-Plainsboro Chronicle (circulation 3,000), and the existence of his writings was little-known in political circles until The Star-Ledger of Newark published excerpts from several columns on Sunday. Since then, Democrats have begun distributing them to reporters and to advocacy groups that promote gun control and laws to restrict drunken driving, saying they prove that Mr. Forrester is a conservative extremist who is out of step with New Jersey's generally moderate electorate. 
Mr. Forrester's campaign has tried to prevent the columns from mushrooming into a major campaign issue. When questioned by reporters, Mr. Forrester said that he now supports a ban on assault weapons and thinks Atlantic City has finally received its long-overdue renovation. But he said he still believes sobriety checkpoints are an intrusive way to enforce drunken-driving laws.
His campaign manager, William Pascoe, said that at a time when the nation is on the brink of war, voters are likely to have little interest in columns Mr. Forrester wrote more than a decade ago.
"We don't have to worry about this being a distraction," Mr. Pascoe said, "because the voters of New Jersey want to hear what people are going to do to strengthen national defense and fight terrorism, strengthen our economy and get a prescription-drug program through Medicare. If Frank Lautenberg thinks he can pull the bait-and-switch with voters on this, he's barking up the wrong tree," he said, referring to Mr. Forrester's opponent, Frank R. Lautenberg. 
The discovery of Mr. Forrester's writings is nonetheless likely to complicate his campaign. Since Senator Robert G. Torricelli dropped out of the race two weeks ago, Mr. Forrester has sought to focus the campaign on the issues of national security and terrorism, so his writings are likely to draw attention to the issues of gun control and drunken-driving policy -- political terrain that New Jersey Democrats consider their home turf.
Mr. Forrester has also been trying to define himself as a moderate to New Jersey voters, half of whom say they do not know enough about him to form an opinion, according to recent polls. So his campaign strategy did not seek to highlight his conservative position on gun control.
Political analysts say it is unclear how voters will react to Mr. Forrester's columns. Cliff Zukin, a pollster and public-policy professor at Rutgers University, said that Mr. Forrester has focused his campaign on so few issues that his newspaper columns will at the very least offer voters a deeper understanding of his political philosophy.
"On one level, I think this means that Forrester is an interesting, complex character," Professor Zukin said. "But New Jersey is more pro-gun control than most states. To not be in favor of an assault weapons ban in New Jersey is way out of step with our culture. And with a sniper running around Washington, this issue is on people's minds, so that's unfortunate timing for Mr. Forrester."
While Mr. Lautenberg's aides were gleefully distributing the columns, the candidate himself made only passing reference to Mr. Forrester's recently unearthed writings. Speaking at a center for the elderly in Hamilton, where he signed a pledge to protect Social Security, Mr. Lautenberg described Mr. Forrester as an extremist who has avoided revealing his position on many important issues.
"Now we find out he's against drunken-driving checkpoints," said Mr. Lautenberg, who wrote the law that used federal transportation funds to encourage states to raise the drinking age from 18 to 21. "What's next?"
Mr. Lautenberg's campaign manager, Tom Shea, made a particular point of passing along a March 21, 1991, column headlined "Forgive Your Enemies," in which Mr. Forrester argued that Americans should forgive the Iraqis who tortured four American journalists who were held captive during the Persian Gulf war. Mr. Forrester has repeatedly criticized Mr. Lautenberg, a World War II veteran, as being soft on defense and voting against the gulf war resolution.
"These columns show you what Doug Forrester really thinks, as opposed to what he says when he's campaigning," Mr. Shea said. "Guns do nothing. Drunk driving do nothing, Terrorism do nothing. He's do-nothing Doug."
Mr. Forrester said that he expected that Democrats would try to use the columns to distort his current policy positions, but he doubted that they would succeed.
"I'm concerned about those things, but I trust that New Jerseyans will see through that," he said.

HEADLINE: Terror's Calling Card in Bali 

 BODY:
The weekend massacre at an Indonesian nightclub on the idyllic island of Bali, apparently the work of Al Qaeda and local allies, is a horrifying reminder that Islamic extremists who take aim at America and the West may be on the run but are not defeated. Even as the Bush administration readies for confrontation with Iraq, it must take new steps to combat a resurgent international terrorist threat with no single address or state sponsor.
 Most of the nearly 200 people killed and hundreds others injured on Saturday were foreign tourists, but Indonesia has been badly hurt as well. Its sense of security has been jolted, its stock market is reeling and Bali's economically important tourist industry faces ruinous free fall. 
 This was the latest and deadliest of several recent assaults. Together they offer evidence that Al Qaeda and its allies have survived the war in Afghanistan and are regrouping to organize new strikes. Two weeks ago Kuwaiti terrorists opened fire on American marines who were in the country for joint exercises with the Kuwaiti military, killing one of them. One of the assailants left behind a tape pledging allegiance to Osama bin Laden. Yesterday more gunfire was directed at American troops in Kuwait. Late last month a French oil tanker was set ablaze off Yemen in what Paris believes was a terrorist attack. Meanwhile a new tape by Osama bin Laden's top deputy, Ayman al-Zawahiri, has begun circulating. American authorities believe it was recorded recently.
A reactivated Qaeda is a threat America cannot afford to ignore, as President Bush acknowledged yesterday. An array of different strategies will be needed, including heightened cooperation with foreign governments, police and military forces and financial monitoring agencies. Fighting loosely linked and mobile terror cells is an entirely different operation from invading Iraq. Mr. Bush said that the two could be done simultaneously, and perhaps they can. But fighting terror is partly a battle for Muslim hearts and minds. A war against Iraq is likely to make it harder.
Indonesia, the world's most populous Muslim country, presents one of the toughest challenges. Law and order are extremely fragile in the sprawling archipelago, while its brutal and corrupt armed forces are politically and professionally unreliable.
Thus far, President Megawati Sukarnoputri has failed to acknowledge the seriousness of the Islamic terror threat. She has also been unwilling to take the steps needed to force the army to become more accountable, and the Bush administration has been reluctant to pressure her to do so. This must now change. Until Jakarta shapes up its policies and security forces, it will be difficult for Washington or anyone else to halt Al Qaeda's inroads there.
The United States continues to run up against conflicts between its desire to bolster its allies in the Islamic world and the need to take a stand against corruption and anti-democratic governments. In Pakistan, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, a crucial American ally, has isolated himself through high-handedness and thwarting of constitutional procedures. As a result he emerged from last week's legislative elections in a weakened position, not only in relation to the secular parties he unwisely tried to stop, but also to a strengthened Islamic fundamentalist political movement. 
The war against terror requires Washington to build and lead a broad coalition, using diplomatic as well as military tools, and hold it together for many years to come. It is unclear how war with Iraq will affect this endeavor, but the events of the last few weeks are a reminder that it is likely to make things harder rather than easier.
