HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Markets Continue to Rise On Upbeat Earnings Reports
Stocks soared almost 5 percent as investors celebrated upbeat earnings reports from two financial institutions and began to shift their views from gloomy to hopeful. In a four-day rally, the Dow Jones industrial average has risen almost 1,000 points.
 The consensus among investors seemed to be that the steady drumbeat of bad news in recent months -- corporate scandals, a struggling economy, the prospect of war -- had pushed stock prices too low. As a result, even a few pieces of good news about earnings were enough to fuel a comeback. Page A1. 

A Series With Stock Consequences
For the third time since a California World Series became a possibility, there is a battle between North and South. All three series have come at a time when Wall Street was reeling. And they have often occurred before a market surge. Floyd Norris: Market Place. C9.

Advertising Executive Leaves CBS
Joseph D. Abruzzese, left, who has led the advertising sales department at CBS for 12 years, is leaving to join the Discovery Networks of cable television as president of sales. The move surprised CBS, which is enjoying one of its best years ever in advertising sales. Mr. Abruzzese said that the time was right to move to a different challenge. C8.

Mark Gill, a Miramax Films executive regarded as a marketing expert, has left to join the Stratus Film Company, a finance and production company. C8.

Daimler in Tentative Deal in Canada
Negotiators for DaimlerChrysler and the Canadian Auto Workers union reached a tentative agreement on a labor contract. C4.

Time Warner Offers a Video Service
Time Warner Cable, the biggest cable TV provider in New York, said that it would offer video on demand to hundreds of thousands of homes by the end of the month and to more than one million by the end of the year. B5.

AOL Is Eliminating Pop-Up Ads
AOL Time Warner said that its AOL service would eliminate pop-up advertisements for other companies as it seeks to restore the allegiance of its members, reinvent its advertising business and fend off Microsoft's MSN. C8.

Revenue Rises for Charles Schwab
Charles Schwab reported that its third-quarter earnings rose 18 percent before one-time costs. Revenue rose to nearly $1.04 billion from $997 million a year earlier. C4.

Businesses Trim Inventories
Businesses trimmed their inventories in August for the first time in four months. Inventories edged down 0.1 percent. C9.

Bank Rejects $16 Billion Offer
Bank of Ireland published details of its $16 billion offer for Abbey National, and Abbey has once again rejected the proposal as insufficient. World Business, Section W.

Earnings Rise at Johnson & Johnson
In sharp contrast to its rivals in the pharmaceutical industry, Johnson & Johnson reported double-digit earnings growth and told analysts to expect strong results for the year. The company said it earned $1.8 billion, or 60 cents a share, for the third quarter, an increase of nearly 19 percent. The company also reported a 13 percent increase in sales. C5.

This and That From Ad Conference
Reliving some of the highlights, lowlights and sidelights from the 2002 conference of the Association of National Advertisers. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C8.

German Funds Pour Money Into U.S.
Changes to the regulation of some German funds and mortgage banking practices are contributing to an increased flow of German capital into commercial real estate in the United States. Commercial Real Estate. C6.

HEADLINE: THE HUNT FOR A SNIPER: THE OVERVIEW; 
Sniper Left Clues This Time, and Police Report Progress in Inquiry

BYLINE:  By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: FALLS CHURCH, Va., Oct. 15 

 BODY:
This time the roving sniper left more clues, with a number of witnesses getting a better, more chilling glimpse of him and his getaway van as they looked beyond his latest victim on the floor of a parking garage.
 Law enforcement officials working on the sweeping manhunt for the sniper marked qualified progress today as they investigated the killing of a 47-year-old woman, his 11th victim, here on Monday night. 
 This time, officials said, there were more immediate witnesses than in previous killings, and the witnesses provided much more information, including license plate data noted as the gunman fled in the now- familiar light-colored van reported at the last three killings. 
One government official described the closest, starkest sighting yet by a witness who reported seeing the gunman step brazenly from his van in the indoor parking garage, about 90 feet from Linda Franklin and her husband, Ted, as the two were loading shelving into their car after leaving the Home Depot store here at 9:15 Monday night. 
"He had his choice and he took her," the official recounted of the sniper's taking aim, firing once and striking Ms. Franklin in the head, killing her instantly.
The gunman then fled, once more successfully eluding an intense police dragnet activated soon after the shooting.
Hoping to prevent that from happening again, the Pentagon agreed today to deploy secret surveillance planes to patrol the skies over the Washington area. The planes, which have sophisticated sensors, will be used to respond to future attacks. Page A18. 
This morning, the police confirmed that overnight ballistics tests conclusively showed that Ms. Franklin, an analyst for the Federal Bureau of Investigation who was not involved in the manhunt, was the ninth person killed by the roving suburban sniper.
In the two weeks of the sniper's terrifying shooting spree, the killing in this busy suburban community was the first in which witnesses said they saw the actual shooting, police officials privately emphasized.
Witnesses offered enough partial glimpses of the fleeing sniper to allow a police sketch artist to try a composite drawing, detectives said.
"We have been receiving quite a bit of information from witnesses," the Fairfax County police chief, Thomas Manger, said at a news conference after a long night of interviews by investigators combing the scene.
In the busy crossroads mall, Seven Corners Center, officers crawled in waves on hands and knees in the search for evidence.
"We're confident that ultimately that information is going to lead us to an arrest," Chief Manger said, expressing guarded optimism that was not widely shared in the Washington region. 
"We have received license plate information from several witnesses," Chief Manger said. 
If so, it would be one of the most promising clues that has yet been spoken of publicly by officials during the manhunt. Investigators have mostly been close-mouthed so the sniper could not profit from some nugget of crime-scene evidence or detective strategy. The new information stoked hope that an identification of a suspect might be in the offing, but officials declined to speculate.
In intensifying their search, the police took care to speak theoretically of the "person or people" responsible for the shootings, since some witnesses were reported to have talked of possibly two people hurriedly glimpsed fleeing scenes of attacks. 
The shooting scene here, six miles west of Washington, was a study in the sniper's method of attack.
He killed with only a single shot from a high-powered rifle as he has each time in the two-week rampage that has left nine dead and two critically wounded. He appeared to stalk an open area more than a particular victim. His perch, as usual, was close to a fast escape route that allowed him to be lost in minutes.
Government officials said today that the gunman had 15 to 20 minutes before they were able to seal off major roads.
One difference this time was the added touch of cruelty of shooting Ms. Franklin as her husband was a step away, unseeing and powerless to help. They were in a mundane, off-guard moment -- another of the sniper's now-clear preferences -- putting purchases into their red convertible, shelving to be used in a move they were planning this month from the Washington area.
"There she was, the poor woman, her body right there," said Zuhair Massoud, a 50-year-old businessman who emerged from the Home Depot a minute or two after Ms. Franklin was cut down.
"When the F.B.I. agent questioned me later," Mr. Massoud recounted, "He told me: 'This guy's gone already. He's very good. He knows what he's doing.' "
The shooting meant further consternation for the police armada of local, state and federal investigators conducting a thus-far-fruitless manhunt stretching more than 50 miles across the Washington metropolitan area.
If nothing else, detectives were able to eliminate some possible suspects they had under surveillance elsewhere on Monday night as the sniper struck again.
Publicly, officers steadfastly declined to answer questions about how close they think they might be to identifying a prime suspect, or what their strategy is beyond the grim hope that he will get more careless with each new killing.
"How did he get away again?" a reporter shouted at Chief Charles A. Moose of the Montgomery County police as he faced a demanding clot of reporters in Rockville, Md.
Chief Moose is head of the coordinated regional manhunt by dint of the fact that the northern Montgomery County suburban area has had six people killed by the gunman.
Once more questioning whether reporters are compromising the manhunt in their search for crucial details, Chief Moose declined to speculate on the sniper's wiliness or the police strategies.
"If the person or people involved in this were paying attention, they would have that strategy and therefore would make that part of their strategy," the chief replied.
The police released a composite depiction of the sort of light-colored van being sought, based on witness accounts of the slaying of a man on Friday at a gas station in Four Mile Fork, Va. Rather than displaying one van, it shows two possible models close to witness descriptions, a Chevrolet Astro van and a Ford Econoline.
White vans were being stopped all over the region by the police, some with their hands on their pistols. One driver trying to go about his business in his white Chevrolet Astro van with a roof ladder rack -- the kind described in one police report -- had plastered the side windows with signs reading, "This Ain't The One."
The sense of fear and bewilderment in the Washington suburbs has become palpable with each shooting. But beyond fear, there is growing impatience among the public with the investigation, with promises of progress by the police while the sniper strikes at a near daily rate.
"How can you predict what this guy is going to do?" Mr. Massoud, the Home Depot shopper who saw Ms. Franklin lying dead, said in defending the police. "When it comes to this kind of terrorism how do you fight it?"

HEADLINE: Tears and Hugs as 5 Abducted Japanese Go Home to Visit 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 15 

 BODY:
On the tarmac of Tokyo's domestic airport, tears and long hugs contrasted today with the festive red-and-white Japanese flags and the homemade banners reading "Welcome Home."
 Nearly a quarter-century in the making, the homecoming was one that many Japanese doubted they would ever witness: five Japanese citizens, snatched off beaches by North Korean agents in 1978, bundled into bags and taken away by boats, returned for the first time. 
 "He leaned down and hugged me and said, 'I'm sorry to have worried you,' and then the long 24 years seemed somehow a bit shorter," Hatsui Hasuike, said after embracing her son Kaoru.
Last seen in Japan as a college junior, he returned today as a 45-year-old father of two. When his elder brother, Toru, asked him about the kidnapping, he deflected the question, saying: "Not now. Let's talk about it later." 
In North Korea, Kaoru Hasuike and as many as 12 others -- eight of whom North Korea says have since died -- were pressed into service as Japanese language and cultural tutors for spies by the Communist state.
Sequestered for more than two decades in one of the world's most reclusive and impoverished countries, the five survivors will visit here for one week with the permission of North Korea's government. 
Today they appeared to be rusty even in their own language as they spoke with family members and learned for the first time of births of nieces and nephews, and of babies who are now college students.
The visit comes as controversy continues to rage over the kidnappings. It is still unclear whether those who did not survive were killed. North Korea's decision not to allow the children of those who returned today to travel with them has prompted accusation that they are being held hostage.
Two couples, who had been kidnapped on dates, returned today married with grown children. Another woman married an American now in North Korea, who reportedly deserted the United States Army. 
In the coming days they will discover a Japan where eight-track tapes have been replaced by CD's, where black hair and green tea have given way to dyed hair and gourmet coffee, where social lives revolve around cellphones and the Internet, and where 14 prime ministers have spun in and out of government since they were spirited away.
North Korea for decades denied that the kidnappings had even taken place. But last month, Kim Jong Il, North Korea's leader, unexpectedly admitted to 13 abductions and apologized during a groundbreaking visit to Pyongyang by Junichiro Koizumi, the Japanese prime minister.
The admission was greeted here with a mix of anger and relief, and on Monday Mr. Koizumi openly suggested what many Japanese believe: that North Korea executed many kidnap victims. Two groups of relatives of those abducted say that the real number of kidnapped may be 50 to 60.
"Certainly North Korea is an unpardonable country," Mr. Koizumi said on national television. "It abducts, takes away and kills."
He later backpedaled a bit, saying he was conveying the opinions of many people in Japan, not necessarily his own.
Next week the five visitors, who all wore pins of the North Korean flag in their lapels, will fly back to North Korea to rejoin their children, who remained behind. 
Pyongyang has said that the six children of the returnees did not want to accompany their parents to Japan. But in Tokyo, the Japanese grandparents said their grandchildren were being held against their will.
The Japanese government is preparing passports for the five who came here today.
Trying to put the bizarre episode behind them, Japan and North Korea are to hold talks on Oct. 29 and 30 in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, with the aim of eventually normalizing ties. Analysts say that with North Korea desperate for economic aid, the chances are good that it will ultimately release all of the family members.
Today Mr. Koizumi vowed to use the talks to win their return and to "probe into the truth about other abductees whose fates are yet unknown."
"My heart aches when I think of the sorrow and hardships those abducted and their families have experienced in the long 20-plus years," he said in a statement. "With the realization of this temporary homecoming visit, we were able to take the first step forward to resolve the abduction issue."
Japan's press greeted the arrival of the five with a frenzy today -- special newspaper editions, live television coverage and hundreds of reporters and cameras assembled for a huge news conference. But in an indication of how uncertain their position remains, the five were unwilling to speak their minds in interviews.
At a brief news conference, several returnees had red eyes from crying, but their public comments were short and circumspect. With several speaking with light Korean accents, the five limited themselves to apologizing to relatives for the worry their kidnappings had caused.
Two sets of those kidnapped returned as married couples. Mr. Hasuike came here with his wife, Yukiko Okudo, 46. Yasushi Chimura, 47, was here with his wife, Fukie Hamamoto, also 47.
Hitomi Soga, 43, left behind in Pyongyang not only two daughters, but also her husband, Charles Robert Jenkins, 62, a North Carolina native who is reported to have deserted the United States Army in South Korea in 1965.
Akitaka Saiki, a Japanese official, talked to Mr. Jenkins today at the airport in Pyongyang, where he saw his wife off. The official said Mr. Jenkins recalled living in Japan at an Army base near Tokyo in the early 1960's but was reluctant to fly here today, apparently out of fear of arrest and deportation to the United States.
North Korea's explanations of how the eight kidnapped Japanese died have little credibility in Japan. They include assertions that a woman succumbed to heart disease at 27; that another who was kidnapped at 13 hanged herself when she was 29; that the deaths of a family of three resulted from gas poisoning at home; and that, in a country where car ownership is restricted to the top elite, two others who died in a car accident.
According to the accounts provided by North Korean officials, most of the graves of those who died were washed away in the floods that ravaged the country in the mid-1990's.
This morning the 15-year-old daughter of the woman who committed suicide went to Pyongyang's airport, evidently believing that her grandparents would be coming on the plane that arrived from Japan carrying Japanese officials.
"I want to meet the girl as soon as possible," the grandfather, Shigeru Yokota, said today in Japan.
A leader in a decades-long campaign to win freedom for those who were kidnapped, Mr. Yokota said he was devastated to learn last month that his daughter, Megumi, had apparently fallen into a deep depression in Pyongyang, leading to her suicide a decade ago in a psychiatric hospital.
Looking at a photo of his 15-year-old granddaughter, he said, "She is small in stature and looks like me and my wife."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 17, 2002

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the first homeland visit by five Japanese who were abducted by North Koreans more than 20 years ago referred incorrectly in some copies to the background of Charles Robert Jenkins, who married one of them in North Korea. He deserted the United States Army while stationed in South Korea, but it was in 1965, not during the Korean War. 
The article also misstated the number of auto accident deaths among the eight other people that North Korea acknowledges having abducted. According to the official account, only one died in a car accident, not two.

HEADLINE: Museum Gives Voice to Doubts on Dr. King's Killer 

BYLINE:  By JEFFREY GETTLEMAN 

DATELINE: MEMPHIS 

 BODY:
James Earl Ray, a drifter and ex-convict, shot and killed the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. with a single bullet here on an April evening in 1968.
 That is the official story, the reason Mr. Ray spent the last three decades of his life in prison. Everybody knows it. 
 But not everybody accepts it. Almost as soon as Dr. King was cut down -- and even more so after Mr. Ray recanted his guilty plea -- conspiracy theories abounded. Some said the assassin was an army sniper. Mr. Ray insisted he had been framed by a man named Raul, hired by the C.I.A. There was even a report that one of Dr. King's entourage had helped to kill him.
The authorities have repeatedly dismissed such talk, most recently in 2000, when the Justice Department, after an 18-month investigation, said there was no evidence that the assassin was anyone but Mr. Ray, and that there should be no more inquiries.
Now, however, the conspiracy theories have stirred to life again at the National Civil Rights Museum, in the former Lorraine Motel where Dr. King was shot. The museum recently opened an exhibit in a new $11 million wing primarily to document the assassination and the mystery that still surrounds it, at least in some people's minds.
On display are 200 pieces of evidence, freshly unsealed from police archives. The gun. The 30.06-caliber bullet tweezed out of Dr. King's body. A fake passport and guidebook to Rhodesia found on Mr. Ray, curious artifacts for an unemployed ex-convict supposedly working solo.
The exhibit, called "Lingering Questions," opened on Sept. 28. Questions are stamped on the wall, in bold letters. "Did Ray have help? Did someone else do it? Was the Memphis Police Department part of the conspiracy?" 
A haunting voice leaks out of a pair of speakers. "There was this climate of hate. It was simply in the air. You knew it was going to happen."
That voice, sad and steady, belongs to Coretta Scott King.
The King family believes that Mr. Ray, who died of liver disease in 1998, was not the killer. Dexter King, Dr. King's son, visited Mr. Ray on his deathbed. The government killed my father, Dexter King told him, not you.
A spokesman for the King family, which is not officially involved in the museum or this exhibit, said the family appreciated "the dialogue." Mr. Ray's family said they were finally getting the vindication they deserved. Visitors are entranced.
"We're just putting the ideas out there," said the museum director, Beverly Robertson. "Let's face it. A lot of people have doubts about who killed Dr. King. I've looked at the evidence. I've found it fascinating. I still don't know."
But Peter G. Beeson, one of the investigators in a 1979 Congressional inquiry into the killing, said there was no doubt in his mind, "no lingering questions," that Mr. Ray had done it.
"We examined all these theories as carefully as we could," said Mr. Beeson, now a lawyer in Manchester, N.H. "The evidence kept coming back to Ray. I guess you'll always have those who still want to believe in government conspiracy theories."
The assassination exhibit will be a permanent addition to the National Civil Rights Museum, which opened in 1991 and traces the story of the movement from 1619, when the first slaves arrived in Jamestown, Va., to modern times.
The museum, which draws about 130,000 visitors a year, is financed by donations and grants. It includes both the motel where Dr. King was shot and the rooming house across Mulberry Street where Mr. Ray stayed. Federal agents said Mr. Ray, a convicted robber who was on the run after escaping prison, fired the fatal shot from a second-floor bathroom directly across from the motel.
But the exhibit hedges on that. In the rooming house bathroom, James Earl Ray is not mentioned. However, Mr. Ray's belongings are featured in glass cases. One houses a bottle of Gillette Sun-Up aftershave, a hairbrush and pair of Mr. Ray's boxer shorts.
Under an agreement drawn up by the Tennessee Legislature, state police archives gave 200 pieces of evidence to the museum to put on display. None had been seen before, because there had never been a trial.
Mr. Ray's younger brother, Jerry, says the F.B.I. knows who killed Dr. King. "And it wasn't Jimmy," Jerry Ray said. "I guess this museum thing is good because it shows both sides, the truth and the lies. I still want that rifle back, though. It's our family's not theirs." (Museum officials said the rifle was staying.)
Several display boards compare leading conspiracy theories with the conclusions of the investigations that have been held over the years. 
"These boards really make you wonder," said Mary Moore, a St. Louis social worker who recently visited the exhibit. "And that's O.K. I think things like this put a stamp of approval on our tradition of questioning."
The Rev. Fred Shuttlesworth, an 80-year-old civil rights champion and friend of Dr. King, agreed.
"It may be upsetting to go through all this again," Mr. Shuttlesworth said. "But we got to. So many things are covered up these days."
One display board suggests that the Memphis Police Department might have been involved in Dr. King's murder because police officers cleared away part of the crime scene within hours of the shooting. As with the Kennedy assassination, the suspicion lives on, no matter what the authorities say.
"There are so many conspiracy theories around Dr. King's death, you can't count them on your hands and feet," said LaTanya Able, a Memphis police spokeswoman. "It's unfortunate we were included."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 22, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article on Wednesday about an exhibit at the National Civil Rights Museum in Memphis that questions whether James Earl Ray acted alone in the assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. misidentified a recorded voice that speaks of "a climate of hate" at the time and says, "You knew it was going to happen." It is the voice of Myrlie Evers, widow of Medgar Evers, not Coretta Scott King.

HEADLINE: A Smaller Loss Than Expected At Delta Sends Shares Up 21% 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG 

 BODY:
Delta Air Lines reported a deeper loss yesterday, reflecting a summer in which passengers -- worried about the shaky economy and inundated with talk of war and terrorism -- failed to return to the skies at the rate executives had hoped for.
 But the loss, excluding unusual items, was better than analysts had expected, and shares of Delta rose $1.59, or 21 percent, to close at $9.09 yesterday. That was the largest single-day percentage gain for Delta in two decades, said Jamie Baker, an analyst at J. P. Morgan. 
 "The fundamentals may not be showing any improvement, but at least the deterioration appears to have halted," Mr. Baker said. "Before anything in life starts getting better, it has to stop getting worse first." 
Delta, the nation's third-largest carrier, was the first airline to report its third-quarter earnings, and its numbers portend a depressing week for the industry.
AMR, the parent of American Airlines, the world's largest carrier, is expected to report its financial results today. Analysts expect its numbers to be bleak, though likely not as bad as those of its biggest rival, United Airlines. UAL, the parent of United, is scheduled to announce its third-quarter results on Friday, and has said it could file for bankruptcy by mid-November. 
Over all, the industry is expected to lose $7 billion or more this year as companies struggle to keep flying.
With special charges and gains factored in, Delta lost $326 million, or $2.67 a share, in the third quarter. Excluding one-time charges and gains, the loss at Delta was $212 million, or $1.75 a share, better than analysts' consensus estimate of a loss of $1.84 a share, according to a survey by Thomson First Call. 
The one-time unusual items included a $139 million charge from a reduction in market value of its aging MD-11 and Boeing 727 aircraft and spare parts. 
Delta had revenue of $3.42 billion in the quarter, up slightly from $3.4 billion a year earlier, when the Sept. 11 attacks devastated air traffic. 
In the third quarter of last year, Delta had a loss of $259 million, or $2.13 a share.
Delta's bad quarter was not a surprise, because the company had predicted a big loss in a Securities and Exchange Commission filing on Sept. 27. 
Executives foretold a gloomy year ahead for airlines during a conference call yesterday morning.
"There is no doubt that this has been a demanding quarter for Delta and the entire industry," said M. Michele Burns, the chief financial officer. "We do not see a near-term improvement."
Ms. Burns said the fourth-quarter loss would be in line with analysts' expectations. The consensus estimate by Thomson First Call is for a loss of $2.20 a share in the fourth quarter.
To cut costs, Delta said it planned to ground all 15 of its MD-11 aircraft and defer deliveries of new Boeing planes in 2003 and 2004. The deferrals -- five planes next year and 24 in 2004 -- will help reduce $1.3 billion from capital expenditures over that time period, executives said.
The elimination of the MD-11's, a McDonnell Douglas line that first went into service in 1992 at Delta, will help simplify the fleet of Delta, a move that many large carriers are also undertaking. The fewer different types of planes in a fleet, the more the airline will save in long-term employee training and maintenance costs.
Frederick W. Reid, the chief operating officer, said Delta had been relatively successful in predicting the decline in traffic around this Sept. 11, the anniversary of the attacks. The airline reduced the number of seats and flights throughout the quarter, and its systemwide capacity was down 8.3 percent from the period two years ago. (Comparisons to 2001 would be less relevant, because of the unusually drastic cutbacks in flights after the terrorist attacks.) 
In the third quarter, Delta also received $22 million from the Air Transportation Stabilization Board, which was set up by the federal government to grant $5 billion in cash assistance to the industry after the attacks.
In the last month, the chief executive, Leo F. Mullin, has joined rival airline executives on Capitol Hill to urge the government to give the industry more financial aid. They are pushing for the government to pick up security costs, as well as costs related to terrorism insurance. 
Late last month, the aviation subcommittee in the House of Representatives proposed a bill that included several very limited provisions to help the carriers, but did not tackle the issues that the executives were most concerned about.
The current legislation, if passed, would extend the government's role in helping to provide war-risk insurance and to accept again applications for a $10 billion loan guarantee program if the United States goes to war with Iraq.
But the legislation would not end a security tax of $2.50 a flight segment that the government has levied on airline tickets. Executives argue that the tax unnecessarily raises ticket prices at a time when people are already reluctant to fly. Mr. Mullin said he expected Delta to forgo $250 million of revenue this year because of this tax.
"I don't think it's done yet, obviously, and we'll continue working on this," he said of the government's proposed aid package.
It is questionable whether this bill would even go to a full vote in the House and the Senate, because many members of Congress are preoccupied with sifting through what is generally considered more important legislation dealing with war against Iraq.

HEADLINE: Europe Pushes for Renewable Energy 

BYLINE:  By PAUL MELLER 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Oct. 15 

 BODY:
Romano Prodi has seen the hydrogen-powered light.
 In an interview today, Mr. Prodi, the president of the European Commission, described his view of Europe in a post-fossil-fuel era, when homes would generate the power they need from renewable sources like the wind and the sun, store it in hydrogen fuel cells and harness it as needed, replacing all the polluting energy sources in use today. 
 He is not just musing. Speaking for the 15-nation European Union at a conference in Johannesburg over the summer, he said the union had set a goal of obtaining 22 percent of its electricity and 12 percent of all energy from renewable sources by 2010. 
Economics and geopolitics are behind the move as much as environmental concerns. Europe depends much more heavily on imported energy than the United States does: around 70 percent of its oil and gas comes from abroad, mainly the Middle East and Russia.
"For us, reducing fossil fuel dependency is a priority," Mr. Prodi said.
The great impediment to wider use of renewable energy has been the difficulty of storing and transporting it for later use, a practical necessity that fossil fuels make relatively simple. Hydrogen may, too, which is why Mr. Prodi takes it so seriously.
Last week, the commission convened the first meeting of a panel of senior executives from European companies with stakes in the matter, like Royal Dutch/Shell, DaimlerChrysler and Rolls-Royce, the aircraft engine maker. The panel will advise the union on the development of hydrogen fuel cells, which promise to be a practical power source for vehicles and fixed use. 
The commission, the executive body of the union, has already earmarked more than 2.1 billion euros ($2 billion) for research over the next five years into sustainable energy projects, a 20-fold increase in the last five years (1997-2001). A central focus will be hydrogen fuel cells, a field where the union has lagged the United States and Japan in publicly financed research.
Mr. Prodi said that Europe was poised to leap ahead of its rivals in its overall energy strategy. "Neither the United States nor Japan is clear on its goals," he said, and without clear goals, there is little progress.
Industry agrees. "The European commission is playing a very significant role now in developing hydrogen fuel cells," said Don Huberts, chief executive of Shell Hydrogen, after the advisory panel met last week. "It is providing a framework for the introduction of the new technologies in the E.U. It would be very hard to convert the environmental benefits into consumer benefits without this political leadership."
Herbert Kohler, director of environmental affairs at DaimlerChrysler, said political support was vital. "For the car industry, we can do a lot ourselves, but at a certain point we need fuel -- and that means involving others," Mr. Kohler said after the meeting. "We need legislative and financial support to stimulate this sector, and for that we need government involvement."
Researchers have been trying for decades to harness hydrogen as a cheap fuel. Mr. Prodi said that now, for the first time, technological advances "give us the message that we are on the eve of being able to do this cost effectively."
"We are not working on a scientific experiment," he continued. "Science is already on board. We are working for change in the most important pattern of consumption of a contemporary society."
Before assuming the presidency of the European Commission, Mr. Prodi was prime minister of Italy, where he was credited with preparing the country to adopt the euro. In Brussels, he has overseen preparations for the European Union to take in 10 new members in 2004.
The energy project is in the same league as these other big ideas, Mr. Prodi said. "The difference is that with enlargement and with the euro, there is a big bang. Not here. My role here is to kick this process off; others will work on its implementation."
But before Mr. Prodi can fulfill his wider energy ambitions, there are still the union's existing energy goals to achieve, notably the creation of a liberalized market in energy within the union. Continuing state ownership and support of some major utilities, like Electricite de France, is creating friction with neighboring nations that have privatized faster.
Even old-fashioned energy monopolies like Electricite de France have a role to play in the energy future Mr. Prodi foresees, he said, by helping with the transition.
Mr. Prodi put the cost of converting Europe to a decentralized energy grid based on hydrogen fuel cells placed at or near the point of energy consumption at about five times the cost of installing a mobile-phone network. "The cost is enormous," he said, "but it is not out of reach."
Without involvement of the private sector, the project will not succeed, he said, but companies will become involved in building the new energy network only if there is a strong political will behind them.
What if the looked-for dawn of cheap hydrogen energy never breaks? "Maybe this will fail," Mr. Prodi said. "But then there are no other serious alternatives."

HEADLINE: Learning to Work in an Heirloom After Life in a Warren 

BYLINE:  By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
Six weeks into its reincarnation as the headquarters of the New York City school system, the Tweed Courthouse has forced its 600 new inhabitants to make major adjustments.
 For veterans of 110 Livingston Street, the famously dismal building in downtown Brooklyn that housed the central school administration for 63 years, the sunlight dappling the halls of Tweed -- filtered through the stained-glass skylight of a dazzling rotunda, no less -- has been shocking. 
 "From the catacombs to the cathedral, right?" Chancellor Joel I. Klein said as he bustled through the third-floor hallway the other day, sweeping an arm toward the rotunda and grinning wickedly.
Mr. Klein may be the only "educrat," as the central school administrators are known, who is 100 percent pleased with the move to Tweed, which underwent a nearly $100 million renovation starting in 1999. Going from the warren-like offices of 110 Livingston to the airy, bullpen-style rooms that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg installed at Tweed has been, well, unsettling. 
In contrast to the secretive culture that inspired one former chancellor to nickname 110 Livingston "the puzzle palace," all meetings at Tweed are held in the open, at gleaming new tables scattered through the ornamented hallways.
Mr. Klein and Mr. Bloomberg hope the physical change will bring about a profound cultural shift at the Department of Education, one idea being that a beautiful workplace will inspire administrators to work harder on behalf of the city's 1.1 million schoolchildren.
Mr. Bloomberg -- who works in his own bullpen at City Hall, just behind Tweed -- also believes the open layout will encourage cooperative planning and decision-making, neither of which was a hallmark of 110 Livingston.
Norman Fruchter, a New York University professor who studies the school system and has attended several meetings at Tweed, said he was "blown away" by the building's grandeur and believed its large, open spaces could indeed change how school system business is done.
"It does feel very different, to have a meeting with the chancellor or some other folks right in the cubicles or out in one of the public spaces," Mr. Fruchter said. "Before, you were always squirreled away in somebody's office and there was nothing open about it."
Others have noticed a sense of calm and order that they say was never present at 110 Livingston.
"Everything about that place was so chaotic," said Ernest Clayton, president of the United Parents Association of New York City. "It was almost like you were in a subway station. The first thing that strikes you about Tweed is the orderliness and the sense of professionalism."
Some Tweed transplants say that what Mr. Clayton perceives as orderliness, they see as an uncomfortably sterile, hushed environment. Working in the open in such opulent quarters feels oddly like being on display, they say, conjuring images of dioramas at the Museum of Natural History. The casual conversations, jokes and gripe fests that are common in most workplaces are rare at Tweed, these people say, because everything can be overheard.
"So much of the communication at 110 took place in the hallways, in the bathrooms, hanging out in someone's office," one midlevel employee said. "That may be the intent at Tweed, but it's going to be a long time before people feel comfortable having those spontaneous discussions."
Dennis M. Walcott, the deputy mayor for policy, does not consider the discomfort a bad thing.
"There is a higher level of professionalism in the way people are interacting and even dressing at Tweed because you know you are going to run into the boss," said Mr. Walcott, who can wave to Mr. Klein from the window of his City Hall office. "It's not like the boss is disappearing into his 10th-floor office or his car. The boss is suddenly all over the place. And people are looking good."
Back at 110 Livingston, the files, office equipment and personal belongings that were abandoned over the last month and a half would make for a curious archeological study. 
Most of the offices still have desks, computers, copy and fax machines, file cabinets and phones; a few look as if whoever worked there left for a fire drill and might return at any moment. Outside the chancellor's office on the 10th floor, a sign that reads "To teach is to touch someone's life forever" has been left behind, as have several plants, a time clock and a dictionary, opened to the page that starts with digestive and ends with diluter.
A few rooms away, a half-full water cooler remains outside the deputy chancellor's office, along with a refrigerator containing two bottles of salad dressing and some fruit cups. Bound minutes from years of Board of Education meetings are stacked everywhere; Margie Feinberg, a spokeswoman for Mr. Klein, said they might end up at Teachers College of Columbia University. There are also boxes and cabinets jammed with files, some labeled "Tweed," others, "Shred."
David Chai, Mr. Klein's press secretary, said the Department of Education planned to distribute the abandoned equipment and supplies among schools. The city has spent $13 million on new furniture, computers and other equipment for Tweed.
The Police Department has taken over the 11th floor of 110 Livingston, where Board of Education members had their offices. About 160 of the roughly 800 Department of Education employees who worked at 110 Livingston are still there, including some from the Office of Legal Services and the chancellor's district of low-performing schools, Mr. Chai said. Some especially large divisions, like Human Resources, will not move to Tweed but will reside for now in the department's other Brooklyn buildings, including 65 Court Street and 131 Livingston Street.
Refugees from Livingston Street, who have been moving to Tweed in waves since Sept. 3, were allowed to bring only two boxes, which helps explain why the old building is still brimming with paraphernalia.
They sit back to back at L-shaped desks, about 35 to a room, on the second, third and fourth floors of Tweed. Mr. Klein's "L" is toward the back of Room 320, which he shares with senior staff members including Diana Lam, the deputy chancellor for teaching and learning; Anthony Shorris, the deputy chancellor for operations and planning; and Michele Cahill, Mr. Klein's senior policy adviser.
For small meetings, Department of Education employees can huddle on benches or in easy chairs in the circular hallways that look down on the building's street-level floor. For larger ones, there are gleaming new tables scattered through several palatial conference rooms, each with a marble fireplace that "looks like a boar's head should be hanging over it," in the words of one longtime school system official.
Mr. Bloomberg said back in March that he would put a school on Tweed's first floor, and in a news conference yesterday, he offered some vague details. He said that there was not enough space for a traditional school with multiple grades and classrooms, and that instead, he envisioned "a place to try out new things, to experiment, to demonstrate that we can do better." Mr. Bloomberg suggested using the space for teacher training, classes for disabled students or an honors program that would bring students from around the city together and "give them a chance to meet great New Yorkers who have come through the New York City school system and built their careers."
And whither 110 Livingston, which former Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani memorably declared should be "blown up"? The Giuliani administration issued a request for proposals in May 2001, hoping that someone would offer to buy not only 110 Livingston but its neighbors, 131 Livingston and 65 Court. But it came to naught, perhaps because of the economic downturn or because at the time nobody could even remotely imagine the Board of Education picking up roots.
Mr. Walcott said that City Hall and the Economic Development Corporation were mulling the buildings' future, and that they might be sold as a package or separately. Asked whether he had a grand vision for the future of 110 Livingston, Mr. Walcott begged off, saying, "I'm not prone to that kind of speculation."
Some Tweed transplants, however, are betting that their former home -- once the headquarters for the Benevolent and Protective Order of Elks, a luxurious private club with a ballroom, bowling alleys, Turkish baths and a swimming pool -- will be turned into apartments or loft space. Wistfully, they picture 110 Livingston Street evolving from a notorious address to a coveted one.
"We're talking about some serious work that will have to be done first," one Department of Education employee said, "but it has condos written all over it."

HEADLINE: Our Towns; 
From Bottom Of Bird Cages, An Issue Rises

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW PURDY 

 BODY:
THE problem with writing a newspaper column is that you are forced to be wise and provocative on deadline, whether or not you feel wise and provocative at that moment.
 The payoff is that, inevitably, the deadline is met, newspapers are put out for recycling, and your last attempt is often forgotten by you and everyone else by the time the next deadline rolls around. 
 Unless you happen to run for the United State Senate.
That's why Doug Forrester has a columnist's nightmare on his hands. It turns out that Mr. Forrester, the Republican Senate candidate in New Jersey, wrote a weekly column a decade ago for The West Windsor-Plainsboro Chronicle. Mr. Forrester, a political neophyte enjoying the advantage of having no real record, suddenly has one -- a pile of clippings called Grover's Mill Ponderings. 
He should have called them Ponderings in Courage, given how they are being mined for his true political leanings.
They offer his new opponent, Frank Lautenberg, fodder for a few commercials, since Mr. Forrester opposed an assault weapons ban and sobriety checkpoints as unfair government intervention.
Mr. Forrester's oeuvre offers a rare columnoscopy of this seminarian-turned-government official-turned-businessman-turned-crusader against the ethically flawed Robert Torricelli.
You confront Mr. Forrester's inner stiffness. Of a family Disneyland trip, he wrote, "I, alas, have also made the transition from amusement which is based on a sense of wonder to that which is based on fear."
He thinks hard, perhaps too hard, even about that which is based on pleasure. "There is something about ice cream which reduces all who partake to common ground," he wrote. "Even as the ice cream melts, so do the artificial barriers of economics, social status, age, sex, appearance, and other impediments to the enjoyment of our simple humanity."
He admits past mistakes. "I used to believe that country music was the bastard offspring of bad liquor and low I.Q.'s," he wrote. "No more."
He is vox suburbanite. "I cleaned the garage last week," began one column. Another recounts slaying a shrew in the bathtub. A third is titled, "Men's Last Refuge: The Barbecue."
HIS column was named for the Grover's Mill section of West Windsor, the mythical landing place of Martians in "War of the Worlds." He imagines a morally mythical world, with citizens in control and government in its place.
He chides those building a brick wall between church and state and, at every turn, favors personal freedom over government intervention, saying, "there is a direct relationship between the size of government and the liberty of its citizens." More libertarian than conservative, he sees flag burning as free if distasteful expression.
He now says he supports an assault weapons ban, but his past thinking is revealing. Without proof it would stanch crime, he said, the ban undercut the individual right to do things others view as extreme. He compared it to "someone who smokes tree-size cigars."
"Liberty is all about the government allowing citizens to do weird things unless there is a compelling, documented public purpose which should preclude them," he wrote. "The failure of a majority to understand an activity is not a compelling public purpose."
He never wrote about abortion, but his view that it is a private decision, which the government should neither regulate nor finance, fits that libertarian streak.
Whatever one thinks of Mr. Forrester's style or positions, only one column, "Gossip: The Invisible Assassin," precludes him from the brethren of news hounds. A true journalist would have written, "Gossip: The Invisible Source."
"It is way out of line," he wrote, "to suggest in public that someone is mishandling money unless there is some supporting evidence which has been checked in private. Anyone who is genuinely concerned about a matter and trying to be a good citizen has the opportunity to ask the parties involved to respond before trying to make it an issue of public gossip."
Imagine if he had applied this principle to his race against Mr. Torricelli: "Senator Torricelli, tell me you didn't do what those nasty people say you did so I don't perpetuate gossip by publicly calling you an oozing, disgraceful sore."
But perhaps no columnist can live up to all those deadline ponderings.
"My wife claims that the high point of my political wisdom," Mr. Forrester once wrote, "occurred when I decided to excuse myself from electoral politics."

HEADLINE: Bank of America Beats Estimates, and Share Price Jumps 

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Bank of America reported third-quarter earnings yesterday that exceeded analysts' estimates, as profits from retail operations more than offset weakness in investment banking and trading. 
 Earnings at Bank One in Chicago and at Wells Fargo, based in San Francisco, were in line with analysts' expectations. 
 Shares in the banks rose sharply on the news. 
Bank of America, based in Charlotte, N.C., said that a strong performance in its retail operations including mortgages, credit cards and deposits increased net income to $2.24 billion, or $1.45 a share, in the third quarter from $841 million, or 51 cents a share, a year earlier. 
The 2001 figures included costs related to leaving the auto leasing and subprime real estate lending businesses as well as a good will write-down. 
Analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call had expected earnings of $1.41 for the quarter. 
Shares increased $5.04 yesterday, to close at $65.75. The bank chairman, Kenneth D. Lewis, said that strength in retail operations had offset weakness in market-related revenue from trading and equity investments. 
The chief financial officer, James Hance Jr., said he expected fourth-quarter performance "to look a lot like the third." He said consumer banking continued to be strong and that there was some improvement in commercial lending. Net income for the first nine months was $6.64 billion, or $4.22 a share, up from $4.73 billion, or $2.90 a share, a year ago. 
At Bank One, third-quarter profit increased to $823 million, or 70 cents a share, from $754 million, or 64 cents a share, a year earlier. 
That was in line with the estimates by Thomson First Call. 
Shares increased $2.61, to $39.74.
The chief executive, James L. Dimon, said retail operations "had net growth in transaction accounts for the first time in nearly three years" and that nonperforming commercial loans were down for the first time in three years. 
Net income for the first nine months was $2.45 billion, or $2.08 a share, compared with $2.1 billion, or $1.78 a share, in 2001. 
At Wells Fargo, third-quarter earnings were propelled by low mortgage rates and a surge in new depositors. The bank earned $1.44 billion, or 84 cents a share, in the quarter, up from $1.16 billion, or 67 cents a share, a year earlier. That matched the consensus of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call.
Shares climbed $2.55, to $49.78.
With mortgage rates low, millions of homeowners have been refinancing, which has been a boon for Wells Fargo. 
Through the first nine months, Wells's mortgage volume totaled $221 billion, more than its previous full-year record of $202 billion in 2001. 
In the third quarter, the bank collected $6 billion in revenue, a 10 percent improvement from the period last year. Through the first nine months, revenue totaled $18 billion, a 26 percent gain from last year. 
Loan losses in the third quarter totaled $415 million, down from $454 million a year earlier. 
In the first nine months, Wells earned $3.97 billion, or $2.30 a share, up from $2.24 billion, or $1.29 a share, last year.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
In the High-Tech Sector,Optimism Is Just a Faded Memory

BYLINE:  By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz., Oct. 15 

 BODY:
At this year's Agenda conference, traditionally an upbeat gathering of the computer and Internet industries' elite, attendance was low and the mood even lower. Executives engaged in a hunt for the bottom of the decline with few seeing even a hint of new growth on the horizon.
 For the first time, those who have had a near-religious faith in enduring technical progress debated whether their industry had become a slower-growing and mature one. Some executives dared to express the view that the boom years of double-digit growth and dot-com wealth might be over not temporarily but permanently. 
 "A lot of people don't want to admit that the technology industry is maturing," said Ann Livermore, an executive vice president of Hewlett-Packard who leads the company's services division. "It's a maturing industry with a slowing growth rate."
Some executives offered another view, saying that it was not the industry's maturity but the rapid pace of the technology development driven by Moore's Law -- the doubling of computing capacity every 18 months -- that has created the industry's financial crisis. 
For example, they argued, taking on huge long-term debt burdens during the telecommunications industry build-out of the 1990's was out of sync with the rapid depreciation and obsolescence of computer-based equipment.
Whatever the cause of the crisis, several of those who attended were even more blunt about the prospects of the industry, which until last year was held out as a bright spot and a national economic savior.
"The tech industry is in danger of looking like Japan: it's down and out for a long time," said Rob Glaser, the chairman and chief executive of RealNetworks, a maker of multimedia software.
Several of the nation's leading technologists expressed the view that the technology downturn was an immediate threat to the nation's global industrial standing.
"Maybe our current downsizing in the U.S. tech industry is a permanent downsizing and we are headed toward being a second-class industrial citizen in the world," said Patrick Gelsinger, vice president and chief technology officer of Intel.
The new pessimism, which has become increasingly common in Silicon Valley, contrasts sharply to the prevailing view among high-tech executives last year. The consensus then was that the technology recession would be characterized by a "v-shaped curve" with a sharp decline and quick recovery.
At this year's conference, however, it was apparent this idea had passed. "We're talking in terms of years, not months," said Eric Schmidt, the chief executive of Google, the Internet search engine company, which, although privately held, is one of Silicon Valley's remaining bright spots.
This year's gathering was also distinguished by the presence of politics and national security issues in a forum that had until now been dominated by technology and the economy.
On Monday, Richard Garwin, a national security expert and former I.B.M. physicist, engaged in what was billed as a fireside chat with the conference moderator, James Fallows. Dr. Garwin spelled out various potential doomsday terrorism threats ranging from nuclear war to biological warfare.
On Tuesday the conference for the first time presented a speaker from what could only be described as the old economy: Charles T. Burbage, the executive vice president and general manager of Lockheed Martin's Joint Strike Fighter program.
The new interest in military technology is being driven at least in part by a search for financial growth. David Readerman, director of growth equity strategy at Thomas Weisel Partners, a San Francisco investment firm, said that military contractors were increasingly of interest to him.
"I'm not finding a lot of growth in the technology areas our firm was founded on," he said. "So we cast a net and the defense sector is what comes up."
The most heated debate of the event came during a panel of Hollywood executives who criticized the technology industries for their lax adherence to intellectual property protection and copyright issues in the digital era. 
That evoked a response from many executives here that the entertainment industry's unwillingness to explore new business models was primarily responsible for the industry's lack of growth. 
"We're in a real technology gridlock," said Peter Schwartz, co-founder and chairman of the Global Business Network, a consulting group based in Emeryville, Calif. "All of the entrenched industries are attempting to protect their positions so that in broadband, digital television and digital distribution of content, we're stuck."

HEADLINE: Israeli Hints at Withdrawal From a 2nd West Bank City 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BENNET 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, Oct. 15 

 BODY:
Israel's defense minister suggested today that the army might withdraw from a second West Bank city by the weekend, sounding a conciliatory note as Prime Minister Ariel Sharon arrived in Washington to meet with President Bush.
 The Bush administration, seeking support for a possible war on Iraq, has recently criticized Israel, saying it has not kept its promises to ease the plight of Palestinians. The Americans have also questioned recent Israeli military actions, particularly in the Gaza Strip, citing the danger to civilians. 
 Mr. Bush's meeting with Mr. Sharon is expected to focus on Iraq rather than Israeli-Palestinian relations. But advisers to Mr. Sharon said he is anxious to fend off any hint that Mr. Bush may try to gain Arab support or acquiescence in an Iraq venture by promising Israeli concessions toward the Palestinians.
Mr. Sharon temporarily left behind a tense, troubled country. With municipal workers on strike, the smell of burning garbage filled the air here today, and waste piled up on street corners and around overflowing trash cans. 
In a speech on Monday in which he called on Palestinians to replace their leadership, Mr. Sharon also demanded that the strikers and others "make painful compromises" for "our very existence and livelihood." That call has gone unheeded, as the prime minister prepares for a difficult political fight to win passage of a budget meant to relieve what he called "this economic crisis." 
Four Israelis were slightly wounded today by broken glass after something hit a bus in northern Israel, near the boundary with the West Bank. The police said they were not certain whether Palestinians opened fire on the bus, whether a gun was accidentally discharged, or whether there was some other cause. 
"We know that it was a bullet," said Gil Kleiman, a police spokesman. But the police later said that machinery might have sent bits of metal or rocks flying at the bus. 
The defense minister, Benjamin Ben-Eliezer, said during a visit to France that Israel was in "intensive talks on widening the area" of Israeli withdrawal in the southern West Bank. He mentioned Hebron, saying he hoped the army would leave by the end of the week "if the conditions in the field will allow it."
Israel seized control of seven of the eight West Bank cities in midsummer, after a devastating suicide attack on a bus in Jerusalem, but withdrew from Bethlehem two months ago after gaining assurances from Palestinian officials that the city would remain quiet. Bethlehem was supposed to be a test case, but though the city has remained relatively calm, Israel has made no further withdrawals, citing violence elsewhere in the West Bank. 
The Israeli police today detained the chief Muslim cleric here, Ikrema Sabri, the mufti of Jerusalem. The police said he was questioned for about three hours on a report in an Arab newspaper that he had called suicide bombing a form of self-defense. 
Leaving the police station this afternoon, Mr. Sabri, who was appointed to his post by Yasir Arafat, told reporters the report was inaccurate. "I clarified my positions," he said.
Mr. Sabri was also detained for about three hours and questioned on Sept. 14, 2001. He said then that the police had accused him of incitement in his sermons.

GRAPHIC: Map of the West Bank, Israel, highlighting Hebron: Hebron is the focus of talk of a possible pullback by Israelis.

HEADLINE: Deep Pockets Aside, Forrester Is Short on Donors 

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOCIENIEWSKI 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Oct. 15 

 BODY:
Douglas R. Forrester has raised barely $1 million from individual donors since winning the New Jersey Republican Senate primary in June, according to campaign records filed with the Federal Election Commission today. The sum is considerably less than political analysts had expected and raises questions about how well his campaign will be able to compete as the Senate race goes into its final three weeks.
 Mr. Forrester also received $200,000 from the National Republican Senatorial Committee and lent his campaign an additional $1.3 million from his personal assets, leaving him with $2.6 million cash in the bank. But Democrats expect to spend at least $10 million on the campaign of former Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, in a state where Republicans have not won a Senate race in 30 years and Mr. Forrester remains barely known. 
 Mr. Forrester's campaign tried to put a brave face on its financial showing, saying that it was still collecting an additional $280,000 from the fund-raiser featuring President Bush last month and that it had seen a spike in donations in recent weeks, including two $50,000 events today. 
Appearing at a fund-raiser with Senator John McCain of Arizona, Mr. Forrester said that he would have more than enough money to get his message to voters, and that he felt gratified his campaign forced Senator Robert G. Torricelli, the Democratic incumbent, to withdraw from the race last month.
But many analysts, and even some New Jersey Republicans, conceded that Mr. Forrester's fund-raising effort had been disappointing. Joseph R. Kyrillos Jr., chairman of the New Jersey Republican Party, blamed a weak economy and the perception that, until his ethics problems snowballed and forced him to withdraw from the race on Sept. 30, Mr. Torricelli was too formidable an opponent to be beaten by a political neophyte.
Mr. Kyrillos also said that many would-be donors assumed that Mr. Forrester -- who spent $3 million of his own money on the primary, but said he could not underwrite the bulk of a general election campaign -- was wealthy enough to pay for the entire campaign himself.
"There was an unfortunate signal sent early on, inadvertently, that Doug can finance his own race -- which is not the case," he said. "Mr. Forrester is a self-made man and he's a successful businessman, but he's not Jon Corzine. He can't afford to pay $68 million on a campaign."
Mr. Forrester has given his primary and general election campaign $7.5 million over all.
Because Mr. Lautenberg entered the race just this month, he is not required to file his financial statement until next week, but officials from both parties expect that he will have a considerable financial advantage. Mr. Lautenberg, who served in the Senate for 18 years, has said he expects to raise about $3 million between now and Election Day. 
The Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee recently spent more than $1.5 million to purchase television time for Mr. Lautenberg's ads, which are scheduled to begin this week, and has earmarked an additional $4.5 million for New Jersey, party officials said.
Mr. Lautenberg has also given $1 million of his own to the campaign, according to Democratic officials, and has agreed to spend up to $2 million more. After receiving an endorsement from the Black Minister's Council of New Jersey today, Mr. Lautenberg said he hoped that it would not be necessary for him to dip further into his own assets.
"The old gray mare ain't what she used to be," he said of his finances.
Mr. Lautenberg's advisers tried to portray Mr. Forrester's fund-raising performance as evidence that he was out of touch with New Jersey voters.
"He has no money because he has no message," said Tom Shea, the campaign spokesman. "Why would people give money to someone who is so much more conservative than the rest of the state on all of the issues?"
Others say that Mr. Forrester's biggest fund-raising problem is the current disarray within New Jersey's Republican Party, which is still reeling after losing control of the governor's mansion and both houses of the Legislature last fall. Compounding that problem is that many of the party's most proven fund-raisers are unable to help raise money for the Forrester campaign. Clifford M. Sobel is now serving as American ambassador to the Netherlands, Christopher J. Christie became the United States attorney for New Jersey, Lewis Eisenberg became chairman of the Republican National Committee in Washington and Candace Straight is running her own race for Essex County executive.
Despite those obstacles, Mr. Forrester's aides say he is confident he will raise enough money to prevail.
"I don't know anybody who would be disappointed with the fact that Doug Forrester kept his first camp promise -- to retire Bob Torricelli," said Bill Pascoe, his campaign manager. "We're in a new race now, against Doug's seventh opponent, and he's still committed to making sure that the campaign has all the resources that will be necessary on Election Day."

HEADLINE: THE 2002 CAMPAIGN: THE REPUBLICANS; 
G.O.P. Chairman Says Economy Won't Hurt His Party at Polls

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 

 BODY:
The Republican national chairman today dismissed the Democratic Party's response to the nation's economic problems as "impotent," and said he did not believe that a fall campaign revolving around the economy would hurt his party's Congressional candidates.
 The chairman, Marc Racicot, said Republican candidates were prepared to battle Democrats over the economy notwithstanding Democrats' assertion that the issue plays to their strength. 
 In a 90-minute discussion over lunch with editors and reporters of The New York Times, Mr. Racicot also disputed the Democrats' argument that in focusing intently on Iraq, President Bush had neglected the economy. Actually, he said, Mr. Bush has given as much attention to domestic issues as to national security, but most of the public is unaware of it because it has not often been reported by news organizations. 
"Even though he has simultaneously been addressing economic issues, they are not the object of your reports, frequently," Mr. Racicot said. "And that's understandable. But I think that has somehow created the misperception that he has not been as focused on the economy, which is simply not the case. There has never been a wanting of his attention on those issues."
Jennifer Palmieri, a spokeswoman for the Democratic National Committee, disputed Mr. Racicot, saying the voters would hold Republicans and the president accountable.
"Here's the evidence that Bush is not paying enough attention to the economy: Unemployment is up, incomes are down, the stock market has experienced record losses," Ms. Palmieri said. "Did I say that poverty is rising? Poverty is rising, and 401(k)'s are falling."
With the Congressional votes on an Iraq resolution now over and the lawmakers near recess, Mr. Racicot's aggressive remarks today appeared to signal a Republican effort to get out in front of Democrats as the campaign moves into what both sides say will be an increased emphasis on domestic issues in the closing three weeks. Only today, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, the House Democratic leader, offered a $200 billion package of tax cuts and spending to help the economy.
Throughout recent weeks, senior members of both parties argued that the debate on Iraq had helped the Republicans, by keeping Democrats from talking about the domestic problems that might help them win the election.
But with the Iraq issue receding from the floor of Congress, at least for now, Mr. Racicot said today that he was not concerned. He argued that Democrats had failed to make a case that they could handle the nation's economy, and said voters were more comfortable with Republicans in charge.
"As the loyal opposition, if you don't like something, you ought to advance an alternative," he said. "They do nothing. They have been impotent to move forward an agenda. And I think there is overwhelming proof of that, and that is why we feel comfortable talking about the economy."
"I've never believed it was strong Democratic ground," Mr. Racicot said of economic issues. "I think the polling shows the American people trust the Republicans more to deal with the economy than the opposition. I think that is more a perception that people have somehow subscribed to."
He also said his party had not advised its candidates to invoke Congress's Iraq votes while campaigning this fall. But he has encouraged them, he said, to attack Democrats for opposing the president's version of the legislation that would create a Department of Homeland Security.
The chairman also belittled former Vice President Al Gore for resurrecting discussion of the disputed Florida vote that cost him the 2000 presidential election. In speeches in Iowa this week, Mr. Gore recalled the problems at the Florida polls in urging Democrats to vote. 
"He's a complete mystery to me," Mr. Racicot said of the former vice president. "I don't what he's doing."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Marc Racicot, chairman of the Republican National Committee. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Shaping Strategy With Israel 

 BODY:
As a potential target of Iraq's unconventional weapons, Israel is a crucially interested party in America's looming confrontation with Baghdad. When Prime Minister Ariel Sharon meets with President Bush today in Washington, the two leaders need to discuss ways that Israel can defend its citizens without undercutting American diplomatic and military strategy.
 These are sensitive subjects. Mr. Sharon's recent loose talk about retaliation against Iraq could make things easier for Saddam Hussein. And while Israel's need to defend itself is obvious, it has been doing so in ways that are causing unnecessary suffering of innocent Palestinians, complicating America's relations with Arab and Muslim countries whose support is needed against Iraq. 
 When Baghdad launched conventionally armed Scud missiles against Israel during the 1991 Persian Gulf war, Israeli leaders wisely agreed to let Washington respond. Mr. Sharon has suggested that he might not be restrained if Iraq attacked Israeli cities again, especially if it used biological or chemical weapons. Raising the possibility of a devastating Israeli counterattack is one thing. Actually carrying one out is another. The last thing Mr. Sharon should want is to let Baghdad shift the focus off its own illegal weapons and onto the possibility of a new Arab-Israeli war.
In the battle against Palestinian violence, Israel has increased its military pressures in recent weeks, especially in the Gaza Strip, leading to a corresponding rise in the suffering of Palestinian bystanders. In a letter to Mr. Sharon last week, Mr. Bush rightly urged greater restraint. Suggestions that Israel may soon withdraw troops from Hebron are welcome. Overall conditions in the territories have grown truly desperate. 
Figures presented to Israel's cabinet earlier this week by the coordinator of government activities in the territories, Maj. Gen. Amos Gilad, show that three in five Palestinians now live below the World Bank's official poverty line, and an even higher percentage depend on international humanitarian aid for survival. 
It is not enough, as Mr. Sharon did Monday, to blame the disastrous leadership of Yasir Arafat for this suffering, although that is certainly a major factor. So long as Israel occupies the territories, it has a responsibility to ease the plight of the roughly three million Palestinians living there. It also has an interest in doing so. The democratic election of more enlightened Palestinian leadership is unlikely to emerge from such widespread misery.
It is reasonable for Mr. Bush, facing war in the Mideast, to ask his closest regional ally to contribute constructively toward the mutually desirable goal of disarming Iraq. Reducing unnecessary Palestinian suffering is one requirement.

HEADLINE: THE 2002 CAMPAIGN: A DEMOCRATIC PROPOSAL; 
Gephardt Offers Tax Cut in Economic Plan

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 15 

 BODY:
Representative Richard A. Gephardt set out a Democratic proposal today to stimulate the economy, calling for $75 billion in one-time tax cuts and $125 billion in new spending as part of a strategy to create jobs and restore growth.
 Mr. Gephardt, the House Democratic leader from Missouri, detailed his ideas in a speech just three weeks before the midterm elections. His party is making a concerted effort to turn attention away from the just-concluded Congressional debate over Iraq and back to the economy. 
 Mr. Gephardt, a possible presidential contender in 2004 who faced criticism from his party for working with President Bush to authorize the use of force in Iraq, accompanied his plan with scathing criticism of the administration's economic record as "an abdication of leadership."
"The president should not ask for bipartisanship on Iraq and then turn his back on bipartisan efforts to promote jobs and economic growth," Mr. Gephardt said in the speech sponsored by the Economic Policy Institute, a liberal policy group.
"The fact is America faces a clear and present danger to the economic life of working families," he said. "But all the president and the Republican House have offered is an extreme ideology of trickle-down economics and ineffective gimmicks."
Several senior Senate Democrats as well as an independent, Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont, took to the floor today to amplify Mr. Gephardt's criticism of the administration. 
Senator Tom Daschle, the majority leader, accused Mr. Bush of campaigning too much, saying "he needs to spend less time trying to save the jobs of Republican politicians and more time trying to save the jobs of average Americans." 
In a sign of the debate's political importance, House Republican leaders, swiftly branded Mr. Gephardt as a old-style, big government Democrat. "Dick Gephardt offers regurgitated ideas from the Democrats' outdated tax-and-spend playbook," said Representative Dick Armey of Texas, the majority leader. 
But the White House struck a different tone. Ari Fleischer, the White House press secretary, said of the proposal for $75 billion in tax cuts or rebates, "The idea of tax incentives to help stimulate growth is always an interesting idea."
The debate takes place as the economy is clearly a rising public concern. Republicans are circulating a memorandum from Matthew Dowd, Mr. Bush's pollster, warning Republican candidates that "a majority of the public thinks the economy is going in the wrong direction." 
"Thus far the public hasn't heard a single positive message from Democrats on the issue," Mr. Dowd said.
Senator Don Nickles, Republican of Oklahoma and the assistant minority leader, made the same point in the Senate today, saying Democrats "just want to throw rocks at the president."
Clearly sensitive to that accusation, Mr. Gephardt offered a five-point plan under the rubric of a "new economic agenda for a new House."
The plan's long-term measures included cuts in corporate welfare, as well as measures to make pensions more portable; to raise the minimum wage by $1.50, to $6.65, an hour by 2004; and to make the treatment of corporate executives' stock and pension plans more commensurate to that of employee plans.
He said his plan would move "beyond rigid left-right thinking to promote economic growth as soon as possible." The Republican economic strategy, by contrast, he said, "has become an amalgam of patronage for the wealthy, passivity and denial."
Mr. Gephardt is often considered liberal. But his proposals for short-term tax cuts and spending were a mixture that could appeal to Democratic centrists and liberals. The centrists could rally to the call for tax cuts for the less well off and for business. The liberals could embrace the call for spending on school construction, health care and homeland security.
Like many Democrats, Mr. Gephardt did not call for a rollback of Mr. Bush's 10-year tax cut program, though he noted he had voted against it as the right prescription for the economy.
"The one thing you don't do when you're in slow or no growth going into a recession is raise taxes," Mr. Gephardt said. "You cut taxes." 
He did not detail his proposals for $75 billion in tax reductions beyond saying they should be "rebates or credits for working families and one-time tax incentives for company investment." 
His only hint that he might one day consider slowing the fulfilling of Mr. Bush's $1.35 trillion tax cut came when he proposed using "triggers and caps" that could be applied to both spending and tax cuts to restore long-term fiscal discipline. He did not, however, specify any domestic spending programs he would trim.
Many centrists in Congress have spoken of using triggers to make tax cuts contingent on the performance of the economy.
Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, by contrast, in a speech today, did call for parts of Mr. Bush's tax cut to be reconsidered, saying it was time "to put on the table future tax cuts for the wealthiest individuals."
House Republicans are also promoting tax cuts and other economic measures in the waning days of the Congress as Election Day nears.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Representative Richard A. Gephardt unveiled an economic plan yesterday that included elements meant to appeal to centrists and liberals. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New York: Manhattan: Bill For Business Groups 

BYLINE:  By Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez) 

 BODY:
 Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed a bill yesterday authorizing 19 business improvement districts to increase the amount that they can request of their members for annual expenses. 
The districts' budgets would range from from $85,000 to $11 million. The bill, brought to the City Council at the mayor's request, was needed, Mr. Bloomberg said, because operating costs for districts have increased and the organizations have plans for enhanced services and programs. The bill applies to 19 of the 44 BID's. Most of the affected BID's have not increased their budgets for at least four years, and this is the first increase for six of them. Jennifer Steinhauer (NYT)
