HEADLINE: G.M. Offers Investors a Bag of Mixed Messages 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 15 

 BODY:
For a company that is selling sport utility vehicles and pickups at a blistering pace and making progress in cutting costs that were out of control a few years ago, General Motors offered investors an oddly mixed outlook today.
 First, the good news. Despite reporting a much wider third-quarter net loss, the profit of the company's North American operations grew 15 percent. And its operating earnings, excluding a huge write-down related to its investment in the Italian conglomerate Fiat's auto business, handily beat analysts' expectations. 
 The market, in a bullish mood over all today, rewarded the company with a big rally, driving G.M. shares up 10.3 percent, or $3.44, to $36.70.
Now, the bad news. What happens next year and beyond? Of foremost concern are G.M.'s enormous health care and pension obligations, which some analysts fear could outstrip its cash flow for the next couple years. The stock market's recent decline is not helping. G.M. said today that its pension assets had fallen 10 percent through September and that the decline would cost the company $1 billion, or $1.80 a share, in earnings next year. The company will probably not be able to offset the new requirements with more cutbacks, G.M. officials said today. 
Further, G.M.'s reliance on ever-accelerating incentive deals, like interest-free financing, is not improving its profitability and is seen as a sign of underlying sickness. Despite strong auto sales, the company's profits, while more robust than its weaker crosstown rival, Ford Motor, have been relatively slight. And what happens if, as many analysts believe, sales fall next year?
Such fears, along with the market's overall weakness, pushed G.M.'s stock to 10-year lows last week from a high of $68.02 in May. While most analysts agree G.M. is in much better shape than Ford, a variety of factors could send its foray into the sunlight back into eclipse.
At Fidelity Investments, the nation's largest mutual fund manager, G.M. was replaced by Toyota among the top five holdings of the Fidelity Select Automotive fund during the third quarter. The fund's manager, Kelly Cardwell, is looking beyond manufacturers for many of his top investment ideas. 
"If you had to pick, you'd go with the suppliers first," said Mr. Cardwell, who also serves as an auto analyst for Fidelity's fund family. "Their pension issues are less onerous and they tend to have better cash flow." Incentive costs, he added, are "coming out of the Big Three's income statements and the retailers are getting the free ride."
Ronald Tadross, an analyst at Bank of America, said G.M. was "walking this tightrope between how much cash flow they're generating and their pension needs."
"We're at a peak environment in terms of sales and they should be making more money," he added.
For the third quarter, G.M. posted a net loss of $804 million, or $1.42 a share, compared with a loss of $368 million, or 41 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenue increased 2.6 percent, to $43.6 billion.
G.M.'s third-quarter profits were wiped out by a write-down in its investment in 20 percent of Fiat's auto business, to just $220 million from $2.4 billion. Excluding the Fiat write-down and other one-time items, earnings grew to $615 million, or $1.20 a share, compared with $385 million, or 85 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. On that basis, analysts had expected G.M. to earn 99 cents a share in the latest quarter, according to Thomson First Call.
But Wall Street is still concerned with the rest of the Fiat deal. Fiat has an option to sell the remaining 80 percent of its car business to G.M. between 2004 and 2009, holding out the prospect of combining Fiat's struggling auto operations with G.M.'s struggling European arm. Some analysts say G.M.'s motivation for such a steep write-downs was to establish a low value in case the purchase is forced on it, though G.M. denied that was a factor.
"I think if you combine the pension and health care issues and Fiat, you have some issues they have to work through," said Stephen J. Girsky, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, adding that the company would have difficulty reaching its earnings goal of $10 a share annually by mid-decade. 
"They need some things to break their way for $10 to happen," Mr. Girsky said. "North America has to continue to show improvement and Europe needs to get out of the red."
The company's share of the North American passenger car market continues to show weakness, falling from 26.6 percent a year ago to 25.1 percent. Its share of the light truck market -- including sport utility vehicles and pickups -- rose to 30.6 percent from 28.6 percent.
For much of the 1990's, G.M. was the dowdy company that couldn't. It built Buicks and Oldsmobiles and Pontiacs that all looked alike and inspired little love. Last year, the company's resurgence was led by flashy sport utility vehicles and by surprising strides in the improvement of manufacturing operations.
But there has been some speculation that the company's momentum may be stalling.
"The concern has been twofold, the combination of the economy -- is the consumer going to go away? -- and the balance-sheet issues, in particular pensions," said John Devine, G.M.'s chief financial officer. "We're not ducking them, we're trying to lay them out as transparently as we can.
"In this market it pays to have a negative view, and you're seeing that," he added. "On the other hand, if you look at what we've done, and the progress we've made, I think G.M. stock is a pretty good deal."

HEADLINE: Shedding Egos, Joining Forces; 
Museums Team Up to Foot the Bill and Find the Space for Art

BYLINE:  By CAROL VOGEL 

 BODY:
When the pioneering video artist Bill Viola's biggest and most important work was up for sale at the Anthony d'Offay Gallery in London last year, several major museums coveted it. But the work, "Five Angels for the Millennium," a 13-minute video depicting figures sequentially ascending and descending into pools of water, did not come cheap.
 Any one of the museums could have dipped into its acquisitions budget or asked a donor for $700,000 to buy the room-size work, which requires an arsenal of equipment, including five ceiling-mounted projectors, each accompanied by its own DVD player and speakers. 
 Owning the video surely would have been a feather in any museum's cap, but after the initial viewing, then what? Most museums, even those with newly enlarged galleries, would be able to show it for no more than a few months at a time. Between showings, the video would languish in storage along with thousands of other rare works of art that museums simply have no room to exhibit. 
So the Whitney Museum of American Art, the Tate Modern in London and the Georges Pompidou Center in Paris made an unprecedented decision. They joined forces to buy "Five Angels for the Millennium" with the help of several donors: Leonard A. Lauder, the Whitney's chairman, put in the Whitney's share; Lynn Forester de Rothschild, a collector and friend of the Tate, donated the Tate's portion; and the Pompidou Center is looking for someone to step in and contribute the remaining third. 
A decade ago the museums would have competed for the purchase. Now, as joint owners of the video, the only question is who will show it first? Museums that were keen competitors are bonding in ways they never have before, driven by the rising cost of acquisitions, escalating operating expenses and a kind of bottom-line common sense vital in today's rocky economy. 
Museum directors, like shopaholics, find it hard to resist a purchase, even when there's little room to show it off. Much of the art produced today requires more space than a traditional-size gallery can accommodate. Collections have to grow and change with the times and to give audiences something new to see. And while contemporary art may start out being affordable, as artists like Mr. Viola gain in stature, their prices rise to levels that give even the richest donors pause. 
"We all acknowledge that the 21st century is a century of networks," said Kathy Halbreich, director of the Walker Art Center in Minneapolis. "These days none of us can afford to go it alone." 
Last spring, before Neal Benezra started his job as director of the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, he heard the museum was looking for a partner to buy the Cuban-born artist Felix Gonzalez-Torres's first self-portrait. He turned to the Chicago Art Institute, where he had been deputy director and curator of modern and contemporary art. Well aware that the Chicago Art Institute was trying to beef up its contemporary art holdings, Mr. Benezra suggested that the two museums pool their resources to buy the work, valued at $500,000. 
Joint ownership seemed natural since the Gonzalez-Torres is a text-based work in which the artist's image is conveyed through words painted on a wall. It exists only according to the instructions prescribed by the artist, who died in 1996. (The buyer, in this case the two museums, gets a set of instructions along with a certificate of authenticity and ownership. And unlike creators of some conceptual work, who do not allow it to be shown more than one place at a time, Gonzalez-Torres made no such stipulations.)
Aside from economic considerations that lead museums to collaborate, the kind of art being produced today lends itself more readily to group ownership. Video works require space for display and rely on sophisticated technology that gets quickly out of date. Pieces like the Gonzalez-Torres or wall drawings by masters like Sol LeWitt rely on specific artist's instructions but do not actually require the hand of the creator. And partnerships are at the heart of the process of Internet art. 
"While possessions have been the basis for how museums operate, artists today are testing something more elastic," said Maxwell L. Anderson, director of the Whitney and president of the Association of Art Museum Directors. "The Internet is an especially interdependent world, and younger artists are especially more open to collaborations."
Museums are pooling their resources in other ways, too. Carol Mancusi-Ungaro, a star restorer and conservator who specializes in modern and contemporary paintings, has such an unusual skill that she is on the staff of both the Whitney and the Harvard University Art Museums. Others, like the Museum of Modern Art in New York and the Tate Gallery in London are promoting exchange programs between curators. The Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum is in talks with the Massachusetts Museum of Contemporary Art to lend it a large chunk of the Guggenheim's permanent collection, including large-scale works that will fit in the giant MassMOCA galleries for extended periods.
"I can't see a downside," said Ms. Halbreich of the Walker, who helped arrange with the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art the joint purchase of Matthew Barney's "Cremaster 2: The Drones' Exposition." The fourth video installation of his five-part saga, the work includes sculptures as well as film and takes up about 2,500 square feet. "We just have to park our egos outside the door," she said.
Still, "that doesn't mean we will no longer be competitive," warned Alfred Pacquement, director of the Pompidou Center. "I hope we all don't show the same artists and do the same projects. We each have to have our own personalities." 
Because each institution is so different, negotiating a joint acquisition like the Viola video was not easy. Talks went on for nearly a year before the purchase was complete. Lawyers for the three museums had to hammer out a formula for how to share the work including presentation dates and maintenance costs. The contract, one lawyer said, had to be simple and comprehensive enough to hold up for decades.
"Joint ownership is much more feasible in new media than other areas," said Sir Nicholas Serota, director of the Tate, about the Viola work. "Fortunately we're not talking about a work of art that's going to be damaged or deteriorate by travel. This is a response to the high market prices for works of art. Why shouldn't museums fight back and share?"
Thomas Krens, director of the Guggenheim, said he saw the benefits of partnerships years ago, although most museum directors shun the comparison, saying that the alliances he has formed on behalf of the Guggenheim are born more out of desire for empire building than a love for art.
His first project, completed in 1997, involved getting the government of the Basque region in Spain to agree to pay for the cost of building a $100 million museum in the economically depressed city of Bilbao. Besides the building itself (which the Spanish government pays to operate) the arrangement includes a $50 million acquisitions budget. Since then, the Guggenheim has opened a branch in Berlin and formed partnerships with the Hermitage in St. Petersburg, Russia, and the Kunsthistorisches Museum in Vienna. 
Often these arrangements involve joint acquisitions. Even counting all its branches and partnerships, the Guggenheim has more art in its permanent collection than it can show. The arrangement under discussion with MassMOCA would be beneficial to both museums. The Guggenheim would get a chunk of its vast permanent collection out of storage, itself a cost-cutting measure, and spread its name to Massachusetts. The fledgling Massachusetts museum would get a body of important work that, like a permanent collection, is likely to be a constant visitor attraction. 
"It will strengthen the museum to have core works," said Joseph C. Thompson, director of MassMOCA.
"It's unlikely many of these works will make their way out of storage once every 10 years," Mr. Krens said. He does not pretend that collaboration is a new idea. Few people today remember that in 1947, a time when Americans were predicting the country could suffer from another depression, a far more radical idea was being hatched than any of the alliances being created today.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Museum of Modern Art and the Whitney had plans to become inextricably linked. For a brief moment that year they formally agreed that the Whitney would merge with the Met, its collection joining an expanded American wing there. Meanwhile the Met and the Modern would play distinct roles. Officials at both museums were eager to pool their collections, with the Met devoted primarily to the "visual arts of the past," as the agreement read, and the Modern to the "encouragement and study of the visual arts of the present and recent past." Some people thought it was a sensible move, but the deal fell through.
While nothing so drastic is under way today, museums in the United States and abroad are coming up with new ways of doing business together. The Modern has collaborated with the Tate and the Pompidou Center on a traveling Matisse-Picasso exhibition now on view at the Pompidou Center. (It arrives at the Modern in February.) For the first time the three museums set up a joint Web site devoted to the show (www.matissepicasso.com), giving visitors a single source of information with links to the three museums' own Web sites. 
Two years ago the Modern and the Tate tried collaborating on an Internet project, but when the dot-com business began to go sour, so did the project. Now the two institutions have staff exchanges. 
Mr. Lowry said he believed working with like-minded institutions was crucial these days. "Competition is good, rivalry is not," he said. "In an increasingly competitive environment museums are trying to capture everyone's leisure time, so we need to find a way to work together, or we'll get subsumed by the entertainment industry."

HEADLINE: New Moves for Nervous Merchants 

BYLINE:  By MARIANNE ROHRLICH 

 BODY:
EVERY year Jonah Zuckerman, a furniture maker in the Dumbo section of Brooklyn, participates in the Art Under the Bridge festival, a weekend when artists and craftspeople open their studios to the public. His goal in the past was to spur interest in future commissions. But when the festival kicks off tomorrow, he will have a different agenda: to sell all the showroom samples at his company, City Joinery. "I'm anticipating being slow for a while," he said of his first-time effort to sweep out everything. He said he hopes to generate cash so that he can "make a lot of new things" while he waits for business to pick up again.
 An uncertain economy, coupled with fears it may get worse, is driving store owners in New York to think creatively. Some are participating in group events. Others are offering preseason sales. 
 One of the hardest-hit neighborhoods is SoHo, according to Faith Hope Consolo, vice chairwoman of Garrick-Aug Worldwide Realty, which specializes in retail rentals. "The rents had become absurd," she said. "At $400 or $500 a square foot, retailers are trying to pull out.
"Not only do you see vacancies," she added, "but you see availability signs on stores whose owners are even willing to subsidize a new tenant just to get out."
Based on recent retail lease signings, Ms. Consolo said, shoppers, whether city dwellers or tourists, are staying uptown.
In SoHo, some store owners say their sales are down to frightening lows. "The last two weekends were terrible," said P. J. Casey, the owner of C.I.T.E, a store on Wooster Street that carries vintage midcentury furnishings as well as new items.
After Sept. 11, 2001, sales at her store through the end of that year dropped 43 percent below those for the same period in 2000. This year, sales are down another 20 percent, Ms. Casey said. 
The manager of a neighboring shop, who did not want to be named because she was not authorized to speak for the owner, said sales last month were 25 percent below the same period last year. 
Store owners on Wooster Street have scheduled a block party on Oct. 26 and 27, to take place between Houston and Spring Streets. The event was designed to entice people to shop, and will include come-ons like pottery demonstrations and sidewalk sales. Drinks will be given away, and special prices will be offered on high-end furniture.
Ms. Casey said other attempts this year by civic groups and large-scale businesses in SoHo had failed to lure crowds. This summer, sales were dismal: an apparel and travel gear store she manages for a large European company had projected 2002 sales at $4.7 million, but now thinks it unlikely that they will climb above $1.8 million.
At C.I.T.E., Ms. Casey plans to offer customers 50 percent off on some floor samples and a sidewalk sale. She has hired children's face painters and a tarot card reader.
Cappellini Modern Age will knock 20 percent off the price of furniture ordered that weekend. At Simon Pearce, another store on the block, there will be pottery demonstrations and reduced prices on selected merchandise. The prices on expensive wool rugs at Entree Libre will be lowered 20 percent or more, and Ligne Roset will raffle a chair.
In the meatpacking district, efforts to stimulate foot traffic date to June, when Renata Bokalo, an owner of a home-accessories and fashion boutique called Auto, organized neighborhood-wide late-night shopping events on the first Thursday of every month. Her name for the evenings was Shop Lift -- "literally to lift sales," she said. She added, "People are out now, but sales are not where they were a year ago. It's pretty dead." She hopes not to have to lower prices during the holidays.
The efforts are not restricted to small stores. Bloomingdale's, for one, has stepped up the number of fall promotional events by 20 percent over last year, including cooking demonstrations, book signings and appearances by celebrities like Pierce Brosnan. "We're trying to have as much going on in the store as possible," said Anne Keating, a vice president for public relations. 
In Brooklyn this weekend, on a 10-block stretch of Atlantic Avenue from Hicks Street to Fourth Avenue, an event called Walk the Windows will offer shoppers a smorgasbord: a sample sale of modern home textiles at Bark, free interior design consultations at Foundation, free appraisals at the Antique Room, a Tibetan rug-weaving demonstration at Kea Carpets, and at Town & Country Antiques, discounts on selected items. The windows of many shops will be dressed by artists who are also hoping to drum up business. 
Organized by a nonprofit group, the Atlantic Avenue Local Development Corporation, Walk the Windows will begin with a cocktail party at Axelle Fine Arts tomorrow night to raise money for the creation of a master plan for Atlantic Avenue (tickets from $75; 718-875-8993). The event will continue Saturday and Sunday from noon to 7 p.m. 
The festival in Dumbo runs tomorrow through Sunday. The opening night party, $10, is tomorrow from 10 p.m. to 4 a.m. at 56 Adams Street (eighth floor). Among the participating stores and studios are 20th Century Modern and Industrial Furniture, RR Frames, ABC Carpet & Home, Cronverk Furniture Land and Excalibur Bronze Sculpture Foundry. More information is available on the Web at www.dumboartscenter.org or by calling (718) 694-0831.

HEADLINE: Candidates Disagree Sharply On Gloomy Ledger in Albany 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 16 

 BODY:
Spending by New York State is up sharply this year, receipts are down just as steeply, and the state's balance sheet looks even worse over all than the gloomy predictions made earlier this year.
 While no one disputed the numbers, in the overheated air of a campaign for governor, there was sharp disagreement over whether it came as a surprise. 
 H. Carl McCall and Tom Golisano, the candidates running against Gov. George E. Pataki, have said for months that the budget was out of balance and poised to fall apart after the November election. They have cited predictions of a state deficit of $5 billion to $10 billion next year, which the Pataki camp insists are too high. 
Excluding federal grants for programs like Medicaid and welfare, state income in the first six months of the fiscal year, a period ended Sept. 30, fell 8.2 percent, a drop of $2.4 billion, from the same period a year earlier. At the same time, state spending outside federal grants rose 8.8 percent. The figures were included in an annual report by Mr. McCall, the state comptroller.
In a statement, Mr. McCall, a Democrat, said the governor, a Republican, built the budget "on a foundation of shaky revenues and backdoor deals," and he questioned whether the state had enough money to finish the fiscal year.
The governor's office projected earlier this year that general fund revenue would drop 5 percent this fiscal year. In the first six months, the actual decline was 16 percent. Personal income tax collections, the state's biggest source of income, were predicted to decline 10 percent; so far, they are down 23 percent, almost $4 billion.
But the administration insisted that things were going about as expected to this point. "While we face serious challenges as a result of 9/11 and the national economic downturn, we're confident we can manage them," said Carole E. Stone, the governor's budget director.
Administration officials also argue that the timing of tax payments can skew the numbers, and that first-half figures mean less than those from later in the year, when a disproportionate share of taxes is paid.
Mr. McCall's report predicted that the state and local governments would have to pay an added $847 million into the pension fund next year because of stock market losses in the fund, which he manages. During the market boom, governments did not have to pay into the fund at all. This fiscal year, they are paying $138 million. Next year, the comptroller estimated, they will have to pay $985 million.
A spokesman for the governor blamed the change on mismanagement by Mr. McCall. Independent monitors say the state's pension fund is among the best managed in the country.

HEADLINE: STATE OF THE ART; 
For a Two-Digit Price, A Two-Button Palm

BYLINE:  By David Pogue; E-mail: Pogue@nytimes.com

 BODY:
AT this point in the information age, it has become clear that the high-tech industry operates according to certain unwritten laws. For example, there is Sony's Law: Smaller always costs more. There is Symantec's Law: Good tech support is hard to find. And above all, there's Microsoft's Law: Each version of a product must offer a longer feature list than its predecessor, even if the overall result isn't an improvement. 
 This month Palm broke that last law with the release of its latest palmtop, bizarrely called the Zire (pronounced "like the second part of desire," a canny public relations person points out). This device embodies a notion that dare not speak its name in Silicon Valley -- that maybe, just maybe, more features every year is not what people want. Perhaps a certain percentage of the populace, even a big percentage, is overwhelmed by the featuritis that makes their electronics purchases ever more complex and ever more susceptible to failure. 
 Put simply, the Zire is a pocket organizer that does less -- a lot less. It's the most stripped-down palmtop you can buy, unencumbered by a color screen, a synchronization cradle, a voice recorder, expansion slots, jog dial, MP3 music player and so on. Its screen doesn't even offer a backlight, a standard feature on every Palm model except the original 1996 Pilot. In dim or dark lighting, the Zire is about as useful as a windshield scraper.
 Palm claims that it eliminated so many standard features of the modern palmtop in the name of simplification, as a gift to technophobes who still haul around a paper Filofax. But surely it's no coincidence that in addition to being the simplest organizer in years, the Zire makes its debut with the lowest price in Palm history: $99. 
 That, according to Palm's research, is a magic number. It puts the Zire into a category no name-brand organizer has ever occupied: the impulse buy, no longer a check-with-your-spouse-first purchase. (Furthermore, Palm prices traditionally drop by about 50 percent over their two-year life spans.) Fittingly, the Zire is packaged in blister pack wrapping, like D batteries or squirt guns, to be hung from rods at Kmart, Target and other fine purveyors of inexpensive stuff. 
 Palm's research also indicates that what most people do with their Palms, most of the time, is check their calendars and phone books. So the Zire has only two push buttons on the front, corresponding to the Date Book and Address Book programs, rather than the usual four. (The To Do List and Note Pad programs are still on board, along with Expense, Calculator, games and the other usual Palm programs. But it takes a few taps on the grayscale touch screen to get to them.)
 The Zire doesn't even have the bottom-edge jack (the Universal Connector) that a few years ago Palm promised to install on every new Palm model. The idea was to ensure consistent compatibility with snap-on modems, portable keyboards, G.P.S. trackers and other add-ons, which previously had to be reworked each time Palm changed the design of that connector. No Zire owner will ever open up the folding Palm Portable Keyboard, to the amazement of onlookers, with a rakish James Bond smile.
 Palm argues that the kind of person who would buy a $99 palmtop would not be likely to spend another $80 on a folding keyboard for it, but that doesn't necessarily follow. Plenty of people buy $4,000 color laser printers to go with their $1,500 PC's, or $10,000 speaker systems for their $5,000 stereos. In any case, Palm probably wishes it had chosen a name other than Universal Connector for this no-longer-universal connector.
 The Zire still keeps itself up to date with your agenda and social circle by synching itself with a Macintosh or Windows computer; that, after all, is the very heart of the Palm concept. But instead of the cradle that usually holds the Palm and recharges its built-in batteries, the Zire comes with a simple U.S.B. cable. The good news: a cable is much simpler to pack and carry than a cradle. The bad news: the Zire comes with a separate power adapter for recharging, which makes for a messy three-piece suite to carry around. The good news: you might not need that power adapter. The U.S.B. cable can also recharge the Zire, albeit slowly, by drawing a "trickle charge" of power from a laptop or other computer. 
 Now, a true child of the information age might well object to all this: "Stripped-down and cheap? If I really wanted a cheap Palm with only two megabytes of memory, a 16-megahertz processor and no expansion capability, I'd pop on over to eBay and buy an old Palm III for $45." 
 The truth is, though, that the Zire isn't quite as bad as all that. For starters, it doesn't look cheap at all. In fact, its smooth, shiny, snow-white face connotes the same elegance as the shiny white Apple iPod. ("White is the new black," a Palm representative says.)
 Its software is modern, too. It runs Palm OS 4.1, which has come a long way since the Palm III days. For example, you can designate certain addresses, memos and other information morsels as "protected." They appear masked by a gray bar until you enter the password, which is good to know if you're the kind of person who occasionally leaves doodads unattended on the desk.
 Remember, too, that the Zire offers such modern luxuries as a U.S.B. connection to your computer -- far faster than the serial connectors of the Palm III days -- and built-in rechargeable batteries, saving you the monthly expense of new AA batteries. 
 Yes, you read that correctly: monthly. With only a grayscale screen and very few bells and whistles to operate, the Zire cruises for three or four weeks between charges. It's enough to send cellphones and color-screen palmtops into therapy.
 Finally, the Zire is much smaller and lighter than the gray, boxy models of old. In fact, at 3.8 ounces, it's the lightest Palm-based organizer ever made -- even lighter, if you think of it, than a McDonald's Quarter Pounder before cooking. At 4.4 by 2.9 by 0.6 inches, it's about the same size as the Palm V or Palm m515, which is to say, svelte indeed. 
 It's probably in my contract somewhere that as a professional gadget freak, it's my duty to sniff at this exercise in minimalism. Of course the Zire is small and light -- there's practically nothing inside it. It doesn't take a rocket scientist to see that from a pure price perspective, Palm's own m105 model, now in its final days of availability, is a better deal: For the same $99, it offers four times the memory and a backlight. And how dare a product in 2002, or its owner, show up in polite company these days without a color screen?
 But as a human being who thinks that life's too short for pointless complexity, I'm not sure Palm isn't on to something here. I know a lot of people with Palms, and most never do much besides check calendars and phone numbers, play games and beam favorite programs to fellow Palm owners by infrared. 
 The small, light, power-stingy, good-looking Zire is excellent for those tasks and those people, at less than a third of the price of a Palm m515 or color Sony Clie. If this approach catches on -- and in this economy, it just might -- Palm may well turn out to have written a new high-tech law of its own.

The State of the Art column in Circuits yesterday, about the Palm Zire hand-held computer, described the screen display incorrectly. It is monochrome; some other Palm models have gray scale screens, providing multiple shades of gray.

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: THE MONEY TRAIL; 
Report Says Saudis Fail to Crack Down on Charities That Finance Terrorists

BYLINE:  By JEFF GERTH and JUDITH MILLER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 

 BODY:
Al Qaeda's terror network derives most of its financing from charities and individuals in Saudi Arabia, but the kingdom has "turned a blind eye to this problem," according to a new report by experts on terrorist finances.
 The report faults the United States for failing to confront the Saudis, saying American government officials have asserted that Saudi Arabia is cooperating on stopping terrorist financing "when they know very well all the ways in which it is not." 
 The report released today was prepared by a committee sponsored by the Council on Foreign Relations in New York. Although examples of the misuse of Saudi donations by terrorists have been previously reported, the council's study goes further by concluding for the first time that Saudi Arabia is the single largest source of terrorist financing. 
Moreover, the study's authors warn that the relationship between the United States and Saudi Arabia needs to be changed after the attacks of Sept. 11 last year. Previous criticism of Saudi ties to Al Qaeda stemmed largely from the fact that 15 of the 19 hijackers came from the kingdom.
"There's always been a tendency to treat the kingdom with kid gloves because of its economic and strategic importance," said one member of the panel, Stuart E. Eizenstat, a former deputy treasury secretary. 
But he said the report aimed to emphasize that "you have to make a fundamental judgment that dealing with terrorist financing is important enough to break with the mold in our relationship."
In one of its starkest conclusions, the report said, "It is worth stating clearly and unambiguously, if only because official U.S. government spokespersons have not: for years, individuals and charities based in Saudi Arabia have been the most important source of funds for Al Qaeda, and for years Saudi officials have turned a blind eye to this problem."
Rob Nichols, a spokesman for the Treasury Department, said the report was helpful but flawed because it focused too much on the Clinton administration's efforts and did not reflect the "exponential increase in people, agencies and money dedicated to terrorist financing" by the Bush administration.
Mr. Nichols said the administration was "pleased with the cooperation with the Saudis," including their efforts to regulate charities and the designation of two Saudis as supporters of terrorists.
Saudi officials declined to comment on the report's findings. Last month, Saudi Arabia released a list of actions they said had been taken to combat misuse by terrorists of charitable donations and legitimate transactions. 
Those included establishing financial control mechanisms meant to "ensure that terrorist organizations cannot take advantage of these charitable groups in the future."
While praising the Bush administration for blocking assets of some charitable organizations since the Sept. 11 attacks, the report from the Council on Foreign Relations concluded that there was much work to be done in shutting down the financing of terror groups.
The report contains dozens of organizational and policy recommendations for the United States and other countries. 
The first strategic recommendation calls on the United States to "speak out bluntly, forcefully and openly" about failures by foreign countries to combat terrorism. Past lack of candor, the report said, is a crucial part of the problem.
The chairman of the nonpartisan committee is Maurice R. Greenberg, chairman and chief executive of the American International Group, a leading financial conglomerate. 
Other members include former and current government officials like William H. Webster, former director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Central Intelligence Agency; David Cohen, deputy commissioner for intelligence of the New York City Police Department; and William F. Wechsler, former director for transnational threats at the National Security Council.
The report said tracing terrorist financing was complicated by a basic tenet of Islam known as zakat, which requires every Muslim to give a small percentage of his wealth each year to charitable causes like hospitals, mosques and schools. Because it is the world's richest Muslim nation, Saudi Arabia is the largest backer of Islamic charities.
But the report maintains that the "widely unregulated, seldom audited and generally undocumented practices have allowed unscrupulous actors such as Al Qaeda to access huge sums of money over the years."
In 1999 and 2000, officials of the Clinton administration, including some who worked on the council's report, went to Saudi Arabia to raise the subject of charitable donations. But the issue never became a priority at the top levels of government, according to Mr. Eizenstat and other former officials.
In 1999, Saudi Arabia tightened its money laundering laws to bring it into compliance with international standards, but according to the report, the changes "have not been implemented."

HEADLINE: Relying on Business Clients, AMR Posts a Loss 

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG 

 BODY:
The AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, reported a third-quarter loss yesterday that was more than double its loss in the period a year ago. The company's dire financial numbers are expected to be among the worst for the airline industry this week, as the biggest carriers report earnings.
 AMR said it would defer deliveries of aircraft from Boeing, temporarily park some planes and continue working to cut costs in an effort to compete with low-cost carriers -- efforts that appeared naive to some analysts yesterday. 
 The company reported a net loss of $924 million, or $5.93 a share, significantly more than the $414 million loss, or $2.68 a share, in the third quarter last year. Excluding special gains and losses, which included downgrading the value of aircraft, AMR had a loss of $475 million, or $3.05 a share. The amount was virtually the same as analysts' consensus estimate of a $3.06 a share, as reported by Thomson First Call.
AMR had revenue of $4.49 billion in the quarter, down almost 7 percent from the same time a year ago.
Shares of AMR fell 59 cents, to $3.89.
"Despite our progress so far, we need to do more to reach an operating cost structure that will allow us to survive in this very challenging environment," Jeffrey C. Campbell, the chief financial officer, said yesterday in a call with analysts.
Mr. Campbell attributed much of the revenue decrease to American's reliance on business travelers, especially ones in the high-technology and telecommunications industries. American also has many routes to Latin America, and the economic instability in those countries has lowered revenue.
"Unfortunately," he said, "we see this trend continuing and expanding beyond Argentina and Brazil."
AMR said it would defer delivery of 34 Boeing planes from 2003 through 2005. It plans to park 42 aircraft, which it said could save $100 million in maintenance costs over two years.
Mr. Campbell stressed that American is working hard to find ways to cut costs, ranging from tinkering with its hub schedules to more efficiently using voice recognition software for customer service. He estimated that AMR could save $1.4 billion in 2003 and $1.7 billion in 2004 with these cost cuts.
But some analysts sounded skeptical.
"We haven't seen a high-cost carrier move yet to lower costs substantially without revenues also moving in that direction," said Brian D. Harris, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney.
Jamie N. Baker, an analyst at J. P. Morgan, asked Mr. Campbell: "What you're doing right now just doesn't seem to be working. When does AMR try something truly radical, something other than layoffs and aircraft deferrals?"
Mr. Campbell responded that some of AMR's cost-cutting efforts were innovative.
AMR announced in mid-August that it would layoff 7,000 workers this fall and reduce the number of planes flying. The capacity in the fourth quarter will be 6 percent greater than in the period last year, when American and its rivals cut flights after the Sept. 11 attacks, but will be 13 percent below the period in 2000.
"I expect we will report another significant loss for the seasonally weak fourth quarter, one which will exceed our loss in the third quarter," Mr. Campbell said.
He also said AMR was examining its "noncore assets" -- including American Eagle, its regional operation -- to see whether they should be sold. "I don't want to announce on this call that we're selling anything," he said, "but clearly everything is on the table."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
Interpublic Group surprises investors with yet another warning of financial setbacks.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
THE Interpublic Group of Companies in New York, which had previously warned of earnings disappointments and accounting irregularities, has surprised Wall Street again with disclosures of additional financial shortfalls and setbacks. The unexpected announcements, made yesterday after the stock market closed, threaten to unleash a firestorm of criticism that is likely to reach the highest levels of the agency company.
 The disclosures included additional charges related to a restatement of earnings for the last five years; the charges will be almost twice what was indicated to investors in an unexpected announcement two months ago. Also, Interpublic significantly reduced estimates of earnings for the third quarter and the full year. 
 "It's a disaster," a senior Interpublic executive said, speaking only on the condition of anonymity. "This thing's broken. They're going to throw people overboard."
Actually, several people have already been thrown overboard. Top managers at two divisions of the McCann-Erickson World Group and at Octagon Motor Sports, a unit of the Interpublic Sports and Entertainment Group, have been dismissed over the last two months. This time, however, lower-level dismissals like those may not be enough to satisfy blindsided shareholders.
In trading yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange before the announcement, Interpublic shares fell 75 cents, or 4.4 percent, to $16.30. After the announcement, Wall Street rendered its verdict in after-hours trading by sending the shares down another $5.30, or 32.5 percent, to $11.00, below the 52-week low of $12.75.
Interpublic is the world's second largest agency company, owning agencies like Bozell; Foote, Cone & Belding; Lowe & Partners; and McCann-Erickson. Revenue last year was $6.7 billion and the agency company suffered a net loss of $505.3 million, reflecting the advertising recession and internal difficulties. Billings for Interpublic agencies were estimated at $66.7 billion, from blue-chip marketers like Coca-Cola, General Motors and Unilever.
A leading Interpublic rival, the Omnicom Group in New York, has lately reassured Wall Street that its third-quarter earnings projections would be met.
Philippe Krakowsky, a spokesman for Interpublic, said that he could not elaborate beyond what was disclosed in a news release because of federal fair-disclosure regulations. That was also the reason, Mr. Krakowsky said, that he could not provide interviews with John J. Dooner Jr., chairman and chief executive at Interpublic, or Sean F. Orr, chief financial officer.
In a statement that was part of the news release, Mr. Dooner said: "It is regrettable that we have had to revise our earnings forecast, but this new guidance reflects the difficult economic conditions we are facing around the world. We are dealing with our short-term issues in marketing services aggressively and directly."
The release said that a recent review of expenses that had been improperly accounted for at the European operations of McCann-Erickson had found more problems. On Aug. 13, Interpublic said the restatement was to have been $68.5 million; yesterday it amended that to say the amount was "not expected to exceed $120 million."
In revising downward its earnings estimates, Interpublic lowered the forecast for the third quarter to 8 cents to 10 cents a share. By comparison, the consensus estimate of industry analysts had been 28 cents a share.
The forecast for 2002 was lowered to 85 cents to 90 cents a share from a previous corporate estimate of $1.25 to $1.35 a share.
In the third quarter, revenue declined approximately 7 percent, Interpublic said, and revenue for the full year is now expected to fall about 9 percent.
The revisions are just the most recent in a series by Interpublic that has contributed to large recent declines in its share price. The latest problems were attributed to what was called "significant deterioration" of the operations of Octagon Motor Sports, which owns car-racing tracks in Britain and Hong Kong, along with "general revenue pressure" on all of Interpublic, partly because of economic problems in Latin America and Japan.
In the news release, Mr. Orr said that previous estimates that the problems at Octagon Motor Sports would reduce earnings at Interpublic by 4 cents a share for the year had been revised to a reduction of 15 cents to 20 cents a share.
"We are currently reassessing the composition and structure of our motor sports holdings," Mr. Orr said in the release.
Additionally, Interpublic said that certain other marketing-services operations outside the realm of traditional advertising, in fields like corporate identity consulting and retail promotion, had suffered what was described as "significant deceleration" in the third quarter. There will be additional severance expenses related to cutbacks in those areas, the Interpublic statement said.
The trade publications Advertising Age and Adweek reported that those problems were centered on two divisions of the McCann-Erickson World Group: FutureBrand, the corporate identity consultant, and Momentum, a promotion and event-marketing agency. The problems at the units result in part from a shift of marketers' ad budgets to more traditional approaches like television commercials, which caused the units to miss their earnings projections. 
Among its other woes, Interpublic said, clients in Brazil, Japan and Mexico are canceling or postponing their ad campaigns in response to the souring economies in those countries.
Interpublic will announce its results for the third quarter after the stock market closes on Nov. 13.

HEADLINE: Coke's Glum Forecast Sends Stock Down 10% 

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that its third-quarter earnings increased 8 percent. But its stock fell more than 10 percent, the steepest one-day decline in four years, after Coke said it would not meet earnings projections for the year because of weakness in Latin America and difficult weather conditions in some other foreign markets.
 Analysts said that the company, in lowering its forecast yesterday, showed how closely its sales were tied to the global economy. Coke earns 76 percent of its profit from sales outside the United States. 
 "If you look through what Coke was saying, why they're taking the numbers down, I don't have a problem with it," said Marc Greenberg, a beverage analyst at Deutsche Bank. "They're taking a rational view of global economic weakness."
Earlier this year, Coca-Cola said it was comfortable with analysts' projections for full-year earnings of $1.78 a share. But yesterday, the company said earnings for 2002 might be 1 to 2 cents a share below the Wall Street estimates.
"As we went into the year, I think we very clearly stated our expectations were built off of improving macroeconomics in the second half of the year, and obviously that has not happened," Gary P. Fayard, Coke's chief financial officer, said in a conference call. "In fact, they've gotten much worse."
Mr. Fayard said the financial crises in Argentina, Venezuela and Brazil had weighed on business. He also said flooding in Europe and bad weather in Japan and South Korea had hurt sales.
"There was no summer in Europe," said Mr. Fayard, who maintained that the company would probably "come pretty close to what the full-year estimate was." But he declined to forecast earnings for the fourth quarter or for 2003.
In the third quarter, Coca-Cola's net income rose to $1.16 billion, or 47 cents a share, compared with $1.07 billion in the period a year earlier. The results, which included a deduction of a penny a share because of foreign currency adjustments, met Wall Street's expectations. Revenue increased 13 percent, to $5.32 billion, from $4.69 billion.
Investors focused on Coke's lowered forecast yesterday, and sent the stock down $5.28, to $47.20.
"This market is very funny," said Ann H. Gurkin, a beverage analyst at Davenport & Company. "Any kind of misstep, stocks are just crucified. It doesn't mean that's right. The decline in the stock is overdone in our opinion. A penny or two is not a big deal, given the weak economies around the world." 
Despite investors' severe reaction to Coke's announcement, there were several bright spots in its report. The company reported a 9 percent increase in volume growth in North America. The volume gains were linked to strong sales in soft rinks, buoyed by the introduction of vanilla Coke and diet Coke with lemon, and by sales of bottled water.
Sales were also robust in Asia, where, despite typhoons in Japan, volume increased 9 percent. But in some other international markets, the results were disappointing. In Latin America, volume increased only 1 percent in the quarter as vigorous sales in several smaller countries were offset by the weak economies in Argentina, Brazil and Venezuela. Volume growth was also weak in much of Europe as cool, rainy weather held down summer sales in Germany, Austria and the Czech Republic, the company said. Case volume sales rose 3 percent in Africa despite boycotts of American products by small groups and some individual buyers in Morocco and Egypt.
While analysts said Coke's forecast for the year was disappointing, they did not fault the company's business strategy. The projected earnings misstep was a result of uncontrollable global economic forces, some of the analysts said. 
"It's kind of a pity for them that in a year where their new product innovations have been the best in probably a decade that they're not being able to crow about it because the economies are depressing growth," said Caroline S. Levy of UBS Warburg. "When the backdrop improves, I think this is going to be a formidable company; it's just hard to say when that is."
Coca-Cola Enterprises, Coke's primary bottler, also reported its third-quarter earnings yesterday. The company said its net income rose to $190 million, or 42 cents a share, from $10 million, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter a year earlier.

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES; 
In Iraqi's Words: White House Seems to Be Caught in 'Hysteria of War'

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from the speech yesterday by Iraq's ambassador, Mohammed Aldouri, to the United Nations Security Council, as recorded by The New York Times:
 The sanctions imposed on Iraq have caused a humanitarian catastrophe which is no less than any that have befallen the world in history. They have claimed thousands of children, of women and elderly people. It has been a crime which can be considered a genocide by all standards, and the number of victims goes far beyond the number of victims of the use of weapons of mass destruction in history. 
 Parallel to the imposition of the embargo, Mr. President, since April 1991, the United States of America and Britain have declared two no-fly zones in the south and north of Iraq, in blatant violation of the U.N. Charter and the established rules of international law, in violation also of the relevant resolutions of the Security Council, which have all underlined the importance of respecting the sovereignty of Iraq, its territorial integrity and its political independence. . . . 
The Iraqi side has held four meetings with the secretary general, which led to some progress but did not achieve the objective because of the pressures brought to bear by the United States of America, who prevented the Security Council from participating in the efforts to seek a comprehensive solution which would deal with all aspects of the relations between Iraq and the Security Council, while guaranteeing the implementation of all the requirements of the Council(TM)s resolutions. . . . 
The Iraqi government, on Sept. 16, 2002, agreed to the unconditional return of the inspectors on armaments of the United Nations -- unconditionally -- in order to dissipate any doubts concerning Iraq's continued ownership of weapons of mass destruction, and as a first step toward reaching a solution which would include lifting the overall embargo imposed on Iraq and implementing the other provisions of relevant Security Council resolutions. . . . 
Yet the United States of America tried to hamper such agreements, increasing their threats against Iraq, and came to the Security Council in order to impose and obtain the blank check to carry out their aggression, calling for the imposition of unfair and impossible conditions -- arbitrary conditions -- on Iraq. The least we can say about the conditions they are asking for is that they are an insult to the international community and the United Nations, as well as to international law, and bring us back to the law of the jungle rather than international relations. 
The hysteria of war that seems to have hit the American administration at present is fed by hatred and the attempt to settle old accounts, and to impose their hegemony on the world, politically, militarily and economically. They have nothing to do with implementation of Security Council resolutions. 
The United States of America is the main ally of Israel, which has refused to implement 28 resolutions of the Security Council, and scores of General Assembly resolutions calling for Israel to withdraw from the occupied Arab territories to allow the Palestinian refugees to return to their homes. They have been providing the entity with the state-of-the-art weapons to kill the heroic Palestinian people and to destroy their property. 
This American aggressive hysteria has nothing to do with putting an end to the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction in the world, for the United States of America is the state which owns the largest arsenal of weapons of mass destruction, and they have a long history which shows they have used these weapons against the people, starting with Hiroshima and Nagasaki and then Vietnam and, finally, shells of depleted uranium against Iraq and against Yugoslavia. . . . 
From this rostrum, we call upon the international community to speak loudly in order to voice their objection to the aggressive purposes of the United States of America against Iraq, and to prevent the United States of America from using the Security Council as a tool to carry out their aggressive policy. 
To meet all these attempts with silence will have its repercussions on international peace and security, for it will be the beginning of the end of the collective security system pursuant to the Charter of the United Nations. . . . 
There will be many victims of this hegemonistic tendency if we do not put an end to it. The urgent task today is that of refusing Washington's attempts to hamper the return of the inspectors after Iraq has indeed adopted all the practical measures and arrangements and paved the way for the return of the inspectors to carry out their work easily. 
Iraq has pledged to cooperate with them in every possible way so as to facilitate their task in ascertaining the fact that there are no weapons of mass destruction in Iraq. So in fact there is absolutely no need for a new resolution to be adopted at the Security Council. 
The attempts of the United States of America to hamper and delay the return of the inspectors, and their attempt to make the Security Council adopt a new resolution establishing conditions which are impossible to respect and establishing a pretext to cover aggression against Iraq, with the purpose of colonizing our country and imposing American domination on our oil as a first step in imposing American colonialism in the region as a whole, controlling its oil and allowing Israel to continue its genocidal war and aggression against the Arab countries. 
Mr. President, The United States of America does not want the inspectors to come back. Because if the inspectors do come back, they will prove the Americans to have been repeating one lie after another, and one allegation after the other, at which point the Security Council will be faced with the necessity of lifting the embargo against Iraq, and respecting national security in Iraq and regional security, and implementing all the other requirements of the Security Council resolutions -- and that is what the United States of America does not want.

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN; 
A Counterattack, Maybe

BYLINE:  By SHAILA K. DEWAN 

 BODY:
 This is a new 30-second commercial that H. Carl McCall, the Democratic candidate for governor, began broadcasting yesterday in upstate New York.

PRODUCER -- GMMB

ON THE SCREEN -- For the first half of the commercial, a photo of Gov. George E. Pataki -- the first to appear in a McCall spot -- is displayed with newspaper headlines like "Pataki Ads Set Back the Cause of School-Aid Reform" and superimposes quotes like "not true" and "a disservice" that apparently refer to Mr. Pataki's commercials.

Then, the music strikes a distinctly more positive note, and Mr. McCall appears as his proposals are praised in the voiceover.

THE SCRIPT -- "George Pataki's trying to fool us again. Trying to hide his failed record by taking Carl McCall's words and votes out of context . . . misleading voters . . . with attacks the press called 'not true' and 'a disservice.'

"Fact is, McCall's plan increases funding for upstate schools. That's right -- increases funding. McCall will roll back back the property tax increases and get the upstate economy moving again. So don't believe Pataki's false negative ads. Read Carl McCall's plan."

ACCURACY -- It is sometimes hard to understand the argument that the Pataki campaign has taken his words out of context. For example, Mr. McCall distinctly said, on video, that he favors restoring the commuter tax -- a moment that Mr. Pataki has featured in his commercials. Mr. McCall has gone from disavowing that statement entirely to explaining that it was made in the wake of 9/11, and no longer reflects his position. Mr. McCall has also said that upstate schools would have to get used to the idea of getting less money, but now disavows that idea as well.

But in other instances, voters would be able to better evaluate Mr. McCall's actions if they had more context than Mr. Pataki provides. Mr. McCall did vote to raise taxes as a state senator, as Mr. Pataki's advertisements say, but at a time of fiscal crisis when Republicans also approved such measures. As comptroller, Mr. McCall did not cast proxy votes in favor of forcing companies to improve their environmental standards, but neither did the vast majority of large pension funds.

SCORECARD -- Too little, too late. Mr. McCall plays the innocent good guy, trying to make voters indignant over the barrage of attacks from Mr. Pataki that have been on television for weeks. But for months before that, Mr. Pataki mortared in his own good-guy image with commercials featuring the smiling faces of his daughter, Emily Pataki, and Rudolph W. Giuliani.

Mr. McCall has said repeatedly that he will not run negative ads, but here he could not resist slipping in nuggets about the governor's "failed record." By beginning with the line "Pataki's trying to fool us again," the campaign makes the dubious assumption that voters believe the governor has fooled them before. SHAILA K. DEWAN

HEADLINE: Profit at Caterpillar Rises 4 Percent in 3rd Quarter 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: PEORIA, Ill., Oct. 16 

 BODY:
Caterpillar reported third-quarter earnings of $213 million today, up nearly 4 percent from the same quarter last year and above analysts' expectations.
 Net earnings increased $8 million compared with 2001. 
At 61 cents a share, profits were 2 cents higher than the period a year ago. Analysts predicted profits of 55 cents a share. 
 The company's chief financial officer, F. Lynn McPheeters, said that engine and heavy equipment sales had remained soft and that the overall economy has been slowed by the prospect of a war with Iraq.
But Mr. McPheeters said Caterpillar had been able to post its first quarterly gain of the year because of the diversity of its products and markets.
The company had a 26 percent earnings decline in the first quarter and a 51 percent drop in the second quarter.
The profit increase stemmed in part from a reduction of Caterpillar's income tax rate, to 28 percent from 30 percent, because of a shift in its mix of domestic and foreign sales.
Sales for the quarter were $5.08 billion, up $19 million from a year earlier. Mr. McPheeters said sales had been strong in Asia and the Pacific, which helped offset declines in North America and Latin America. 
Over all, sales of truck and bus engines were up, along with heavy construction and quarry equipment. Sales of coal mining, general construction and electrical power equipment dipped. 
Caterpillar repeated projections that its year-end earnings would fall about 15 percent below 2001's. Mr. McPheeters said the company expects moderate growth in 2003, though that could be affected if the nation is at war.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene; 
Music sales slump,concert ticket costs jump and rock fans pay the price.

BYLINE:  By Alan B. Krueger; Alan B. Krueger is the Bendheim professor of economics and public affairs at Princeton University and editor of The Journal of Economic Perspectives. E-mail: akrueger@princeton.edu.

 BODY:
IF you have gone to a rock 'n' roll concert lately, you probably noticed that the price of tickets has been rising faster than the decibel level. Although concert prices have always grown somewhat faster than inflation, from 1996 to 2001 the average price soared 62 percent, while the Consumer Price Index increased just 13 percent and the price of sporting events, movies and theater rose 24 percent.
 The average price to see Billy Joel and Elton John in concert, for example, jumped from $44 when they toured in 1995 to $110 this year. The best seats rose even more: to $175 from $50. 
 The reasons for this extraordinary growth are debatable. 
Many point to Clear Channel Communications, the giant multimedia conglomerate. After the Telecommunications Act of 1996 relaxed constraints on radio station ownership, Clear Channel gobbled up nearly 1,200 stations. It also owns amphitheaters and billboards. Clear Channel entered the concert promotion industry by acquiring SFX Entertainment in 2000, and it now promotes two-thirds of all concerts, by dollar sales.
Critics have accused the company of monopolizing the industry. Representative Howard L. Berman, a California Democrat, has urged the Justice Department to investigate whether "Clear Channel has 'punished' recording artists, including Britney Spears, for their refusal to use its concert promotion service, Clear Channel Entertainment, by 'burying' radio ads for their concerts and by refusing to play their songs on its radio stations."
Although the anecdotal evidence is strong -- and the concert industry certainly appears to be more monopolized lately, with rising prices and declining ticket sales -- it has proved surprisingly difficult to find systematic evidence linking Clear Channel to the exorbitant growth in concert prices. In particular, analyzing data from Pollstar and Arbitron, I find no correlation between Clear Channel's share of radio listeners in a city or state and its share of concerts promoted there, or between its share of radio listeners and the growth of concert prices. Likewise, there is no correlation between the change in the concentration of concert promoters in an area from 1994 to 2001 and the corresponding growth of prices or ticket sales.
Furthermore, ticket prices have also risen sharply in Canada and Europe since the mid-1990's, suggesting that deregulation of radio in the United States is not driving the trend. 
It is certainly possible that Clear Channel uses its muscle to sign up concerts for national or international tours, but one would have expected the regional data to leave some trace of Clear Channel's influence if it was the main force behind accelerating prices. 
Another problem is that Clear Channel is losing money on concerts. The company blames artists for demanding higher fees, which it says cause higher ticket prices. Although paying higher fees may reflect predatory behavior intended to drive out competitors, it is nonetheless surprising that Clear Channel has not managed to profit from concerts in areas where it dominates the radio market.
So what does explain the surge in ticket prices? 
One possibility is that the cost to the consumer has not actually increased because scalped tickets render the list price irrelevant. The rapid growth in list prices, especially for the best seats, could have merely displaced scalpers. That seems unlikely, however, because declining ticket sales suggest that costs are rising. Fewer concerts sell out, and prices have surged even for those that sell fewer than 90 percent of their tickets.
Furthermore, the extent of scalping is often overrated. To check, I conducted a survey of 858 fans when Bruce Springsteen and the E Street Band performed at the First Union Center in Philadelphia this month. The concert was a throwback: every ticket in the house sold for $75, well below the market rate. Yet only 27 percent of the tickets were bought through a scalper or ticket broker, or over the Web. The average ticket that was resold went for around $280, yet most fans paid the list price. The list price is indeed relevant.
Mr. Springsteen deliberately set the price at $75 for his entire tour to give value to his fans -- and succeeded. If the market price for a ticket was $280, Mr. Springsteen gave almost $3 million of extra "consumer surplus" to his fans in Philadelphia, double the ticket revenue the concert actually took in.
So why the surge in ticket prices?
I suspect the main reason is that the growing ability of fans to download music free from the Web -- legally or illegally -- has cut into artists' revenues. Millions of people have downloaded music from Napster, Morpheus and KaZaA -- and bought fewer records as a result. Music sales are plummeting, putting downward pressure on artists' royalties. 
In this environment, concerts take on a different meaning for artists and their managers. In pre-Napster days, concert prices were kept below their market rate to help sell albums, a complementary good. Now concert prices are set with an eye toward maximizing concert revenue.
Bands have always had cadres of fans, whose loyalty conferred monopoly power. Yet they were reluctant to exploit this power by charging higher prices because they wanted to sell more albums. When revenue from albums began to dry up, it was natural for bands to raise concert prices. 
There is some empirical support for this hypothesis. Jazz and blues fans are probably less likely to download music from the Web than are fans of rock and pop. Since 1996, prices increased by only 20 percent for jazz and blues concerts, but by 74 percent for rock and pop.
"Music itself is going to become like running water or electricity," the singer David Bowie said recently. "You'd better be prepared for doing a lot of touring because that's really the only unique situation that's going to be left." 
It is not that bands have become greedier; it is that the technology changed to make it less profitable to charge below-market prices for concerts. Not all artists are as generous as Bruce Springsteen -- and even the Boss now charges twice as much as he did in 1996. 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Bruce Springsteen seems to be keeping his ticket prices below the market rate. (Richard Perry/The New York Times) Graph: "Hot Tickets"From 1996 to 2001, the average cost of a concert ticket went up 62 percent, while the Consumer Price Index increased only 13 percent. HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Stocks Plunge As Earnings Disappoint

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Stocks plunged yesterday as an onslaught of negative earnings news damped the spirits that had powered a four-session rally that sent the Dow Jones industrials up 13.3 percent.
 The disappointing earnings news came from Intel, J. P. Morgan Chase, Motorola, Coca-Cola, Boeing, American Airlines and Ford. The message from many of these and other companies was not only that the third quarter was weaker than expected but also that the fourth quarter did not look any better. 
 "We have not yet seen the improvements in macroeconomic conditions that we anticipated when we set our earnings objectives at the beginning of 2002," Douglas N. Daft, Coke's chairman and chief executive, said in the company's earnings announcement. And because "economic conditions are not expected to improve in the fourth quarter," he said the company's 2002 earnings were likely to fall pennies short of expectations. 
Donald J. Carty, the chairman and chief executive of AMR, the parent of American Airlines, said the "terrible financial results" were a result of a sluggish economy, the uncertainty of events in the Middle East, higher fuel prices and higher security costs. "We could not overcome the cumulative weight of the economic challenges, and the environment shows little sign of improving," he said in the company's news release.
The Dow Jones industrial average was down 219.65 points, or 2.7 percent, to 8,036.03, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was off 21.25 points, or 2.4 percent, to 860.02. The Nasdaq composite index fell 50.02 points, or 3.9 percent, to 1,232.42.
Yesterday's decline was just the kind of selling that normally follows a big rally in the market. The Dow's 13.3 percent surge was the best four-session gain since a 15.3 percent run that ended April 22, 1933. The S.& P. jumped 13.5 percent over the last four trading sessions while the Nasdaq climbed 15.1 percent.
The market is still down sharply for the year and still below the levels it reached during an August rally that sent the Dow above 9,000 for a day.
Whether the stock rally resumes remains to be seen and will probably depend on the earnings outlook as more and more companies announce their third-quarter results and discuss the future.
Profits for the third quarter are up 6 percent so far compared with results in the period a year earlier, based on reports from 125 companies in the S.& P. 500 and the forecasts for the remaining companies, according to Thomson First Call, which tracks Wall Street earnings forecasts. While that is better than the 1.4 percent earnings growth in the second quarter, it is well below the 16.6 percent forecast at the beginning of the third quarter.
For the fourth quarter, the earnings growth forecast is down to 18.6 percent, from 27.7 percent on July 1.
"Everyone thought we would see some good news on the outlook when companies reported for the third quarter," said Joe Cooper, a research analyst at Thomson First Call. "But we haven't seen that."
The final performance for the third and fourth quarters will depend a lot on how well banks and other financial companies do because they account for about 23 percent of the total profit of the companies in the S.& P. 500.
The third-quarter earnings forecast for financial companies is for 28 percent growth over the third quarter of last year, counting the 37 actual reports and the forecasts for the remaining 44. But that forecast is down from 39 percent on July 1.
Many companies and Wall Street analysts that follow them still refer to operating and pro forma earnings, which allow a company to put a better face on its performance by excluding certain items. Because of this, J. P. Morgan Chase was able to beat the Thomson First Call earnings forecast of 7 cents a share by 9 cents. But on a net income basis, J. P. Morgan's earnings were just 1 cent a share in the third quarter.
So earnings growth for financial companies in the S.& P. 500 stock index may appear stronger than the overall condition of the banks themselves.
For example, Citigroup had third-quarter earnings of 74 cents a share with exclusions but beat expectations by just a penny. Yet its net income rose 23 percent, compared with the quarter a year earlier, while J. P. Morgan's fell 91 percent. Shares of J. P. Morgan fell 32 cents, or 1.7 percent, to $18.29 yesterday, while Citigroup dropped 29 cents, or 0.8 percent, to $33.85. Citigroup rose 12.6 percent Tuesday when it announced its earnings.
Intel was down $2.98, or 18 percent, to $13.54, after reporting on Tuesday evening that its third-quarter earnings missed forecasts by 2 cents a share and warned that the outlook was not getting better. "The economy is not recovering, at least in our industry," said Andy D. Bryant, Intel's chief financial officer. 
After the market closed yesterday, another big technology company, I.B.M., said that its third-quarter net income fell 18 percent. But excluding its disk-drive business, which it is selling to Hitachi, the company's results beat Wall Street expectations. Shares of I.B.M., which fell $3.58, to $64.90, during regular trading jumped more than $5 after hours.
Boeing's stock was down $1.65, or 5.1 percent, to $30.50, after it said it expected profit margins to shrink next year and that sales would come in below forecast.
While Ford beat Wall Street forecasts when excluding the expenses connected to its sale of the Kwik-Fit car repair chain, its net loss for the quarter was 18 cents a share. Shares of Ford fell 61 cents, or 6.9 percent, to $8.26.
General Motors fell $2.56, or 7 percent, to $34.14, after its long-term credit rating was lowered by Standard & Poor's to BBB, from BBB+, because of growing pension liabilities. S.& P. said it might lower Ford's credit rating as well.
Motorola fell $2.25, or 22.3 percent, to $7.85, after it warned that its earnings in the fourth quarter and for the year would fall 60 percent and 11 percent, respectively, below expectations.
Despite the decline in stocks, prices fell in the bond market, driving yields higher. The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note was at 4.05 percent, up from 4.01 percent Tuesday and up from 3.57 percent last Wednesday, the day before the four-session rally began. That was the lowest yield on a government security with a 10-year maturity since 1958, according to the Federal Reserve. The price of the 10-year note, which moves in the opposite direction, fell 10/32, to 102 21/32.
