HEADLINE: NORTH KOREA SAYS IT HAS A PROGRAM ON NUCLEAR ARMS 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 16 

 BODY:
Confronted by new American intelligence, North Korea has admitted that it has been conducting a major clandestine nuclear-weapons development program for the past several years, the Bush administration said tonight. Officials added that North Korea had also informed them that it has now "nullified" its 1994 agreement with the United States to freeze all nuclear weapons development activity. 
 North Korea's surprise revelation, which confronts the Bush administration with a nuclear crisis in Asia even as it threatens war with Iraq, came 12 days ago in Pyongyang, the North Korean capital. A senior American diplomat, James A. Kelley, confronted his North Korean counterparts with American intelligence data suggesting a secret project was under way. At first, the North Korean officials angrily denied the allegation, according to an American official who was present. 
 The next day the North Koreans acknowledged the nuclear program and according to one American official said they, "have more powerful things as well." American officials have interpreted that comment as an acknowledgment that North Korea possesses other weapons of mass destruction. 
Administration officials refused to say tonight whether the North Koreans had acknowledged successfully producing a nuclear weapon from the project, which uses highly enriched uranium. Nor would administration officials who briefed reporters say whether they think North Korea has produced such a weapon. 
"We're not certain that it's been weaponized yet," said another official, noting that North Korea has conducted no nuclear testing, which the United States could easily detect.
The idea of a North Korean nuclear arsenal immediately alters the delicate nuclear balance in Asia and confronts the Bush administration with two simultaneous crises involving nations developing weapons of mass destruction: one in Iraq, the other on the Korean Peninsula. 
"We seek a peaceful resolution to this situation," a senior administration official said tonight, briefing reporters as news of the North Korean program began to leak. "No peaceful nation wants to see a nuclear-armed North Korea."
Yet the administration's demands on North Korea tonight were muted. "The United States is calling on North Korea to comply with all of its commitments under the Nonproliferation Treaty and to eliminate its nuclear weapons program in a verifiable manner," an American official said. There was no discussion of the consequences if that appeal was ignored, even though the announcement came only hours after President Bush issued some of his toughest and most ominous-sounding warnings yet to Iraq.
Mr. Bush said nothing about North Korea today. Instead, the State Department dealt with the issue tonight through a statement issued by Richard A. Boucher, the state department spokesman, and through briefings by midlevel officials. Mr. Boucher said Mr. Kelly and Under Secretary of State John R. Bolton had been dispatched "to confer with friends and allies about this important issue." He also said, "This is an opportunity for peace-loving nations in the region to deal, effectively, with this challenge."
At a meeting on Tuesday of the National Security Council, Mr. Bush and his aides decided to handle the North Korean declarations through diplomatic channels, a senior official said.
Japan and South Korea, which is now in the midst of a presidential election campaign, both wanted to avoid confrontation, according to several officials. 
But American officials said that there was no early indication that North Korea would admit inspectors or give up its program. One senior official characterized the North Korean attitude at the Pyongyang meeting as belligerent, rather than apologetic, even while it admitted violating the 1994 accord to freeze its nuclear weapons development.
The strongest action the administration announced tonight was the cessation of talks that could lead to economic cooperation. "The United States was prepared to offer economic and political steps to improve the lives of the North Korean people," Mr. Boucher's statement said, "provided the North were dramatically to alter its behavior across a range of issues," including its weapons programs, its past support for terrorism, and "the deplorable treatment of the North Korean people."
But in deciding on a very measured response, the White House was also implicitly recognizing the reality of how North Korea differs from Iraq. It may already have nuclear weapons, and it has a huge army and conventional weapons capable of wreaking havoc on South Korea.
Moreover, even the prospect of military action against North Korea, conducted at the same time the administration is considering an attack on Iraq, would mean that the Pentagon would be confronted by the prospect of fighting a two-front war.
Deeply impoverished, with its military might waning, North Korea has long sought nuclear capability. It pursued an aggressive nuclear weapons program in the 1980's and 1990's that resulted in a major confrontation with the Clinton administration in 1994. Officials who served at the time said they believed that the dispute nearly veered into war. At one point in 1994, President Bill Clinton ordered Stealth bombers and other forces into South Korea to deter a pre-emptive North Korean strike.
But a deal was struck, partly with the intervention of former President Jimmy Carter. The result was a 1994 agreement under which North Korea committed to halting its nuclear work, and the United States, Japan and South Korea, among others, agreed to provide the country with fuel oil and proliferation-resistant nuclear reactors to produce electric power.
While ground has been broken on the project, the reactors have yet to be delivered, and now that agreement appears dead, officials said tonight.
Around the time that the Clinton administration negotiated the 1994 accord, the Central Intelligence Agency estimated that North Korea's nuclear weapons facilities at Yongbyon, a program that was based on reprocessing nuclear waste into plutonium, had already produced enough material to manufacture one or two weapons. 
If the North Korean assertions are true -- and administration officials assume they are -- the government of Kim Jong Il began in the mid- or late-1990's a secret, parallel program to produce weapons-grade material from highly enriched uranium. That does not require nuclear reactors, but it is a slow process that the United States may have discovered through Korean efforts to acquire centrifuges. That is also the process that the administration believes the Iraqis are undertaking.
"We have to assume that they now have the capacity to build many more weapons, and they may have already," said a senior official who has seen the intelligence. 
It was unclear today why North Korea admitted to the weapons program. Only last month, Kim Jong Il admitted that North Korean agents had kidnapped Japanese decades earlier, and he apologized. Five of those kidnapped people returned to Japan for visits this week.
But one official who was in the room on Oct. 4 when the North Korean deputy foreign minister, Kang Sok Joo, described the existence of the nuclear program, said, "I would not describe them as apologetic." 
The administration's decision to keep news of the North Korean admission secret for the past 12 days while it fashioned a response appears significant for several reasons. Mr. Bush and his aides have clearly decided to avoid describing the situation as a crisis that requires a military response at a time when dealing with Iraq is the No. 1 priority.
"Imagine if Saddam had done this, that he had admitted -- or bluffed -- that he has the bomb or is about to have one," one senior official said. "But there's been a decision made that the system can take only so much at one time."
The response also has much to do with the vulnerability of America's allies. Every American administration that has considered military action against North Korea has come to the same conclusion: it is virtually impossible without risking a second Korean war and the destruction of Seoul in South Korea. North Korea maintains a vast arsenal of conventional weapons and hundreds of thousands of troops. 
But dealing with the problem diplomatically will be a tremendous challenge, at a time when the administration is already at odds with many of its closest allies over how to deal with Saddam Hussein.
American officials used the past dozen days to formulate a common response. At a news conference in South Korea on Thursday morning, local time, Lee Tae Sik, deputy minister for foreign affairs, urged North Korea to abide by a series of agreements it now clearly violates: the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, the 1994 agreement, and a "joint declaration" signed with South Korea to keep the Korean Peninsula nuclear-free.
"All the issues including the North's nuclear program should be resolved through peaceful methods and by dialogue," Mr. Lee said. 
Tonight, senior administration officials said that inside the White House, theories have sprouted about what North Korea hoped to gain from its declaration.
According to one theory, discussed widely in the Pentagon and the State Department, North Korea's leaders want to demonstrate that they cannot be bullied by the United States. "Here they are declaring they have the stuff to make a nuke," one official said. "Whether they have one, or they are bluffing, we don't know for sure. But the message is, 'Don't mess with us.' "
Another theory holds that North Korea is seeking attention, as it has done many times before, hoping to trade its nuclear capability for economic aid. That worked in 1994, according to this theory. But it could backfire now, in a post-Sept. 11 environment.

HEADLINE: For Ford and G.M., the Problems Ahead Have Different Sources 

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich., Oct. 16 

 BODY:
While the stocks of General Motors and Ford Motor are falling almost in tandem, the risks seen in the two American automakers are divergent. For Ford, there is worry about its auto business; for G.M., there is worry about much besides its auto business.
 Today, Ford reported a $326 million loss for the third quarter and the long-term ratings of both Ford and its financial subsidiary, Ford Credit, were put on a credit watch with negative implications by Standard & Poor's. The bond market has taken a dim view of Ford's prospects and the action by the S.& P., a crucial rating agency, only served to drive the company's borrowing costs up further. Wall Street is concerned about the progress that Ford executives are making in cutting costs from bloated manufacturing operations while also bolstering a product lineup that has been losing market share. 
 S.& P. went a step further today with General Motors, downgrading its long-term credit rating, as well as that of its finance unit, the General Motors Acceptance Corporation, to BBB from BBB+. G.M.'s share of the lucrative market for sport utility vehicles and pickups has been growing and its manufacturing operations are considered the most efficient of the Big Three. But its problems lie beyond its core business, principally in the soaring obligations required to finance its huge pension fund. There are also problems related to difficulties in selling its stake in Hughes Electronics and with its investment in the struggling Italian conglomerate Fiat.
"The primary reason for the downgrade is that poor pension investment portfolio returns have contributed to a huge increase in G.M.'s already large unfunded pension liability," an S.& P. credit analyst, Scott Sprinzen, said in a statement.
He said in a conference call that the fact G.M. was not downgraded further was "a real tribute to the remarkable progress G.M. has made in improving the competitive position of its North American business." 
Mr. Sprinzen added that "in the case of Ford, the real concern is the North American business" and whether the company's restructuring can offset pressure from its competition and economic conditions. 
Hanging over both Ford and G.M. is the fact that analysts are forecasting slight earnings in a year with strong sales, as well as fears that sales will slow next year. And there is also the unknown, like the effect of a possible war with Iraq and what it would do to oil prices and the sales of automobiles that guzzle gasoline, notably the S.U.V.'s and pickups that are mainstays of Ford and G.M. 
Both stocks, which had a reprieve on Tuesday after falling to 10-year lows last week, were punished again today. Ford fell 61 cents, or 6.9 percent, to $8.26. G.M. stock fell $2.56, or 7 percent, to $34.14. 
Today, Ford executives stressed strides the company had made in meeting and exceeding goals in the turnaround plan laid out in January. 
Its loss of $326 million, or 18 cents a share, was better than the $692 million loss a year earlier and was a result of a $525 million charge related to the sale of Kwik-Fit, a group of auto repair shops in Europe. Ford is selling operations unrelated to carmaking. 
Without one-time charges, Ford reported an operating profit of $220 million, or 12 cents a share, in contrast to an operating loss of $502 million a year earlier. The results beat analysts' expectations of 3 cents a share, according to Thomson First Call.
"It was a nice surprise against low expectations; we weren't expecting them to make much money," said John Casesa, an auto analyst at Merrill Lynch. He downgraded both Ford and G.M. to neutral from buy on Monday.
"Pricing is getting worse and it's hard for me to see how the industry works its way out of this," he added. "The headwinds all of the companies in this industry face are blowing harder."
Mr. Sprinzen said Ford's "progress and success is in a pretty narrow context," adding "they still are losing money in a very strong market in terms of volume."
Ford said today that it expected to earn 40 cents a share this year; the turnaround plan had a more modest goal of breaking even after the $5.5 billion loss last year. Cost-cutting helped trim the operating losses in North American automotive operations to $50 million this year from $849 million in the third quarter of 2001.
Operating losses for Ford's European automotive business increased to $121 million from $24 million, driven by struggles at the Jaguar unit and delays in its redesigned XJ sedan, which has an unusual all-aluminum body. Ford Credit earned $408 million on an operating basis, up from $389 million a year earlier.
Ford's overall share of the United States market declined to 21.3 percent at the end of the quarter from 22.1 percent a year ago. While pension issues are not the issue for Ford that they are for G.M., the company's deficit doubled to $6.5 billion from $3.2 billion in the quarter. 
Ford views the bond market as becoming increasingly expensive.
"There's clearly general skittishness out there in the bond market," said William Clay Ford Jr., the company's chairman and chief executive. "What can we do about it? Well, we can start by continuing to post performances like we are today, meet our targets. 
"We're in a tough environment now, a tough macro environment, a tough industry environment, and the spotlight has been on Ford for the last couple years and the world is saying 'show us.' Well, we've now shown it for three quarters, and we'll continue to show it."

HEADLINE: Selling Furniture From the Hot Seat 

BYLINE:  By LIZ SEYMOUR 

DATELINE: HIGH POINT, N.C., Oct. 16 

 BODY:
There were bets that she wouldn't show up at all, at the country's most important furniture market. But Martha Stewart arrived here today, only slightly late because a private jet was delayed by rain in Westchester. 
 Expectations for her first line of furniture for the home -- a mammoth introduction of 200 pieces -- were shadowed by the news on Tuesday that her friend Samuel D. Waksal, founder of ImClone, pleaded guilty to six charges of securities fraud, perjury and obstruction of justice in the ImClone case -- a case in which she may be questioned or face charges. Bernhardt, the 113-year-old North Carolina company manufacturing Ms. Stewart's Signature furniture, had planned to introduce it with a party at a local horse farm, but opted for a showroom tea party this afternoon. 
 "They're the most gentlemanly, proper, decent furniture company in the business," Warren Schoulberg, editor in chief of HFN, a trade publication, said of Bernhardt. "It's ironic they're caught up in this. Are they spooked? They've got to be." 
With preliminary orders from three major retailers, things here looked brighter than might be expected for Ms. Stewart's furniture -- two groups inspired by her homes on Lily Pond Lane in East Hampton, N.Y., and in Seal Harbor, Me. The pieces were designed by an in-house team at Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia, working with Bernhardt.
Ms. Stewart's furniture introduction was closely guarded, though she did fly here in August to greet the selected buyers, who were allowed to order only if they made a serious commitment to the entire collection. This is Berhardt's first foray into celebrity-licensed products, and the industry's first hard bump with a celebrity name hitting turbulence.
"I am a hard-working C.E.O. of a very successful company," Ms. Stewart said in a telephone interview before the tea party. "Celebrity comes from something else." Asked if the negative publicity would become a liability in selling the new line of furniture, she said, "It will sell if I'm alive or dead."
But Robert Bendetson, the owner of Cabot House, a 16-store chain based in Haverhill, Mass., expressed some concern over Bernhardt's ability to market the line. "The way I see it, the furniture is an asset and Martha Stewart is a liability," he said. "How does a retailer market it if the signature person can't make appearances?"
Ms. Stewart responded, "It's a lot of pieces that will appeal to everyone." 
While she would answer questions about the furniture (which will go on sale in April in specialty department stores like Carls Furniture, an 11-store chain based in Boca Raton, Fla.; Breuners in the San Francisco Bay Area; and in the New York region at Huffman Koos), her trip, the weather, the planned tea party, the choice of fabrics and the number of rooms of her furniture being shown (14), she would not answer any questions about the ImClone case, or Mr. Waksal.
The typical new furniture collection is 75 pieces, and the furniture industry's high-end manufacturers, like Bernhardt, have been hard hit by the economic downturn. "Furniture retail has not been strong," said Lee Buchanan, editor in chief of InFurniture, a trade publication. "There are a lot of concerns coming into market; the industry needs a good market this month." The introduction of the Oscar de la Renta collection, another high-visibility entrance, was postponed from April until now.
Bernhardt, however, seems confident as it faces unwelcome publicity about its association with Ms. Stewart. Alex Bernhardt, president of Bernhardt, said this morning: "We've had conversations with Armani, Tommy Hilfiger, Donna Karan, but we didn't feel that they carried much authority in home design. Martha Stewart is obviously an authoritative voice for the home."
When the deal with Ms. Stewart was struck in November, that authority had not yet been put into question by the stock market issues connected with ImClone, and shares of Martha Stewart Omnimedia were trading at $17 rather than under $7, where they closed today.
It is a huge risk for Bernhardt, the largest introduction in its history, and more than twice the size of Thomasville's Hemingway line, introduced in 1998. And though the furniture industry is competitive, few here want to see the Martha Stewart lines fail.
"It's not good for the industry," said Powell Slaughter, an editor at Furniture Today. "If the product is good, people buy it. If she gets led off in handcuffs, that's different."
Her line of Lily Pond furniture is light, contemporary and casual, combining typical "Martha" touches like painted pieces and milk glass with the unexpected, like cast aluminum Windsor chairs. The Skylands collection, based on the former Edsel Ford property she bought on the coast of Maine, is darker and more traditional. It will include darker finishes, deeper, rounder upholstery and slightly bulkier proportions.
Bernhardt is one of four licensees in the new Martha Stewart Signature collection; the others are P. Kaufman for fabric; Sherwin-Williams, which will carry 416 colors of her paint, and Shaw for floor coverings, which will include broadloom, area rugs and tile. All are designed to position the Martha Stewart brand a rung up from the $20 bedside water carafes and $35 faux bois doormats available on her Web site, www.marthastewartliving.com. 
Sharon Patrick, the chief operating officer of Martha Stewart Omnimedia, who accompanied Ms. Stewart here, called the furniture being presented "our midtier brand label" and "very affordable." The company had no reservations about readers and viewers following Ms. Stewart upward to furniture, including her Peconic Hutch, priced at more than $1,700. "Very few things are marked that high," Ms. Stewart said.
Ms. Patrick, also interviewed by phone, said, "We know our customers pretty well." 
Retailers are being required to market the furniture with the Martha Stewart Signature name, but that could change if Stewart were indicted and convicted. Fred Friedman, president of Carls in Boca Raton, committed a substantial part of his sales space in each of his stores to the line when he saw it in August. (In order to carry the Martha Stewart collection, retailers must commit to at least 2,000 square feet of display in a fully accessorized gallery and must guarantee a certain visual presentation.)
"When people first heard about the collection there was talk about whether the name would hurt," Mr. Friedman said. "Once they saw the collection they realized that it was a lifestyle look that people would accept with or without the Martha Stewart name." 
The place here where the two lines are displayed, a 6,000-square-foot 20-room display area hidden in one corner of the showroom, was by invitation only. Bernhardt expects to take no more than 300 dealers through the collection during the market, which will ends next week. The press has been excluded from the Martha Stewart section of the showroom until an invitation-only tea party with Ms. Stewart this afternoon.
Jerry Epperson, an industry analyst with Mann, Armistead and Epperson, investment bankers and advisers in Richmond, Va., said the line could succeed. "She's going to be the poster child of insider trading," he said. "But it doesn't affect her knowledge of the home. We're talking about a Bernhardt product, with her input, her taste level. I think that's going to have a lot of clout."

HEADLINE: DINER'S JOURNAL 

BYLINE:  By Eric Asimov 

 BODY:
With the recent opening of Aix, Didier Virot's Provencal restaurant at Broadway and 88th Street, and the arrival last year of Ouest, Tom Valenti's restaurant at Broadway and 84th Street, much talk has been heard about the pioneering discovery of the Upper West Side by the high end of the restaurant business.
 Almost forgotten are high-end restaurants that have been on the Upper West Side for years, like Restaurant 222, which opened in a West 79th Street town house a decade ago. While 222 may have had to battle the perception that its neighborhood was restaurant-starved, it bowed to no one in pricing. It was one of the first restaurants in New York to crash the $30 barrier for main courses. It actually left the barrier smoldering in the dust, with main courses upward of $40 and a Kobe beef dish for $180. 
 Times, as they say, have changed at 222. With the downturn in the economy, the restaurant lost much of its corporate clientele, the owner, Frank Valenza, said, forcing a modest reduction in prices and a revamping of the menu.
What was once a Continental restaurant has now become an Italian steakhouse. And while it is still possible to splurge on a $49 rib steak, it is also possible to have a three-course prix fixe dinner, including a small but well-flavored filet mignon, for $30. (For some reason, the prix fixe is cash only.)
These days, the once elegant oak-paneled dining room feels a little the worse for wear, and the dolls, music boxes and other tchotchkes strewn about convey a Victorian fustiness. At the frequent birthday celebrations (it's that kind of place), desserts arrive with sparklers blazing, unsettlingly showering sparks everywhere.
As for the food, it can be very good, though it can also feel dated. I might pass on the $24 appetizer of three colossal shrimp, which our waiter pushed hard one evening: "I've seen couples divorce over who gets the third shrimp," he asserted. The shrimp are tasty enough but come bathed in a syrupy sweet-and-sour sauce that may be better than any you've had at a Chinese restaurant, but is nonetheless sweet-and-sour sauce. Peppered carpaccio of tuna is a better bet. The dish is a cliche, yes, but the tuna is superb.
A prime sirloin steak is superb as well. The meat is so good that it doesn't need its topping of sauteed mushrooms. A small filet mignon, served Italian style, sliced on the bias, is exceedingly good as well, and a mere $25.
Restaurant 222, 222 West 79th Street, Manhattan, (212) 799-0400. Appetizers, $12 to $29; main courses, $22 to $49; prix fixe, $29.95.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sampling West Side haute cuisine (and prices) at Restaurant 222. (James Estrin/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: INSIDE ART 

BYLINE:  By Carol Vogel 

 BODY:
A Retrospective That's a First
 When a retrospective of the 19th-century French painter Theodore Chasseriau opens at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Tuesday, it will include a three-quarter-length portrait of the Comtesse de La Tour-Maubourg, posed at the Palazzo Colonna in Rome in an elaborate ivory satin-and-lace dress that was the height of Paris fashion in 1841. 
 Chasseriau, a pupil of Ingres, was an influential painter in the first half of the 19th century, but today he is little known. "Theodore Chasseriau (1819-1856): The Unknown Romantic" will be the first retrospective of his work in the United States. And the portrait, not seen publicly since 1933, is the latest addition to the Met's collection. 
Its appearance ends a search by Gary Tinterow, curator of European paintings at the Met, and curators at the Louvre who organized the exhibition. "It was always an object of fascination because it was not accessible," Mr. Tinterow said. "During the seven years of working on the show, we tried to find it."
The curators knew it had been shown at the Paris Salon of 1841 and again in Paris in 1933 at a Chasseriau retrospective. They also heard that it had stayed in the sitter's family and was stashed away in a chateau in Brittany. Two years ago they discovered that the owner had died and that the portrait was part of an estate in the process of being settled. "Over time it became clear that the painting was for sale," Mr. Tinterow said.
Before the museum would think of acquiring it, however, several things had to be determined. The first was whether the French government would give it an export license. Fortunately, Baron Arthur Chasseriau, the artist's nephew, had given the Louvre the contents of his uncle's studio. Because the Louvre already had other paintings by the artist, Paris had its share of his work, so the government decided to let it leave the country.
Then there was the painting's condition. Mr. Tinterow said he had heard there were dark lines on it. An inspection showed that when the portrait had been lined, some glue had seeped through the canvas to the surface, a problem easily fixed by careful cleaning.
The heirs decided to sell the painting in June at Sotheby's in Paris, where it became the star lot. Jayne Wrightsman, a longtime Met trustee and one of its most generous donors, bought the painting for the museum for $1.1 million. "It's a highly important Romantic portrait in the style of Ingres," Mr. Tinterow said.
The exhibition is coming from the Grand Palais in Paris and the Musee des Beaux-Arts, Strasbourg, where it closed on Sept. 21. The portrait was not in either show.

A $50,000 Prize
The French artist Pierre Huyghe has won this year's Hugo Boss Prize. Mr. Huyghe is well known in the United States and Europe for his provocative video and installation pieces. Last year he represented France at the Venice Biennale, where he won an award for the three entrancing rooms he created about music, sound and light. His work has also been on view at Documenta 11 in Kassel, Germany; the Pompidou Center in Paris; Carnegie International in Pittsburgh; and P.S. 1 Center for Contemporary Art in Queens.
The $50,000 prize, established in 1996 by the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum and named for the German men's wear company that sponsors it, is given every two years to recognize significant achievement in contemporary art. The other finalists this year were Francis Alys, Olafur Eliasson, Hachiya Kazuhiko, Koo Jeong-a and Anri Sala.
"Pierre has spearheaded collaborations with his peers in other disciplines, which is relevant to what's happening today," said Nancy Spector, curator of contemporary art at the Guggenheim. "His work is often a commentary on memory, history, fact and fiction and the confusion between them."
The Guggenheim will have an exhibition of Mr. Huyghe's work early next year.

Another Forbes Sale
The publishing magnate Malcolm S. Forbes and his son Christopher put together a collection of Victorian paintings and other artworks over some 30 years. This week Christie's announced it would auction 361 works by leading artists of the era, including Edward Burne-Jones, William Holman Hunt, Arthur Hughes, Sir John Everett Millais, Sir Edwin Landseer, Lord Frederic Leighton and Dante Gabriel Rossetti in two days of sales at Christie's in London beginning Feb. 19.
The Forbes family has sold other portions of its vast collections at Christie's over the last nine years, including part of the Forbes Historical Manuscripts Collection for about $30 million in October and some Faberge works for $5 million in April.
Malcolm Forbes, who died in 1990, was a passionate collector of everything from antique toys to Faberge eggs. To dispel any rumors that the reason for the sales might have to do with the economy or the downturn in the magazine business, Christopher Forbes said in a written statement, "After three decades of expanding the collections that my father began, my siblings and I have decided to let others have a chance to enjoy them as much as we have."
When the collection was first being formed, the Forbeses decided that every painting they bought should have been exhibited at the Royal Academy in London during Queen Victoria's reign. Over the years, however, this guideline was abandoned with the addition of some artists who complemented the collection. Every aspect of Victorian painting will be represented in the sale.
The timing is good, said Martin Beisly, director of Victorian painting at Christie's in London. "Museums are at last digging out their Victorian pictures from their storerooms," he said. "Academically, they're being taken more seriously." Mr. Beisly was speaking of museum exhibitions over the last few years, including "Edward Burne-Jones: Victorian Artist-Dreamer" at the Met, the Birmingham Museums and Art Gallery in England and the Musee d'Orsay in Paris in 1998-99, and "Exposed: The Victorian Nude," which was at Tate Britain in London and is on view at the Brooklyn Museum of Art through Jan. 5.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Comtesse de La Tour-Maubourg, painted by Theodore Chasseriau. (Metropolitan Museum of Art)

HEADLINE: DRIVING; 
In Suburbs, Old Wheels Keep On Turning

BYLINE:  By JIM MOTAVALLI 

 BODY:
KRISTEN JONES, 32, of Fairfield, Conn., who works for a direct marketing agency, hopes no one notices when she slinks around town in a rusty 1987 Chevy Celebrity, a hand-me-down from her grandmother. Despite having been driven only about 50,000 miles, the Celebrity is a hideous abstract art statement, blending two shades of gold paint (one liberally applied from a touch-up can) and edged by bright brown rust. Fabric from overhead has come unmoored and hangs in the driver's eyes. 
 "On the days when my husband has our real car and I'm forced to drive it, I sink low in the seat," Mrs. Jones said recently, speaking from her home. "I didn't think that cars mattered much until I drove one like this." Of the three Jones children, only the youngest, at 4, is willing to ride in the Celebrity. 
 The Jones family's Celebrity is a prime example of suburbia's guilty secret, the beaten-up car given space in the garage only to save the real family cars from the risks and rigors of commuting. 
Some of these cars get all the way to the workplace, but the Celebrity is a station car -- its primary purpose in the Jones family is to be driven back and forth to the Fairfield railroad station by Mrs. Jones's husband, Gordon, 48, who commutes by train to his job in Manhattan as an executive at the Wisdom Television network.
Given the chances of thefts, break-ins and stress-related fender benders in the station parking lot, Mr. Jones prefers to use an otherwise embarrassing car to get from home to train. 
Mr. Jones doesn't lock the aged Chevy. He doesn't even mind leaving it overnight at the station parking lot on days when he works late and stays in the city. "But when I pull the Celebrity into the station lot next to a guy in a 2001 Benz, I can feel him sizing me up," Mr. Jones said. " 'At least he dresses well,' he's thinking." 
One evening at the parking lot at the Metro North station in Westport, one of Connecticut's most exclusive commuter communities, peeling Peugeots, high-mileage Hondas, dented Dodges and Bondo-coated Buicks were sitting cheek-to-jowl with multiple Mercedes-Benzes, BMW's -- even a Maserati. 
Tom Zoubek, 38, who commutes to his job teaching in a private school in Stamford, Conn., certainly notices the flashy cars when he parks his 1994 Pontiac Grand Am SE at the Westport station. But he defends his unpretentious Pontiac as the perfect station car.
"It's small, easy to park and it gets good gas mileage," he said. "And it's a Pontiac Grand Am, so who cares if anybody dings your bumper?" 
His other car is an Audi.
Bill Alpert, 53, drives 25 miles from his home in Bridgeport to the University of Connecticut in Stamford, where he teaches economics. Three years ago he finally gave up the scabrous 1981 Toyota Corolla in which he had made the trip for 18 years. "I had enormous power at four-way stops," he said. "People knew I didn't care about protecting my paint job." 
The Corolla had 160,000 miles on its odometer. There were no working door locks because it had been broken into six times. "They didn't actually steal it because it had a four-speed transmission and they could only drive automatics," Mr. Alpert said. He drives a newer model car now but nostalgically remembers the old Corolla. "It was a beautiful car," he said. "It always started." 
It took a fair amount of humility for Richard Boon, 35, to drive his aging 1985 Dodge Aries (complete with fake wire wheels) to work at a DaimlerChrysler Canada assembly plant in Windsor, Ontario, before selling it a couple of weeks ago. At least it was in the Chrysler family.
"The car said two things," Mr. Boon said. "On one hand it let people know that I'm poor, and on the other it showed how smart I am by putting my money in the bank rather than dumping it all into a car." Despite its decrepit appearance, he said, the Aries was as reliable as a Swiss watch. 
That's not an unusual story. The paradox of the old-wreck commuter car is that the rust and dents usually hide the heart of a lion. 
"The kids tell me it smells," Mrs. Jones said of her family's Celebrity. "They refuse to be picked up in it after play dates. But it never gives us any trouble -- that's its most endearing quality."

HEADLINE: FILM REVIEW; 
A Poet Finds His Past Is Just Where He Left It

BYLINE:  By ELVIS MITCHELL 

 BODY:
"The Business of Fancydancing," the directorial debut of the novelist and screenwriter Sherman Alexie, is an often affecting, low-budget melodrama that is occasionally sabotaged by its economy of means: the image quality is sometimes so poor that it's like watching the pixel breakup on digital cable. But although the film is initially clumsy and a little hard to follow, Mr. Alexie takes his time in setting his characters in play, and the visual clunkiness becomes secondary to the eloquent emotional desolation.
 "Fancydancing," which opens today in Manhattan, is difficult material -- a drama about self-destructiveness -- and the novice director is sometimes tangled in the biggest trap inherent in such a project. Presenting such a motif means that almost everybody on screen sees himself as a victim and is prone to displays of sloppy articulation about self-loathing. This must be countered with a directorial toughness that Mr. Alexie, a critically acclaimed American Indian writer, has shown in his prose more than in "Smoke Signals," his first filmed script (directed by Chris Eyre), which was a show-offy exercise in suffering. 
 The film's narrative is told mostly from the perspective of Seymour Polatkin (Evan Adams), a gay writer and poet and a member of the Spokane tribe. It starts with a high school flashback of Seymour and his friends Aristotle (Gene Tagaban) and Mouse (Swil Kanim), an ill-fated violinist who never shirked telling the truth no matter how painful. When he dies, he leaves as much misery in his wake as he did while he was alive.
The difference between Mouse and Seymour is that Seymour throws the verbal acid back into his own face. He mocks his own shifting psychological identity, giving each of the fans at a book signing a different story about his background as he autographs his book for them. Mouse treated honesty as a weapon, and his duty was to subject whoever happened to be in his line of sight to coruscating rants.
Mouse's funeral takes Seymour back to the reservation, where he's forced to exhume his past, much of which still lives there. This includes Agnes (Michelle St. John), the half-Jewish, half-Spokane woman he briefly dated before realizing that he was "two-spirited" -- gay. She's involved with Aristotle, who has no trouble labeling Seymour a sell-out and a deserter of his people. This seems harsh yet reflects what Seymour thinks of himself. He has a particularly funny and bitter monologue -- "How to Write the Great American Indian Novel" -- that he uses on himself in which he observes: "Indians must see visions, and white people can have some visions if they are in love with Indians."
Mr. Alexie doesn't make Aristotle and Mouse one-dimensional poles between which Seymour exists. Aristotle has squandered his gifts and lies about complaining and drinking instead of doing anything with his life; he's bitter because he was afraid to leave the reservation. And his anger is made worse by Agnes's respect for Seymour, despite the damage he did to her.
The story is fragmented, like a poem, shards that can be assembled into a narrative. There are a few too many devices, like a television interviewer (Rebecca Carroll) whose primary function seems to be to give Seymour a chance to display his contradictory nature. And his white boyfriend, Steven (Kevin Phillip), is saddled with some unfortunate lines to broadcast his sympathy, like "They're not your tribe anymore. I'm your tribe."
But casting Mr. Adams was a thoughtful gambit by the director. The actor's vague boyishness suggests any number of ethnicities; his indistinct handsomeness is a physical manifestation of his own confusion about who he is. (Mr. Adams also appeared in "Smoke Signals.") The movie is as much about Seymour's need for spirituality as anything else, and his attempt to reject it is a denial of his own identity.
But the confessional aspect of the story is often pushed a little too hard; the characters are too eager to let us know exactly what's going on in their heads.
The director's dry sincerity leavens the sentiment of this quasi-autobiographical film, a tale about the burden of constantly being asked who you are and where you come from -- a question that artists of color constantly hear, either from others or themselves. Mr. Alexie is smart enough to know it's never satisfactorily answered.

THE BUSINESS OF FANCYDANCING

Written and directed by Sherman Alexie; director of photography, Holly Taylor; edited by Ms. Taylor; production designer, Jonathan Saturen; produced by Larry Estes and Scott Rosenfelt; released by FallsApart Productions. At the Cinema Village, 22 East 12th Street, Greenwich Village. Running time: 103 minutes. This film is not rated.

WITH: Evan Adams (Seymour Polatkin), Michelle St. John (Agnes Roth), Gene Tagaban (Aristotle Joseph), Rebecca Carroll (Interviewer), Kevin Phillip (Steven) and Swil Kanim (Mouse).

GRAPHIC: Photo: Evan Adams, left, and Gene Tagaban in "Fancydancing." (Lance Muresan/FallsApart Productions)

HEADLINE: Talks on Russian Entry Into W.T.O. Hit Snag 

BYLINE:  By SABRINA TAVERNISE 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 17 

 BODY:
Russia, whose economy is by far the largest outside the World Trade Organization, has hit an impasse in talks with major trading partners about joining the group.
 Trade officials from Russia, the United States and the European Union met in Moscow this week but failed to find common ground on a number of central issues, including Russia's low energy prices and its protection for its banks and telecommunications industry. The meetings were meant to prepare for multilateral talks next month at the organization's headquarters in Geneva on Russia's bid to join the group. 
 As recently as a few months ago, Russian officials were predicting that their country would join the 144-nation trade organization in the next year or two. They now say that negotiations are at a standstill because other nations refuse to compromise. 
"If we consider that the losses from joining outweigh the benefits, we will never join," said Russia's chief negotiator, Maxim Medvedkov, in a phone interview this evening. "Now, if we meet all the demands of our partners in full, it would mean a big loss for Russia."
European and American negotiators say Russia wants to retain too much protection for industries like financial services and insurance. In those fields, Russian law now limits foreign participation, on the ground that Russian firms are not yet strong enough to compete with major international rivals. 
Broadly, membership in the World Trade Organization would entitle Russian manufactured goods and certain other goods and services to favorable treatment in other member nations' markets, with standardized rules and low tariffs. In exchange, Russia would have to open its own market to other members' exports. For nations that mainly export manufactured products, like the United States and China, the benefits are obvious. For Russia, which mainly exports commodities like oil and gas, they are less so. 
"I am against rapid, reckless accession," said Konstantin Remchukov, chairman of the advisory board of Basic Element, a firm that controls Russia's second-largest carmaker. "The W.T.O. is an instrument to get finished goods into department stores abroad. But finished goods are only 9 percent of our exports."
At times this week, negotiators for the two sides seemed to be talking past each other. Mr. Medvedkov said tonight that Russia could still join the group as soon as 2003, but that it was up to the Western nations to make concessions.
"It will be possible only if our partners review their demands, and if those demands will be pragmatic," he said. "Now, they are simply outside of the framework within which we are willing to work."
At a press briefing today, a senior American trade official voiced a similarly categorical view. Asked what had actually been agreed upon this week, the official said, "There is agreement that Russia needs to change its trade regime."
Russia's low domestic energy prices are a central sticking point for European negotiators. The Russian state sets the prices, which are about one-sixth of the average level in Europe; the Europeans say that the pricing amounts to an unfair subsidy for Russian industry.
The Russian government has been gradually raising the prices of natural gas and electricity over the last decade. But its negotiators flatly refused to discuss the faster, larger increases the Europeans want, saying that abundant, cheap energy is no subsidy, just a competitive advantage. 
After all, Mr. Medvedkov said, other nations make the most of their natural advantages: "We aren't fighting the prices of oranges from Morocco or wine from Spain." 
Most of the former Soviet republics in Central Asia are waiting for Russia to join the organization before they do; Kazakhstan, another major energy exporter, is particularly anxious to open accession talks.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Maxim Medvedkov, Russia's chief negotiator, said the gains of membership must outweigh the losses. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Panel Is Set to Prescribe Japan's Economic Medicine 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 17 

 BODY:
Japan is set to announce on Friday a series of measures aimed at supporting an economy that is likely to be hurt in the near term by the government's plan to speed up write-offs of bad loans by the nation's banks.
 With tax revenue falling and the national debt exploding, however, such measures may, at best, only prevent another recession instead of spurring growth, experts said. 
 Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's Council on Economic and Fiscal Policy favors tax cuts and other support worth no more than 5 trillion yen ($40.2 billion), or about 1 percent of gross domestic product. But the council has said that accelerating write-offs of the estimated $423 billion in bad loans will depress growth by an equal amount, 1 percent, as bankruptcies and unemployment rise. Worse, the government expects to raise social security taxes next year, a step that would wipe out most benefits of any tax cuts. 
Still, the government's report on Friday is expected to include calls for tax cuts of 2.5 trillion yen ($20.1 billion), mostly aimed at companies. It is also likely to recommend expanding low-cost loan programs for small businesses under pressure from their banks, and it is expected to propose broader unemployment benefits.
The council may also call on the Bank of Japan to loosen monetary policy further to counter the negative effects of the write-offs of bad loans.
The governor of the Bank of Japan, Masaru Hayami, who is a member of the economic council, said the group had not discussed the bank's monetary policy at today's meeting. The central bank's policy board will meet on Oct. 30.
While the government scrambles to find ways to bolster growth as the nine-month recovery loses steam, one of the few drivers of the economy -- exports -- is slowing. Shipments overseas have declined for three consecutive months on a seasonally adjusted basis as economic growth in the United States and Asia has slowed.
All of this, combined with continued weakness in capital spending and new-home starts, make it increasingly likely that Japan's economy will tip back into recession, analysts said.
"We are in for tough times," said Kazutaka Kirishima, an economist at the Sumitomo-Life Research Institute, adding: "The risk of a double-dip recession is high. The government's stimulus package will have little impact in this environment."
If the government carries through with its plan to push banks to write off their bad loans faster, the unemployment rate could easily spike to 7 percent from the current 5.4 percent, economists said.
Personal bankruptcies are also likely to rise. The number of people filing for bankruptcy was already on track to grow nearly 40 percent this year, according to The Nihon Keizai Shimbun, the leading Japanese business newspaper.
The government fears that its push to get the banks to write off their bad loans will lead to a credit squeeze in which even healthy companies have trouble getting money, as happened in 1998 and 1999. Most of the measures it is considering are aimed at helping businesses get the financing they need to keep employees working.
Mr. Koizumi's council said the government would create more jobs, but it offered few specifics.
The new chief financial regulator, Heizo Takenaka, said that his Financial Services Agency would be setting up a telephone hot line to field calls from small businesses that are having trouble obtaining loans from banks.
With interest rates still at rock bottom, the central bank has little left to offer, except uncollateralized loans to companies in need. And that throws the burden back on the government, which is wrestling with a national debt that is expected to grow by March to 693 trillion yen ($5.6 trillion), an amount equal to 140 percent of the gross domestic product.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
EMC Makes a Small Profit, Thanks Solely to a Tax Benefit

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
EMC, the leading supplier of data storage systems for large corporations, said yesterday that it eked out a profit in the third quarter thanks to a one-time overseas tax benefit but that business conditions worsened as the quarter drew to an end.
 William Teuber, EMC's chief financial officer, said that despite stringent cost-cutting measures, including the recently announced layoffs of 1,350 employees, EMC did not expect sales to rebound strongly enough for the company to achieve break-even results before the second quarter of next year. 
 EMC said that it earned $21 million, or a penny a diluted share, in the quarter, in contrast to a loss of $945 million, or 43 cents a diluted share, a year earlier. Excluding the tax adjustment, EMC lost $51 million, or 2 cents a share, in the most recent quarter. 
EMC said revenue rose 4 percent, to $1.26 billion. That was the first year-to-year sales improvement since early last year. But revenue fell 9 percent from the second quarter. Joseph M. Tucci, the president and chief executive, said that major customers were cutting back on their already reduced budgets for information technology.
Such conditions once seemed inconceivable to EMC, which is based in Hopkinton, Mass. Two years ago, as it completed a decade of rapid growth, EMC expected revenue of close to $15 billion this year. EMC preached that the amount of data essential to business was exploding, so investments in storing it were likely to soar even if the economy weakened. But data storage proved just as vulnerable to recession as the rest of the technology industry, and EMC will do well to reach $5.5 billion in revenue for the year.
That reality has punished the stock price. After topping $102 two years ago, shares of EMC went into a long decline that took them as low as $3.83 early this month after it warned Wall Street about the earnings reported yesterday. With no significant new bad news in yesterday's report or the conference call that followed it, EMC's stock rose slightly in the morning before retreating to finish at $4.60, down 16 cents.
Analysts said the biggest question left unanswered by the report was the degree to which the disappointing quarter reflected general market conditions as opposed to increasing competition from I.B.M. and Hitachi, EMC's major rivals at the high end of the market where storage devices can cost $1 million or more. Both rivals have updated their flagship product lines more recently than EMC, said Rob Schaefer, who follows the sector for the META Group, a market research and consulting company.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
Sun Reports Loss, Beats Estimates And Cuts Jobs

BYLINE:  By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 17 

 BODY:
Struggling with an increasingly uncertain and bleak corporate economy, Sun Microsystems said yesterday that it would lay off 11 percent of its employees and reported a loss for its first quarter, but it still exceeded Wall Street's earnings expectations.
 Through 2001, Sun, a computer company, was one of the biggest beneficiaries of both the dot-com boom and the telecommunications and Internet industry expansions. Now the company is trying to navigate an increasingly challenging technology recession, as corporate capital spending declines and competitors offering the Windows and Linux operating systems on their computers challenge Sun. 
 Sun said that it planned to cut 4,400 employees at sites around the world, beginning in November. Sun now employs about 39,400 workers. 
The cuts were lower than financial analysts had speculated in recent days. Several Wall Street technology analysts said that the level suggested that Sun's chief executive, Scott McNealy, was having some success in managing the company through the recession.
Sun's revenue for the first quarter of its 2003 fiscal year was $2.75 billion, down 4 percent from $2.86 billion in the quarter a year earlier. The figure was slightly less than analysts had expected, and the company said that an end-of-the-quarter improvement it had hoped for had not materialized.
But the company's net loss for the first quarter was $111 million, or 4 cents a share, compared with a net loss of $180 million, or 6 cents a share, for the year-earlier period. Excluding several one-time financial charges and benefits -- including a $31 million loss on equity investments, a $24 million charge in connection with previous revamping charges and a $22 million tax benefit -- the net loss was $78 million, or 2 cents a share. The Wall Street consensus was a loss of 4 cents a share, according to Thomson First Call. Sun's stock closed at $2.99 in regular trading, up 19 cents, and rose after hours as high as $3.09.
The company said it was pushing hard to break even financially and suggested that if it saw some seasonal improvement in the economy, it might return to profitability in the second half of next year.
Sun's break-even point was once $4 billion, and the company has made continual cutbacks as the economy has deteriorated. Sun's chief financial officer, Steve McGowan, said the company would now break even around $3.2 billion, but he said that would be affected by Sun's margins.
The company said that it was continuing to generate cash despite its losses and that the amount of cash it had on hand had grown to $5.2 billion, against $1.5 billion in debt.
Sun said it had paid off $200 million in debt and bought back $500 million in stock during the quarter as a demonstration of its financial strength.
"They're a big company; they're not going away," said Steven Milunovich, a financial analyst at Merrill Lynch. He noted that corporations would increasingly need the technology that Sun was selling, but the challenge for the company would be to remain relevant to its customers.
Despite Sun's continued losses, its executives said that the company was holding its own in market share. Mr. McNealy said that third-party data showed that Sun had increased its share of the Unix market against the Hewlett-Packard Company, one of its closest competitors. Sales were down 7 percent for the quarter in the United States, flat in Europe and down 13 percent in Japan.
The company said one bright spot was the sales of its new Star Office software package, which had revenue of $5.8 million for the quarter. The company hopes to compete on cost against Microsoft's Windows and Office desktop suites, luring corporate customers who have tens of thousands of personal computers.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Computer hardware is tested at a Sun Microsystems plant in Newark, Calif., one of many Sun sites around the world. The company said yesterday that it would lay off 4,400 of its 39,400 employees but did not say where. (Kim Kulish/Corbis SABA for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Microsoft Reports Strong Revenue and Net Income Even Though the Economy Was Weak 

BYLINE:  By STEVE LOHR 

 BODY:
Microsoft reported a remarkably strong quarterly performance yesterday with both profits and revenue up sharply at a time when the economy is weak and technology spending is depressed.
 Microsoft did get an unusual increase in revenue in the quarter, largely from corporate customers rushing to sign up for a new licensing program before a July deadline. 
 But the company's first-quarter performance also showed that it was succeeding in its strategy to persuade personal computer makers and end users to buy the larger and more costly business version of its Windows operating system, and to move increasingly into the lucrative market for corporate computing.
In the corporate market, Microsoft sells not only software for desktop PC's but also the software for the big data-serving computers that power corporate networks. How Microsoft fares in the server market, analysts say, is crucial for its long-term growth and profitability. 
Microsoft is bringing the low-cost economics of the personal computer industry into the corporate market, often undercutting the offerings of Oracle, Sun Microsystems and I.B.M. So at a time when corporate technology buyers are trying to cut costs, Microsoft, analysts say, is benefiting and gaining ground on its rivals. 
"A down economy is good for Microsoft because it is the low-cost supplier," said David M. Smith, an analyst at Gartner Inc. "That accounts for a lot of Microsoft's strength in this environment."
In a conference call with analysts, Microsoft executives warned that there are uncertainties ahead. First, they warned that they did not expect the traditional year-end pickup in personal computer sales this year.
Next, Microsoft said earnings would probably be somewhat lower in the current quarter, in part because higher holiday sales of its new Xbox video game would trim profits. The company currently loses money on each console sold, betting it can make money later by selling its game software designed to run on its Xbox machines.
Executives admitted game machine sales were less than expected in the quarter ended in September, by nearly $100 million. But they reiterated their previous prediction that by the end of the year the total number of Xbox consoles sold since it was introduced last year would be 9 million to 11 million.
"This holiday season is a big test," said John G. Connors, Microsoft's chief financial officer.
Other challenges Mr. Connors enumerated included the rising popularity of GNU Linux, a variant of the Unix operating system, which is increasingly being used as an operating system on server computers. He also mentioned the "significant legal risk" from the possibility that a federal judge in Washington could place additional sanctions on Microsoft, in addition to those agreed to by the Bush administration in a settlement of the government's antitrust suit against the company.
Still, Microsoft's quarterly results mainly underlined just how much Microsoft has been able to sidestep the travails of much of the rest of the computer industry.
Revenue grew 26 percent in the quarter ended Sept. 30, to $7.75 billion. Operating profits increased 40 percent, to $4 billion. Microsoft's net income more than doubled to $2.7 billion, or 50 cents a share. But the jump in net income was magnified because the earlier quarter included a charge of $980 million to write off strategic investments in telecommunications and cable companies whose share prices had plummeted in 2001.
Both Microsoft's revenue and earnings results easily surpassed the estimates of Wall Street analysts. The Wall Street estimate of profits was 43 cents a share, and the revenue estimate was $7.13 billion.
In the last few days, however, some analysts had said an acceleration in corporations signing up for Microsoft's new subscription-based software pricing program before the July 31 deadline imposed by the company could lift quarterly revenue by hundreds of millions of dollars.
The rush of new licensing commitments also added substantially to Microsoft's so-called deferred revenue -- a balance sheet item that lets the company recognize revenue gradually over the course of a long-term license, typically two or three years. By the end of September, Microsoft's deferred revenue was $9.1 billion, up from $7.7 billion in the quarter ended in June.
"This truly was an exceptional quarter," Mr. Connors said.
Shares of Microsoft, which released its results after the close of trading, rose 36 cents, to $50.77. They jumped as high as $52.45 in after-hours trading.

HEADLINE: Philip Morris Profit Rises; Foreign Sales Offset Lag in U.S. 

BYLINE:  By SHERRI DAY 

 BODY:
The Philip Morris Companies reported yesterday that third-quarter earnings increased, largely on the strength of sales in foreign markets. But domestic business continued to show signs of weakness as cigarette taxes rose sharply in more than a dozen states and the proliferation of cheaper brands hurt sales of higher-priced products like Marlboro.
 The company said it would stand by its projections of earnings-per-share growth of 3 to 5 percent for 2002, and predicted earnings would increase 8 to 10 percent in 2003. 
 Net income in the quarter rose to $4.36 billion, or $2.06 a share, an increase of 87 percent from income of $2.33 billion, or $1.06 a share, a year earlier. The latest results included a gain of about $1.7 billion from the sale of the Miller Brewing Company. 
Excluding that gain and other special items, Philip Morris posted earnings of $2.7 billion, or $1.26 a share, up just over 5 percent from $2.57 billion, or $1.16 a share, in the period a year earlier.
Revenue decreased 1.7 percent, to $19.9 billion, from $20.25 billion.
The results, which were in line with Wall Street expectations, were predictable; the company had revised its forecast in September.
"It's hard to characterize this as a positive report when the company is losing share at retail, and the premium-discount mix is slipping," said Robert T. Campagnino, a Prudential analyst. "The data points were certainly not positive; however, it's information that I don't think that the market didn't have already."
Philip Morris reported strong sales abroad, but for much of the third quarter its weak spot was domestic business. Operating income at Philip Morris USA declined 3.7 percent in the quarter, to $1.5 billion. Shipping volume fell 6 percent, to 49.4 billion units, from the third quarter of 2001.
The company's share of premium cigarette sales declined 0.1 percent. Its share of all cigarette sales, which had fallen to 49 percent of the market in July, rose slightly.
Since 1998, discount cigarette brands have made significant gains because major companies have raised prices to offset expenses related to their legal settlement with a number of states. In addition, increases in excise taxes on cigarettes in several states have helped generic brands siphon customers from Philip Morris.
In time, analysts said, smokers will probably return to more expensive brands. But for now, major tobacco companies are expected to continue to see a decline in sales.
"People are still smoking," said Bonnie Herzog, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney. "I don't think overall consumption has been that impacted. It's been a channel shift and a product shift. People are buying their cigarettes from different places, and they may be different types." 
To prop up sales, Philip Morris increased prices and spent heavily on promotions and discounts. Dinyar S. Devitre, the chief financial officer, said Philip Morris expected to spend more than $600 million on promotions in the fourth quarter.
"We always have to, sort of, almost experiment with this," Mr. Devitre said yesterday. "We will obviously take our foot slightly off the accelerator from time to time, and we just have to wait and see how Marlboro reacts." 
The company, which said its settlement payments would decrease next year, is hoping that a larger domestic sales force will help it compete with the discounters.
Outside the United States, its operating income rose 8 percent, to $1.6 billion, because of higher pricing, lower costs and favorable currency exchange rates. Volume increased 2.3 percent, to 187.8 billion units, because of robust sales in Europe.
Analysts said that although Philip Morris's domestic business had been a cause of concern, the company performed well in a difficult economy. The future, they suggested, is less certain.
David J. Adelman, a tobacco analyst at Morgan Stanley, said it was good that Philip Morris was starting to see some growth in its overall market share, "but they are spending to get it."
"The worst possible outcome," he said, "would be if they were spending aggressively and not getting any growth."
In trading ysterday, Philip Morris stock rose $1.70, to $40.30.

HEADLINE: Georgia Wins Bidding War For a DaimlerChrysler Plant 

BYLINE:  By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, Oct. 17 

 BODY:
The latest bidding war between Southern states for a new auto manufacturing plant was resolved today in Georgia's favor when DaimlerChrysler said it had chosen a site near Savannah over one near Charleston, S.C., to assemble two types of vans now made only in Germany.
 Construction of a $754 million assembly plant in Pooler, 12 miles west of Savannah, will start in July, "barring any unforeseen changes in the economy," said Joselyn Butler Baker, a spokeswoman for Gov. Roy Barnes, who announced an agreement in principle with the company this afternoon. 
 Gov. Jim Hodges of South Carolina had offered as much as $346 million in incentives to try to lure the DaimlerChrysler factory, which is to produce Sprinter and Vito passenger and cargo vans and employ about 3,300 people. Mr. Hodges, a Democrat, is in a close battle for re-election with former Representative Mark Sanford, who has attacked Mr. Hodges's economic-development record, and Mr. Hodges made no secret of his desire to win the new factory to improve his chances in November. But aides to Mr. Hodges said his refusal to have the state buy the land for the factory without a guarantee that the plant would be built was a deal breaker for DaimlerChrysler. Georgia already owns the Pooler property.
Charlie Way, South Carolina's commerce secretary, said DaimlerChrysler had informed him that it would make no final decision on whether to build a plant in the United States until July. But Ms. Baker, of the Georgia governor's office, said only a sharp economic downturn could stand in the way of the new factory.
In his announcement today, Governor Barnes, a Democrat who is also up for re-election next month, said state and local government incentives to DaimlerChrysler totaled $320 million, or $67,000 per job.
South Carolina officials, however, suggested that Georgia had actually offered more than South Carolina's $346 million in incentives. By comparison, South Carolina tax incentives to attract a B.M.W. plant added up to only $202 million, officials said.
The new plant will have a payroll of $155 million a year, or an average of $47,000 per worker, and would generate another 700 jobs once parts suppliers locate nearby, Governor Barnes said.
The factory would take up 2.3 million square feet on 1,560 acres near both the Savannah and Brunswick, Ga., seaports and the Savannah airport.
In recent years several Deep South states have lured foreign auto makers.
Mercedes and Honda have plants in Alabama, and Hyundai and Toyota have announced plans for plants there.
Nissan is opening a factory in Canton, Miss. Saturn and Nissan have plants in Tennessee, and B.M.W. employs thousands of South Carolinians between Greenville and Spartanburg.
Georgia already has two automotive plants, but until now it had failed to lure a foreign carmaker, and its existing factories are not exactly late models. One, a General Motors plant in Doraville, opened in 1947. The other, a Ford plant in Hapeville, opened in 1909.

HEADLINE: Housing Starts Jump 13.3%, Helping LiftThe Economy 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
With storms gathering elsewhere, the housing industry continues to shield the economy during its halting recovery.
 The number of houses that builders started working on jumped 13.3 percent last month, the biggest increase since 1995, the Census Bureau said yesterday, as low interest rates spurred developers to try to satisfy rising demand. The surge reversed a three-month streak of declining housing starts that had raised some concern about whether homebuilding would continue to add to overall economic activity. 
 Even as consumers have reduced their retail spending in recent weeks, they appear confident enough to continue making large purchases, analysts said. 
"If you have a job and want to buy a house, interest rates tell you this is the best time to buy," said Chad Dreier, chief executive of the Ryland Group, a homebuilding company, explaining the construction boom. "There's just more demand than there is supply out there."
But the recent rise in mortgage rates may temper some of that demand in the months ahead. At the same time, corporate executives still seem to lack the confidence of consumers and remain committed to cutting costs, according to other reports released yesterday.
Initial claims for jobless benefits rose to 411,000 last week, from 389,000 the previous week, according to the Labor Department's seasonally adjusted numbers. Industrial production fell slightly last month, its second straight decline, in a sign that manufacturers expect growth to remain weak in coming months.
Investors seemed to focus on the more positive economic news and indications of improving earnings, however, sending stock prices higher and bonds lower. The Standard & Poor 500-stock index rose 19.18, or more than 2 percent, to close at 879.20.
As strong as the housing market is, economists already see reasons to think that it will not remain one the economy's biggest growth engines in the coming year. Mortgage rates have jumped this week by the largest increase in almost a year, as investors have become less fearful recently of a double-dip recession. When investors are optimistic, interest rates tend to rise, pushing bond prices down.
The average annual interest rate on a 30-year fixed mortgage rose to 6.23 percent, from 6.02, over the last week, according to BankRate.com, a research company in North Palm Beach, Fla. On a $150,000 mortgage, the difference equals $20 a month.
"Housing is probably close to a peak," said James O'Sullivan, an economist at UBS Warburg. "Over the course of the next year, we'll have decent enough growth that interest rates will climb and housing will start to fade."
That certainly has not happened yet, however. In September, builders started construction on homes at an annual pace of 1.84 million, the highest level since 1986, the Census Bureau said. Construction increased the most in the Midwest and West.
While starts of single-family homes soared, multifamily house construction fell slightly, reflecting weakness in the rental market, analysts said. The economic slowdown has left some renters with less money to spend, and others have taken advantage of low interest rates to buy their own homes.
The decline of stocks over the last two years has also made real estate look like an increasingly attractive investment, causing some people to spend more money on homes than they might have in the past.
The strong overall market suggests that consumers will continue to spend heavily on many big-ticket items in the months ahead, when they furnish the houses now being built. About two-thirds of houses in the first stages of construction have already been sold, according to the National Association of Home Builders.
Over the summer, Americans slightly increased their spending on home remodeling, Harvard's Joint Center for Housing Studies said yesterday. Over the last 12 months, households have spent about $115 billion on remodeling.
If interest rates were to rise only modestly, homebuying could remain at a high level, since rates would still be lower than they had been for much of the recent past. "The interest rate thing is in our favor, even if it rises a little bit," said Mr. Dreier, the housing executive.
But a small increase in rates would be more likely to cause a sharp fall in the number of people refinancing their mortgages, that activity has reached record levels in recent weeks. By reducing monthly housing payments for millions of families and allowing many homeowners to move money from their homes to their bank accounts, refinancings have helped to offset the stock-market declines of the last three months and to keep consumer spending strong.
Executives continue to be far more frugal than consumers, however, as they have been throughout the last two years. 
"My biggest concern is the timing and strength of the economic recovery," said David J. O'Reilly, chief executive of ChevronTexaco. "This has been a slower year than most people expected."
Weak retail spending and the potential war in Iraq, which could lead to a spike in oil prices, have caused some companies to cut production.
The new report on jobless claims suggests that companies are doing little new hiring, although layoffs are not as common as they were a year ago. While new claims for unemployment insurance have fallen almost 13 percent since last October, the number of people receiving benefits has risen 8 percent, to 3.48 million, according to the Labor Department, which adjusts the number to account for normal seasonal variations.
The manufacturing sector looks especially weak. A survey of executives in the Philadelphia area showed that manufacturing activity there decreased more rapidly than it had in nearly a year, the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia said. 
After a mild rebound in the first half of this year, Mr. O'Sullivan, the UBS Warburg economist, said, "it's pretty clear that manufacturing has lost momentum."

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: BALI; 
Nightclub Blasts Leave Carefree Crowd Less So

BYLINE:  By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: KUTA, Indonesia, Oct. 17 

 BODY:
If there is any place on earth where war and terror could be forgotten it should be this carefree seaside town where the only imperative is self-indulgence. 
 But since the terrorist attack last Saturday, the young travelers who gather here from around the world have begun to carry the weight of the world in their backpacks. 
 Intentionally or not, the terrorists who bombed two nightclubs packed with partygoers have sent a shock through a borderless, shifting but increasingly cohesive world of low-budget travelers that has taken form in recent decades. 
As much, perhaps, as the World Trade Center was a symbol of international commerce, the name of Kuta has resonated as a capital and a crossroads for people on the backpacker circuit. 
When disaster struck, these citizens of the world turned to one another on the Internet, their common home, where they often meet to share the latest news from Katmandu in Nepal or Khaosan Road in Thailand. 
"How can they do this to Bali?" lamented a person with the cybername Chowmaipohtang. "This is too much. Is nowhere safe?" 
In the days since then, the travelers' Web sites have taken on a tone of fear and anger, and shown a new appetite for political discourse. Bulletin boards created to share low-budget travel tips are heavy with surprisingly sophisticated analyses of world affairs. 
"Just wondering whether the bomb blast in Bali would affect the whole backpacking culture here in Southeast Asia in general and in Muslim countries like Malaysia, Brunei and Indonesia," wrote Intruder. "Would it get any worse if the Americans do decide to attack Iraq?" 
The concept of a backpacking culture has been emerging since the 1970's, when the pioneers of rough travel put places like Nepal on the map and invented what is now almost a uniform of sandals and loose cotton clothes. 
Low-budget travelers now have guidebooks to a worldwide network of guest houses and Internet cafes that has emerged to serve them. On their voyages of discovery they are accompanied by legions of their peers. As they follow a beaten track, way stations like Kuta offer a haven where they can share tales of their common experiences while they drink and dance and bunk together. 
This carefree culture, it seems, is already being affected.
Web sites now carry impassioned debates over the question of safety, particularly here in Bali. There is a shared sense that the world is a more dangerous place even for people who want to have nothing to do with it. 
"It can happen again anytime, anywhere," wrote Wimos. "Nobody expected Bali, nobody expected New York. Next target?" 
Some correspondents even have the temerity to suggest that it might be safer to stay home. 
These fears have met with fierce expressions of something that sounds like patriotism. If backpackers had a flag, they might all be flying it now. 
"I am a traveler and this unspeakable act of terrorism will not stop me from trekking around this crazy world," wrote Swayze. 
A man who introduced himself as Jason Gaspero, a surfer, sounded a bit like Patrick Henry as he said: "Let me tell you this, and I believe it from the bottom of my heart. Evil will lose. Freedom will win. Our sense of freedom and traveling spirit is too strong to be defeated." 
If a clincher was needed, NicB declared that if young travelers abandon their surfboards, temporary tattoos and banana pancakes, "The terrorists win." 
A number of people are making a more serious argument that backpackers have a moral duty to continue to support the economy that has evolved to serve them. 
That notion was attacked widely by people like PST, who said, "We are talking about going on VACATION here -- not support for countries under attack just because the people of that particular country are nice. How about a cheap vacation in Afghanistan? Bosnia? Get real." 
The economic argument cuts both ways, though. Now is the time to come, urge the less timid, when a rare visitor can be king of the waves and the beaches, and when rates at guest houses are expected to drop. 
A shameful notion, said Manydreams. "While 200 people lay dead, you are going to be in Bali having a 'damn good time.' Pathetic." 
But this is in fact a pattern among backpackers and surfers, said Bill Dalton, an authority on travel in Indonesia. "Veteran travelers know that if there are any upheavals or revolutions or civil wars or hurricanes -- like, if there's a coup in the Seychelles you drop everything and you go to the Seychelles," he said.
These veteran low-budget travelers are likely to be heading for Bali now, Mr. Dalton said. All the infrastructure of tourism remains in place, "only 30 percent cheaper." 
No one knows how deeply the world of the backpacker has been affected, but there are new, real concerns. 
"Something tells me inside that the bombing is just a precursor to the terror that may come," wrote Donluciano. "Not only in Bali, but worldwide. Iraq, Europe, Israel, you can expect some very wicked things to come." 
There was a quick reply, though, from Ptclouds: "A bit extreme?"
