HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: THE ECONOMY; 
Indonesian Finance Chief Warns Of Need for More Foreign Aid

BYLINE:  By WAYNE ARNOLD 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, Oct. 17 

 BODY:
Indonesia's finance minister warned today that the deadly bomb blast in Bali last weekend would force the government deeper into the red next year, raising the cost to the international community of keeping Indonesia afloat.
 Indonesia still relies on foreign aid to recover from the Asian financial crisis of 1997 and 1998. In addition to a $5 billion economic rescue package administered by the International Monetary Fund, it counts on billions of dollars a year in deficit financing from a group of international donors that includes the World Bank, the United States and Japan. 
 Indonesia had forecast a budget deficit next year equivalent to 1.3 percent of its gross domestic product, down from 2.5 percent this year, and had been expected to ask donors for $3 billion in new aid.
That number is now likely to be higher, said Finance Minister Boediono. Earlier this week, Finance Ministry officials acknowledged that the tragedy on Bali would force the government to miss its budget deficit target this year. Mr. Boediono's statements today suggested a more lasting effect. 
The monetary fund, the World Bank and other key donors postponed a meeting scheduled for this month until early next year in order to determine the impact of the attack. "We are working with the government to assess the real economic effects of the attack and to anticipate any additional needs arising from it," said Andrew Steer, World Bank country director for Indonesia.
The consensus among foreign investors, economists and executives, though, is that the attack will have a muted impact on Indonesia's economy. Tourism will suffer and foreign investment will be put off, but the shock value of the attack is low for the business community, which has witnessed five years of intermittent violence and threats in Indonesia, they said. "It's seen a number of these surprises, but they aren't by themselves going to cause people to leave," said Charlie Taylor, president director of McKinsey Indonesia. 
Indonesia's tourism industry represents as much as 5 percent of its economy, and Bali is its most important tourist gateway, accounting for 40 percent of all foreign arrivals last year, according to the Indonesian statistics bureau. The Consultative Group on Indonesia, representing Indonesia's biggest foreign donors, said it would hold an informal meeting in two weeks to discuss the possibility of emergency aid to Bali.
In a report issued on Wednesday, Desmond Supple, managing director of Barclays Capital in Singapore, noted that tourism's contribution to the economy has been declining, and that historical trends reveal that tourism will decline only so far in response to violence. During riots in Indonesia's cities in 1998, foreign arrivals fell by only about 11 percent.
A greater risk, according to Barclays, is a drop in foreign investment as companies recoil from Indonesia's political risks. Executives in Jakarta dispute this, however, saying that foreign inflows have already fallen so far that only the most intrepid investors remain interested in Indonesia, many of them oil and mining companies to whom terrorism is a familiar risk.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Profit and Revenue Rise In Quarter for Microsoft
Microsoft reported a strong quarter with both profits and revenue up sharply at a time when the economy is weak and technology spending is depressed. Revenue grew 26 percent, to $7.75 billion. Operating profit increased 40 percent, to $4 billion, and net income more than doubled, to $2.7 billion, or 50 cents a share.
 Microsoft gained from customers rushing to sign up for a new licensing program, but its performance also showed that it was succeeding in persuading personal computer makers and users to buy the larger and more costly business version of Windows. Page C4. 

Sun Microsystems announced that it would lay off 4,400 employees, and it reported a loss of $111 million, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter. Revenue was $2.7 billion, down 4 percent. C3.

Foreign Sales Help Philip Morris
Earnings at Philip Morris increased in the third quarter, largely on the strength of sales in foreign markets. Net income rose to $4.36 billion, or $2.06 a share, compared with $2.33 billion, or $1.06 a share, in the period a year earlier. Revenue decreased 1.7 percent, to $19.9 billion, from $20.25 billion. C2.

Rules Proposed on Tax Shelters
The Treasury and the Internal Revenue Service are proposing rules to force high-income people and corporations to disclose their use of potentially abusive tax shelters. C2.

Auction Revenue Increases at EBay
EBay, the Internet auction site, said revenue from transactions increased 73 percent in the quarter, to nearly $264 million. C3.

Deal Near on Terrorism Insurance
Administration officials and lawmakers have reached a tentative agreement on legislation to provide up to $100 billion in support to the insurance industry for terrorist attacks. A11.

Delta Air Lines Plans More Layoffs
Delta Air Lines announced plans to cut 7,000 to 8,000 more jobs. In addition, Continental, Northwest and America West reported losses for the quarter; Southwest had a profit. C4.

Sales and Income Increase at Nokia
Nokia, the world's largest cellphone maker, reported third-quarter net income of $598.8 million, up from $182.6 million in the comparable quarter a year earlier. Sales for the period grew 2 percent, to $7.1 billion. Though its sales ticked up only slightly in the third quarter, Nokia managed to triple its net income from the period a year ago. Analysts said the results show how efficiently Nokia controls its costs and negotiates prices with suppliers. World Business, Section W.

First Boston May Face Complaint
Massachusetts regulators who have been investigating Credit Suisse First Boston and its research practices are expected to file an administrative complaint against the firm, according to someone close to the inquiry. C10.

EMC Reports $21 Million Profit
EMC, a supplier of data storage systems, reported a quarterly profit of $21 million because of a one-time overseas tax benefit. C3.

Cranberry Ads Take Health Angle
Cranberries are the latest fruit to order up a multimillion-dollar publicity campaign using health as a selling point. The Cranberry Marketing Committee has hired Publicis Dialog U.S. to promote the fruit. Advertising. C4.

HEADLINE: Jobless Rate In City Hits 8-Month Low 

BYLINE:  By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
New York City's unemployment rate dropped sharply in September, to 7.1 percent from 7.6 percent, its lowest level since January, the New York State Department of Labor announced today. 
 But economists were not ready to break out the party hats and confetti, even though the unemployment rate, which is adjusted for seasonal fluctuations, has fallen every month since June. 
 One reason for their hesitation is that the unemployment rate is based on a very small survey of households, and many economists consider it somewhat unreliable in the short term. 
More important, companies added only about 19,400 jobs in September, which is usually a strong month for hiring (over the last 10 years the private sector job count has risen by an average of 26,200). So after adjusting for seasonal factors, employment was basically flat, said Barbara Byrne Denham, chief economist for the newsletter The New York STAT. 
Despite the dire news on Wall Street (and from Wall Street firms), employment in the securities business dropped by only 300, Ms. Denham said, adding that the small size of the loss may well be a statistical fluke. The method economists use to adjust for seasonal factors assumes that Wall Street follows its traditional practice of hiring a lot of interns in the summer and laying them all off in the fall; that did not happen this year.
Employment in the securities business and financial services remains the driver of the city's economy, said Jason Bram, an economist at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. "Until we those those turn up -- or a lot of other things turn up, which would be nice, too -- it's pretty hard to get excited about a drop in the unemployment rate," he said.
But there were bright spots in the data released yesterday. Tourism-related jobs increased, especially at restaurants, and employment continued to rise in areas like health care, education and social services, said James P. Brown, who analyzes the New York City economy for the State Labor Department.
Local government employment fell sharply, which Mr. Brown attributed to seasonal layoffs of people who had worked at summer jobs.
Business services, a grab bag of industries from advertising to temporary-help agencies, is showing signs of firming after months of steep losses. "We're not going back to dancing-in-the-streets buoyancy," Mr. Brown said. "But baby steps first."

HEADLINE: Sears Earnings Will Be Hurt By Credit Unit 

BYLINE:  By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
Sears, Roebuck, midway through a crucial effort to attract more shoppers to its stores, said yesterday that its credit division had suffered unexpected losses from delinquent cardholders that would depress earnings for the rest of the year. 
 Sears said its earnings for the third quarter would be higher than last year but still 26 percent below the company's prediction made earlier this month. For the full year, earnings will total $4.86 a share, down from $5.15 forecast at the same time. 
 "There's no question that this is a setback," said Alan J. Lacy, the chairman and chief executive of Sears, calling the results "a difficult situation for all of us." 
Wall Street, surprised at the extent of the credit losses, pounded the stock, which posted one of its biggest one-day drops as it fell $10.80, or almost 32 percent, to close at $23.15. A long-planned analysts' meeting yesterday at the Sears headquarters in Hoffman Estates, Ill., where Sears had hoped to impress investors with its plans for Lands' End and other merchandise, turned into a grilling of senior management over the extent of the credit difficulties. 
"They could have done this a week and a half ago," fumed Marie Driscoll, a retail analyst for Argus Research in New York. "You start to question management's credibility."
Most of the credit trouble seems to be rooted in the Gold MasterCard program that Sears began offering two years ago. The company was betting that catering to more upscale customers with check-writing privileges and low-interest transfers of old debt to the new cards, would bring in profits to help sustain its stumbling retail stores. 
But instead, with the economy soured, Sears now finds itself caught in the worst of both worlds: its credit division, which accounts for 60 percent of earnings, will cost the company an additional $222 million in uncollectible charges for the third quarter alone, and its stores have yet to turn themselves around. 
At the meeting, Mr. Lacy said that the head of credit operations, Kevin Keleghan, who was dismissed over what Sears called a "credibility" problem earlier this month, had materially misled senior management about the the condition of the credit division. Mr. Lacy, who made a name for himself turning around the credit division in the late 1990's, said that the risk manager had been dismissed as well. He would not identify the executive, but the Nilson Report, which tracks the credit industry, identified him as K. R. Vishwanath.
Mr. Lacy told analysts that the company planned to tighten its requirements for MasterCard applications. According to the Nilson Report, the company expects to sign up 5.5 million new cardholders this year, 2 million of those from direct mail. Of the company's credit card receivables, 37 percent is from MasterCard and 63 percent is the Sears store credit card, a spokeswoman said. Although MasterCard represents fewer cardholders, experts said their balances were probably far higher than those of the Sears cardholders.
"We have some things that haven't gone as well as we would like them to," Mr. Lacy said in an interview. "We have done a lot to mitigate that already."
He added: "The average credit quality on our MasterCard portfolio is quite good, and much higher than our average proprietary card. Our growth in MasterCard is attracting better-quality customers."
Other leading consumer lenders, including Citigroup and J. P. Morgan Chase, reported strong growth last quarter, suggesting that Sears, whose credit cards are backed by its Sears National Bank subsidiary, has attracted a weaker pool of applicants than some of its competitors. Sears offered a 2.9 annual percentage rate for new cardholders, and included checks at the same rate if used by Jan. 15 of next year. It had issued 25.8 million MasterCards through the end of last year, and it is the second- biggest MasterCard issuer, behind Citigroup. Its profits from credit cards totaled $1.5 billion last year, according to the Nilson Report. 
Investors also punished other retailers with large credit card operations. Target Stores fell $1.32, to close at $29.51, and Kohl's declined $2.16, to close at $55.11, although both have more conservative credit policies than Sears. 
"Credit is a four-letter word in retail these days," said Emme P. Kozloff, a retail analyst with Sanford C. Bernstein & Company. 
While Sears executives blamed Mr. Keleghan for hiding information and insisted they would be able to increase profits from credit despite all the bad news, analysts were skeptical.
"Some of the strategy they laid out for growing the portfolio we found to be a bit unconvincing," said Roz Bryant, a retail analyst for Morningstar in Chicago. "They talked about leveraging the retail business and getting customers to sign up and spend more in the Sears stores." 
Sears already uses its credit program to promote big-ticket items in its stores, offering shoppers a "zero pay" deal in which they pay nothing for 12 months -- a move that one analyst, Howard K. Mason of Sanford C. Bernstein, said could distort delinquency rates. The company is also considered aggressive for its accounting of the money it is owed by cardholders; Sears is not governed by the same rules as banks, and moves those receivables into its corporate accounts. 
Mr. Lacy said comparisons to banks were "irrelevant," and added that the system gave Sears "tremendous financial flexibility."
With the stores still in a makeover period -- with renovations under way that are intended to make them more appealing to shoppers -- relying on them for credit growth may be difficult to pull off, Ms. Bryant said. "They are expecting to be able to woo a lot of their appliance customers over to Lands' End," she said, "but it is a little troubling to think of how they will do that."
Lands' End, which Sears acquired in a $1.9 billion deal in May, is featuring $138 cashmere sweaters and $88 parkas, she added, prices above what the typical Sears customer looks for. 
"The consumer doesn't necessarily know what to expect," said Michael Green, a retail expert with Cap Gemini Ernst & Young. "They are integrating the Lands' End acquisition, and that's got to create some distractions. Then they are introducing a line of apparel with a lower price point to compete with Target and Wal-Mart." The new lines are intended to draw shoppers who are not the typical Sears customer, who is 50-ish and less concerned about fashion than about value. 
Mr. Lacy said the economy was to blame for some of the delinquencies, while others were a result of the MasterCard program's hitting its second anniversary. For many credit card issuers, delinquency rates peak within 18 to 24 months, said Anita Boomstein, a lawyer specializing in credit programs. "After accounts have matured, you start to get a spike in charge-offs," she said, using the industry term for accounts that cannot be collected. 
At the same time, MasterCards may have been issued to consumers whose ability to pay may not have been as sound as Sears anticipated. Layoffs and cutbacks in various industries have increased the risk at the same time, Mr. Green said. 
"You have people hanging on by their fingernails, and it will continue to drift down until this economy really takes a hard turn," he said. "People who lost their jobs two or three months ago probably had some savings, but at some point they are going to stop paying their bills."
One sign of increased credit risk is a leap in the use of credit cards for cash advances, Ms. Boomstein said. "Most issuers watch that very carefully," she said. "And this stuff doesn't sneak up on you in two weeks. It should have been obvious to all of them." 
Mr. Lacy said that the credit business had cycles and that Sears would work them out. "We've got lots of risk techniques we can use to manage through this," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Stocks Climb as Investor Gloom Appears to Ease

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Stocks rose more than 2 percent yesterday while bond prices continued their slide, indicating that investors may be losing some of their gloom over the economy. In the last six trading days, longer-term interest rates have risen nearly two-thirds of a percentage point, while the Dow Jones industrial average has climbed 13.6 percent.
 The interest rate rise has pushed mortgage rates higher and if it persists would slow the refinancing and housing boom that has helped the economic recovery bump along. 
 But over all the rise in Treasury yields could be positive to the extent it reflects a decline in the economic and geopolitical fears that had gripped investors.
"In this climate, it is a sign that some of the excessive fear has unwound," said Robert V. DiClemente, chief United States economist at Salomon Smith Barney. 
James E. Glassman, senior United States economist at J. P. Morgan, echoed that view. "If rates are going up because it looks like the economy is doing better," he said, "that's great."
The slide in bonds yesterday came as stocks bounced back from Wednesday's sell-off. The Dow rose 3.2 percent, to close at 8,275.04; the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 2.2 percent; and the Nasdaq composite index finished up 3.2 percent. Positive earnings reports from I.B.M. and Eastman Kodak and a government report showing a 13.3 percent surge in housing starts in September helped stocks rise yesterday after a bunch of negative earnings reports pushed equities lower Wednesday.
But only the Dow managed to reclaim all of Wednesday's losses and then some, winding up almost 20 points above Tuesday's close.
After the stock market closed Microsoft raised its earnings and sales forecast for the year ending June 30, sending its stock up 3 percent in after-hours trading and, possibly, laying the groundwork for another stock rally today.
Still, the market could continue to be volatile because investors are uncertain about the outlook. This makes it easy for a positive earnings report to push the market higher one day even as a negative one can drag it lower the next. Lingering doubts about the strength of the recovery mean a surprising economic report can kill a rally or start a new one. And big developments on Iraq and terrorism will always be market movers.
Whether this high volatility -- in which the S.& P. 500-stock index has risen or fallen by 2 percent or more on 9 of the 13 trading days this month -- is a signal that the stock market has finally hit bottom and started to turn up remains unclear.
The Chicago Board Options Exchange index of volatility hit its most recent high on Oct. 9, the day before stocks began their rally. Now that index is falling again. But this same volatility indicator hit a high on July 23, the day before the stock market turned around the last time. The Dow than rallied to 9,053.64 before plunging again.
In the bond market the yield on the Treasury's 10-year note was at 4.20 percent in late trading yesterday, up from 4.05 percent Wednesday and a 44-year low of 3.57 percent on Oct. 9. The price, which moves in the opposite direction, fell 1 8/32, to 101 12/32.
The yield on the Treasury's two-year note was at 2.15 percent, up from 2.01 percent Wednesday and 1.67 percent on Oct. 9.
The surge in the yield on the 10-year note is the fastest six-day increase since November of last year and the fourth fastest since 1986.
Mortgage rates, which are influenced by the 10-year note, have also risen. The average national rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage was 6.15 percent this week, up from 5.98 percent last week, according to Freddie Mac, the mortgage lender.
But Ian Shepherdson, chief United States economist for High Frequency Economics, is not worried. "Even at this level you can easily say that mortgage rates are stimulative," he said. "In order to dampen down mortgage activity, mortgage rates have to go above 7 percent."
A sell-off in bonds is common when stocks rally. But this sell-off also indicated that some investors had decided that the strength in the bond market had gone too far, with bonds priced as if investors were expecting more weak earnings, slower economic growth, perhaps even a double-dip recession, and the near-certainty of a war with Iraq that would push oil prices higher.
"The Treasury market has been the lightning rod for everything bad and had taken yields to lows that made no sense unless the world falls apart," Mr. DiClemente said. "So when you get a whiff of normalcy, it unwinds."
One sign of the change in attitude is that on Wednesday, when the stock market fell sharply, bond prices also fell, pushing yields higher. This selling of bonds while stocks were falling broke the recent pattern of bond prices going up when stocks decline sharply.
Another indication of the changing investor mood in the bond market is that expectations for another rate cut by the Federal Reserve are fading. On Sept. 30, the yield on the November futures contract on the federal funds rate, which is the central bank's benchmark interest rate, showed that investors thought there was a 96 percent chance of a quarter-point rate cut in November. Those odds have plunged to 18 percent. The odds of a quarter-point rate cut in December are now down to 44 percent; there had been a 65 percent chance of a half-point rate cut on Sept. 30.
"What some people seem to understand," Mr. Glassman said, "is that if the stock market is doing better it will be positive for the economy."
The spreads, or difference, between the yield on corporate bonds and Treasury securities have also narrowed in the last few days, another sign of reduced investor tension.
In the stock market, the Dow rose 239.01 points, to 8,275.04. The S.& P. 500 climbed 19.18 points, to 879.20, finishing 2 points below Tuesday's close. The Nasdaq rose 39.87 points, to 1,272.29, which was 10 points from Tuesday's close.
I.B.M. said after the close of trading Wednesday that it had profits from continuing operations of 99 cents a share, beating Wall Street estimates by 3 cents and offsetting some of the negative news from Intel's earnings report late Tuesday. I.B.M.'s stock jumped $7.30, or 11.3 percent, to $72.20 and was the biggest contributor to yesterday's rally in the Dow. Intel, after plunging 18 percent Wednesday, climbed 69 cents, or 5.1 percent, to $14.23.
Kodak contributed to the upbeat mood on Wall Street when it disclosed yesterday that it expected its third-quarter earnings to be $1.04 a share on an operating basis, well above Wall Street estimates of 73 cents. But Kodak said that it expected sales in the fourth quarter to be flat and that profits would falter at 60 cents to 70 cents a share. The Wall Street consensus estimate is 66 cents a share. Kodak jumped $2.09, or 6.9 percent, to $32.44.
Among the negative earnings reports yesterday, Sears, Robuck lowered its 2002 forecast 5.6 percent, to $4.86 a share from $5.15, and set aside $222 million for uncollectible loans to its credit card users. The revision of 2002 earnings came just 10 days after the higher number was reaffirmed. Sears plunged $10.80, or 31.8 percent, to $23.15.
And that leaves a puzzle still to be solved. The news from Sears and weak sales at other retailers like Wal-Mart Stores should keep investors wondering if consumer spending is slowing down. If so, that would put a big drag on the economy and future corporate earnings.

HEADLINE: A Vestige of King Cotton Fades Out in Mississippi 

BYLINE:  By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: PORT GIBSON, Miss., Oct. 13 

 BODY:
The Port Gibson Oil Mill died in June. The steam whistle that once summoned all 50 workers at 7 every morning -- and woke everyone else in town -- is silent. The day-and-night din of machines crushing cottonseeds is gone, and with it the comforting odor of the seeds cooking. The big tractor trailers have all moved on.
 The mill ran for 120 years, which townspeople say is longer than any other cotton-oil mill anywhere. It was the town's biggest private employer, its biggest taxpayer and the last vestige of an industry that once made Port Gibson one of the richest little towns in America. Shutting it down, said Emma Crisler, editor and publisher of the weekly Port Gibson Reveille, "is like losing a piece of your soul." 
 The Archer Daniels Midland Company of Decatur, Ill., the agribusiness behemoth and the mill's owner for the past 11 years, closed it with two weeks' notice, then filed a request to demolish it. "There was overcapacity in the industry," said Larry Cunningham, senior vice president at Archer Daniels. "The Port Gibson facility was less efficient, smaller and older than other facilities. Market conditions dictated survival of the fittest, which unfortunately did not include Port Gibson." 
This town of 1,840 between Natchez and Vicksburg, eight miles east of the Mississippi, is fighting back. It has thwarted the demolition, at least for now, and local business owners are searching for someone to revive the mill. Failing that, civic leaders would use it for some other purpose, like a museum. "We want A.D.M. to donate it to the city," Mayor Amelda J. Arnold said. "But A.D.M. wants a piece of change."
Port Gibson is 80 percent black, and poor. Twenty percent of the families have incomes less than $10,000 a year, the 2000 Census found. About 10 percent of the work force is unemployed. It has an entrenched population of whites, many of whom are related and have some historical connection to cotton.
"My husband's family and mine have not moved more than 50 miles since 1763, when the British first acquired the area," Martha Lum, a widow, said. Her forebears were early investors in the mill, and for many years her father was president of the board. She fought the sale of the mill to Archer Daniels and lost.
An assemblage of immense sheds and tanks sheathed in gray metal on 10 acres behind a chain-link fence, the mill is just a five-minute walk from the Claiborne County courthouse. By all accounts, it was a good neighbor. There is no record of complaints about the trucks or the odor. It paid most workers $8 to $9 an hour, a good wage here. With new investment in plant and machinery, said C. Y. Katzenmier, 93, for many years the general manager, "they almost doubled the capacity."
But cottonseed oil has become a troublesome commodity. Once the only widely used vegetable oil, it has lost ground to soybean and corn oils. The supply of cottonseeds has declined as dairies have begun feeding the seed to cows. "Cotton oil production has declined 30 or 40 percent in the last 12 years," said Ben Morgan, executive vice president of the National Cottonseed Products Association in Memphis.
No one here has tallied up the toll of the closing. The city is losing $10,000 in local taxes, a sizeable chunk of its budget. It has also lost its biggest water and gas customer. Local plumbers, electricians and machine repairmen have lost their best customer. Only one employee, Jerry Messer, 48, a former shift foreman who started at the mill in 1979, remains. He keeps it secure and cuts the grass. 
"I'm the last man standing between me and those pigeons," Mr. Messer said. "Before, this mill never shut down unless we ran out of seeds. It was a good place. They never laid anybody off that didn't want to be laid off." 
Some other former workers have found lower paying jobs; some have found nothing. Percy McGloster, 52, worked in the ancient seed-crushing building. "Ain't no jobs around here," he said. Like other workers, he received severance of a week's wages for every year worked up to 21 years, and two months' health insurance. 
Mr. McGloster's wife Derdira, 39, is a cashier at the M & M grocery store in town. They have a daughter, Brittany, 11. Mr. McGloster had a two-minute walk to the mill from the 16-by-80-foot mobile home that the McGlosters bought in March. They could soon lose it because of the payments.
"I started working there when I was 19," Mr. McGloster said. "My daddy worked there. He worked there for 50 years. He loved that oil mill. He used to love to hear that old whistle blow." 
At work one day in late May, Mr. McGloster said, "They said, 'You all get yourselves together' in the clapboard office. 'We're going to close it down,' they said. They said the mill wasn't putting out enough production. It didn't make sense. We were putting out good production. We were booming."
"It was a hurting thing to walk in there and tell my wife I didn't have a job any more," Mr. McGloster said. "You know a husband, he always got to be strong. Even when you're hurting, you got to act like things aren't hurting." 
Some people attribute the plant's demise to a bitterly fought decision among the heirs of early investors to sell it in 1991. The mill's last general manager, James Beesley, 80, acquired close to a third of the stock and negotiated the sale. One group of heirs, including Mrs. Lum, delayed the sale while less partial investors reviewed it.
In the end, said Robert D. Gage IV, chief executive of the River Hills Bank in Port Gibson, "We felt it was in the best interests of the shareholders to sell, but to negotiate a better price." Most went along, and Archer Daniels accepted a price of $430 a share, or about $4 million. 
"A.D.M. committed to operate it for the foreseeable future," Mr. Beesley said. "They operated it for 10 years. I guess you can say that's more than the foreseeable future."
There is still some hope for the mill. It lies within the city's historic district, so the company needs the approval of the Port Gibson Historic Preservation Commission to alter its buildings. On July 26, Archer Daniels filed its request to demolish the mill. On Aug. 6, a company official met with local officials. " 'If we tear everything down,' they said, 'we will give you the whistle,' " said Joan Beesley, president of the commission and Mr. Beesley's wife.
"But that's not the way the process works," said Alton C. Hollingsworth, who manages an organization that is restoring the downtown. "With demolition, you have to see if there are other uses first." So Archer Daniels proposed selling the mill to the city for $750,000 and claiming a charitable contribution of $3 million. 
"The city doesn't have $750,000," Mrs. Beesley said. Mayor Arnold said,"In my opinion, they should give it all to the city and have a bigger tax write-off." 
Mr. Gage and other business leaders, meanwhile, have found two oil mill operators in Mississippi who have shown interest in reviving the mill. "I've tried to contact A.D.M.," he said, "but they will not return my phone calls."
The company, Mayor Arnold said, "doesn't want the competition."
Mr. Cunningham of Archer Daniels said, "We're open to ideas and suggestions."

HEADLINE: Senate Follows House on the Road Out of Washington and Plans to Return on Nov. 12 

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE and DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 

 BODY:
Congress called it quits today, as both parties gambled that they would be in a stronger legislative position next month after the elections that will determine control of the House and Senate.
 Lawmakers, who had joined together after the Sept. 11 attacks, recessed to campaign after the drive to create a new agency to combat terror threats died in recriminations over the motives of each side. 
 Unable to make progress on the domestic security initiative, the Senate threw in the towel on the measure, as well as most other pending business, joining House members who left town on Wednesday night after agreeing to finance federal agencies through Nov. 22 and return in mid-November. 
Both sides quickly seized on the stalemate as a campaign issue. Republicans said the Democrat-controlled Senate had failed to deliver. 
"Shame on the Senate," Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the second-ranking Republican, said as he stood in front of sign attributing the unfinished business to the Democrats. "This kind of leadership is unacceptable, particularly when you put the nation's security at risk."
Democrats said Republicans had failed to give enough attention to a faltering economy.
"The Republican House left town on a one-way ticket to the campaign trail without addressing people's most pressing economic problems, which are happening in their lives every day," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader.
Others said voters would be correct to wonder about the relevance of a Congress that left so much undone. 
"The American people have a right to ask some tough questions about who is doing what and who is objecting to what," said Senator Byron L. Dorgan, Democrat of North Dakota. 
The drive to create a Homeland Security Department is now over, at least until after Nov. 5 and, perhaps, until next year. Democrats and Republicans refused to budge on workers' rights. 
That bill was just one of a raft of domestic initiatives left hanging.
Senators said they would continue to work on outstanding issues. But for all intents and purposes, the session was suspended until a postelection return, scheduled for Nov. 12. House officials said it was doubtful that members would be called back for a vote on any agreement other than one on a domestic security agency, even though negotiators seemed near a deal today on government-backed terror insurance.
House and Senate leaders have said that besides 11 of 13 annual spending bills, the postelection Congress would probably take up the domestic security agency, terror insurance, an overhaul of the federal bankruptcy law, military policy and, perhaps, an energy bill. Aides said other contentious issues like a Medicare prescription drug benefit would probably be left for the next Congress. 
Some lawmakers held out hope that the midterm election could prompt a breakthrough on the domestic security bill. Others said that issue might be put off, too.
Republicans refused to create the department unless President Bush was given the right to cut Civil Service protections and erase union work rules. Democrats refused to create the agency without a guarantee that workers' rights would remain difficult to change.
"It's not going to happen," said Senator Phil Gramm, Republican of Texas, who blocked a vote on the issue today. "The Democrats have killed homeland security between now and the election."
The lame-duck session is scheduled to start a week after the elections that could shift power in both the House and the Senate. The session should also feature lawmakers who could be in their final days, depending on the polling results. If Senator Jean Carnahan, Democrat of Missouri, loses a special election, it is conceivable that Republicans could control the Senate in the session. 
The logjam has several origins, including the intense attention to a resolution on Iraq. The House and Senate were also never able to bridge their differences on spending, preventing Congress from performing the fundamental job of distributing money to agencies through appropriations bills.
Though some major bills made it to negotiations between the House and Senate, lawmakers were unable to hammer out final agreements. 
Here are some potential issues that could come up in a lame-duck session:

APPROPRIATIONS -- The House and Senate, separated by $9 billion out of a total budget of more than $750 billion, have passed two spending measures, both concerning the military. House Republicans have also fought among themselves about spending levels in some bills.
Legislative leaders say the spending measures would be a top priority of the session. But members of the Appropriations Committee say it would be highly unlikely if they could all be passed separately, raising the prospect of a measure to merge them. The biggest fight could occur over labor and health spending.

ENERGY -- A new policy was once a top goal of the White House, which last year issued a wide-ranging proposal calling for greater domestic fuel production and new conservation measures. The House and Senate took different approaches in their bills. Negotiations, while resolving some differences, have stalled over new rules for the electricity industry. Any proposal that would allow Arctic drilling could also doom the bill.
The bill's authors and segments of the energy industry that could gain new government benefits are eager to see a bill approved and may ultimately push to separate the provisions where there is agreement.

BANKRUPTCY LAW -- Early in the session, a bipartisan consensus seemed to form around the need to rewrite the bankruptcy code. Pressed by business and credit-card lobbyists, leaders of both parties had agreed to make it more difficult to file for personal bankruptcy. The measure stalled after Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, inserted a provision that would prevent anti-abortion protesters from escaping their court-imposed fines by declaring bankruptcy. Backers hope that it could still pass after the pressures of the election subside.

MILITARY -- Though Congress cleared a record military spending bill, it did not approve a separate Pentagon policy bill that spells out how to use some of that money, including a pay raise. The chief obstacle is a proposal to lift some environmental rules on the military and a provision backed by Congress that would let veterans collect both retirement pensions and disability pay. The White House has complained that the approach is too costly and threatened to veto the measure. Lawmakers hope to reach a solution after the election, particularly because the legislation would be important in the event of a conflict with Iraq.

HEADLINE: Bloomberg's Shift of Homeless to Hotels Alarms Some Neighborhoods 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH BERGER 

 BODY:
From Richmond Nelson's porch, the building across the street looks like just another hotel in a strip of five imposing hotels north of Kennedy International Airport, a place where you might find globetrotters resting for the night. The sign near the roof still says "Best Western." 
 But the travelers Mr. Nelson has seen arriving at the hotel since July have been more than 1,000 homeless people -- mothers and their children and a few fathers. They are ferried to his neighborhood after being evicted by their landlords or asked to leave by relatives weary of the crowding. 
 The city's homeless population has mushroomed by 13 percent since July 1 to 8,900 families -- the highest on record -- and forced the Bloomberg administration to take controversial measures like housing families in a vacant Bronx jail. 
But since taking over City Hall in January, the administration has also quietly set up 18 new shelters, some virtually overnight, for more than 1,200 families, usually by paying nonprofit social service providers $93 a night per room to place them in whatever failing or marginal hotels the providers could find. The total number of family shelters is now 124.
In response, there have been protests from neighbors and their political leaders across the city, in Fort Greene and Prospect Heights in Brooklyn, South Ozone Park and East Elmhurst in Queens and Hell's Kitchen in Manhattan. While some of the grievances have been of the not-in-my-backyard variety, the residents have also complained that the shelters were opened with no notice and little chance to have their voices heard.
Helen Marshall, the Queens borough president, learned of plans to convert the Best Western two weeks before it opened "through the community grapevine," never officially, said a spokesman, Daniel Andrews. And the first public hearing was not held until 11 days after the shelter's opening. A city councilman from Brooklyn, James E. Davis, recently introduced a bill requiring the agency for the homeless to give local public officials 60 days' notice before building or acquiring a shelter.
And homeowners like Mr. Nelson and other residents near the new shelters say their quiet streets have been ruffled by annoying incivilities. Homeowners opposite a former Best Western -- with more than 300 rooms, now the city's largest shelter -- say they have seen residents or their visitors drop beer bottles and fast-food cartons on their lawns, urinate behind their trees, have sex in cars alongside their sidewalks and play basketball in their backyards.
"The quality of life has just plummeted because the nature of a lot of the people that came in helps it go down," said Mr. Nelson, a 68-year-old retired high school teacher. "They don't have an inkling of our lifestyle here." There have also been complaints from area businesses. Marc Leffman, the general manager of the 386-room Radisson next door to the Best Western, said his hotel had lost contracts worth $750,000 for rooms for flight crews. "What I worry about is perception," he said. "And the perception is that if your neighbor is a homeless shelter, it's a haven for prostitutes and drug addicts and people who would pick your pockets."
City officials said court orders -- including one barring them from using the Bronx jail -- had given them no choice but to patch together the best accommodations that they could, and quickly. They blamed the upsurge in homeless families on rising unemployment and a tight housing market.
Linda I. Gibbs, the commissioner of homeless services, said that there would always be a "tremendous amount of community anxiety" and "transitional issues" when a shelter was introduced but that the department's experience was that neighbors eventually became supportive of the shelter residents. She acknowledged that little notice had been given to the neighborhoods affected, but she said she could not afford to provide "months of notice, with families awaiting shelter."
"We do not go in in the dark of night," she said. "We are responding to the demand we are experiencing, and we do not have the lxuury of providing long periods of notice."
Given a shortage of housing that can be paid for through federal subsidies, residents will probably stay at the shelter for an average of 11 months, officials said.
Some of the homeless mothers, like Cynthia Reed, said the neighborhood complaints were being blown out of proportion. Ms. Reed, a 45-year-old mother of two, was evicted from a $1,025-a-month apartment in East New York after she lost her job as a health aide.
"Some of these people don't realize they could be one paycheck away from being homeless," Ms. Reed said. "They look at us as being nobody because we're homeless."
The homeowners facing the Best Western, on 135th Avenue near the Van Wyck Expressway, sometimes sound like the white homeowners who decades ago resisted the arrival of minority families. "We see something like this decreasing our property values," said Leroy Reid, a retired Police Department property specialist who has lived in his clapboard house for 36 years and raised two daughters there. 
But most of the protesting homeowners are black, and several say most of the shelters were put in largely black and Hispanic neighborhoods. Ruth Bryant, president of a community organization, Southeast Queens Concerned Neighbors, said city officials seemed to think "the community won't make as much noise as some other communities, like Bayside and Forest Hills, which are not predominantly black."
Mr. Nelson said he learned about the move from a security guard at the Radisson. "It was kind of sprung on us," he said.
Responding to allegations that minority neighborhoods had been made targets for the shelters, James Anderson, a spokesman for the homeless agency, said, "We've opened facilities where facilities have become available."
In South Ozone Park, the conversion of the Best Western into what is now called Carlton House was done at the initiation of its owner, a partnership called JFK Acquisition Group. It filed for bankruptcy in November 2001, partly as a result of the decline in air travel after the terrorist attacks, and then, to help pay off creditors, it asked the Salvation Army if it would be interested in taking over the hotel. The Salvation Army is now negotiating a $71 million contract to manage Carlton House for another four years and nine months.
The organization has imposed an 11 p.m. curfew and posted two security guards at the 135th Avenue gate to make sure that only residents enter the hotel. Alfred Peck, the Salvation Army's director of social services for families and adults, said one security guard was dismissed for fraternizing with a resident outside the hotel. He suggested that the homeowners' complaints exaggerated problems, saying in five nights of sitting with security guards that the worst thing he had seen was someone parked in a homeowner's driveway.
Residents at Carlton House, who spend much of their days inside their rooms watching big-bellied jets lumber into the sky, said the rules made them feel as if they were confined to a prison.
"I've never committed a crime, but I feel like a criminal," said one mother of two, who asked that her name not be used. "They call you by your room number instead of by your name."
Nearby homeowners said they had worked hard to raise children in houses that now sell for more than $200,000 and they did not want to struggle with unruly behavior. Mr. Reid's wife, who asked that her full name not be published, took pains to say, "We have nothing against these people, for there but the grace of God it could be us."
But she added: "We figured we'd retire, we'd lay back and enjoy ourselves. Now we're reluctant to leave our house."

HEADLINE: Pataki Viewed Favorably in Poll, Despite Qualms About Economy 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA and MARJORIE CONNELLY 

 BODY:
New Yorkers give Gov. George E. Pataki high marks over all, especially on his response to the World Trade Center attack and its aftermath, despite some misgivings about his handling of the economy, a New York Times poll shows.
 In his bid for a third term, Mr. Pataki is running strongly across geographic, ethnic and ideological lines, with less than three weeks until Election Day. While he is not faring quite as well as a Republican usually would upstate and among conservatives, he more than compensates with serious inroads into traditional Democratic voting blocs, like New York City voters, Hispanics and liberals -- all of which spells serious trouble for H. Carl McCall, his Democratic opponent. 
 The poll shows Mr. Pataki leading Mr. McCall, the state comptroller, by 11 percentage points among likely voters. The Times surveyed 860 registered voters in New York, with a sampling error of plus or minus three percentage points. Of those judged likely to vote, the sampling error is plus or minus five percentage points on each candidate. 
Among registered voters, 64 percent approve of the governor's performance in office, against 27 percent who disapprove -- a rating that is near his all-time high. He wins his best grades, by far, for his handling of the World Trade Center attack. Approval of his response is 83 percent, and on his handling of the recovery, 71 percent approve.
Voters rate him moderately well on areas like the environment, education and cutting taxes, though no more than a small fraction say he has made "a lot of progress" in any of those areas.
But New Yorkers take a lukewarm view of Mr. Pataki's economic record -- an area that weighs heavily on their minds, with 55 percent rating New York's economy as "fairly bad" or "very bad." When asked what the next governor should focus on, two out of five voters said the economy or unemployment. Twice as many people named the economy or unemployment as a priority for the next governor to focus on as named education, the highest priority four years ago.
Only 47 percent of voters approve of Mr. Pataki's handling of economic development, against 39 percent who disapprove. On creating jobs and taming the state's large debt, nearly half the voters surveyed say Mr. Pataki has made "not much" progress or "none at all."
Perhaps most striking, more than half of all voters say they believe that their taxes will be raised, whether Mr. Pataki or Mr. McCall wins on Nov. 5. 
In one warning sign for the governor, by a small margin, 49 percent to 42 percent, more voters say they think Mr. Pataki will be more interested in helping "special interests" than ordinary people, while the opposite is true of Mr. McCall. Thirty-seven percent say they think Mr. McCall will favor special interests, while 46 percent think he will favor ordinary people.
Among likely voters, 39 percent say they would vote for Mr. Pataki, to 28 percent for Mr. McCall and 16 percent for Tom Golisano, the Independence Party nominee. When undecided voters are pressed to say which way they are leaning and are added to the totals, Mr. Pataki receives 42 percent, Mr. McCall 31 percent and Mr. Golisano 17 percent, while 8 percent remain undecided.
Mr. Golisano does best among voters upstate, where the concerns about the economy are strongest. Upstate, 40 percent favor Mr. Pataki, 17 percent are for Mr. McCall and 21 percent are for Mr. Golisano. But the governor is at 50 percent in the New York City suburbs, and only 26 percent in the city itself.
"This poll, like every other public poll, demonstrated again that Governor Pataki has strong, broad support and will be elected in November," said Michael McKeon, a spokesman for the Pataki campaign.
But Steven Greenberg, a McCall campaign spokesman, said the survey was cause for optimism in his camp. "This shows that there's an incredible amount of room for growth in Carl's numbers," he said. "What we have to do is bring Democrats home, and I think they will come home in droves, because people are just starting to focus on this race."
Ernest C. Baynard, a spokesman for Mr. Golisano, said the poll did not accurately reflect Mr. Golisano's strength upstate and the candidate's gains among New York City residents, particularly Latinos and African-Americans.
The Times poll draws with unforgiving clarity the weaknesses of Mr. McCall, who has been badly outspent on two sides, and has often seemed slow and unfocused in responding to the governor's attacks.
Most important, he has yet to establish his identity in voters' minds. By a 2-to-1 ratio, voters who know of him have a favorable opinion of him. But tellingly, after he has spent nine years in statewide office and more than a year running for governor, half of all voters say they either do not have a firm opinion of Mr. McCall or do not know enough about him to establish one.
When his supporters are asked what they like best about Mr. McCall, by far the most common response, at 28 percent, is his party affiliation -- a sign of just how unfocused he remains in the public eye. Only 6 percent of Mr. Pataki's supporters say party is what they like best about him.
Mr. McCall has been unable to solidify his support among traditional Democratic groups, and he has the backing of only about half of all registered Democrats. In New York City, he has the support of 47 percent of voters, far below what a Democrat needs to win statewide. He has a statistically insignificant lead among the Hispanic voters the governor has courted aggressively.
Outside New York City, Mr. McCall is merely running even with Mr. Golisano, with the support of fewer than one-fifth of upstate and suburban voters -- an extraordinarily weak position for a Democrat.
That Mr. Pataki has not turned the race into a runaway is testament both to New York's inherent Democratic tilt and to the presence of Mr. Golisano, attacking the governor from the right.
Follow-up interviews with some of the voters surveyed provided a sense of the odd political alignments in a race that has a Republican running largely on liberal themes.
When asked why she supports Mr. Pataki, Mary Pembleton, a Democrat, first cited the state's programs to expand health care coverage, especially for children -- some of the most liberal steps the governor has taken. "He took enough concern to promote that for kids who didn't have any medical coverage," said Ms. Pembleton, 56, a secretary who lives in Cornwall, in the Hudson Valley.
"He was very good with 9/11," she added. "He was trying to help everybody -- the smallest right up to the big corporate people who lost their office space and everything. He tried to get everyone back to work."
Ms. Pembleton had very little to say about Mr. McCall, except that "he doesn't seem like he can provide enough."
David Hartman, a registered Republican, is one of many New Yorkers who worry about economic issues and have turned to Mr. Golisano, the billionaire businessman from Rochester.
"Pataki has said that taxes would go down, but our net taxes have gone up and we're retired and we're feeling sort of the pinch of the times, so I'd like to see a businessman in there," said Mr. Hartman, 83, a retired engineer who lives in Manlius, in central New York. "I don't think he's been a bad governor, but he certainly has not fulfilled his promises, and I think it's time for a change. McCall would be my second choice, frankly."
The challengers' attempts to get voters' attention have produced limited results. Only 8 percent of voters say they watched or listened to the first debate among the candidates last Sunday. About one in five say they have not seen Mr. Golisano's ubiquitous television ads.
Mr. McCall has called for the closing of the Indian Point nuclear power plant, and criticized the governor for not moving in that direction. But only one-third of voters say their choice for governor would be influenced by the candidates' positions on Indian Point, and they are almost evenly split between those who favor the plant and those who oppose it.
Three-quarters of voters say they think the quality of New York's schools has deteriorated or stayed about the same over the last four years, suggesting that they agree with one of Mr. McCall's central themes. Yet 61 percent give Mr. Pataki credit for at least some progress on education.
Voters overwhelmingly favor changing the state's Rockefeller-era drug laws, to end long mandatory prison sentences for low-level offenses, give judges more discretion in sentencing, and use treatment as an alternative to prison in some cases. Seventy-nine percent favor changing the law, and 83 percent think drug rehabilitation should be an option.

How Statewide Poll Was Conducted
The latest New York Times poll of New York State is based on telephone interviews conducted Oct. 12 to 16 with 1,103 adults throughout the state. Of those, 860 said they were registered to vote. Interviews were conducted in either English or Spanish.
The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges across the state. For each exchange, the telephone numbers were formed by random digits, thus permitting access to both listed and unlisted numbers. Within each household, one adult was designated by a random procedure to be the respondent for the survey.
The results have been weighted to take account of household size and the number of telephone lines into the residence, and to adjust for variations in the sample relating to region of the state, race, Hispanic origin, sex, age and education.
In addition, the question about voting preference if the 2002 election for governor were being held today was based on "likely voters." Likely voters are those who say they voted in 2000 or 1998, further weighted so that those who reside in New York City make up 29 percent of the entire state, which is the city's typical share of total ballots cast on Election Day.
In theory, in 19 cases out of 20 the results based on such samples will differ by no more than three percentage points in either direction from what would have been obtained by seeking out all adult residents of New York State. For likely voters, the potential sampling error is five percentage points.
In addition to sampling error, the practical difficulties of conducting any survey of public opinion may introduce other sources of error into the poll. Differences in the wording and order of questions, for instance, can lead to somewhat varying results.

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: THE INSURANCE INDUSTRY; 
Tentative Deal Is Reported on $100 Billion in Aid to Insurers Facing Terror Claims

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON with JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 

 BODY:
After months of bickering, House and Senate negotiators said tonight that they were close to a final deal on legislation to provide up to $100 billion of support to the insurance industry for future terrorist attacks.
 Administration officials and Democratic and Republican lawmakers said that a tentative agreement had been reached but that the language of the legislation was still being completed. 
 The preliminary deal would provide federal assistance for the next three years and provide as much as $100 billion in aid. The legislation would require the federal government to pay 90 percent of future terrorism-related insurance claims when insurers exceed certain levels of loss. For the first year, federal aid would be given to individual insurers that have sustained losses equal to 7 percent of their premiums. The level would rise to 10 percent in the second year and 15 percent in the third year. 
The legislation would also give the treasury secretary the authority to seek repayments from the insurance industry if the government determined that it was able to bear those costs.
The agreement is the product of a year of lobbying by the nation's largest insurers, real estate developers and banks, which contended that because the government did not provide financial guarantees to stabilize the insurance market, it was slowing down projects and contributing to the economy's problems. Several labor groups also lobbied hard for the measure, and in recent months, President Bush spoke frequently about the need for swift Congressional action.
Still, reports of the insurance problem have been conflicting. While some well-known properties have had trouble obtaining low-cost insurance coverage for terrorist activities, many others have managed to obtain financing. 
Republican and Democratic lawmakers said they had agreed in principle to reconcile competing House and Senate measures but were still working out the language this evening.
"I'm very confident that we've got an agreement," said Senator Christopher J. Dodd of Connecticut, who led the negotiations for the Democrats through Wednesday night and this morning. "We haven't dotted every i and crossed every t, so I have to be cautious. But we have shaken hands."
A similar statement was issued by Representative Michael G. Oxley of Ohio, who led the negotiations for the Republicans. And a White House spokeswoman, Claire Buchen, issued a statement saying that the negotiators "have made a lot of progress" and were completing the details. 
"We're on the 1-yard line" said Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York. "This has been a long hard road, but the benefits to the economy of large cities like New York and nationally has made all the work worth it."
The legislation's prospects remained uncertain. The Senate could take up the measure as early as next week. But House members are gone for the last three weeks of the campaign season, so it is not clear that a vote can be taken before the members return for a session after the elections next month. 
Moreover, some Republican members were said to be angry that the preliminary deal reached by the negotiators and the White House deleted a provision from a House bill that would have prohibited victims of terrorist attacks from seeking punitive damages from companies and real estate owners.
The provision on punitive damages had been sought by Republican lawmakers and the White House and was opposed by Democrats, most notably the Senate majority leader, Tom Daschle of South Dakota. 
A senior administration official said tonight that the White House was disappointed that the provision had been dropped but pleased that the legislation did not contain a counterproposal that he said would have expanded the ability of victims to win punitive awards.
The official also said that the bill would contain a provision requiring all cases arising from a terrorist attack to be consolidated in one federal court that would apply the law of the state where the attack occurred. As a result defendants in such cases, like property owners and insurers, would not have to face competing claims in different courts.
"The provisions will help workers, boost the economy, and improve the litigation process," the official said.
Among insurance company executives, the reaction to the tentative deal was delighted but cautious.
"We've heard the general outlines of the bill, and it sounds promising," said Julie Rochman, a spokeswoman for the American Insurance Association, a trade group in Washington that was a leader in the lobbying campaign. "But the operational details will be very important to our industry."
Wall Street analysts also hailed the legislation. But they suggested that since the insurers had already been including terrorism coverage for many small and medium-size businesses, while limiting coverage on the riskiest buildings, the legislation would probably not have a big impact on insurance stocks. Ronald Frank, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, called the legislation "a net positive."
Some consumer advocates criticized the legislation as a government giveaway to big business.
"This agreement will likely do far more for the insurance fat cats than the working hard hat," said J. Robert Hunter, the director of insurance for the Consumer Federation of America. 
With insurers likely to be responsible in the first year only for losses equal to about 7 percent of their premiums, Mr. Hunter said, "the taxpayer assistance would kick in at ridiculously low levels." 
Mr. Hunter also said the legislation -- by reducing the potential costs to the insurance industry of a major attack -- would reduce the industry's incentive to require businesses to take security measures that might deter terrorists.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
Making a Change in Chelsea: Rentals Go Co-op

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
The 16-story Marais building nearing completion at 520 West 23rd Street in the western corner of Chelsea was intended to be a rental, but when the building opens next month, its 107 apartments will be for sale.
 The building will break from current development patterns by being marketed as a co-op -- albeit without some of the restrictions normally associated with co-ops -- and also by carrying lower price tags than have been typical in the area. 
 The trend in recent years in Chelsea has been rental towers and condo lofts aimed at the upper end of the market, said Gil Neary, president of DG Neary Realty, sales agent for the Marais. The building's developers, the Hudson Companies, of Brooklyn, made the switch because "we concluded there was a tremendous demand for affordable-priced for-sale housing," said David Kramer, a company principal. Lower mortgage interest rates also supported the switch, he said. 
Within blocks of the project, nine rental buildings have opened in the nearly four years since zoning changes between Seventh Avenue and Avenue of the Americas from 16th to 23rd Streets permitted housing to be built in much of what had been a commercial district. The new buildings have a total of more than 2,000 apartments. Two more buildings, with nearly 600 apartments, are planned, including a 327-unit building at 555 West 23rd Street, opposite the Marais. Twenty percent of the units at 555 West 23rd Street will be set aside for families with low and moderate incomes.
"We could be reaching a saturation point," Douglas Wagner, president of Benjamin James Associates, a Manhattan brokerage, said of the rental construction. So far, he added, rents are holding or rising, and incentives, like a period of free rent, are disappearing.
At 22 Chelsea, a new 50-apartment rental building at 160 West 22nd Street, the Benjamin James brokerage began leasing five weeks ago. Tenants have signed leases for 46 apartments, which Mr. Wagner said range from 400-square-foot studios to 1,050-square-foot two-bedroom apartments. Occupancy begins next month. Monthly rents at 22 Chelsea, which will not have a doorman, are $1,590 to $4,490, Mr. Wagner said.
At the Marais, prices for the 460-square-foot studios to 1,000-square-foot two-bedroom units are expected to be $252,000 to $820,000, Mr. Kramer said. That comes to an average of $280,000 for studios, $375,000 for one-bedrooms and $580,000 for two-bedrooms, for an average of $650 a square foot.
That figure is significantly below the average per-square-foot price of $788 for new condominiums in the area in 2002, said Tara Hogan, a market analyst at the Marketing Directors, a real estate marketing and consulting firm that has represented other buildings in the area. "But on average," she said, "the Marais buyers get a much smaller apartment, a less central location and more modest amenities and finishes, enabling the developer to keep prices down."
Mr. Kramer said part of Hudson's pricing strategy was not altering the size of the apartments when the switch was made from rental to co-op. It is also using an affiliated company, Monadnock Construction, to build the project. Roslyn Savings Bank financed the $40 million project, designed by SLCE Architects of Manhattan.
The choice of the co-op form of ownership has been very unusual in recent years, with almost all new for-sale buildings being offered as condominiums. The Marais is becoming a co-op because Hudson leases, rather than owns, the land under the building. But Mr. Kramer said it would operate like a condominium; owners will not need board approval to sell or sublet their units.
In switching to a co-op, Hudson also invested $450,000 to upgrade the finishes in the apartments. There will be granite countertops instead of plastic laminated ones and stripped flooring instead of parquet. 
The initial monthly maintenance cost is estimated to be just over $1 a square foot -- $690 for a 660-square-foot unit -- and includes the rent to lease the land. The rent from the building's 4,000 square feet of retail space will go to the co-op board, which will own the stores. The rent from the stores is intended to help keep maintenance fees down. Sales of the apartments are expected to begin this month.

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Marais building, marketed as an affordable co-op, bucks a real estate trend in Chelsea. (Frances Roberts for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE 2002 CAMPAIGN: POLITICAL MEMO; 
G.O.P. Election Strategy on Economy: Accentuate Positives, Ignore the Rest

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 17 

 BODY:
After surveying public opinion about the sluggish economy, President Bush's pollster, Matthew Dowd, provided the Republican National Committee with a compelling if somewhat self-serving conclusion last weekend: Democrats hold no advantage on the issue and Republicans should not shy away from talking about it.
 With Election Day fast approaching, talking is all they are doing. 
 After floating the possibility this summer of backing a package of tax breaks for investors, Mr. Bush quietly shelved the idea. He instead adopted a strategy of riding out the rocky recovery for the rest of the Congressional campaign by emphasizing the positive about the economy while acknowledging the troubles of people who have lost jobs or savings. 
Republicans on Capitol Hill have taken much the same approach, if only by default. House Republicans headed home today to campaign after pulling the plug Wednesday on legislation to help investors and some unemployed workers. The bill was put on the back burner after it became clear there was no consensus that the tax breaks should be more of a priority in the campaign's closing days than other unresolved economic issues, like drought aid for farmers.
Sensing a chance to cast the president and his party as unresponsive to a deteriorating outlook, Democrats are eager to step into what they see as a policy vacuum. Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the House minority leader, called this week for an emergency package of new spending and tax cuts to help the economy. Senator Joseph I. Lieberman of Connecticut plans to call on Friday for specific steps to help restore investor and consumer confidence. 
Democrats failed this fall to get serious consideration for their economic proposals, even staples like raising the minimum wage or extending unemployment benefits. They remain split about whether to press for a freeze of the rest of Mr. Bush's tax cut. But Democrats maintain that it is Mr. Bush and his party who are underestimating the political and economic danger of standing pat in the face of economic warning signals.
"The rosy scenario they're promoting doesn't fit with the real world life of the people in my state and across the country," said Senator Jon Corzine, Democrat of New Jersey.
The administration has concluded that the economy is recovering, though haltingly, and that voters in any case do not blame Mr. Bush or his party for what troubles remain.
Beyond reacting to events like the labor dispute at the ports on the West Coast, Mr. Bush has proposed no new economic initiatives as the stock market has tumbled and other warning signals intensified in recent months. Even the big ideas that are bubbling quietly within the administration, like creating personal investment accounts within Social Security and overhauling the tax code, were under consideration long before the current economic weakness, and Mr. Bush almost never mentions them in public these days anyway.
Instead, Mr. Bush and other administration officials have asserted that the economy is fundamentally in good shape.
"Maybe two days out of three we see favorable data and the third day we see data we don't like so much," Paul H. O'Neill, the treasury secretary, said in an interview. "On balance, our economy is doing reasonably well." 
To the degree he talks about specific legislation, Mr. Bush has limited his calls for action to demanding that Congress make permanent last year's 10-year tax cut and pass a long-stalled bill to give real estate developers better access to insurance against terrorist attacks. He tells audiences that the terrorist insurance legislation would create 300,000 jobs by allowing big building projects to go forward. He casts the Democratic leadership in the Senate as the impediment to progress on those and other pieces of economic legislation.
But Mr. Bush almost never mentions the financial markets anymore, especially after seeing the stock market fall several times this spring and summer after his comments on the investment climate. Publicly, he glosses over or ignores entirely the prospect that a war with Iraq could entail serious economic risks.
It is not clear whether the administration's generally upbeat message will sound out of touch to voters, who, judging by the decline in consumer confidence, are increasingly nervous. One of the great unknowns is whether the new mass investor class -- 50 percent of households and a much higher percentage of voters now own stock -- will tally the losses in their 401(k) accounts and take their frustrations out in the voting booth.
Indeed, there are few guidelines for the politics of an economy whose main problem is not so much job losses, the traditional focus when times are tough, but a huge loss of stock market wealth and a sharp decline in business and consumer confidence.
"My sense from being home on weekends is that people are concerned, particularly about the market," said Representative Rob Portman, Republican of Ohio. "In my region, we haven't been focused on the unemployment issue because we haven't had big layoffs. But everyone is invested one way or another now, either through their retirement accounts or more directly."
Mr. Portman's point explains why Republican leaders in the House scrambled in the last two weeks to produce a bill to help investors and rush it to the House floor before Election Day. But with the stock market in the midst of its best week in months, the effort fizzled in the last few days, leaving Republicans to face voters with no new initiatives in hand.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
73% Bounce Makes EBay an E-Commerce Bright Spot

BYLINE:  By JOHN SCHWARTZ 

 BODY:
EBay, the Internet auction giant, announced continuing growth yesterday, with nearly $264 million in net revenue from transactions in the third quarter, 73 percent higher than the figures for the period a year ago. 
 The chief executive said that eBay might have gotten a helping hand from the same economic troubles that have made a boneyard of the dot-com marketplace. 
 EBay remains a "compelling place to do business," said Margaret C. Whitman, the president and chief executive, "despite the current climate, or because of it." 
The company, based in San Jose, Calif., helped the online world buy and sell $3.77 billion worth of everything from collectibles to cars during the quarter that ended on Sept. 30.
EBay said its net income had reached $61 million, or 21 cents a diluted share, for the quarter. The year before, income was $18.8 million for the quarter. Ms. Whitman called it "an outstanding quarter for eBay."
Industry analysts agreed. "It's kind of a nice change, isn't it?" asked Derek Brown, an analyst at W. R. Hambrecht who watches the company. He pronounced the quarter "spectacular," adding, "It certainly provides a respite from some of the other news going on."
The company announced its results after the close of trading. EBay shares ended the day at $58.15, up 17 cents. But the shares lost value in after-hours trading, falling at least as low as $55.50.
"The news is as good as it sounds, and as good as was expected," said Safa Rashtchy, an analyst at U.S. Bancorp Piper Jaffray. The reason for the after-hours decline, he said, was that the results were "probably disappointing for people who expected more" out of the company's estimates of future growth.
Looking ahead, the company said it expected that net revenue for the fourth quarter would be $372 million to $381 million, with earnings per diluted share of 19 to 20 cents. 
For the year, the company said, it expects that consolidated net revenue could range from $1.172 billion to $1.181 billion, with earnings per diluted share of 76 to 77 cents.
That represents an increase of 4 to 5 cents a share in the company's previous guidance. 
For 2003, eBay expects that the earnings per share may range from $1.02 to $1.05 and that consolidated net revenues could be $1.77 billion to $1.83 billion.
The strategy for future growth includes making a greater international push and getting current customers to buy more on eBay and to become sellers themselves, said Rajiv Dutta, the chief financial officer.
"We have begun to focus more on increasing the activity of existing users," he said. 
EBay's continued success during the current economic slump is not surprising, he said.
"We make inefficient markets efficient," Mr. Dutta said, and that can bring greater profits to sellers and lower prices to buyers. "Nowhere is that more important," he added, "than during times that are difficult."

HEADLINE: China Frees Dissident Tibetan Nun 9 Years Ahead of Schedule 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: BEIJING, Oct. 17 

 BODY:
A young Tibetan nun imprisoned nearly a decade by China for "counterrevolutionary" crimes, was released today, nine years ahead of schedule, according to the United States-based Dui Hua Foundation, which had pressed for her freedom.
 The woman, Ngawang Sandrol, was in her mid-teens in 1992 when a Chinese court first convicted her for her protests on behalf of Tibetan independence. She is among China's longest-serving female political prisoners. 
 In 1993, while in prison, she and 12 other jailed nuns made a clandestine recording of songs praising the Dalai Lama, Tibet's exiled spiritual leader. The tape was smuggled out of prison and circulated in Tibet and abroad. It won her international recognition as well as the enmity of Chinese authorities, who extended her initial 3-year sentence to 19 years.
China frequently paroles political prisoners as a good-will gesture before summit meetings with Western leaders. This high-profile release occurred weeks before President Jiang Zemin of China is scheduled to meet President Bush at his ranch in Crawford, Tex. 
Rights groups, the State Department and numerous legislators have raised this case with the Chinese over the years.
The release also coincides with signs of a mild warming of relations between China and the Dalai Lama. Last month, high-level envoys of the Dalai Lama visited Tibet for the first time in decades and returned cautiously praising Beijing's "greater flexibility."
But rights advocates have suggested that China's new attitude is at least partly prompted by its desire for better relations, and public relations, with the United States, where the Chinese repression of Tibet is a perennial campaign issue. 
The strategy seems to be working: Upon returning from Tibet last month, a special envoy, Lodi Gyari, asked pro-Tibetan groups in the United States to refrain from demonstrating when President Jiang visits Chicago and San Francisco this month. 
Chinese troops invaded Tibet in the early 1950's, eventually forcing the Dalai Lama into exile in India. In recent years, the Chinese government has sought, with limited success, to assuage Tibetans with large amounts of economic development aid.
Ngawang Sandrol is the latest in a string of Tibetan political prisoners released this year. Last fall, during a bilateral rights dialogue, the State Department raised the cases of 18 Tibetan political prisoners; 9 of those have since been released. 
"Members of human rights groups around the world have worked tirelessly on Ngawang Sandrol's behalf for many years, and will take comfort and pride in this development," said the Dui Hua Foundation in its statement today announcing the release. 
So far, the Chinese have been less responsive to pressure to release other prisoners, like Rebiya Kadeer, a Muslim businesswoman and activist from Xinjiang Province, and Xu Wenli, a Beijing-based democracy activist.
Ngawang Sandrol was not due to be released until Nov. 3, 2011. But last week, the Chinese authorities told John Kamm, executive director of the Dui Hua Foundation, that they had decided to release her early because of her recent good behavior and because of their commitment to "light or reduced sentences for individuals who enter prison as juveniles."
