PERSON: Masayuki Komatsu 

HEADLINE: THE SATURDAY PROFILE; 
An Environmentalist Who Loves to Eat Whales

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO 

 BODY:
IN "Whale Hunters," a new BBC documentary, Masayuki Komatsu can be heard giving a Japanese whaling ship captain advice on how to deal with Greenpeace protest boats: "When they approach, blow them out of the water."
 In a nation of bland comment, Mr. Komatsu loves the one-liner. In a nation of deference, he likes confrontation. In a nation of low profile, Mr. Komatsu is the Japanese nail that never gets hammered down. 
 Mr. Komatsu has striking advice for a visitor, coming as it does from the man whose job is to protect Japan's marine environment.
"First, you go whale watching," he suggested. "Then, on shore, you go eat whale sushi!"
The line was just what critics and supporters alike have come to expect of Mr. Komatsu, a career bureaucrat with steel-rimmed glasses and a row of pens neatly arrayed in a pocket protector. He has taken up the cause of restoring Japanese whaling to its golden days, the years before Americans placed "Save the Whales" stickers on car bumpers, before a later generation was ruined by the movie, "Free Willy!"
Mr. Komatsu's cause is unpopular in a world where commercial whaling has been banned for 20 years. He has pursued it with what many see as an indigestible mix of old-fashioned nationalism, selective culinary history and transparent political ambition.
He is not above rough tactics. In May, when the International Whaling Commission once again refused to end the global ban on commercial whaling, Mr. Komatsu grabbed a microphone from his delegation leader and single-handedly blocked what was supposed to be a nearly automatic vote to allow whales to be hunted by Alaskan Eskimos and Siberian natives, indigenous peoples who depend on them for food. With his action, Mr. Komatsu said in effect, if Japan can't whale, no one can.
Delegates were incensed. The American representative called it "the most unjust, unkind and unfair vote ever taken" in the more than half century the group has been in existence. Others said the future of the entire organization was in doubt. But at a special session of the commission in Cambridge, England, this week members voted to restore whaling quotas to Alaskans and Siberian natives, undoing the vote orchestrated by Mr. Komatsu last summer. 
In early November, Mr. Komatsu plans to lead a campaign at a United Nations conference in Chile on endangered species to end a longstanding ban on the international trade in whale meat.
Indeed, official Japan increasingly clings to whale hunting as a nationalist badge of honor. Last month, Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi named to the post of environment minister Shunichi Suzuki, a leader of the Parliament's pro-whaling faction, a man who rejected the anti-whaling movement as "culinary imperialism."
That has long been Mr. Komatsu's view. Sometimes he tries to express it with reserve. "The Japanese mentality is to not stand out," the 48-year-old father of two explained in an interview here in a ministry meeting room decorated with a dusty stuffed seal. "I try to tone it down, to take my wife's advice."
THE son of a part-time fisherman, Mr. Komatsu grew up in a Rikuzentakata, a coastal town of 27,000 people about 250 miles northeast of Tokyo. 
When he was a boy, an accident in which 20 family friends, all tuna fishermen, were lost at sea inspired him to a career in maritime safety. After graduating from a regional university, he got a job with the Japanese Ministry of Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries in 1977, and he has remained there ever since.
To the regret of American environmentalists, he came away from two years of study at Yale with a business degree, but not much of New Haven's green thinking. Instead, he turned his new American linguistic and educational tools to defending Japanese whaling on cultural, historical and often economic grounds.
"You eat cows and drink beer," he told his American visitor. "We eat whales and drink sake. Japan is a country surrounded by oceans, and for many years, Japan has appreciated the riches from the ocean." 
Citing three anti-whaling nations, he added, "Australia, New Zealand and the United States have vast agricultural lands where they can raise meat -- sheep, cows, kangaroos, whatever -- so they don't have to rely heavily on seafood from the oceans."
JAPAN is about one-third of its way to reaching a self-imposed annual quota of killing 550 whales for what it calls scientific research. The meat is then sold to restaurants, though many Japanese, particularly young people, do not eat whale meat.
Mr. Komatsu rejected the view that Japanese whaling is a sunset industry, heavily subsidized and providing employment for only 200 workers. Instead, in defending attempts to revive whaling in coastal towns, he focuses on the long history of whaling in Japan, going back to eighth-century government records.
America's role in Japan's whaling history has been significant. Mr. Komatsu notes that Commodore Perry forced Japan to open to the outside world in 1853 in order to provide supply stations for American whaling fleets. After World War II, Gen. Douglas MacArthur staved off famine in Japan by ordering Japanese whaling ships to Antarctica to catch whales.
Mr. Komatsu said he blocked the renewal of Eskimo whaling quotas because anti-whaling nations refused to allow Japanese coastal communities to resume their own traditions. At the time, he accused the United States of a "double standard" and said it was America's turn to feel "some pain."
The American delegates returned to Washington, protesting bitterly. Administration officials intervened, forcing Prime Minister Koizumi's government to agree to a compromise that allowed American Eskimos and Siberian natives to hunt whales, as they have for hundreds of years.
ONE might think this would spell trouble for a mid-level Japanese bureaucrat. But Mr. Komatsu's position seems as sturdy as ever. Last month, he settled into his new office at the ministry: director of fisheries research and environmental protection.
While Japanese diplomats privately lament his aggressive approach, Mr. Komatsu's apparent untouchability comes from careful cultivation of his political base -- fishing companies, fishing towns and fishing unions -- each a pillar of support for Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party.
It also has not hurt that his performance at the whaling conference enthralled Japanese television viewers and brought him popularity akin to a rock star. After the conference, Mr. Komatsu said, the ministry received 20,000 e-mail messages, 95 percent approving of Japan's position.
Speculation runs strong here that he is building a political base to run for Parliament, a move that would bring relief to anti-whaling activists. For the moment, they resort to circulating snide e-mail comments saying that his teenage daughters swim with dolphins.
At the mention of this e-mail campaign, Mr. Komatsu visibly tensed.
"My younger daughter was very taken with dolphins," he said, in a confessional tone. "Our two daughters went to aquariums, swam with dolphins. Yes. They also went whale watching."
Then he regained his composure. "At the same time," he added, "they eat seafood and other fish -- such as whales."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Markets Finish an Impressive 2-Week Run

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Stocks finished a volatile week with small gains yesterday but still managed a milestone of sorts: one of the better two-week performances since World War II.
 The Dow Jones industrial average and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index, which were each up 0.6 percent yesterday, rose 10.5 percent in the last two weeks, their best performance since last October, when the stock market was rebounding after the terrorist attack. It was the fifth-biggest two-week rally for the S.& P. 500 index since 1945 and the seventh biggest for the Dow. 
 The Nasdaq composite index, which jumped 1.2 percent yesterday, climbed 13 percent over the two weeks, its ninth-best performance since the Nasdaq was started in 1971. 
How comforting investors find the performance depends on whether this rally continues. If stocks falter, it will be just two good weeks from the lowest the overall market has been in five and a half years.
By one measure -- the flow of money into stock mutual funds -- retail investors may not be that impressed yet. One reason may be that the big summer rally that began in July and took the Dow Jones industrial average over 9,000 for a day, fizzled in August.
In the week ended Wednesday, investors took $4.1 billion out of stock mutual funds, according to AMG Data Services. The overall value of these funds rose more than $100 billion in the week because of the rise in stock prices. In every week since June, except for one, there have been outflows from stock mutual funds, using a four-week moving average.
"In the 1990's and even in 2000, investors took the opportunity to buy more stocks on any dip," said Robert Adler, president of AMG. "This has not occurred here. Investors are taking a more considered view."
On the other hand, the big sell-off in the bond market may indicate that investors who had landed there in search of a market haven may be feeling a little better about the prospects in stocks. The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note, which moves in the opposite direction of the price, has jumped half a percentage point in seven trading days.
"I am not a snarling bear anymore," said William E. Rhodes, chief investment strategist at Rhodes Analytics in Boston. "I'm sitting and looking at my paws, wondering when they will change to hooves."
But stocks, he added, are still too expensive and there are still too many companies that are just beating corporate earnings forecasts by selling property. 
Yesterday, the Dow was up 47.36 points, to 8,322.40, while the S.& P. 500-stock index climbed 5.19 points, to 884.39. The Nasdaq rose 15.57 points, to 1,287.86.
Among the stocks leading the market higher yesterday were Microsoft, which rose $2.38, or 4.7 percent, to $53.15 after announcing late Thursday that it was raising its revenue and earnings forecasts for the year ending June 30. I.B.M. -- up $2.05, or 2.8 percent, to $74.25 -- rose for a second day on its positive earnings report. The decliners included General Motors, off $1.09, or 3.1 percent, to $34.31, and Johnson & Johnson, down 85 cents, or 1.4 percent, to $59.35.
Treasury securities rebounded yesterday after falling for six consecutive trading sessions. The yield on the Treasury's 10-year note fell to 4.11 percent, from 4.20 percent Thursday, while the price rose 23/32, to 102 5/32.
The driving force in the stock market the last two weeks has been good and bad news in earnings announcements for the third quarter. Citigroup and Bank of America powered a furious rally on Tuesday, sending the Dow up 4.8 percent. Intel, J. P. Morgan Chase, Motorola, Coca-Cola, Boeing and Ford helped send the Dow down 2.7 percent on Wednesday. Then I.B.M. and Eastman Kodak gave a lift Thursday, propelling the Dow 3 percent higher. Microsoft was a positive yesterday.
Third-quarter earnings reports have been positive, but that is partly because many companies toned down Wall Street expectations in advance. Based on actual results from 210 companies in the S.& P. 500 index and forecasts for the rest, third-quarter operating or pro forma earnings, which exclude some items, are up 6.4 percent over a year ago. But that is down from the forecast of 16.6 percent growth made July 1. And earnings that exclude items can allow a company to put the best face on its performance, an accounting procedure that is under fire.
Operating earnings for technology companies, including those that have reported and the current forecasts, are up 24 percent for the third quarter so far. This performance can be attributed largely to the big lifts from I.B.M. and Microsoft this week. Before these two companies' reports, earnings growth for the technology sector was 13 percent.
But the outlook for fourth-quarter operating earnings is still slipping. The current estimate of 17.8 percent growth from a year ago is down from a 27.7 percent forecast on July 1 and a 19.9 percent consensus as of Oct. 1.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS; 
A Vulnerable Time to Be Moving Oil by Sea

BYLINE:  By NEELA BANERJEE and KEITH BRADSHER 

 BODY:
After the United States began its war in Afghanistan, many in the oil industry braced for what they saw as inevitable: terrorist attacks on tankers.
 The first came early this month when an explosion crippled the French tanker Limburg in the Gulf of Aden, an incident Yemeni officials said Wednesday was the work of terrorists. Few think it will be the last. After the nightclub bombing in Bali last weekend, Indonesian officials said oil operations would probably be the next targets of terrorists in their country, which sits astride crucial tanker routes. And maritime insurers are beginning to sharply raise the premiums they charge to cover tankers in risky waters. 
 Shipping and oil executives say tankers have been taking what precautions they can. But without a lot more help from national governments, especially in hazardous areas like the Persian Gulf and Southeast Asia, the tankers will remain highly vulnerable, the executives said. Even an all-out effort by the world's navies and coast guards probably could not completely safeguard the tanker fleet.
"Tankers are sitting ducks," said Harry Banga, the vice chairman of the Noble Group, a shipping and logistics company based in Hong Kong. "They don't have any security; they don't have any protection."
And they have nowhere to hide. Geography forces the tankers carrying much of the world's oil supply to pass through one or more of three narrow straits -- the entrances to the Red Sea and the Persian Gulf and the Straits of Malacca between Indonesia and Malaysia. "The biggest areas for transit are in the terrorist areas," Mr. Banga said.
The deep-water shipping channels in these straits can be so narrow that a single burning supertanker and its spreading oil slick could block the route for other tankers, executives said; in these and several other straits in Indonesia, there would not be not enough room for naval escorts to screen tankers from attack, even if the escorts were available.
A tanker's huge size makes it somewhat hard to sink, but very easy to hit, shipping executives said. Tankers are too slow and cumbersome to maneuver away from attackers; their radar systems are designed to avoid collisions with other large ships, but not to detect small boats. Even the double hulls used on newer tankers to reduce the risk of spills are not designed to stop explosives, though they may fare better than older single hulls.
Large commercial vessels like tankers almost never mount deck guns to ward off attackers themselves, because many ports prohibit the weapons.
About all the ships can do is stay far from shore when possible and take the basic precautions commonly used in areas with piracy problems, said Chris Horrocks, secretary general of the International Chamber of Shipping, a maritime trade association: "Manning fire pumps, extra deck lighting so that you are very visible, additional deck patrols in high-risk areas -- anything that will make it less likely that it will be you rather than someone else." 
Mr. Horrocks's organization and others say that only governments can provide any significant protection to tankers. So far, oil companies have said little publicly about the attack on the Limburg, and it is unclear whether they are lobbying governments for greater protection.
Asian shipping executives say that it is hopeless to expect effective military protection for vessels passing through the straits near Indonesia. There are too many vessels, too many islands and too many long, narrow sea passages for that to be practical, they argue.
"If we go around protecting every large tanker against small-boat attacks, we miss the larger point," said Arthur Bowring, the managing director of the Hong Kong Ship Owners Association, one of Asia's largest shipping trade groups. "We should more actively aid the Indonesian economy to stop the attacks."
There are 50,000 tankers and other freighters plying the world's oceans, and it would be hard to make a case for defending oil tankers and not, for example, chemical tankers or tankers carrying liquefied natural gas, Mr. Bowring said. And if tankers alone were protected, terrorists could simply board an undefended freighter carrying a dry bulk cargo like iron ore and then ram it into a tanker, he said.
The Indonesian Navy did offer escorts two years ago for vessels leaving certain ports to reduce the risk of piracy, but it found few takers. "Some people feel that if you have an escort, it advertises that you have a cargo on board worth stealing," Mr. Bowring said. "There is an advantage to anonymity." The piracy problem in Indonesian waters peaked in the late 1990's; police crackdowns ashore have reduced it somewhat since then.
More valuable than naval escorts, Mr. Bowring said, would be better navigational aids and ship-traffic control in the busy straits, which would allow more vessels to use them safely and reduce the risk posed by a single wreck in a bad spot.
There are alternative routes through Indonesia for ships headed from the Indian Ocean to the Pacific, but most are poorly marked for navigation by large tankers, and would greatly lengthen journey times.
Carriers said governments could also help by tightening security in ports. On Monday, the International Maritime Bureau, a watchdog group based in London, called for the approach-channels used by tankers reaching port to be declared off limits to other vessels. Yemeni officials said on Wednesday that they would enforce a 500-yard no-entry radius around tankers loading at Ash Shihr, its southern port, and would patrol the area with gunboats and helicopters. "There was security there before, but now it's much more intense," said Yemen's deputy oil minister, Abdulmalik Alama.
On Thursday, maritime insurers tripled the premiums they charge tankers passing through Yemeni waters, raising concerns in the shipping industry that further increases could be on the way for other regions as well. For a typical supertanker carrying about two million barrels of oil, Mr. Banga, the Asian shipping company vice chairman, said the rate rose to $450,000 a trip from $150,000, adding about 15 cents a barrel to the delivered cost of the oil -- and that is just for the ship; the cargo is insured separately.
Dieter Berg, manager of the marine division at Munich Re, a major reinsurance company, said that for the moment the higher premiums appeared to be confined to high-risk areas, and rates have not risen for ships in waters thought to be safer, like the North Sea.
"If we come to the conclusion that this is no longer a localized problem, but a global one, then premiums across the board should begin to rise," Mr. Berg said.
Mr. Horrocks and others said that oil and shipping companies are hoping that the attack on the Limburg will turn out to be an isolated incident. But they are not counting on it. 
"I'm afraid that is a fact of life at the moment," said Michael Raper, the head of security services for Europe, the Middle East and Africa at Kroll Associates, a leading security consulting firm. "It's not a particularly easy one to deal with."

HEADLINE: Strong Dollar Runs Into Renewed Resistance 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 

 BODY:
To hear many American manufacturers complain, the biggest competitive threat is not China or South Korea and certainly not Europe. It is the seemingly unsinkable value of the American dollar.
 Already wounded by the global economic slowdown and a severe drop in spending on new equipment and factories, American manufacturers say their plight has been made far worse by a dollar that is still more than 20 percent higher against other big currencies than it was five years ago. 
 The government offered new ammunition today for the manufacturers' argument. The trade deficit, which has been the highest in the world for years, surged an additional 10 percent in August, to a record $38.5 billion. The jump was much higher than most economists had expected, though analysts cautioned that the immediate reasons were unrelated to the dollar. 
The high dollar has raised prices of American exports and lowered the prices of imports from Europe, Asia and Latin America. The United States trade deficit has ballooned, not only against China and South Korea but Canada and Europe.
"We just cannot compete against the Canadian dollar," said Judith Jewell, owner of Olympian Precast, a small company in Redmond, Wash., that produces custom-order concrete pillars and facades.
Since 1997, when the Canadian dollar began a long slide against the American currency, Ms. Jewell has been underbid by Canadian rivals on jobs like a federal building in Seattle and office buildings at Microsoft. Her sales have slumped to $3.5 million from $5.5 million, and she has reduced her work force to 47 from 62.
Manufacturing groups have complained for years about the high dollar, but they have become more strident lately as a result of the persistent slump in industrial production.
The National Association of Manufacturers has lobbied the Treasury to back away from a "strong dollar" policy, complaining that the dollar amounts to a penalty on products made in the United States.
"There is no question that the strength of the dollar has made life difficult for exporters," said Ian Shepherdson, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics. In addition, he said, the high dollar has squeezed profit margins as American companies have struggled to match lower prices on imports.
The disagreement, and it is a huge one, is about what to do. Low import prices have been a crucial reason for low inflation and for the continued strength in consumer spending. 
Globalization has made the cost-benefit calculation much more complex because American manufacturers from Whirlpool to Compaq import a huge percentage of their components from overseas.
"We are currency neutral," said Ken Holland, a spokesman for Deere & Company, the farm equipment manufacturer. Deere, based in Moline, Ill., has doubled its overseas work force over the last five years, to about 16,000 from fewer than 8,000.
According to Robert Z. Lawrence, professor of trade at the Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, about 40 percent of goods imported into the United States come from subsidiaries of American companies.
Such complexities are one reason Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill has dismissed repeated pleas from industry lobbyists to encourage a mild decline in the dollar.
Mr. O'Neill has sent mixed signals about his views. He has generally argued that market forces should determine the currency's value, but he has also said that a strong dollar merely reflects the strength of the American economy and the eagerness of foreigners to invest here.
"The weight of historical evidence shows that those who have tried to fix underlying economic problems with protectionist measures -- artificially depreciating the currency is one of those -- actually weaken their own economy," he said at a conference in Tokyo earlier this year.
Mr. O'Neill was unperturbed when the dollar declined modestly against the euro and the Japanese yen, but he was equally sanguine when the dollar stabilized this summer.
That position is not much different from that of Robert E. Rubin, Treasury secretary under President Bill Clinton.
Although the Treasury has the legal authority to intervene in currency markets, many economists and currency traders are skeptical that the government can do much more than nudge the currency in a direction it was already heading.
The dollar's powerful rise during the late 1990's stemmed in large part from the huge inflow of foreign investment, from stocks and bonds to long-term investment in factories and equipment.
Direct investment from overseas has dropped sharply in the last year, but the dollar has remained relatively strong because economic growth in Europe and Japan is even weaker than in the United States.
"The European economy is moribund, and Japan is a complete disaster," said Mr. Shepherdson of High Frequency Economics. "If you are looking for return on assets, the U.S. is the place to be."
Some argue that the Bush administration could have a significant impact simply by backing away from rhetorical support for a strong dollar.
"The Treasury Department ought not to say anything about exchange rates," said Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers. "We would be happy with letting market forces work."
In principle, that is the Treasury Department's view, as well. The problem is that Mr. O'Neill sometimes sounds more hawkish than he is, for example, when he argues that a strong dollar simply reflects the strength of the economy.
Some executives are also convinced that Mr. O'Neill has strengthened the dollar by tolerating efforts by the Japanese government to promote Japanese exports by keeping the yen artificially low.
"If you go and talk to friends in Japan, they will tell you the administration is not fully behind its statements" about deferring to market forces, said G. Mustafa Mohatarem, chief economist for General Motors. "They are willing to give Japan some flexibility on their currency."
Treasury officials insist they have criticized Japanese currency intervention, though they acknowledge that Mr. O'Neill's remarks have been mild and relatively seldom. 
Big companies like Deere, which has had declining exports but has increased its manufacturing overseas, are adept at shifting strategies to compensate for the dollar.
But for small companies like Olympia Precast, not far from the border with Canada, changes are more difficult. "People tell me we should set up a factory in Canada," Ms. Jewell, Olympia's owner, said. "Well, that's not really what I'm about."

HEADLINE: Fed Mood Seems to Be Shifting Against aRate Cut 

BYLINE:  By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 18 

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve, which flooded the economy with money by sharply lowering interest rates last year as growth collapsed, appears much more unwilling to fend off another potential tailspin today.
 In the last few days, a host of senior Fed officials have made clear that they think the economy is more robust than it appears to most Americans. 
 Industrial production may be down; job growth may be almost nonexistent; and corporations may be too nervous to invest in new factories and equipment. But at least for the moment, the message out of the Fed seems to be that the anxiety is overdone and that there is no compelling need to juice up the economy by reducing interest rates yet again. 
"If we could all just settle down -- both the public and the private sector -- and try to get the uncertainty level diminished, the markets will take care of themselves," William McDonough, president of the New York Federal Reserve Bank and the most important of the 12 regional bank presidents who help set monetary policy, said at a conference in Manhattan on Thursday.
Jack Guynn, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta, declared earlier this week that lower interest rates have "nothing at all" to do with the readiness of companies to start investing in new factories and adding more workers.
And other members of the Federal Reserve's monetary policy committee have echoed the view that the economic recovery, while still fragile, is nonetheless clearly under way.
"I think the probability of a so-called double-dip recession is relatively low," Gary Stern, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, said in a speech on Tuesday.
The tone of those remarks contrasts strongly with the impression left after the most recent meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee, on Sept. 24.
At that meeting, 2 of the 12 voting members publicly dissented from the majority and argued that the weak economy was in need of a lift in the form of even lower interest rates. In a nod to pessimists, the Federal Reserve also took heed of the "considerable uncertainty" and said the risks were "weighted mainly to the conditions that may produce economic weakness."
Many analysts say the meeting hinted at a deep disagreement within the Federal Reserve. But a growing number say the debate is not just between those who want easier money and those who do not.
The board may also have another camp, whose members want to take a firmer line, actually discouraging hints that a rate cut is likely if conditions deteriorate much more.
Rarely have analysts and investors been as divided and uncertain as they are now about the prospects for the economy. 
Most analysts and government officials say the economy grew rapidly in the quarter that ended Sept. 30, perhaps at an annual rate of 4 percent. The growth was powered by low interest rates. Homeowners refinanced their mortgages at lower rates, often taking out home equity loans to buy cars and furniture. Construction of new homes surged, as did the housing prices in general.
But most analysts say they believe that growth will be slower in the last quarter of this year, because both corporations and consumers have become more nervous. 
William C. Dudley, chief United States economist at Goldman, Sachs, argues that the economy is far weaker than most people expected a few months ago and that the Fed must cut rates.
Mr. Dudley, who predicted in early August that the Fed would cut rates in the near future, says he is staying with his prediction. "I would say the economy since then has evolved more closely to our view of the world," he said.
Janet Yellen, professor of economics at the University of California at Berkeley and a former adviser to President Bill Clinton, said deep uncertainty provides a good case for cutting rates. "The decline in the stock market and the impact of corporate accounting scandals is taking a huge toll on the economy," she said. "Some people say the Fed should save its ammunition for later. I think that is completely erroneous."
Other analysts argue that the economy is in much better shape than the mood of corporate executives would suggest. Just as the Federal Reserve was early in supplying money when things began to look bad, it is now early to recognize that conditions are getting better.
"There is good reason to think that the stage is set for the most unbelievable performance," said James Glassman, economist at J. P. Morgan. By not acting, he said, the Fed will look as if it had the courage to sit tight when everybody else was panicking.
But the most important decision maker is Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and he has been conspicuously silent since the meeting last month.

HEADLINE: Bring Back Hetch Hetchy? 

 BODY:
In 1913, in defiance of established law and the wishes of millions of Americans, Congress foolishly approved the construction of a dam and an eight-mile-long reservoir in a lush valley known by its Indian name, Hetch Hetchy, in the northwest corner of Yosemite National Park. The dream of righting this wrong has never really died. Now it's back, in the form of a proposal by Environmental Defense and other conservation groups for a feasibility study to see whether it would be economically and hydrologically plausible to knock down the dam, drain the reservoir, uncover 1,900 acres of valley floor and restore what the naturalist John Muir once described as a "grand landscape garden, one of nature's rarest and most precious mountain temples." 
 Hetch Hetchy, once the largest reservoir in California, catches water from the High Sierra and sends it along to San Francisco. A lot of Californians think the idea of draining the reservoir is daft, including Senator Dianne Feinstein, a former mayor of San Francisco. However misguided the original decision, she has said, the reservoir is vital to San Francisco's water supply. 
 And so it is. But the environmentalists point out that the city and state are already talking about spending $3.6 billion to fix the pipes and associated plumbing that deliver Hetch Hetchy's water to the city. For that kind of money, they suggest, existing reservoirs can be enlarged, or a new one built, to replace Hetch Hetchy.
In 1913, over the course of the year, this page ran six thunderous editorials opposing the reservoir and unsuccessfully urging President Woodrow Wilson to intercede. In the uninhibited vernacular of the time, the editorials described the scheme as "sordid," the commercial interests that supported it as "grabbers of water and power," and California's politicians as "trans-Mississippians" who "care nothing for matters of natural beauty and taste." Given this editorial pedigree, the least we can do is endorse a feasibility study. It may well lead to something remarkable.

HEADLINE: THE 2002 CAMPAIGN: THE DEMOCRATS; 
Hawaii Democrats Reeling After Scandals and a Death

BYLINE:  By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: HONOLULU, Oct. 18 

 BODY:
When the voters of Hawaii awake the morning after the Nov. 5 election, they are likely to find they have done two extraordinary things: elect a live Republican to the governor's office and a dead Democrat to Congress.
 Such is the state of politics in Hawaii this year. 
 After dominating the state for 40 years, Democrats are in meltdown. Because of a sour economy and a rash of scandals involving local politicians, voters are disgusted with the incumbent party and seem in a mood to try something, anything, different.
"The Democratic Party is imploding," said Ira Rohter, a professor of political science at the University of Hawaii at Manoa. "Right now, there is no Democratic Party here, just a lot of feuding factions. It's like watching a Three Stooges skit." 
Nowhere is the Democrats' disarray more evident than in the unseemly free-for-all to replace Representative Patsy Mink, who died on Sept. 28 of viral pneumonia brought on by chickenpox. Her name will still appear on the ballot, and she is expected to defeat the Republican challenger, a right-wing state representative, Bob McDermott. The state will then hold not one but two special elections to fill her seat.
On Nov. 30, voters will choose among 38 declared candidates -- 10 of them Democrats -- to serve the remaining five weeks of Mrs. Mink's term. After wavering for two weeks, John Mink, Mrs. Mink's husband, declared his candidacy this week and is thought likely to win a decisive sympathy vote. But he says he is not interested in serving a full term. 
On Jan. 4, if Mrs. Mink wins on Nov. 5, another election will be held for the vacant seat in the 108th Congress. A half-dozen Democrats have expressed interest in that race.
The Democratic Party has done nothing to bring order to the chaos by anointing a preferred candidate, saying party rules and state tradition bar them from intervening.
The situation would seem to provide a ripe opening for a Republican to grab a seat in Congress, but the party's candidate, Mr. McDermott, has been disavowed by Linda Lingle, the Republican candidate for governor and a former state Republican chairwoman, and other officials.
Mr. McDermott, a businessman and former marine, said his main hope was that he would slip in because the Democrats were engaged in a circular firing squad. But he admitted it was a long shot. "I'm the greatest thing since sliced bread," he said. "But what can I do? I'm running against a ghost." 
Gov. Benjamin J. Cayetano said that he could not unite the Democratic Party around a single candidate even if he wanted to. Democrats in Hawaii take orders from no one, not him and not the party's senior statesman, Senator Daniel K. Inouye. Mr. Cayetano surmised that the Democratic candidate for governor, Lt. Gov. Mazie Hirono, or her running mate, Matt Matsunaga, might seek the seat in Congress if they lose the race for governor.
"It's like organizing cats," Mr. Cayetano sighed.
A sign of the Democrats' discontent could be seen on Thursday night in Waipahu, a largely working-class Filipino suburb of Honolulu that has always voted reliably with the Democrats. But nearly a thousand residents of Waipahu showed up at the high school gym for a raucous rally for Ms. Lingle, who has been hammering the Democrats for mismanagement of the government and an array of corruption scandals.
Venus Agpaoa, who emigrated from the Philippines in 1970 and has consistently voted Democratic, said she was more than ready to knock the dominant party from its perch. "You can't make a change unless you change the people who made the state the way it is now," she said.
Ms. Lingle, 49, a former mayor of Maui who lost the governorship to Mr. Cayetano by a narrow margin four years ago, appears poised to reap the benefits of the voters' unhappiness. She is in some ways an unlikely candidate for dragon-slayer -- a divorced Jewish Republican from the mainland who supports abortion rights. But analysts say that, because of the Democrats' ineptitude and the lackluster campaign of her opponent, Ms. Hirono, the race is Ms. Lingle's to lose.
The corruption scandals involving Democrats appear to have made voters weary of the party. In just the last year, two members of the Honolulu City Council have been convicted of misusing campaign funds and engaging in a kickback scheme. The former Council chairman was suspended from practicing law for lying about a hit-and-run accident. A state senator pleaded guilty to tax evasion and campaign finance violations.
The mayor of Honolulu, Jeremy Harris, is under grand jury investigation for his campaign fund-raising, involving contributions in excess of legal limits. Mr. Harris, who was the front-runner for the Democratic nomination for governor until he dropped out of the race because of the investigation, says the charges are groundless.
One result of the scandals is that traditional donors to the Democrats have been sitting on their checkbooks, leaving Ms. Hirono in precarious financial shape. The state's influential unions have been stingy with their money and their volunteers. The state teacher's union is withholding its endorsement because its members are still furious with Governor Cayetano for his lack of support during a three-week teacher's strike last year.
Ms. Lingle has raised nearly twice as much money as Ms. Hirono and has a well-greased political operation to show for it. Various polls have put her about 10 percentage points ahead.
"They have no momentum," Ms. Lingle said of the Democrats. "They're dead in the water."
She added that she did not see any sign that the unions would rally around the Democrats, although the A.F.L.-C.I.O. is sponsoring a visit by former President Bill Clinton on Ms. Hirono's behalf.
"That could backfire," Ms. Lingle said. "He's not only a polarizing figure, but he reminds the voters of all the ethical lapses of the Democrats."
Ms. Lingle is preparing to unveil her secret weapon next week, an endorsement by Konishiki, a grand champion sumo wrestler from Hawaii who is immensely popular here. On Wednesday, he shot a television advertisement for Ms. Lingle, lending his 600 pounds to her campaign. The commercial begins appearing next week.
For her part, Ms. Hirono, 54, is emphasizing her 22 years of public service and trying to turn the ethical tables on Ms. Lingle. She says that as mayor of Maui, Ms. Lingle failed to stop a grading operation by land developers that damaged Maalaea Harbor and cost taxpayers $300,000. She also said Ms. Lingle hired her former husband to represent her in a lawsuit filed against the city and steered business to an auto dealership owned by her father.
"If we're going to talk about ethics, why don't we talk about these lapses?" Ms. Hirono said.
The differences between the two candidates on issues seem relatively minor. Both are for diversifying the Hawaii economy away from its dependence on tourism and both advocate reform of the state-run school system. They differ on some environmental laws and consumer measures, but Ms. Hirono is basing her appeal largely on her service in the State Legislature and the lieutenant governor's office. She also not-so-subtly reminds people of her Japanese heritage (she emigrated with her single mother at age 8) and her up-by-the-bootstraps life story.
"Things are changing in Hawaii," Ms. Hirono said. "My question is, What kind of change, and who are you going to trust to make those changes?"
That is exactly the issue that many voters are struggling with today.
"We need a change," said Gerrie Griffin, 64, the assistant manager of Shooter's Bar and Restaurant, a few blocks from Waikiki beach. "It's time Hawaii stopped being a one-party state. Democrats keep going to jail, and it just seems there are so many dishonest people in politics."
Mrs. Griffin, who is half-Japanese, said she had been a Democrat all her life but was thinking of voting for Ms. Lingle. "It couldn't possibly get any worse," she said.

HEADLINE: THE 2002 CAMPAIGN; 
Golisano's Vision of Government: Leaner, More Efficient and Less Invasive

 BODY:
 Following are excerpts from an interview yesterday with Tom Golisano, the Independence Party candidate for governor, conducted by several editors and reporters of The New York Times. More excerpts are online at nytimes.com/nyregion.

Q. Let's start with the budget. . . . Outline for us $5 billion in savings.

A. . . . One of the areas, to get specific . . . is we have some areas of our state budget to me that are just absolutely definitely not positive to economic development. And the one I'm going to talk about is Medicaid. There's areas of Medicaid that should be very, very concerning to the residents of this state. . . . And No. 1, I think, is we have about 2.5 million people in this state that are using Medicaid as their primary insurance. Now you can argue all day long is -- of course, there are a lot of people that need Medicaid as a primary insurance. But the question mark is, have we drawn off, taken the line too high? And have we got too many people under that umbrella?
I know in New York City alone in the last 13 months there's been 400,000 new people signed up for Medicaid. And people have caught on, believe it or not, because we are in the human resource business. People have caught on to the fact that they can use Medicaid as their primary health insurance and not have to buy it on their own. This is an obvious result of too liberal an attitude about who can use Medicaid and how far they can use it. . . .
. . .

Q. . . . You would restrict more, tighten qualifications for Medicaid?

A. Absolutely. Yeah. . . . What we've done is create this situation where our attitude has become so liberal and so many people have come under this umbrella, that the taxpayers are faced with the fact that not only do most of us have to pay our own health insurance, but because of the liberalness of this Medicaid program we're paying it for millions of other people.
Now, certainly, having said that, we know many, many people need it. . . .
Education is always the second part of it. Because that's the second largest expenditure for the state, I believe. Some people would say the more money we can throw at education the better off we are. In some situations that may be true, but what we have in New York State in my opinion is we have the best of worlds and the worst of worlds. . . .
So what do we do about that? Well, obviously, I don't think the governor has done anything about it. Carl McCall's answer to these issues is to throw more money at it. He threw out a figure that was so outrageous to me I just couldn't believe it. And that was if he had another $8 billion he would give it all to education. He says we've got to reduce class size. Well, if you do the arithmetic on class size, class size is not the issue. Something else is the issue. Is it the curriculum? Is it the facilities that we're teaching these young people in? By aggregating hundreds of children from economic and cultural poverty, is that creating a problem? Is it our school day? Is it our school year? I am sure there's a lot of answers and a lot of things that can be improved. But what's stopping us from doing it? The special interest is stopping us from doing it. And that's the teachers' union.

Q. Would you spend less? Are you saying you'd spend less?

A. No. I'm not saying that at all. . . .

Q. So your point of view is that the funding level right now is appropriate but it's not being used in the right way?

A. I think in many of our urban districts we're wasting a lot of money, not because what we're trying to achieve is a waste but because we're not being effective.

Q. But you're not proposing actually cutting back?

A. No, of course not. But before I would just start throwing large amounts, more money at this problem at a state level, I'd say, "O.K., school districts, what are you doing to become more efficient, more effective, and get your results higher?"

Q. Do you have specific ideas about what the teachers' union should let the state do?

A. I think we should open up the school day. We have this double-edged situation where the school day ends at 2:30, 3:00, and many children are shifted into day care, different facilities, different administration and so forth. If we had an elongated school day we could save the transfer of those students, the cost of the additional administration and the cost of the additional facilities. . . .

Q. Well, if you're talking about opening up the school day through renegotiating union contracts, and getting productivity increases through changes in union contracts, where exactly does the governor fit in? Since the governor doesn't negotiate contracts with teachers?

A. Teachers' union controls an entire financial environment relative to the state. The state, the governor or the Legislature can't come in and say, "O.K. teachers' union or administrators, we want to change the school day." It's not just the governor alone it's the Legislature, too.

Q. O.K. But I'm still a little bit fuzzy about whether you would cut education aid. Do you think that there's a possibility to save money on education aid?

A. What I'm saying is, before we increase the levels of aid, we ought to start taking a look at our effectiveness and efficiency at what we're accomplishing, because throwing money at this problem . . . historically never solves a problem. And that's what I think George Pataki and especially Carl McCall are advocating that we do. . . .

Q. . . . Are there other places in the state government that you would cut in order to get this spending under control?

A. Well, one of the things that you have to look at, of course, is the state payroll. Now, compared to Medicaid and education, I don't think there's as huge an opportunity there. But if you look at the number of employees in New York State on a per-100,000 basis of population, we have a much higher percentage of employees at a much higher pay rate. . . .

Q. So how many heads do you think you could get out of the state payroll and still not affect the delivery of services?

A. . . . If we couldn't reduce the number of employees by 15 or 20 percent, I'd be surprised. . . .

Q. I have a follow-up question on Medicaid . . . If you're restricting people from that Medicaid, what is there to make up for people who don't have the insurance?

A. O.K., remember, this is a question of degree. I said earlier there are many people that absolutely need Medicaid and we need to provide it. But what's happened is the top line has gotten gray. . . .

Q. Do you know how many people you're talking about you believe you could cut without ----

A. Well, I know there's probably 2.5 million people on New York State Medicaid now using it as a primary health insurance. I wouldn't be surprised if we couldn't cut at least 20 percent of them. . . .

Q. You've been running some radio ads upstate suggesting that you would send children to college for free if they can get a B average. That the governor signed legislation to provide state tuition and scholarships to undocumented immigrants. What would your policy be toward undocumented immigrants who now receive a lot of state services without having to prove citizenship?

A. As a taxpayer of this state it makes me unhappy to think that we have an aggressive liberal policy toward people that are not here on a legal basis. . . .

Q. The B or better plan -- opportunity scholarship initiative. You're talking about shifting the lottery money out of the general fund and devoting it to this program.

A. That's right.

Q. Sir, can I go back to the lottery money?

A. Sure.

Q. Because I'm a little confused by that idea. You said it's $1.9 billion coming in in the lottery. Right?

A. Between $1.8 and $1.9 billion, net revenue, to the state.

Q. O.K. So I'm just thinking of this in terms of accounting. So you would take that lottery money and you would designate it for the scholarship program that you proposed?

A. Yes.

Q. Isn't that a growth in the state budget?

A. It's not having as much funds available for other things. You're absolutely correct. And that's why, as I said earlier, if I'm governor, that we have to go after the expense side. And the Medicaid thing, the state payroll and all of those things have to come down before we could fully implement this thing.

Q. So you would designate that money for the scholarship program and then make appropriate cuts to compensate for its loss.

A. Absolutely. Absolutely.

Q. You're talking about an earthquake in Albany terms. I mean if you're ----

A. Isn't that wonderful? You think it's time?

Q. Well, I mean I think it'd be fun to cover.

A. I think it would be exciting, too.

Q. You know that you're facing some entrenched interests in the Senate and the Assembly.

A. Really? I didn't know that.

Q. What leverage do you have? And how would you use it? I mean how are you going to get Shelly Silver and Joe Bruno to go along with the executive?

A. That's a great question. Well, first of all, if I get elected governor, I mean that'll shake the foundation a bit. O.K.? Because it'll be the realization that most people in New York State realize there's something wrong in Albany, that it's dysfunctional. And they want it changed. O.K. Beyond that, when we get to a particular issue, and you can pick one if you'd like, the opportunity for me to go to the public, because I have the resources to do it and I'm willing to use the bully pulpit to do it and I'm not obligated to the special interests, I would just go beyond them and go to the public. . . .

Q. On a completely different subject, the rebuilding of the Trade Center downtown is largely a state matter. Do you have personal visions of what ought to be there?

A. . . . There is no question about it, that thing is as important to our history as Pearl Harbor was. Secondly, it's also very vitally important to New York City economically. So I am in the camp of let's build an appropriate memorial for part of the land . . . and then devote the rest of it to economic recovery and economic development. You know what? I think the federal government should contribute to the construction of that memorial. . . .

Q. What can a governor do to bring those jobs back to New York?

A. . . . New York State has 300,000-plus businesses. What we have to do is create a better environment for those 300,000 businesses for two reasons. We need to have them grow. And we need to have more of them formed. Because we know most job creation now is in the small-business environment and not in the large-business environment. So how do you do that? Well, you do it by making New York State a better place to live economically. We have to bring taxes down. . . . The second thing we have to go after, we still have the third highest, fourth highest workers' compensation rates in the country. And the only reason that is is because we're too liberal on the benefits program. . . .
Third, health insurance. The cost of being an employer in this state for health insurance, every year double-digit growth rates. And we have among the highest rates because of those mandates, those surcharges, etc.
And the fourth thing is the bureaucratic process. . . .

Q. A couple of social issue questions. On gay rights . . .

A. My attitude on gay rights or any of those other issues, I believe the government should have as least impact as impossible. And its No. 1 responsibility is to provide parity and equality to people.

Q. You know a lot of prosecutors love the Rockefeller drug laws. They use them in a way to get a leverage over people they arrest.

A. Yes, I know.

Q. What are you planning -- why fix the system if it ain't broke? Crime is down. Why do this?

A. . . . We've got to find new ways to fight this drug war. The Rockefeller laws were set up to be an end-all. We'll put them away forever. We have people going to jail for 15 years to life at $30,000 to $40,000 a year for having up to four ounces of a substance. That, to me, the constitutional theory that the crime must befit the punishment or the punishment must befit the crime, certainly doesn't seem to apply. . . . So I'm on the camp that says the Rockefeller drug laws are too harsh and they should be repealed. Do we continue to fight drugs? Absolutely. It's a scourge on our society. And we've got to do everything we can do. Do I believe that more effort should be pushed toward prevention and treatment rather than incarceration? Yes, I do.

Q. Sir, we have another example of a man who funded his own campaign and went to government in which he says he is free of the special interests. And he is also facing a huge budget problem right now and having to make very tough choices, not beholden to any group but still having to cut, what looks like will be cuts. And he's also switched and said now he's going to raise taxes. Are there any lessons in that? Or is there anything that you see in that that you are using to guide your own life?

A. I think the first thing is a major difference between myself and Michael Bloomberg as relates to political parties. Michael funded his own campaign, but he's part of the Republican Party. And a number of the -- obviously other members of the Republican Party are very dependent on special interests. Whereas I don't have that condition or that environment. . . .

Q. So would you compare yourself more then to Ross Perot than to Mike Bloomberg?

A. The only person I compare myself to is Tom Golisano.

Q. Well, tell us who that guy is a little bit. People in New York don't know you very well. Leaders have distinctive personalities as leaders. . . .

A. You want me to give you a quick rundown of myself?

Q. Sure. . . . What should people in New York expect if you show up in January in the State House?

A. I don't think I've seen a political candidate that understands financial statements like I do. I'm very economically and results-oriented. I really believe that government should stay out of our lives as much as possible. I don't think we should look to government to solve all of our problems. I really believe in parity and equality and preach it at our company. . . .

Q. . . . How do you approach governing? . . .

A. No. I'm going to tell you, the first day out is, first day in office is, there are many components to state government, the first questions I'm going to ask is: What's our level of satisfaction of our customers? How do we improve it? What's it cost us? And how are we going to save money? That's what you do in a daily routine in business and that's, in my opinion, is how the government should function.

The Candidates
This report is the second resulting from interviews with leading candidates for governor conducted by reporters and editors of The New York Times. Gov. George E. Pataki has said he will not participate.

HEADLINE: THE 2002 CAMPAIGN: THE INDEPENDENT; 
Golisano Proposes Stern Measures to Close Budget Gap and Avoid Tax Rise

BYLINE:  By RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD 

 BODY:
Tom Golisano, the Independence Party candidate for governor, said yesterday that he would close the state's looming budget deficit by pushing some people off Medicaid, limiting others from signing up and holding the line on financing for education.
 He said stern measures were needed to avert tax increases that he said would block economic revitalization. Serious budget reduction must start with Medicaid and education because they are the state's two costliest programs, he said. But, he said, such proposals are "not going to make a lot of people happy." 
 In a 90-minute interview with editors and reporters of The New York Times, Mr. Golisano, a Rochester billionaire who is financing his own campaign, discussed with unusual detail proposals to cut popular programs. 
His opponents, Gov. George E. Pataki, a Republican, and H. Carl McCall, a Democrat, have offered few hints of how they would close a budget gap that could exceed $5 billion next year. Mr. Pataki has said he would make the government operate more efficiently and Mr. McCall has said he would convene a panel of experts.
Mr. Golisano, 60, also promised to bring an earthquake to Albany with a no-nonsense, corporate executive's approach that is intolerant of back-room dealing and political quid pro quos.
If legislative leaders stonewall him -- he needs legislative support for many of his ideas, including changing the Medicaid rules -- he said he would take his case to the public with a media campaign, like the television commercials he is running in his bid for office.
In his third run for governor, a Times poll shows him at 16 percent, compared with 39 percent for Governor Pataki and 28 percent for Mr. McCall, the state comptroller. He garnered 8 percent of the vote when he ran in 1998.
Mr. Golisano said that trimming Medicaid, the medical insurance program for the poor and elderly, by 20 percent -- or about 560,000 people -- through more stringent qualification limits could close or seriously dent the deficit in the state budget next year. He said that in recent years the state has expanded services to people without worrying about the consequences to the budget.
"There are a lot of people that need Medicaid as a primary insurance," Mr. Golisano said. "But the question mark is, have we taken the line too high? And have we got too many people under that umbrella?"
Mr. Golisano said, however, he would press on with a plan he has been pushing through his campaign ads to grant free tuition at state colleges to high school seniors with a grade average of B or better. To finance that plan, he proposes using $1.4 billion from the state lottery now devoted to the general fund for school aid. It would be a de facto expansion of education spending, and Mr. Golisano vows to fill the gap from the redirected lottery money by cutting other parts of the budget.
Beyond fiscal matters, Mr. Golisano, who has said he never registered to vote with any major party, showed a divergence on social issues that made his ideology difficult to pin down. He would cut off illegal immigrants from state services. He would sign a state law outlawing discrimination against gays in housing and employment. He believes in gun rights and keeps a shotgun -- for skeet shooting, he says -- under his bed. He advocates the use of marijuana for medical purposes. He believes government is too intrusive in people's lives.
But the heart of his campaign is an unsparing approach to fixing the state budget, which he promises to review as severely as the ledgers at Paychex, the company he founded three decades ago, of which he is still the C.E.O.
"The first questions I'm going to ask are, 'What's our level of satisfaction of our customers?' " Mr. Golisano said, imagining his first day in office. " 'How do we improve it? What's it cost us? And how are we going to save money?' That's what you do in a daily routine in business and that's, in my opinion, how the government should function."
Medicaid, which serves nearly three million people, is the largest expense for state and local governments, at a total of more than $30 billion a year, and New York spends more on it than any other state.
Mr. McCall has also said he would take aim at Medicaid but, in an interview earlier this week, suggested that the problem was poor management of it through overpayments to providers. 
Michael McKeon, Mr. Pataki's chief spokesman, said Mr. Golisano's proposal would be disastrous for people without other ways to pay medical bills. "This is a guy who wants to slash health care services for people in need," he said.
Mr. Pataki tried to cut Medicaid during his first several years in office, with some success, only to reverse course. He has significantly increased health care spending, as he has forged a close alliance with 1199/S.E.I.U., the powerful hospital workers' union, and its president, Dennis Rivera. 
Mr. Golisano scorns those kinds of alliances, insisting he is not beholden to special interests and, because he is financing his own campaign, owes nothing to anyone. Because he lacks ties to any unions, he said, he could wield the budget ax with a ferocity he considers lacking in his opponents.
He made a similar argument in addressing education, the second-largest expense for the state, scoffing at people who believe education can be improved by "throwing more money at it."
"The last thing we should do right off the top of our hat is start throwing more money at education," he said. "And that is what Carl McCall wants to do. And George Pataki is proud of the fact that he's continuing to throw more money at education. I think from a financial aspect we've got to step back for a few minutes and say, how are we doing and why are we doing this? And what kind of results are we getting?"
Mr. Golisano said he believed school districts operate inefficiently and can save millions of dollars by going on a fiscal diet.
To superintendents asking for money, he would say, "O.K., school districts, what are you doing to become more efficient, more effective, and get your results higher?"
Mr. Golisano identified teachers' unions as the principal obstacle to carrying out changes he would advocate to improve learning, like lengthening the school day and school year and improving curriculums. 
He believes there is an overemphasis on standardized tests but did not explicitly propose rolling them back. He suggested alternative measurements must be considered, particularly because children in urban areas face social and economic difficulties not seen in the suburbs, which he believes affect learning. He brought up problems like teenage pregnancy and dropout rates, and frequently cited the experiences of the school district in Rochester, his hometown, as instrumental in shaping his thinking.
In fact, he brought an upstate perspective to issues that was in contrast to Mr. Pataki and Mr. McCall, both of whom have tried to connect with voters upstate.
On New York City issues, like redeveloping the site of the World Trade Center, Mr. Golisano suggested that the city should have a greater say, despite the governor's role in appointing half of the board, including the chairman, of the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation. Mr. Golisano said the priority should be establishing a memorial. 
"This is just as much, if not more of, a New York City issue than a State of New York issue," Mr. Golisano said. "I think the role of the governor here is to help bring in some federal money, potentially, for the construction of the memorial and for any other infrastructure component that may be helpful. I think the role of the governor here is to encourage action. I mean, you know, we're quite a few months past this thing. And we don't seem to have a clear sense of direction."
For the sluggish economy, he prescribes lowering taxes for businesses and employees in order to draw more companies to New York. He said he would also work to lower workers' compensation and health insurance costs for employers.
Mr. Golisano said he would enter Albany ready to battle the status quo, but not always as a lonely warrior. He said he recognized the need to negotiate, particularly with Sheldon Silver, the Assembly speaker, and Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader, but would stand his ground when necessary.
"The only time you have a good deal is if both sides feel they can win," Mr. Golisano said of his negotiating tactics. "Now there are going to be times when the person on the other side of the table is not going to be reasonable, in your opinion. And then you're going to have to stand your ground."
He added: "We always have to have a redefinition of what victory means to everybody. For example, I'm dealing with Joe Bruno and with Shelly Silver. That's a very important discussion to have right off the bat. What is the definition of victory here? What are we trying to accomplish?"

HEADLINE: Doubts Aside, Pataki Aides See No Gap in the Budget 

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 18 

 BODY:
The Pataki administration defended the state budget today, saying it would hold together through the last six months of the fiscal year despite lagging tax collections.
 H. Carl McCall, the state comptroller who is also Gov. George E. Pataki's Democratic challenger in the governor's race, has suggested that a hole will open in the budget shortly after the election. Mr. McCall's office put out a report earlier this week that said tax collections would have to rise steeply over the next six months to keep the state's books balanced. That is unlikely given the sluggish economy, Mr. McCall said. 
 His skepticism is shared by some bond analysts and other budget experts, who doubt that the stock market and the state economy will improve enough in the second half of the fiscal year to make Mr. Pataki's spending plan work. 
But senior budget officials in the Pataki administration dispute those assertions. They maintain that the naysayers are not taking into account several new sources of revenue expected to materialize in the second half of the year, like $175 million from a tax amnesty program and $300 million from the sale of abandoned assets seized by the state.
The governor's budget office also played down the importance of the slight rise in spending in the first half of the fiscal year. Many of the cost-saving measures the governor is counting on, like a hiring freeze he instituted, will not begin to show results until the second half. 
Finally, the administration officials said, about $1 billion in state health and welfare programs is scheduled to be moved out of the state budget over the next six months and will soon be financed with hospital surcharges and federal money.
"For the first six months of the year we are on track with our plan, revenues are coming in slightly above our expectations, and we are continuing our prudent financial management that has successfully contained spending growth," said Carole E. Stone, budget director for Mr. Pataki.
New York City, meanwhile, has its own budget morass. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg has been bracing for a $5-to-$6-billion budget gap for next fiscal year, as well as possible shortfalls this year, by seeking $1 billion in cuts from city agencies. He said today he was pessimistic that the city's current revenue projections would hold up over the next nine months. "We may or may not have enough," Mr. Bloomberg said. 
As for the state government, some analysts say the steep drop in tax collections during the first six months does not bode well, especially when coupled with a slight rise in spending.
In July, the governor updated his financial plan to say the state would collect about $40 billion in taxes this fiscal year, a 3 percent drop from last year, and spend it all. Spending out of the general fund, which does not include federal money or specialized state taxes, was supposed to fall by $1 billion, or about 2.4 percent. 
The comptroller's office's mid-year report, however, showed that tax revenues were down by at least 7.5 percent, or $1.5 billion, for the first half of the year, budget officials said.
Over the same period, spending out of the general fund ticked up slightly, by about $300 million.
That means that to meet his goal, Mr. Pataki will have to cut spending by $1.3 billion in the second half of the year, and revenue collections will have to be about $850 million more than in the same period a year ago. 
Robert A. Kurtter, an analyst for Moody's Investment Service, said that was a tall order given the current state of the stock market. About two-thirds of the tax revenue comes from income tax, and half of that comes from a small fraction of the population, people who make more than $200,000 a year in adjusted gross income. Unless income from stocks picks up, it is possible that the state could see a $2 billion shortfall this year, Mr. Kurtter said.
"The answer is simple," he said. "You have got to see improvement in the stock market."
State budget officials say that possibility is remote. It is true, they say, that revenues must rise $850 million over the next six months, but most of that money will come from actions worth $750 million that are already in the budget, including the tax amnesty. 
In addition, many of the spending reductions totaling $1 billion are not real cutbacks but a shifting of costs from the state to the federal welfare program or to pools of money fed by hospital surcharges.
The only danger, budget officials say, is that income tax revenues will continue to plummet faster than predicted, something that will be hard to calculate until January. 
One measure of the delicate fiscal position of the state is that the amount of cash it has on hand after six months this year is $5 billion less than last year.
"They are just hemorrhaging cash," Mr. Kurtter said.

An article on Saturday about New York State's financial condition misspelled the given name of Gov. George E. Pataki's budget director in some copies. She is Carole E. Stone, not Carol.

HEADLINE: National Briefing Washington: Small Social Security Increase 

BYLINE:  AP 

 BODY:
 Social Security recipients will receive a 1.4 percent cost-of-living increase in their monthly checks next year, the smallest increase in four years. The new figure reflects a slowdown in inflation caused by the weak economy. The increase will mean an extra $13 a month for a typical retiree, beginning in January. It will affect 46 million people who receive Social Security benefits and 7 million recipients of Supplemental Security Income, the program for the needy. The increase last year was 2.6 percent.

HEADLINE: THE 2002 CAMPAIGN: THE PRESIDENT; 
President Pays Quick Visits To Candidates In Close Races

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: ROCHESTER, Minn., Oct. 18 

 BODY:
President Bush dropped into the middle of two pivotal Senate races today as he campaigned for a pair of Republican candidates recruited by the White House, former Representative Jim Talent of Missouri and former Mayor Norm Coleman of St. Paul, whose victories could change the balance of power on Capitol Hill.
 With only 18 days to go before the Nov. 5 elections, Mr. Bush's political aides have plotted his time by sending him to key states for lightning strikes -- Mr. Bush spent less than an hour and a half in Missouri today. But with the Talent and Coleman campaigns among the half-dozen closest races in the country, a brief glimpse of the presidential pageantry and a quick White House endorsement might make a difference. 
 "Obviously, this helps fire up the troops," said Ken Mehlman, the White House political director, who was hovering in the back of a crowd of thousands at the Rochester Community and Technical College Field House. "It keeps supporters energized, and it reaches out to those who are undecided."
So today, in rallies that were a flashback to 2000 and a foreshadowing of 2004, Mr. Bush shouted out his worries about terrorism and the American economy to thousands of invited, flag-waving guests. He also tailored what he said were the advantages of his tax cut to each state, saying that over 10 years it would save $38 billion in Minnesota and $32 billion in Missouri -- where, interestingly, Mr. Talent's Democratic opponent, Senator Jean Carnahan, is also a supporter of it. Mrs. Carnahan voted for the tax cut in May 2001.
Mr. Bush did not mention that fact today, and instead lavished praise on Mr. Talent as a man who "understands what I'm talking about." He also said that Mr. Talent did not need a focus group to tell him what to think and that he, like Mr. Bush, had married above himself -- a compliment that the president bestowed four hours later on Mr. Coleman, as he does for virtually every male Republican political candidate. 
"Like me, he married well," Mr. Bush said to a roaring crowd.
Mr. Coleman is running against Senator Paul Wellstone, one of the most outspoken liberals in Congress and one of 23 senators who voted against the resolution giving Mr. Bush the authority to attack Iraq, prompting attacks from Mr. Coleman. Mr. Bush did not wade into that local battle today, but instead engaged in his near-daily lashing of Saddam Hussein.
"So long as there's a threat out there, your government will do everything we can to protect you," Mr. Bush said.
Still, Mr. Bush spent nearly half of both speeches, which ran an unusually long 42 minutes and 50 minutes, respectively, on the economy, an issue that Americans say he is not spending enough time taking about.
"And I tell you, we've got some problems -- and we do," the president said here. "The economy is not as good as we'd like it to be. There are too many people looking for work and can't find it."
Mr. Bush got agreement on that from Cheryl Coryea, 51, a Republican from Minnetonka, Minn., who had come to hear the president speak. Ms. Coryea is an unemployed corporate finance officer.
"I can tell you that I'm out looking for a job, and there's nothing out there. Everything is cold," said Ms. Coryea, who supports Mr. Bush.
She said she was concerned about going to war with Iraq and wished that the president had addressed her concerns at home. "I think he should have spent more time on the economy," Ms. Coryea said.
Mr. Bush's appearances today took him to two states that will be of special concern to the White House in 2004. In 2000, Mr. Bush won Missouri but lost Minnesota.
Today, in a briefing to reporters on Air Force One, the White House spokesman, Ari Fleischer, proclaimed that Mr. Bush was the "new sheriff in town and he's dedicated to fiscal discipline."
"And Congress for the first time in a decade has listened to the new sheriff," he said in reference to spending.
Mr. Fleischer did not address why Congress had not so far listened to Mr. Bush on matters like a Department of Homeland Security and terrorism insurance.
