HEADLINE: FILM; 
Fresh Eye on a Jaded Slice of New York

BYLINE:  By JAMIE MALANOWSKI; Jamie Malanowski's most recent article for Arts & Leisure was about the "Austin Powers" movies.

 BODY:
IT'S a confident director who is willing to take the major theme of his film and whip it past his audience like a Pedro Martinez fastball before the moviegoers have managed to get their Peanut Chews unwrapped. Yet in "Roger Dodger," 33-year-old Dylan Kidd, directing his first feature from his first screenplay, does exactly that.
 Setting the film's opening scene at a table in one of those $16-a-cocktail Manhattan restaurants, Mr. Kidd captures five fashionable New Yorkers in mid-banter about the commonplace subject of men, women and the future of the species. But one of them, Roger, played by Campbell Scott, is clearly smarter, sharper and more motivated. While the others want an amusing lunch, Roger aims to compete. And while the others take up the subject to be arch and flirty, Roger wants to present a cleverly cloaked truth: that the male of the species is evolving into irrelevancy. 
 "Ten to 15 generations from now, men will be reduced to servitude," he declaims. "Technology and evolution will have combined to exclude sperm from procreation and our final destiny will be to perform heavy lifting and wait for that day when . . . our gender's last remaining utility is lost forever." 
His friends laugh, and the film moves on. Only later does the audience realize that what it has registered as a moment of sophisticated wit is really a cri de coeur. Roger, drifting in a relationship that's going nowhere, working as an advertising copywriter in a job that bores him, is one hurting, angry cowpoke.
"What I find really interesting about being in New York," said Mr. Kidd over drinks and dinner recently at a $16-a-cocktail Manhattan restaurant, "is that there are a lot of people who are incredibly successful, intelligent and pretty amazing at figuring out other people's weaknesses. Yet these same intelligent people will have absolutely no awareness of what's driving them.
"Before I wrote even a word of this film I was thinking, 'Wouldn't it be fun to make a movie about a bunch of people who are talking here' " -- his right hand mocks a salute at eye level -- " 'and have no idea that this is the real story down here.' " (For the record, just above where his fish lies on its platter.)
"Roger Dodger," which opens Friday, is a real New York film, in the "All About Eve" tradition. Roger's wit and verbal nimbleness would allow him to feel right at home with those vipers. Although, if anything, he's nastier. While he's charismatic in the striking opening scene, we subsequently see him apply his gifts rather less charmingly.
"Roger is somebody who likes to verbally spar," Mr. Kidd says. "He's a gunfighter with words, and he likes to win. I was nervous writing a screenplay built on a character this angry, because maybe people wouldn't want to spend time with him. But when I see a character who's smart, I want to keep watching, even though he's a jerk. And Campbell brings some weird, intangible thing that makes you want to give him the benefit of the doubt. He invests Roger with so much charisma, that even when he's a jerk, the audience is willing to stick around, thinking there's a chance for redemption."
THAT chance comes in the form of Roger's teenage nephew, Nick, who shows up unbidden and unannounced from some Midwestern suburb Roger had long forsaken. Roger's nastiness has been whetted after he's dumped by Joyce, his lover and boss, played by Isabella Rossellini, who has never been more self-evidently desirable. Nick, played with a perfectly pitched expression of incredulity by a newcomer, Jesse Eisenberg (elder brother of the Pepsi girl Hallie Kate Eisenberg), has skipped town after some unexplained flare-up at home. But it's not at all clear why he's come to the less-than-avuncular Uncle Roger. Roger's in the dark, too, but out of some perverse sense of familial duty he decides to help the lad -- by engineering his sexual initiation. And so he takes him into the night on a tour of Roger World, where "Sex and the City"-type women wait to be seduced and abandoned.
"Roger Dodger" may be Mr. Kidd's first feature, but he's been directing for years. The only child of a college professor and an arts administrator, Mr. Kidd grew up, as he puts it, "all over the East Coast." After a false start as a philosophy major at George Washington, he responded to an ad in American Film magazine and enrolled in New York University's film program. Graduating in 1991 into the teeth of a recession, he shuffled through a series of odd jobs in and out of the film business. After several years he determined that he wanted to direct. In 1996 he made a short film, "Ian's Ghost," that won several awards, and then spent his time doing what he terms "industry grunt work" -- industrial movies, fashion videos, corporate work.
"I was happy to do it," he says. "I'd do an industrial tomorrow. You can learn from anything. Even with a corporate job, you're still learning to tell a story. And the way the early 90's were, I don't turn my nose up at anything."
Along the way he wrote screenplays, though "Roger Dodger" was the first he had enough confidence in to show anyone. Getting it to the screen required an out-of-the-blue turn of events worthy of a fairy tale, or perhaps the plot of an indie movie.
"The catch in getting a film made is to get around a firewall of agents to get talent attached," Mr. Kidd says. He and one of his his co-producers, Anne Chaisson, went through the standard process of approaching actors through their agents, but got nowhere. Finally, Mr. Kidd made a decision. "I said: 'You know what? You know how I'm going to feel that I'm for real? Every day I'm going to carry a copy of the script with me, because I'm in New York, and I'm bound to run into somebody.' " 
After a few weeks, he did. Mr. Kidd saw Mr. Scott in a restaurant on Carmine Street in Greenwich Village, and though they were not acquainted on any level, made an approach. "I expected to get the response 99 percent of actors will give you, which is send it to my agent," Mr. Kidd says. "But he took it." A few weeks later, the phone rang. "I was shaving in my boxers," recalls Mr. Kidd. "And the voice said, 'Hey, it's Campbell!' And I didn't know who it was. So I did that thing where you think you'll figure out who it is and said, 'Heeeeeey!' And about 30 seconds later I realized it was him!" 
Mr. Scott was immediately inclined to play Roger -- "It's a very showy part, and not the kind of character I usually get to do," he says -- so much so that he had few reservations about working with a first-time director. "Dylan is very smart, and firm in a very positive way," says Mr. Scott by telephone. "He's able to take in a lot of emotional information quickly, and reproduce it. I was impressed with how assured he was. Working in the city last fall wasn't the easiest thing, and he had a very tight schedule. Yet he was able to listen to the actors and deal with what we wanted, and at the same time get what he wanted from us."
The results are surprisingly accomplished. There are a lot of good films made by capable first-time directors, but there are few where the director seems to have so many ideas. The film was shot with a hand-held camera by Joaquin Baca-Asay, the director of photography, with whom Mr. Kidd has a long association on his industrial films and other projects. The proximity the hand-held camera affords gives the whole film an immediate feel, and its movement underscores the action. "Dylan wanted to push the envelope in what he could depict," said Ms. Chaisson. "He wanted Joaquin to be very aggressive with the camera."
In the opening scene, for example, as the bantering starts going against Roger, the camera starts losing interest in him; when he rallies, he gets it back. The middle portion of the movie depicts an encounter between Roger and Nick and two dancers played by Jennifer Beals and Elizabeth Berkley, first in a bar and then in a park. Mr. Kidd gives the camera to the actors; it moves in tight with glistening close-ups that conjure those tense, swoony, breathless moments when one isn't sure if a romantic encounter is on its way or not. The scene climaxes with Mr. Eisenberg and Ms. Beals sharing a kiss that will surely rank as one of the most charged movie moments of the year.
"Movies can't work with the frontal lobe," says Mr. Kidd. "We can't tell the audience what to feel. We can only figure out what we want them to take away from a scene, and then use the camera to suggest where the undercurrent is going."
Mr. Kidd's personal current seems to be moving quickly. Just a little more than one very fast year since he gave the script to Mr. Scott, the movie, which got strong reactions on the festival circuit, is about to open theatrically. It might be enough to turn a newcomer's head, but Mr. Kidd, who lives in Sunnyside, Queens, with two cats, seems to be working very hard to keep his success at arm's length.
"When a small movie breaks in a certain way, well-meaning people come out of the woodwork and try to get you into the Hollywood system," he says. "Not me. I plan to stay in New York and work on smaller-budget movies. At one point Joaquin said that if we had $20 million to make this movie, we'd mess it up. And he was right; we'd junk it up with something. I want to work at a level where everyone's talent can directly impact the film. That way it's fun -- the most fun activity in the world. Two years ago I was struggling and wondering if it was worth it. Well, it is so worth it."

SECTION: Section 2; Column 2; Arts and Leisure Desk; Pg. 30

HEADLINE: MUSIC; 
Don't Call It a String Quartet. It's a Band.

BYLINE:  By STEVE SMITH; Steve Smith is the classical music editor of Time Out New York.

 BODY:
EVERY month, dozens of ambitious, hungry young bands play in the cramped confines of the KnitActive Sound Stage, downstairs at the Knitting Factory in TriBeCa. So an appearance there tonight by Ethel, a four-piece band hoping that the club's downtown cachet will attract a new audience, may seem nothing unusual. Yet Ethel is basically a classical string quartet, and its concert of works by John King, Phil Kline and Julia Wolfe is part of Sonic Boom, a festival presented by the New York Consortium for New Music, which promotes contemporary classical music.
 "What image does a string quartet put in your head?" asked Mary Rowell, an intense violinist who has played a prominent role in new-music and alternative rock scenes for more than 20 years. "A dour group of people playing perfectly together in perfect harmony. That's not the path that I wanted to go down." 
 In 1998, Ms. Rowell was hired for a recording session along with Todd Reynolds, another violinist, Ralph Farris, a violist, and Dorothy Lawson, a cellist. The collaboration of these extraordinarily skilled, passionate musicians sparked a surge of creative energy and potential. "It felt like a group of friends forming a band," Ms. Rowell said. 
Tapping into a rapidly changing new-music scene, Ethel has graduated with remarkable speed from isolated performances at the Cutting Room, Galapagos and Joe's Pub, which normally feature offbeat strands of popular music, to an extensive string of concerts and series this season. Those appearances, ranging from the club date tonight to a Lincoln Center debut in May, are intended to show different facets of the group's evolving approach to presenting concert music in the 21st century.
Before coming together, the Ethel players were among the busiest freelance musicians in New York. They had performed individually and together in establishment mainstays like the American Symphony Orchestra, Orpheus and the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center as well as in new-music ensembles, including the Bang on a Can All-Stars.
Each player also had extensive experience outside classical music. Ms. Rowell was a member of the Silos, a noted rock band, and she performed and recorded with the pop singers Joe Jackson and Sheryl Crow. Mr. Reynolds, who composes and conducts, improvised with wild abandon as a member of the Mahavishnu Project, an electric jazz-fusion band, and appeared onstage as a dancing fiddler in the Broadway revival of "Annie, Get Your Gun." Ms. Lawson played regularly with the Brazilian jazz pianist Marcelo Zarvos and performed in the pit band for an Off Broadway musical, Jason Robert Brown's "Last Five Years." Mr. Farris served as music director for the Who vocalist Roger Daltrey and as an arranger and orchestrator for pop recordings.
Such diversity is expected of freelance musicians, especially in New York, where conventional work prospects can be scarce. In a difficult economic climate, orchestras and presenters hire fewer soloists, increasingly relying on a handful of guaranteed best sellers.
"For my generation graduating from university, the careers we had been prepared for already didn't exist," Ms. Lawson said. "We had to go out and feel our way along and come up with a lot of things that we'd love to do instead."
Those activities were also responses to challenges within the classical world itself. In school, both Ms. Rowell and Mr. Reynolds encountered resistance from instructors when they tried to bring new music by Philip Glass and Steve Reich into an academic setting. For all four musicians, now in their 30's and 40's, it was natural as well to work in the popular musical forms of their upbringing.
They were already aware of one another when they joined forces for the first time in the recording studio. The excitement they felt while playing together, combined with the diverse musical tastes and experiences they shared, led them to conclude that they could create a performing situation that would address all their artistic interests; in time, perhaps, it might even generate steady work without compromise.
Styling themselves a band rather than a string quartet allowed them to sidestep the pressures of classical music tradition and expectation. "A band doesn't necessarily have an allegiance to anything," Mr. Reynolds said. "A group of four guys, of four girls, of mixed folks gets together and says, 'We want to present an idea.' There's no tradition about this behavior, necessarily. You're just putting an idea out there."
The quartet called itself Hazardous Materials for its earliest concerts, a name soon dropped for its negative connotations. As the players considered other names, Ms. Rowell remembered a scene from the movie "Shakespeare in Love": Shakespeare racked with writer's block as he tried to complete a play called "Romeo and Ethel, the Pirate's Daughter." Ms. Rowell suggested Ethel as a name. Improbably, it stuck.
The group adopted many trappings of popular culture, producing stylish press kits, establishing a Web site with vivid graphics and downloadable MP3 files (www.ethelcentral.com) and participating in a live Webcast. It incorporated lighting, video, choreography and other rock elements in its presentations.
STILL, if Ethel were truly to be a band instead of a string quartet, the music would have to reflect the distinction. The group took up works by young composers who shared its diverse interests, including Mr. King and Ms. Wolfe, who both compose in rock-influenced styles.
"The string quartet goes together like singer, guitar, bass and drums," Mr. King said. "It's a thing in itself that is a great voice for putting out musical ideas." Ms. Wolfe added, "It's the closest classical group I can think of to a rock band."
The Kronos Quartet long ago abolished the hegemony of establishment composers by commissioning all manner of musical artists to write string quartets. Ethel has taken the process a step farther. During some concerts, the players improvise new material to segue between compositions, creating a flow the way D.J.'s do when spinning records, something that might give pause to even the most open-minded composer.
"I wasn't sure how I was going to feel about that," said Ms. Wolfe, a Bang on a Can composer whose spiky, dissonant works have quickly become an Ethel specialty. "But they did it really tastefully, and there was still an acknowledgment of the composers who were making the pieces."
All those elements, and undoubtedly others, will be in evidence in three concerts that Ethel will present at the Kitchen in Chelsea from Oct. 31 to Nov. 2. Mr. King, the Kitchen's music director, booked the series as a coming-out for the group, which will present programs illustrating several aspects of its wide-ranging vision. Among the works to be presented on the first night -- appropriately for Halloween -- is a piece based on the writings of Poe, collaboratively composed by the four members.
Beginning in February, Ethel will present a series at the Miller Theater of Columbia University, devoted chiefly to the quartets of Ms. Wolfe and John Zorn. Each program will also include at least one premiere. Then in May, Ethel takes its countercultural approach to the altar of classical music culture, performing works by Mr. King, Mr. Reynolds and Evan Ziporyn in the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center's new-music series Double Exposure.
Ethel's timing has been serendipitous, a fact not lost on its members. But more important to them is the pleasure they take in one another's company, which is apparent both on stage and off. Egalitarian ambitions aside, their partnership is ultimately based on mutual understanding and acceptance.
"We're four extroverts that in a lot of instances have felt like sore thumbs," Mr. Farris says, "and we found three other thumbs to go along."

Sonic Boom Festival
Knitting Factory, 74 Leonard Street.
Today at 4 p.m.

Sherman)(pg. 30); Ethel played Erik Friedlander's "In Memoriam 9/11" in Berlin on Sept. 11, 2002: players of extraordinary passion and skill. (Associated Press)(pg. 32)

HEADLINE: Can One Man Make a Difference? 

BYLINE:  By STACEY STOWE 

 BODY:
HE is an ambassador for Hartford, the one who cuts the ribbons and gives the interviews. He is the man who presides over city government, opening meetings in the high-ceilinged chamber at City Hall from the power seat, flanked on either side by members of the City Council. His are perhaps the most visible shoulders to carry the hopes of this beleaguered city, but under law, the mayor of Hartford is little more than a figurehead, a man who can't even change the time of trash pick up without approval from nine council members.
 Most people in Hartford said that will change when the city decides on Election Day, Nov. 5, whether to reform the charter to replace its council-manager form of government with one run by a strong mayor. Voters will also decide whether to increase the terms of mayor and City Council members from two to four years. 
 For Eddie Perez, a Democrat who is Hartford's first Puerto Rican mayor, the change cannot come soon enough. After a long career in neighborhood organizing and as right-hand man for Evan S. Dobelle, the charismatic former president of Trinity College, Mr. Perez agreed to run for office only after he was sure the charter revision would pass. A strong mayor, one who serves as the chief executive of city government, is necessary in Hartford, he said, to restore faith in both its residents and businesses needed to invest in it. 
"The current separation of power creates a lack of confidence in political leadership," he said in a recent interview. "Private business and government know the powers are limited and act accordingly. A strong mayor would have the power to move an economic and social agenda in the city."
Such an agenda is a desperate necessity in Hartford, where 30 percent of the population lives in poverty, the school system is among the worst performing in the nation and there is an 80 percent chance a baby born here will have a single mother.
Hartford, along with Lowell and Worcester, Mass., is one of only three cities in New England with populations over 100,000 without a strong mayor form of government, said Allan B. Taylor, a Hartford lawyer who proposed charter reform for the city as early as 1986. Hartford changed to a council-manager form of government in 1947. At that time, although the city had a mayor, the true power had rested with various commissions with no centralized authority. In the past 20 years, the city has had eight city managers, some of whom are credited with negotiating union and pension contracts that experts said would bankrupt a private business.
Mr. Taylor calls the current status of the city an "oddball political moment," with the public dismay with the state of city government and the political balance on the council. He was referring to five council members, including two Democrats, two Republicans and one from the Green Party, who generally vote together.
The general consensus among residents and people in city government is that charter revision will easily pass in November. An attempt to push it through last December failed, some said, because the referendum question was bundled with several others and less than 15 percent -- the minimum number of voters needed -- failed to turn out at the polls.
Its proponents said a strong mayor is necessary on pragmatic and ideological grounds. A strong mayor would be responsible for all city departments, managing the day-to-day operations of the city. He would submit the city budget to the council and set executive policy. The change would simplify city government for residents and businesses, Mr. Perez said. For instance, under the current city manager government, a potential investor in the city must run a bureaucratic gauntlet, seeking approvals and permits from six or seven city offices. After charter reform, Mr. Perez said, the investor would make one stop in the mayor's office, who would streamline the process.
A strong mayor government is more conducive to an urban environment where patronage politics have a more important role and ethnic politics are more significant than in the suburbs, Mr. Taylor said.
Since the late 1940's, the mayor's hands have been tied, said James Kinsella, 78, who was mayor of Hartford for two terms beginning in 1957. It was only through sheer force of the mayor's personality that goals were achieved, a caveat that benefited some more than others, he said.
"You couldn't get anything done," he said. "It was suggested nicely that you don't contact department heads yourself, but work through the manager."
Yet there is a disagreement as to whether the charter reform will bring any real change. Those in favor, like Mr. Perez and Mr. Taylor, said it will hold one person accountable for the city's success or failure and will appropriately merge the political and administrative. Willie Womack, a van driver who has lived in Hartford for more than 50 years, said she believed it on symbolic grounds.
"The city deserves a strong mayor and city government needs someone to answer to," she said.
But others said it is a frail gesture toward a troubled city and question just how strong the mayor will be under charter revision. For instance, the mayor's powers will be stepped up from an ability to nominate commissioners to appointing them, yet both actions require council approval for confirmation.
"It isn't the silver bullet," said Nick Carbone, who retired last year from the Connecticut Institute of Municipal Studies and has long been involved in city politics. "A move to the strong mayor form of government won't be a substitute for corporate leadership."
He said the business community is less engaged than they were in the 1970's due to corporate restructuring that resulted in insurance and banking headquarters and manufacturing companies leaving the city. In addition, he cited the city's abysmally low property values combined with the poorest people needing the most services as a recipe for failure. "I don't feel switching to a strong mayor is a step towards solving the problems," he said.
City Councilman Louis Watkins Jr. said he will support charter reform because the residents have asked for it, but he doesn't believe it will make a difference.
"Whether mayor or council-manager, I don't believe it should affect the city," he said. "The mayor usually gets 85 to 90 percent of what he wants anyway, so some of this strong mayor stuff is a smoke screen."
It should be noted that since taking office last November, Mr. Perez was able to build a five-member coalition. Mr. Watkins is not part of it.
"I think it will pass," said Marie L. Kirkley-Bey, a former member of the City Council and 35-year resident of the city. "It's needed because right now we're missing the accountability piece, but I also think we need to remember the importance of checks and balances."
So much power in the hands of one person makes more than a few people nervous. Several people interviewed pointed to Waterbury and Bridgeport where powerful mayors are both under indictment for various abuses of power and Providence, R.I., where former Mayor Vincent A. Cianci was convicted this year for a range of fraudulent activity.
"I'm a little nervous giving someone that much power," said Clark King, 56, the union president for Hartford city workers.
In response, Mr. Taylor, who has served on the City Council, Board of Education and charter revision commission, said the revised charter will reflect a system of checks and balances by establishing an independent internal auditor's commission selected and appointed by the City Council, treasurer and the city's 10 largest taxpayers, Mr. Taylor said. The commission will appoint an internal auditor, approve work programs and propose the budget for the internal auditing unit.
"We've created an independent group to keep a watch on what the administration is doing," he said.
Robert L. Painter, a first-term Republican councilman and member of the majority council coalition, said in addition to changing the role of the mayor, the revisions will reduce the scope of the charter from a rigid document that proscribes when and how often various boards and commissions meet to create a more flexible plan for city government, giving department heads more responsibility.
Hyacinth Yennie, who is active for her Barry Square neighborhood and a Hartford business owner, said she supports the charter change to step up accountability in the city, but was nevertheless impressed with the efficiency and accomplishments of Albert Ilg, interim city manager from January to September this year. Mr. Ilg was replaced by Lee Erdman, who will become the chief administrative officer if voters accept the strong mayor proposal.
Mr. Perez, a self-described "economist by training and organizer by vocation," said he thinks of city residents as customers who deserve an efficiently run government.
"The biggest reason folks want reform is accountability," he said. On election day, Mr. Perez is counting on these customers to be demanding consumers.

HEADLINE: MONEY & MEDICINE; 
When Insurance Hits the Ceiling

BYLINE:  By MICHELLE ANDREWS; Michelle Andrews is a freelance writer in Manhattan specializing in health care. Her column on its economics appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: moneymeds@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
WHEN people buy health insurance, few worry that it might run out. As long as they pay their premiums, they expect to be covered, no matter how many medical bills they rack up. After all, what's the point of having insurance if, just when you need it most, your policy shuts down like a bank at closing time?
 Many policies, however, do place a cap on the amount they will pay out over the course of a person's lifetime. More than two-thirds of people in preferred-provider organizations have such lifetime benefit maximums, as do nearly half of people covered by conventional indemnity plans, according to a recent survey of employer health benefits by the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation. Lifetime caps are less common among plans offered by health maintenance organizations. 
 When Robin and Michael Rose of Richmond, Va., were choosing a plan several years ago, lifetime maximums never crossed their minds. They were young and healthy, and their main concern was keeping monthly costs down. The premium for family coverage was $25 a month through the University of South Carolina at Spartanburg, which Mrs. Rose was attending, and $125 a month through the sporting goods store where Mr. Rose worked. Choosing the "best" plan seemed obvious: they went with the cheaper policy. (The couple could not recall names of the insurance companies or other specifics about the plans.)
Everything was fine until they decided to have a baby. Just over six months into her pregnancy, Mrs. Rose went into premature labor and doctors were unable to prevent her from delivering. Their son, Austin, was born weighing just 2 pounds.
Mrs. Rose spent every minute she could at the neonatal intensive care unit. Then, about 10 days after Austin's birth, a hospital social worker pulled her into a private conference room and dropped a bombshell: the Roses were about to hit the $300,000 maximum on their health insurance policy. "I had no idea there was a maximum," Mrs. Rose, now 29, said. "And at the time it was the last thing I wanted to deal with."
Austin was in the hospital for 81 days. The hospital charges came to $375,000. Charges for the neonatologist, gastroenterologist and pediatric ophthalmologist added $300,000. Once Austin came home, he had to take 14 medications, plus physical therapy and regular doctor visits.
They said the policy they didn't sign up for, with the $125 premium, would have covered Austin's expenses up to $1 million. That policy limit is typical. But while $1 million may sound like a lot of money, it's getting smaller every day. Health care costs are surging, partly because of continuing technological advances that are good for making people well but rough on insurance pocketbooks. The price tag for health care is expected to climb 15 percent in 2003 alone. Sometimes, that $1 million can disappear faster than you can say "second mortgage."
As employers look for ways to cut health insurance costs, the lowering of lifetime maximums may be too tempting for them to resist. Many employees may not even realize that limits exist in the first place. "A million dollars is starting to look generous," said Patricia Goldsmith, vice president for institutional and business development for the H. Lee Moffitt Cancer Center in Tampa, Fla. "Some small group plans are reducing lifetime maximums to as little as $30,000 to $50,000."
For a serious illness or accident, $30,000 will barely get you a bed in the I.C.U. Bone marrow transplants, the most expensive single procedure in oncology today, are now used to treat some 40 different cancers, said Michael Rabin, a vice president for managed care at City of Hope Cancer Center in Duarte, Calif. The transplant costs $200,000 to $500,000 or more, depending on the donor and whether there are complications. And a car accident victim with several broken bones and brain or torso injuries could easily incur a couple of hundred thousand dollars in medical costs, said Tom Scalea, physician in chief of the Maryland Shock Trauma Center in Baltimore.
Of course, the percentage of people who will face such catastrophic medical bills is small. But for those who do, they can be devastating. The Roses were lucky: the social worker helped them sign up Austin for Medicaid under a South Carolina program for disabled children whose parents' assets exceed Medicaid limits; 19 states have such programs. Austin, who just turned 6, no longer needs special medical care.
MANY people aren't so fortunate. Qualifying for Medicaid or Social Security disability coverage can be difficult, and if they live in one of the 27 states that doesn't have a high-risk insurance pool to cover patients who don't qualify elsewhere, they may be out of luck. "So many consumers just don't fit into one of these neat packages," said Nancy Davenport-Ennis, president and chief executive of the Patient Advocate Foundation.
Helen Darling, president of the Washington Business Group on Health, which represents large employers on health care issues, said most big companies didn't bother with lifetime caps. Because the number of cases that would reach the maximum is small, "you don't save much if you put maximum policy limits in," she said. 
"And it buys you a lot of good will if you don't have them," she added. 
Very cogently reasoned. But as employers scramble to contain rising health care costs, reason doesn't always carry the day.

GRAPHIC: Drawing (David G. Klein) 

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: A Village In the City Hidden in Plain Sight 

BYLINE:  By ALEXANDRA BANDON 

 BODY:
TUCKED into a sliver of space between two buildings on one of Greenwich Village's many crooked streets, a narrow alleyway is closed to the public by a thin black gate. At the far end of the long claustrophobic passage, the signs of an urban paradise can be glimpsed: a couple of fence posts, the vague edge of a flowering bush and a tease of green leaves hanging from a tall tree.
 What cannot be seen, no matter how hard a curious neck is craned, is the charming pair of clapboard cottages that stand behind plants and fence, two of the dozens of hidden houses in the West Village. Built mostly in the 19th century as stables, servants' quarters, stores, workshops and even main residences, the houses have survived the tear-down mentality of New York and a host of tenement laws gradually prohibiting such construction, to remain some of the city's most charming -- and desirable -- properties. 
 Carriage houses or backhouses, as they are known, are one of the secrets of the West Village. These are not the quaint-but-visible blocks like Washington Mews, Patchin Place and Grove Court that are a staple of every walking tour of the historic area; these are houses entirely cloaked from view. They are sometimes hinted at by a tunnel carved into the side of a house and a street address supplemented by a small "a" or a " 1/2," but at other times they are completely hidden and accessible only to someone with knowledge of a door at the far side of the house or apartment building in front.
They survive because many parts of the Village, dating back to the late 18th and early 19th centuries, before the city started regulating how residents could build and live in relation to one another, remain intact. Because the architecture is so well preserved, close to 75 backhouses -- an estimate based on insurance-survey maps and anecdotal information -- still stand in the area from Houston Street to 14th Street between Broadway and the Hudson River. 
The rest of Manhattan is not nearly as dense with such structures. To find them, one must look where the housing stock is very old and tightly clustered, where the back of the lot would have been a viable real estate holding for a 19th-century property owner. There are still a few remaining in the East Village, Chinatown and Little Italy, in Chelsea and in Clinton, and very rarely in other parts of the borough.
Farther north in Manhattan, backhouses appear less often, because the lots were developed later. There are next to none behind the late 19th- and early 20th-century brownstones of the Upper West Side and Harlem.
One gated address, known as Clinton Court, on the quaint 46th Street block between Ninth and 10th Avenues, was a stable on the DeWitt Clinton estate, dating back to the early 1800's. The house, with archways and multipaned casement windows that are visible from the street, was built over a potter's field cemetery and comes complete with a legend about ghosts that frequent it. 
Hidden houses also exist in the older Brooklyn neighborhoods of Carroll Gardens and Williamsburg, where row houses or tenements stand on smaller lots. But in the earliest urban areas of Queens, the Bronx and Staten Island, and even in Village-like Brooklyn Heights, original rear houses are very rare. One carriage house on Monroe Place in Brooklyn was moved from another location and reassembled in the back yard sometime in the first half of the 20th century.
Barry Lewis, an architectural historian, theorizes that rear buildings became residences to accommodate the 19th-century immigrant population that moved into middle-class areas in Lower Manhattan in the 1830's and into the Village and Brooklyn after the Civil War. "Backhouses seem to belong to the era of houses in Manhattan, not the era of apartments," Mr. Lewis said. "The property owner probably shoved more immigrant families into the stable or workshed in the back. Other owners may have built a new backhouse just to get the lucrative immigrant rents.
"At some point," he added, owners "realized it would be even more lucrative to knock down both the front and back houses and replace the whole shebang with a tenement."
The Queens historian Vincent Seyfried said that despite this push to erect apartments, some Brooklyn backhouses still survive; landlords simply moved front houses to the back of the lot when they built a tenement facing the street. (Mr. Seyfried's ancestors owned one such house -- with a tobacco shop on the ground floor -- in Williamsburg in 1848, sliding it back to accommodate a tenement later in the century.) "These places didn't have cellars or plumbing, so it wasn't difficult to do -- it was an economical thing to do," he said.
But in the boroughs outside of Manhattan this phenomenon exists only in neighborhoods -- like Williamsburg -- developed early in the 1800's and only if the houses sidestepped a century and a half of changes to the cityscape. So few rear houses exist in Queens, for example, because the borough was largely built later, Mr. Seyfried said. "The places with backhouses have to be the earliest places people settled," he said. "Most of Queens doesn't get built in the 1820's, 30's and 40's.
"Any houses that did get built that early, as in Jamaica, those houses were torn down because they were inadequate," he continued. Some survived in Flushing -- another of the older towns -- into the early 20th century but were razed to make way for the commuter parking lots built around the end of the new subway lines after World War II. 
Regina Kellerman, an architectural historian who was executive director of the Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation from 1981 to 1989, has investigated some of the West Village houses' histories for clients. "There were a lot where the yards were big or on 'gore lots' -- lots with unequal sides and, therefore, extra space in the back," she explained. Many of the Village's streets were laid out unevenly, following farm-property lines rather than a grid pattern, so such lots are more common there than elsewhere.
Raymond Sokolov, who recently retired as editor of The Wall Street Journal's Leisure and Arts page, and his wife, Johanna Hecht, an associate curator of European sculpture and decorative arts at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, live in one of the two clapboard houses behind the thin gate in Greenwich Village. Their 800-square-foot, four-room house, with low ceilings and exposed beams, was built in 1828 (an old structure even for the Village) within the borders of the early 19th-century Samuel Jones farm.
They are unsure of the building's origins -- as many backhouse owners are -- but their guess is that it and its identical neighbor were put up as housing for workers on the Jones farm or as a workshop for a journeyman. They acquired the property, which is part of a co-op with the front tenement, built later, after deciding that their inherited apartment on the Upper West Side -- half of a classic 12 -- was never going to be the home they wanted it to be. "I wanted something with character," Ms. Hecht said.
The building was in total disrepair when they arrived in 1993. ("The inside of the house looked a little bit like Robert De Niro's place in 'Taxi Driver,' " Mr. Sokolov said.) The couple gutted the cottage, rewiring it and adding soundproofing so it would be a haven from the noise and activity of the busy Village streets. They also put up the fence and planted the garden, creating a cottage that looks as if it belongs on a small town lane rather than surrounded by grime-covered apartment buildings.
The Village's backhouses have diverse histories. One, on Charles Street, was a blacksmith's shop. On 10th Street near Hudson Street, a sailors' boarding house on the street side -- with a tavern on the ground floor and hammocks for beds, catering to the seamen who sailed from the nearby wharves -- was operated by workers who lived in the back. A few of the structures even started out as large privies.
In the 1890's, a carriage house that is entered through the door to the left of what is now the Blue Note, on West Third Street, contained the Golden Rule Pleasure Club, a male brothel. According to "Commissioner Roosevelt," a book by H. Paul Jeffers, the Rev. Charles Parkhurst included the club in his sensational report to a grand jury in 1892 charging that a corrupt, Tammany-influenced police force was turning a blind eye to crime in the city.
Most of these houses were built by property owners who wanted to maximize the use of their land. Before the skyscrapers and tall apartment buildings of the 20th century arrived, building on the back of the lot was an efficient use of space.
In the 19th century, the loss of private outdoor space to a back building was not nearly as traumatic as it might be today. "The back yard would have been a functional courtyard where the residents hung clothes, did some of the housework or had the summer kitchen," Jane Jacobs, the author of "The Death and Life of Great American Cities," and a former Village resident, said in an interview. "It was a service area, and only occasionally a recreational area." Consequently, backhouses did not exist in poorer neighborhoods -- giving up the service space was a luxury affordable only to those who had extra room indoors. "These buildings were for affluent or well-off citizens," Ms. Jacobs said. 
YET it was a movement to protect the poor that eventually killed the backhouse. The Tenement House Laws of 1867 and 1879 were the first pieces of legislation meant to bring housing in the slums of the city closer to habitable. They were spurred by concerns about epidemics, particularly cholera, that thrived in densely populated areas.
Among other things, those laws specified how much space a building could take up on its lot and how many feet had to be left between front and back buildings, eventually requiring no more than 65 percent lot coverage and as much as 25 feet dividing four-story buildings. The rules did not leave much room for a second house on the standard 100-foot-deep lots. 
As a result, construction of most backhouses larger than two stories -- that is, residences rather than commercial structures or outbuildings that were converted later -- ended by the 1870's, though some property owners built oversized backhouses illegally as late as the 1930's. 
"If people had space back there and they happened to have empty yards next to them, like parking lots or coal yards, so they could easily get in and out without too much notice, then they built little houses in the back for extra income," Ms. Kellerman said. Because the laws did not regulate construction of stables and workshops in the rear yards, smaller structures that were converted later were still built as late as the early 1900's.
The inviting two-bedroom house behind Judith and John Stonehill's Federal house was one such building, a stable put up in 1889, probably to replace an earlier one. The house in front, which is on the National Register of Historic Places, was built in 1834 with an arched passageway on one side that would have been just big enough to fit a horse led by a groomsman. (These "horse walks," common in the Village, usually masquerade as second entrances to the house, with wooden doors.)
A hayloft door, topped by a hook for hauling goods to the loft, is still visible above the backhouse's front entrance, and an interior wall still shows evidence of the archway through which carriages would have entered.
The Stonehills bought their property, including the restored barn, in 1968, when the neighborhood bordered commercial areas. The backhouse has a sizable kitchen (by Manhattan standards), which occupies a corner of its open-plan first floor. Behind the soaring ceiling with exposed beams in the living room-dining room, a restored mahogany staircase leads to two large bedrooms and a bath upstairs. The space has often served as a studio and residence for artists, including the photographer Diane Arbus, who rented the rear before the Stonehills bought the property.
These days, the existence of such a rentable rear house can increase the purchase price of a front property in the Village by $750,000 to $1.25 million, according to Debra Kameros, a real estate agent who specializes in the West Village.
Backhouses rarely come up for sale on their own. "There are very few with their own tax lots," Ms. Kameros explained. When they are sold separately, they are desirable properties, especially if they are renovated, single-family homes with private outdoor space (most have to share a yard with the front house). One such two-bedroom, two-bath house with a patio on its roof was listed last spring for $2.25 million, more than double what a similar-sized apartment in the same neighborhood might sell for, though Ms. Kameros was quick to point out that this house was an exceptional example. "In any case, these are atypical properties," she said. "The whole appeal is the hidden nature and the charm." Many, like the Sokolov-Hecht house, are co-ops that are legally part of the front building, which is usually a tenement from a later era.
Whole houses or apartments to rent are almost as rare, listed only once or twice a year. "The people they attract as renters have been waiting a long time for them, and they tend to stay," Ms. Kameros said. 
As rental spaces, rear houses can sometimes be relative bargains. The three-floor, four-bedroom, two-and-a-half-bath 1867 house behind Cher Lewis's quaint brick front building rents for $4,200 a month, a price that is a couple of thousand dollars lower than some tenants are willing to pay. 
"The reason I rent it for less than market value is because it's very difficult to have someone living so near to you," who is not compatible, said Ms. Lewis, a retired consultant for nonprofit organizations. 
THAT sentiment is echoed by John Clarkson, who with his wife, Ellen, rents out a three-room 1850's stable behind their 11th Street house to Howell Binkley, a lighting designer. "We're very picky about the tenants," Mr. Clarkson said. "If we didn't live in the building in front, we might feel differently." 
Ms. Kameros said, "When you get a tenant that is working for you, one you're compatible with, you tend to keep them." She noted that single-family backhouses usually rent to couples or singles, for $4,000 to $7,000 a month. "Maybe you start renting at the lower end of market value, but over time you leave it at that price and that gets to be a good deal" for the tenant.
In backhouses that have been converted to multifamily dwellings, however, the rents are comparable to those elsewhere downtown. In fact, life in the tiny flats could be mistaken for cramped New York in any neighborhood. 
The handful of tenants in the rear at 93 Perry Street enjoy the old-world feel of their 1827 stuccoed and green-shuttered building; their rent-stabilized studio to two-bedroom apartments rented earlier this year for as little as $106 to as much as $2,500 a month, according to an executive of the management company.
Most of the many hidden houses that exist on tiny Cornelia Street, including seven on the west side of the block alone, are apartment buildings containing studios and one-bedroom units. If the tenants -- largely artists and professionals -- are lucky, the original fireplaces still work. But for many, the 200-square-foot, rent-stabilized studios are no different from the ones found in any subdivided house in the Village, costing up to $1,350 a month. One benefit is the extra privacy and inherent charm of life in the back yard.
Ms. Jacobs suggested that it is this allure that could be a template for contemporary urban planning. She supports repealing the state laws regulating back-lot building, so owners can once again erect these hidden gems. "It should be recognized how charming these places are and how sanitized they are, and how inappropriately they have been ruled out. But I guarantee you nobody is re-examining these laws to see why they're still prohibited," she said of the backhouses. "And it's too bad, because these houses are a great treasure."

HEADLINE: Mayors Tout Cities' Health to Tempt Investors 

BYLINE:  By ELSA BRENNER 

DATELINE: YONKERS 

 BODY:
HOPING to tempt a panel of venture capitalists and lure new investment, participants in the first annual Westchester Mayors' Business Summit on Wednesday promoted their cities' recent economic achievements. More than 200 business and government leaders attended. 
 Mayor John D. Spencer of Yonkers detailed recent developments along his city's waterfront. He began with the $53 million Larkin Center, the new home of the Yonkers Public Library and the city's Board of Education, which opened in September. 
 Other Hudson Riverfront projects in Yonkers include the $35 million renovation of the Metro-North station across from Larkin Center, a $10 million six-story parking garage, a $60 million, 266-unit apartment complex being built by Collins Enterprises of Stamford, Conn., and the $13 million Esplanade Park, a 1.5-mile promenade along the shoreline.
Mayor Timothy C. Idoni of New Rochelle highlighted his city's recent economic achievements, among them the $17 million Intermodal Transportation Center, which will serve as a hub for Amtrak and Metro-North train service and is expected to be completed in the spring. Avalon on the Sound, a 25-story luxury apartment building has gone up next to the Long Island Sound, but its second tower has been delayed due to the prolonged economic downturn. Private developers are spending $15 million to convert a former Bloomingdale's, empty for 25 years, to condominium lofts. Because Community Preservation Corporation, a nonprofit consortium of banks and insurance companies based in Manhattan, expects the project to revitalize the neighborhood, it is offering mortgage loans to surrounding property owners so they can build apartments above retail stores.
In White Plains, Mayor Joseph M. Delfino reported that redevelopment is transforming his city. The Valhalla-based builder Louis R. Cappelli is building a $300 million City Center with retail and residential space, a 15-screen movie theater and a hotel. Six blocks away, Fortunoff is building a 260,000-square-foot store. LCOR, a construction company based in Berwyn, Pa., is building a $137 million apartment complex on a 2.6-acre site. A $6 million, 70,000-square-foot Stop & Shop is under construction; it will be the city's first major supermarket.
In late September, Mr. Cappelli bought another city block in White Plains across from his City Center. The new project, a $300 million investment, will include a 200-room hotel, luxury condominiums and street-level retail stores.
Mayor Ernest D. Davis reported on Mount Vernon. There, the Sandford Boulevard Redevelopment Project is progressing, and will include a ShopRite superstore and a CVS. Recently, he said, ground was broken for a Best Buy store, and a 285,000-square-foot shopping center is being planned.
Mayor Steven Otis of Rye said that his city, the smallest of the county's cities, had a 90 percent occupancy rate in its 850,000 square feet of office space.
Venture capital firms represented on the panel included GreenHills Ventures, New York Community Investment Corporation, Milestone Venture Partners and Enhanced Capital Partners, all of Manhattan, Signature Bank of New Rochelle and Morgan Stanley of White Plains.

HEADLINE: COUNTY LINES; 
A Chef's Dream: To Stir Yonkers

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA ROWE 

 BODY:
PETER KELLY, culinary king of the suburbs with four high-flying restaurants in Rockland and Putnam Counties, is preparing to close the crown jewel of his empire on Jan. 1, 2003, and open a new venture on the waterfront in Yonkers, near industrial lots where commuter buses sigh and people push shopping carts piled with their personal belongings.
 "Are you crazy?" asked Mr. Kelly's family and friends when they learned of his plans. "What's wrong with Scarsdale? What's wrong with Bedford?" 
 Nothing, said Mr. Kelly. But those towns have no waterfront, and the Hudson River has beckoned him like a siren since childhood. Mr. Kelly was born in Yonkers not far from the river, and he has been angling for a way to get back ever since opening his first restaurant at the age of 23. That early start, Xaviar's at Garrison, won raves for its gargantuan Sunday brunches where diners gorged on two dozen versions of shrimp, rabbit and roast beef while sipping mimosas and ogling power brokers doing the same. 
After 20 years in Garrison, Mr. Kelly says it is time for a new challenge. And he wants it to be in Yonkers, a city associated more often with bruising racial politics than delicate canapes.
"I know Yonkers has been 'coming back' for the last 45 years," he said. "But this time, it's for real."
No doubt, his optimism is grounded in the city's $400 million downtown revitalization plan, already well under way, with designs to turn gritty lots into a new yuppie haven complete with art galleries, lofts and condominiums. Officials even talk of reviving the old Hudson River ferry to shuttle those new residents from Yonkers to Midtow in 18 minutes. At night they might watch a game in the city's yet-to-be-built minor league baseball stadium. 
All that is part of the glittering future. The present-day site for the restaurant is still peopled with angry-looking teenagers who wander in and out of abandoned buildings and old-timers who say they like Yonkers the way it's always been: tough.
But Mr. Kelly, a breezy, blustery 43-year-old, is not cowed. He has forged his career by building ambitious restaurants in places people don't think they want to visit. The hugely successful Xaviar's at Piermont, which now caters to a roster of celebrities, was built in what he called a "blue-collar outpost." His next venture, the sumptuous Restaurant X, flourishes in in nondescript Congers. Even the airy, blue dining room in Mr. Kelly's flagship seemed outlandish when the unschooled chef opened it in sleepy bucolic Garrison.
Yonkers, however, is no small town. In Garrison, Mr. Kelly's toughest battle was soothing ruffled feathers on the planning board when he wanted to place a sign on a quiet country road. Now he is talking about building a glamour destination within sight of a towering housing project. No one has yet signed papers designating Yonkers's historic pier as Mr. Kelly's new home, though the ever-confident chef says he is sure city officials are with him on this. Anywhere he lands along the waterfront, there will be parking crunches, customer safety concerns and residents who are not necessarily thrilled that Mr. Kelly and his upscale show are coming to town.
"I liked it the way it was," said Frank Kendrick, who runs the boatman's shack on the pier that Mr. Kelly hopes to turn into a glittering magnet for well-heeled gourmands. Mr. Kelly smiled at this grumbling, asked Mr. Kendrick if he could unlock the pier's upper floor and kept right on spinning his vision: the restaurant, all glass windows, leather armchairs and catwalks, would be built right there on the pier's Victorian ironwork, jutting into the Hudson like a ship's figurehead. 
If the chef gets his way -- and he often does -- Xaviar's on the Hudson will open in summer 2003. In Mr. Kelly's mind, the new venture will anchor Yonkers's entire waterfront revival. It happened in Baltimore, he said. And in Hoboken. 
"It's always done with independent restaurants," Mr. Kelly said. "You can't do it with Pizzeria Uno."

HEADLINE: Going Organic 

BYLINE:  By GALE T. SCOTT 

DATELINE: HOPEWELL TOWNSHP 

 BODY:
JOE RUGGIERI'S crops this year at Hopeview Farm included green beans, sold at his produce stand for a dollar a pound. Next year his offerings will include organic "haricots verts" -- French for green beans -- that cost a hefty $6 a pound.
 It is a price consumers will pay for fresh local produce grown free of pesticides. 
 After decades of conventional farming -- using chemicals to clear weeds, kill pests, and fertilize crops -- the 42-year-old Mr. Ruggieri is going organic. 
He plans to return to many of the same techniques his grandfather used so he can grow organic crops on a seven-acre section of the 85-acre family farm. That includes using composts for fertilizer, rotating crops to avoid plant diseases, and planting "cover crops" like alfalfa to keep weeds in control until it is time to sow his pesticide-free organic seeds.
Mr. Ruggieri is joining the small but steadily growing ranks of organic farmers in New Jersey.
There are now at least 55 state-certified organic farms throughout the state, and still more farmland is in transition. By comparison, said Karen Anderson, executive director of the Northeast Organic Farming Association of New Jersey, there were only 12 organic farms in the state as recently as 1990.
In keeping with strict state and federal standards for organic farming, Mr. Ruggieri has been letting 10 acres of his farm "rest" for the past three years. No crops have been grown there -- allowing the chemical pesticides and fertilizers to break down -- the first step in becoming a certified organic grower.
"It's an experiment," he said. "I'll still rely on conventional crops on the rest of the farm. But I'm kind of psyched about the idea."
Since 1990, Ms. Anderson said her advocacy group had been inspecting farms and certifying whether produce met organic standards. At the same, the organization has turned to marketing to get consumers and growers interested. So far, it seems to be working.
Drawn by curiosity, concerns about health and the environment as well as studies showing consumers will pay more for organic crops, many farmers are expressing an interest in learning organic methods, said Patrick K. Mullen, New Jersey Department of Agriculture's acting director of the division of dairy and commodity regulation.
"What's driving the trend is that people want home-grown organic products," Mr. Mullen said.
New Jersey's organic farmlands comprise 2,200 acres, most of which produce vegetables sold directly to consumers or restaurants. Though that is a small percentage of the state's 29,400 acres farmed for fresh-market vegetables, and a smaller still percentage of the 830,000-acre total for New Jersey farmlands, it is a number that is widely expected to increase.

Demand Growing Each Year
"There's a $250 million market in New Jersey for organic produce," said Ramu Govindasamy, an economist and associate professor of agriculture at Rutgers's Cook College in New Brunswick.
He bases that estimate on the $7.8 billion the nation spends annually on purchasing organic foods, noting that demand has been growing by 20 percent to 25 percent a year.
But when New Jersey shoppers buy organic produce at most chain supermarkets, he said, it has come from out of state, often from abroad.
Ms. Anderson said that such produce was often days or weeks old, harvested before it is ripe, and did not always offer the superior taste that local produce offered -- as big a selling point for organic vegetables as health and environmental concerns.
As Mr. Govindasamy noted, if local growers could produce enough organic crops to make it feasible for supermarkets to distribute them, they could tap a huge market.
But for now, he said, it was a problem of distribution methods used by supermarkets; for now, there is not enough organic produce being harvested in New Jersey to make it worthwhile for the big chains to place orders. 
Even so, local farmers who grow organic crops still stand to gross from $5,000 to $10,000 an acre or more by selling directly to consumers or to restaurants, according to a recent Cook College survey of organic farmers in New Jersey, New York, and Pennsylvania. By contrast, the New Jersey Department of Agriculture reported that in 2000, soybean farmers grossed only $176 an acre.
But 30 percent of that money will go toward labor costs, said Ms. Anderson, as against a negligible labor cost for the large-scale mechanized techniques used in crops like soybeans and corn.
Still, another recent Cook College study found that only 17 percent of 162 organic farmers surveyed were dissatisfied with their profits, with 71 percent satisfied or somewhat satisfied and 11 percent very satisfied.
"In the beginning there was a lot of distrust between organic farmers and conventional farmers; they called us hippies and we called them nozzleheads," said Ms. Anderson, a reference to hoses used to spray farms with chemicals. "We tend to be too earnest sometimes. We're trying to lighten up.'
But as the numbers emerge showing that organics can be profitable, she said, more farmers are turning out at her organization's conferences.
"Now we're hearing farmers say they would really like to try organic and they want to learn more about our methods," she said.
In 2000, there were 98,000 New Jersey acres cultivated in soybeans that, almost 45 acres for every acre of an organic crop. Corn grown for grain -- not the sweet corn sold for the table -- took up 75,000 acres and sold for $255 an acre, the 2001 state report found.
It is a set of statistics that frustrates the state's agricultural economists.
"Corn and soybeans are not good for New Jersey," said Mr. Govindasamy. "We need more specialty crops and organic is one of them."
One reason that farmers grow soybeans and corn is that federal price supports encourage the practice. Another is that state programs that use tax revenue to allow farmlands to remain undeveloped make it easier for farmers to grow cheap crops, he said. 
"They are taxed at a far lower rate," said Mr. Govindasamy.
But proponents of organic farming say that it has the potential to be profitable, making it possible to preserve farmlands without taxpayers having to help as much as they now do.
"It's time to start asking ourselves whether we want to preserve these farmlands for more than the view," said Ms. Anderson.
As for the New Jersey Department of Environmental Protection, it says it welcomes the organic trend, since -- as Ms. Anderson said -- it is not as if in the days of Mr. Ruggieri's grandfather farming was particularly sound environmentally.
"They started using arsenic and some other pretty scary things to control pests in the early part of the last century," she said.
But as farms grew bigger in the post-World War II era -- from an average of 242 acres in 1953 to 434 acres in 2000 -- widespread use of pesticides, herbicides, and chemical fertilizers began to take an heavy toll on the environment.
According to the state environmental agency, in 2000 farmers throughout New Jersey used 1,090,300 pounds of pesticides.
According to the state Department of Agriculture, in 2001 farms used 160,359 tons of fertilizers alone -- most of them chemical -- and the runoff from some of them disrupts the ecology of streams and wetlands by spurring the rapid growth of plants and algae.
Yet there is a hesitance to to go organic, said Mr. Ruggieri, largely because in making the change he knows he may lose money for a while.

Land Must Rest Three Years
The first hurdle is the requirement that no chemical insecticides, herbicides, fungicides, rodent-killers, fumigants, growth regulators, bactericides, or fertilizers be used on the land for three years before crops can be considered organic.
That also means giving up crop income for three years, a major obstacle in selling the concept of organic farming to conventional growers, said Mr. Govindasamy. 
The other risk is that although organic crops command a higher price at the market, they are expensive to grow because they need to be hand-weeded, carefully monitored for pest infestation, composted instead of sprayed with chemical fertilizers, and planted with precise timing.
"I'm worried about labor costs," said Mr. Ruggieri.
Moreover, organic farming puts farmers at the mercy of insects and severe weather that can stress or even kill crops.
"No way I could grow sweet corn organically," said Mr. Ruggieri. "Too many insects."
But he does plan to grow gourmet lettuce, cold-weather greens like Swiss chard, cabbages, and kale, and summer vegetables like eggplant, tomatoes, and green beans.
At least for these crops, it will be a planting season free of trips to the local Agway for a load of 10-10-10 fertilizer. No spraying RoundUp when weeds emerge. It will be a challenge.
"But I want to try it," said Mr. Ruggieri. "It gets boring doing the same kind of farming for years and years. It's what consumers want. It's healthy. I want to grow beautiful vegetables.'
He said he got the idea from neighboring Spring Hill Farm and its manager, Pam Flory. "I've been watching Pam farm for three years," he said. "Her produce is really something to look at. She grows fantastic crops."
The world of organic farming is an exclusive club -- in more ways than one.
For instance, Ms. Flory farms a seven-acre tract of Spring Hill for its owner, J. Seward Johnson, the artist and heir to the Johnson & Johnson fortune.
The list of organic sugar-daddies also includes the rock musician Bruce Springsteen, who has commissioned an organic farm at his newly renovated Monmouth County farmhouse.
At least five of the state's certified organic farms are cultivated under a similar arrangement with wealthy individuals, Ms. Anderson said.
"We refer to people like Mr. Johnson as high-resource, high-profile, high-motivational landowners," said Ms. Anderson, a former law librarian whose work is partly supported by a two-year fellowship from the W. K. Kellogg Foundation.
She said these ventures would prove that organic methods worked.
Yet at the same time, seeing millionaires dabbling in organic growing makes some conventional farmers leery of its economic viability.
"The family farm isn't a tax write-off for me," said Mr. Ruggieri. "Some of these farmer have money to burn. I sure don't."
For instance, when deer were destroying Ms. Flory's crop's, Mr. Johnson paid for a fence, Ms. Flory said. As for Mr. Ruggieri, he has to pay for his own fences.
Mr. Johnson said the idea for the organic farm came to him about three years ago when he and his wife bought the farmland, on which they are also building a home. At about the same time he was opening his upscale restuarant, Rats, near his sculpture garden and atelier in Hamilton Township.
"We wanted to get the best food, and my chef was very enthusiastic about getting organic produce," he said. "The taste of these vegetables is really outstanding. Our eggs are phenomenal."
The prospect of having his own farm to visit also appealed to him.
"My father actually tried to encourage me to be a farmer, bought me a farm of my own when I was 19," Mr. Johnson said, "but at the time I hated it. I couldn't stand the sweat and chaffing from the hay. I ended up bringing a girlfriend to the hayloft, I found that was a better use for the barn."
Age has brought a greater appreciation of the beauty of rural surroundings, he said.
He is also pleased with his choice of Ms. Flory to run the farm and tickled by the fact that all her farmhands are women. "She tells me she won't hire men because they don't work hard enough," he said.
On one recent day, Ms. Flory loaded up the farm's battered white van with mesclun salad mix -- a blend of lettuces with herbs -- beets, heirloom tomatoes, sweet Harkuri turnips and more and began her restaurant deliveries. First stop was The Brothers Moon, a restaurant on Broad Street in Hopewell.
"I love this produce," said Will Moon, the restaurant's owner. "The mesclun is out of this world, and when we serve it it's just a few hours old."

A Day in the Life
And with the change in the weather, the crops also change. Soon the winter squashes will be in season, and Mr. Mooney said he could not wait to get his hands on Ms. Flory's kabocha -- a hard green squash he bakes and purees with vegetable broth for soup.
Next stop was an Italian restaurant, where Ms. Flory dropped off a $2 bunch of basil. "It's not worth it except it builds goodwill," she said. The rest of the produce would go to Rats Restaurant, and a harvest later that week would go to greenmarkets, including one in Summit.
A typical day for Ms. Flory starts around 7 a.m. and ends early in the evening. So it goes, six days a week with two days off every other week. She said the seven acres of produce brought in $65,000 last year -- not counting the harvest that went directly to Mr. Johnson's restaurant. It is a big number when compared to the yield from corn or soybeans, but it took a lot of work from Ms. Flory, her co-manager, Amy Longo, and the interns the farm hires -- all young women who hope to start their own organic farms.
Ms. Flory used to work at the Howell Living History Farm, a restored working farm owned and operated by Mercer County, which is where she met her husband Rob, the farm's ox driver.
When Ms. Flory, a Massachussetts native and Peace Corps veteran, heard three years ago that Mr. Johnson was thinking of starting an organic farm she lobbied hard for the job of running it.
Though Spring Hill has yet to turn a profit, she is convinced that within the next three years it will.
Looking out over the acreage, rows of new lettuce curling up from the ground like emerald ribbons of crushed velvet and a deep blue October sky overhead, Ms. Flory, suntanned and windblown, smiled.
Her work is a labor of love.
"I feel like I've won the farming Lotto," she said.

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Some 4th-Quarter Housekeeping Can Save on Taxes

BYLINE:  By JAN M. ROSEN 

 BODY:
WITH the economy stumbling and the stock market still struggling to rebound, a year-end bonus may seem the stuff of dreams. But Americans have one sure way to create their own cash cushions: using fourth-quarter financial moves to lower their 2002 tax bills.
 "It's turning the downturn into some positives -- making the lemons into lemonade," said Kim Landry, a certified financial planner and vice president at A. G. Edwards & Sons in St. Louis. 
 Ms. Landry recommends that investors perform a "portfolio cleanup," to sell some holdings that have declined, along with some winners. "Many people have held onto stocks for a long time because they do not want to pay the capital gains tax," she said. But capital losses offset capital gains dollar for dollar, so selling portfolio losers may let shareholders recognize their gains in the same year with no tax liability. 
What's more, if they have a net capital loss of up to $3,000, it can offset ordinary income. For a middle-class taxpayer, that can mean total savings of more than $1,000 on federal and state taxes. Anything over $3,000 is carried forward indefinitely to future years.
Many people do not want to abandon quality stocks that are down in price, Ms. Landry said. But it is possible to hold on to the stock, yet recognize the loss for tax purposes by buying an equal number of shares of the same issue before Nov. 29 and selling the original holding before Dec. 31.
Taxpayers cannot just sell the stock and buy it right back. That would run afoul of what is known as the wash-sale rule; under it, a loss will not be recognized for tax purposes if a taxpayer buys the same issue within 31 days. Still, someone holding a losing position might consider selling now and buying back into it after 31 days, Ms. Landry said, if he or she does not have the idle cash to double up.
Charitable gifts can also reduce taxes. If appreciated securities are given to charity, the taxpayer deducts the fair market value and owes no capital gains tax on the appreciation. "Taxpayers should be sure the securities are out of their accounts and into the charity's accounts by the end of the year to get the deduction," she said.
Brent Lipschultz, senior manager for personal financial planning in the New York office of KPMG, says that many charitably inclined people routinely fulfill their pledges by giving securities. If a stock is down, however, as many are this year, it is better to sell it, take the capital loss and then donate the proceeds to charity, he said.
Strategies for gifts can be used to lower estate and income taxes, Mr. Lipschultz said. This year, individual gifts of up to $11,000 a recipient have no gift or estate tax consequences, up from $10,000 in previous years. Up to five years' worth of gifts can be made at once to a state-sponsored Section 529 college savings plan. This means that a married couple could put $110,000 into a plan for a child or grandchild with no gift-tax consequences. The money would be out of their estate, and when it was distributed for qualified college expenses, the earnings on the money would be free of tax.
Mr. Lipschultz cited another approach for using gifts to pay college costs. Parents who have invested over the years for their children's educations often sell securities to pay tuition and other expenses, and then owe taxes of up to 20 percent on any long-term capital gains. As an alternative, they can give up to $11,000 in stock to a student who has little or no other income, and the student can sell it to pay the expenses herself; she will be taxed at just 8 percent on gains on stocks her parents held at least five years.
Tax-deferred retirement plans are a longtime favorite way to lower tax bills, and the contribution limits are higher this year. Employed people may put up to $11,000 in a 401(k) or 403(b) plan; those 50 and older can put in an extra $1,000 under new catch-up provisions. Contribution limits for Individual Retirement Accounts are now $3,000, or $3,500 for those 50 and older, up from the long-established $2,000.
Avery E. Neumark, partner in charge of employee benefits and executive compensation at Rosen Seymour Shapss Martin & Company in New York, said many self-employed people could put away more for retirement because the income limits upon which the contributions are calculated have risen this year. For a form of I.R.A. known as a SEP, or simplified employee pension, the limit is $200,000.
Other plans for self-employed people are money-purchase and profit-sharing plans, formerly known as Keoghs. People with any self-employment income, including sideline work or director's fees, should be sure to establish these plans, Mr. Neumark said. By law, the plans must be set up before Dec. 31, although people can wait until the due date of their tax returns to put the money into the account. The wait gives taxpayers or their tax preparers time to complete the complex calculations needed to figure the right amount.
 RETIREMENT contributions can mean a double tax savings, Mr. Neumark noted. The money is not taxed for this year, and it lowers adjusted gross income, which may allow a taxpayer greater savings from itemized deductions and personal exemptions.
Ms. Landry said another way to take advantage of the market's downturn was to convert a traditional I.R.A. to a Roth I.R.A. Such conversations are allowed for taxpayers whose adjusted gross incomes are below $100,000, but taxes must be paid at conversion. (That is because pretax money has gone into a traditional I.R.A., while after-tax money goes into a Roth I.R.A., allowing retirement distributions to be free of tax.) In previous years, she said, many people who wanted to convert to Roth I.R.A.'s felt that they could not afford the tax bite. "Now people can use the depressed value to their advantage from a tax standpoint," she said.
Other tax savings are available to people aged 70 1/2 or older who are required by law to take distributions from I.R.A.'s and retirement plans. "For 2002, the minimum distributions rules were revised again, downward, to reflect longer life expectancies," Mr. Neumark said. "That is good because it allows more money to accumulate in the account tax-deferred."
For increasing numbers of taxpayers, year-end planning now involves calculating whether they are liable for the alternative minimum tax, noted Julian Block, a tax lawyer in Larchmont, N.Y. The Treasury Department projects that 2.7 million Americans will be affected by the A.M.T. this year, roughly double the number in 2001 and triple the number in 2000, because of changes in tax law last year.
If so, appropriate planning can often be reversed. "Traditional advice is to accelerate deductions and defer income," he said. Under the alternative minimum tax, rates are a bit lower, at 26 or 28 percent, versus a normal top rate of 38 percent. But many deductions are not allowed, so a taxpayer may want to accelerate income and defer deductions. One big lost deduction under the A.M.T. is state and local income and real estate taxes. A potential A.M.T. liability may help a taxpayer decide whether to pay estimated taxes and real estate taxes in the fourth quarter or in January.
