LENGTH: 484 words

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST SIDE; 
Strollers Aplenty, but What About Desks?

BYLINE:  By ERIKA KINETZ 

 BODY:
There must be a lot of love on the East Side. The area has experienced a baby boomlet, fueled not only by ardor but also by prosperity, residential construction and good schools.
 Between 1990 to 2000, when the number of children under 5 citywide grew only 6 percent, on the East Side it jumped 22 percent, according to analysis of census data by Andrew A. Beveridge and Susan Weber, sociologists at Queens College. 
 The relatively affluent enclave those children were born into has changed in the last few years. Wall Street is staggering and the city is facing a fiscal crisis. The East Side's good and often excellent public schools, which between 1990 and 2000 had to accommodate an additional 4,100 children, are near or over capacity.
"My husband teases me that every time I see a pregnant woman, I have a little bit of, 'Oh, my God, where is that kid going to go to school?' " said Councilwoman Eva Moskowitz, who represents the East Side of Manhattan and is herself expecting a baby in January.
The situation may get worse. Planned redevelopment of a 9.2-acre site along First Avenue between 35th and 41st Streets, owned by Consolidated Edison, could bring 6,000 new apartments to the area by 2011. FSM East River Associates, a development partnership, bought the property in 2000. 
In response, Community Board 6 has asked the Public Service Commission, which must approve the transfer of land from Con Ed to the developers, to require the developers to include a school in their plans. 
"New school space is critical if thousands of new residential units are created in a school district that is already full of overcrowded classrooms," said Representative Carolyn B. Maloney, whose Congressional district includes the area.
The developers have conceded that a new school is a real possibility.
"The environmental impact statement indicates that if there is a shortage of seats as a result of the development, the Public Service Commission may consider a range of remedies, including construction of a new school on the site," said Howard J. Rubenstein, a spokesman for the developers.
Local residents say that real estate brokers praise Public School 116, on East 33rd Street, as an alternative to newcomers moving into the area, but they fear that an influx of children would create a problem.
"They need to give back to the community by allowing us some space for school," Kathy Marchi, co-president of the P.T.A. at P.S. 116, said of the developers. "P.S. 116 offers an incredible education, which will not be possible if everything is overcrowded."
Many local residents fear that if more schools are not built, recent progress will be unwound. 
"It used to be in the 70's, people would move out before they had their first kid," Ms. Moskowitz said. "If you stop collecting the garbage and regulating the noise, and if you don't provide them with schooling options, you will lose them." ERIKA KINETZ

HEADLINE: TRENDS; 
A Fish Tale

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH D'AGNESE 

 BODY:
ONE sushi place, two sushi places, three sushi places.
 In the same way that towns can boast of two or more pizza places, Chinese restaurants and diners, they can now point out that one's craving for raw fish can be satisfied just as easily. 
 Yet sushi is not cheap, and times are not flush. So why -- at a time when the economy is gasping, when local fishermen are crying foul over the plunder of prime fishing grounds by foreign seamen, and when environmentalists are warning that countless species are threatened -- are New Jersey restaurateurs opening sushi restaurants faster than salmon can climb a ladder? 
"Because it's low-calorie and tasty -- that's why," said Kunio Yasutake, a Washington-based restaurateur who is president of the United States Sushi Association.
Mr. Yasutake says that the number of sushi restaurants in the nation -- currently about 5,300 -- appears to be growing, and that does not include some of the more creative venues like supermarkets, catering halls and mainstream restaurants.
Although the New Jersey Restaurant Association does not break down the number establishments by the types of cuisine offered, Deborah Dowdell, the organization's executive vice president, said her instincts told her something was afoot.
For one thing, Ms. Dowdell said, New Jersey is home to many corporations, providing a steady of stream of Asians coming here to live and work. In addition, the state's Asian population is already more than 2 percent higher than the national average, according to the 2000 census.
While the Japanese population trails behind the number of residents of Chinese and Korean descent, that eclectic mix is having an effect on dining choices. Then there is the inescapable -- New Jersey's proximity to New York City.
"Right now in suburbia you have a concentration of ethnic Asians," said Charles Hamade, co-owner of Wild Ginger, an upscale Asian fusion restaurant in Englewood.
Mr. Hamade, who is Lebanese, shares the business with a Japanese partner, Yoshiharu Suzuki, formerly of Gibbon in Manhattan. "It used to be that these families would live in the city," Mr. Hamade said, "but the city has become too expensive. And after Sept. 11, I think a lot of people are moving out of the city. You're going to see a massive amount of restaurants."
Summit is a perfect study in suburban sushi. The upscale town already has one prominent sushi restaurant, Brix 67, with an outdoor cafe across from the New Jersey Transit station. Elsewhere in town, a small Chinese restaurant sells sushi, and a more traditional Japanese restaurant is also in the works. That means that when Allan Luftig, a commercial photographer from Millburn, and his partners -- Carl Waltzer and On Le, a chef with three sushi restaurants in Manhattan -- open their place, Monster Sushi, they will have competition from no fewer than three sushi restaurants.
Asked if that was a bit daunting, Mr. Luftig said: "I think there's always going to be competition. But I'm confident were going to stick out. Remember, it's not only Summit, but a number of towns out here: Short Hills, Chatham, Millburn."
Not that the appetite for sushi is confined to New Jersey. In the last four years, the California Sushi Academy, the nation's first school for sushi chefs, has graduated about 450 students -- some of whom came from Japan for a six-month course and were snapped up by employers.
"We are getting more and more phone calls from restaurants looking for chefs," said Phillip Yi, the school's director. "That's not just in the United States but all over the world."
Mr. Yi added: "People are looking for alternative ways to eat out. They've had the Italian food, Chinese food, French food, and now they're looking for healthier ways of eating and something that's completely different. At a sushi restaurant, the food is being prepared right in front of you, it's not being brought out from the kitchen. And the atmosphere when you go into a sushi bar is pretty high-energy, pretty lively."
While the number of sushi restaurants in New Jersey is climbing, the phenomenon is not limited to restaurants. Four years ago, Kings Supermarkets, based in Parsippany, started selling take-out sushi. Today, 21 of its 28 stores offer prepackaged meals, of which 8 feature on-site sushi chefs.
While purists might quibble that some of the fish is cooked or smoked, there is no arguing with customer taste; Kings says business has doubled in four years.
These days, when a couple plans a wedding in New Jersey, they are likely to be offered a sushi "upgrade" to their catering plan. For instance, at Mayfair Farms in West Orange, Marty Horn, one of the owners, has made that option available for the last four years, and he says that competitors are doing the same thing.
"Appetites have changed," said Mr. Horn, who is also president of the New Jersey Restaurant Association. "People used to go to Benihana, which was everyone's idea of a traditional Japanese restaurant. But for years now they know and want sushi. They gravitate more toward different rolls -- spicy tuna, California rolls."
Yet this endless ubiquity worries Mr. Hamade of Wild Ginger in Englewood.
"Everyone is jumping on the bandwagon," he said. "You can walk into a Chinese restaurant and get sushi. What no one understands is that it's difficult to find really good Japanese sushi chefs. Some of these people have not lived in Japan, nor have they been trained in Japan. And that's why the food is miserable. There is what I call a uniquely Japanese approach to sushi. It starts with knowing your fish, buying sushi-grade fish, and knowing how to slice it."
Some, like Mr. Luftig of Monster Sushi in Summit, would argue that there is also a uniquely American-style sushi, like the kind his partner, Mr. Le, offers at his restaurants in Midtown Manhattan, Chelsea and the West Village -- known for bright colors, chefs who joke with patrons, playful movie posters and 3-D monsters that spoof old Japanese movies.
"When parents walk past the restaurants in the city," he said, "their kids always want to go inside because they love those monsters."
Of course, not everyone is thrilled, said Mr. Luftig, who noted that one person in Summit griped: "Another sushi place? We need a British tearoom in this town."

HEADLINE: URBAN TACTICS; 
They Fought Side by Side, and Long to Be Buried That Way

BYLINE:  By LAURIE KELLIHER 

 BODY:
SEMYON PUNDIK, 76, and Iosef Kruglyak, 75, never knew each other on the Eastern Front. The two men from Ukraine, among more than 1,000 World War II veterans of the Red Army now living in Brighton Beach, Brooklyn, met only a few years ago. Yet when they talk about one another, they use the word "family." 
 Now, they anticipate the death they thought they would meet on a Russian battlefield more than half a century ago. Like many family members, they want to be buried side by side along with hundreds of their comrades. 
 "We want to be together at one cemetery," said Mr. Kruglyak, who defended the city of Sevastopol during the war and emigrated from Ukraine in 1992. "Because our families, most of them know each other here now, and when our children and grandchildren come to visit us, they will also see this friend and this friend and that friend, and they will remember our heroism." 
The veterans have their eye on a 5,000-square-foot plot in New Montefiore Cemetery in West Babylon, on Long Island. And an organization exists, albeit an impoverished one, that may one day help them achieve their goal. 
The group, the American Association of Invalids and Veterans of World War II From the Former U.S.S.R., began seven years ago with an informal organization of 30. It now has more than 3,000 in the New York region, 2,000 of whom live in Brooklyn. As Jews who shared both the deprivations of a brutal war against Hitler's forces and postwar anti-Semitism under a Soviet system they had risked their lives to preserve, their allegiance is not to the former Soviet Union, nor to the Red Army, nor even to Mother Russia, but to one another. 
Since 1997, the association has been operating on a shoestring out of a small second-floor office on Brighton 11th Street, just off Brighton Beach Avenue. What furniture they have was donated by local synagogues or taken from Dumpsters. The walls are plastered with hundreds of photographs showing the veterans, young and in uniform, during 1941 to 1945.
The $750 monthly rent is paid from membership fees of $1 per month, although only 40 percent of the veterans pay it and no one asks them for the money if they miss a month, or even if they miss every month. With the few hundred dollars left, the veterans publish a newsletter and buy birthday cakes to take to nursing homes and flower arrangements to take to funeral homes.
Seven veterans work as volunteers, arriving promptly at 10 a.m. in coats and ties and answering questions from the several dozen other veterans who visit the office on an average day. "I come here every day," said Leonid Rozenberg, the association's president. "I am 80 years old. I have a pacemaker. I have no strength. But I have to try."
AMONG the snapshots that trace the veterans' lives in Brighton Beach -- the birthday parties, the Victory Day commemorations -- is an image of the parcel of land in New Montefiore Cemetery. When some of the veterans' friends from the shtetls of Byelorussia, now Belarus, began buying small plots there together in 1996, many veterans began thinking about how they, too, would confront the inevitable.
The dream is currently a distant one. A block of several hundred plots would cost more than $25,000, an impossible sum for the veterans, some of whom can barely meet their own living expenses. Still, they write letters to senators, representatives and anyone else they think might help them realize this dream. Their hope is not only to acquire the land, but also to erect a small monument commemorating their war efforts, and perhaps benches where wives and children could sit and talk.
In the meantime, they attend one another's funerals, many of which are conducted by Rabbi Mark Zarkh, who works for Nevsky Chapels Funeral Home in Midwood, Brooklyn.
"The veterans come whenever one of these 3,000 guys dies," Rabbi Zarkh said. "They don't have limousines to take them. They take public transportation."
Most of the mourners are in the 80's, and the trip is difficult. "They push themselves," he said. "It's quite remarkable."
Rabbi Zarkh, whose family emigrated from Leningrad, does not charge for his services. "I owe them," he said. "I owe them my life. If it wasn't for these guys, I wouldn't be here today."
When a veteran dies, Alla Lisovetsky, a funeral director at Nevsky Chapels, arranges the best service she can within the $1,400 Medicaid burial budget. She also fills out all the necessary forms. "I consider each of them my grandfather," she said. "This isn't business."
Ms. Lisovetsky is assisted by Maria Gutman, who lives near Nevsky Chapels and whose father, a pilot, died in the war. "He was killed in Poland, but we don't know the place where he is buried," Ms. Gutman said. "It is the reason this is so close to my heart."
Ms. Gutman, who emigrated from Belarus in 1991, was drawn to the needs of the veterans early on. "When I first went to the funeral of a veteran here, I saw that their medals weren't on display," she said. "I thought, 'This is not good for our people who are going away.' Our people have a lot of medals."
In response, she bought a large burgundy velvet pillow and made some alterations to it so that, as is the custom in Russian military funerals, the pillow can sit on a podium next to the coffin, with all the veteran's medals pinned to it. 
This final service is, paradoxically, one of the few high points in the veterans' lives.
"They don't have much to look forward to," Rabbi Zarkh said. "Happiness is their children and grandchildren and their own funerals. What else is there for them?"
As the association's president, Mr. Rozenberg organizes small contingents to attend these events. "One of us tries to be at each funeral," he said. "Most of us are close to that way ourselves. We try to find kind words to say about it, but it is difficult. We had the same lives ourselves." 
"At the time of the war," Mr. Rozenberg added, "we didn't know anything. We just gave our lives for victory. Only after Stalin's death did we understand that he wanted to get rid of the Jews. Of course, we felt less patriotic after that."
Claudia Reichman, 81, is one of more than 500 women in the association. During the war, women served as radio communicators, translators, nurses, doctors and snipers. Ms. Reichman, who emigrated to the United States in 1982, was an army interpreter in Stalingrad. She says she finds it hard to reflect on the funerals of her compatriots here, largely because she has already seen the deaths of so many in her homeland.
"It was impossible to see every day the death of thousands of people, your comrades," she said. "Not one man, but thousands every day. If I am not crazy today, I don't know how, but nervous I am."
After a service at the funeral home, a veteran's body is taken for burial to one of several favored cemeteries: United Hebrew on Staten Island; Beth David in Elmont, on Long Island; Old Montefiore in St. Albans, Queens; Washington Cemetery in Midwood. The survivors usually make the most economical decision, which leaves the veterans scattered across New York.
This is not the veterans' preference.
"Here, I met people like me who went through the difficulties of war and anti-Semitism and immigration," said Boris Feldman, 81, who emigrated in 1995 and works at the association's office. "Here I have met such people that I want to be with during this life -- whatever is left -- and the next life too."

HEADLINE: Business; 
HSBC's New Loan: 2,000 Environmentalists

BYLINE:  By CHRISTINA LE BEAU 

 BODY:
LYNNE MARSHALL says she has never fully understood why HSBC Holdings, one of the world's largest banks, would send 2,000 employees on far-flung environmental expeditions. But Ms. Marshall, who was among the first to be chosen, is not second-guessing her employer.
 "This was a dream of a lifetime," said Ms. Marshall, 42, an HSBC vice president and trust account officer -- and an archaeology buff. She spent two weeks in July excavating animal bones and sifting sediment to help researchers study early man in Venta Micena, Spain, all at HSBC's expense. "I just can't believe I had this opportunity." 
 Ms. Marshall, from the HSBC office in Buffalo, is part of an uncommon experiment. HSBC, which is based in London, announced early this year that it was donating nearly $50 million to the Earthwatch Institute, WWF (formerly known as the World Wildlife Fund) and Botanic Gardens Conservation International for conservation projects worldwide over the next five years. It is by far the largest donation HSBC has ever made, and by far the largest that any of the three groups has received. 
But this corporate philanthropy is particularly unusual because HSBC employees like Ms. Marshall are spending two weeks at a time traversing jungles and glaciers and battling the elements, all in the name of environmental science. All told, HSBC and Earthwatch estimate that the 2,000 employee "fellows" will contribute in five years what might typically take the usual number of field workers on these projects 100 years to accomplish. And when they return from these research trips -- which are coordinated by Earthwatch -- the employees are expected not only to make presentations to colleagues, but also to create a related project in their home communities, using grants from HSBC.
By year-end, 210 employees will have participated, on trips to Brazil, Iceland, Sri Lanka, Australia and dozens of other places to help scientists study ecological systems and human civilization. An additional 290 will follow next year, with 500 more in each of the remaining three years. Earthwatch is getting $16 million to cover employee expenses and grants to scientists, and HSBC estimates that it will absorb an additional $4 million in costs associated with taking employees away from their work.
WWF is receiving $18.4 million to restore and protect several major river basin habitats. Botanic Gardens Conservation International will use its $11.6 million to protect endangered plant species and pay for botanical education programs.
The first group of HSBC employees to go on Earthwatch expeditions included 16 from the United States and was selected from nearly 2,200 applicants. Of HSBC's 170,000 employees, about 110,000 speak fluent-enough English -- a requirement -- to be eligible. Earthwatch chose the fellows; the bank doesn't see the applications, which ask employees to explain why they want to go and how they plan to share what they learn.
HSBC says the program is part of what it called a longstanding commitment to environmental and educational philanthropy projects. The company is a major corporate donor -- its philanthropic spending totaled $30.6 million in 2001. Until this year, however, HSBC had focused on local programs in the 81 countries and territories in which it operates, never exceeding $2 million or $3 million for a single project. 
"The environment is something that people feel very strongly about, and the reality is that we can make some difference there because of our scale," said Amanda Combes, the HSBC manager who oversees HSBC's community programs, including this latest venture, which HSBC calls Investing in Nature.
Ms. Combes, who is based in London, said the Earthwatch component, especially, showed the staff "that this is not just a perk, but a true demonstration that we as an organization take the environment seriously, that we're not just doing this as window dressing."
NOT everyone agrees that HSBC has a pristine record as a corporate citizen. It has underwritten bonds for the World Bank, which antiglobalization advocates accuse of having economic policies that undermine human rights and the environment in developing countries. And HSBC has made investments in socially and environmentally contentious projects in places like China and Indonesia, financing, for instance, nuclear plants and, in China, the Three Gorges Dam, which critics maintain will destroy the environment in the Yangtze River region. ISIS Asset Management, a London investment firm that monitors socially responsible investing, said in a recent report that HSBC was in its "chasing pack" category -- meaning that the bank had made progress assessing the environmental impact of its lending policies but still had room for improvement.
HSBC has allowed its Investing in Nature partners to scrutinize its investing and environmental policies and has agreed to set up joint committees to monitor progress. The bank also has hired KPMG to review its operations and set targets for lowering greenhouse gas emissions (through reduced utilities use and business travel), water consumption and waste production. Looking ahead, HSBC "will not automatically disengage from specific industry sectors," according to a company report on its behavior as a corporate citizen, but it will "err on the side of caution if we think the environmental risks of a transaction outweigh the benefits."
Earthwatch and the scientists it finances agree that HSBC's philanthropy, notably its donation of employees, has substantial impact. "This project, this type of research, wouldn't exist without the volunteers," said Peggy Rismiller, an environmental physiologist who studies threatened animal species on Kangaroo Island off southern Australia.
Like other scientists who rely on Earthwatch grants, she uses volunteers to gather data and do the grunt work that may become tedious for a researcher or a student. But to volunteers, it can be exhilarating. "Volunteers bring such enthusiasm; they'll go out and work and do the job until it's completed," Ms. Rismiller said.
Earthwatch sends out about 4,000 research volunteers each year, most of whom pay their own way or find sponsors for their trips. The organization has been setting up employee fellowships for about 10 years, for companies like Starbucks, Royal Dutch/Shell and Rio Tinto, a large mining company. But HSBC's program sends out more employees each year than all of the other employee fellowships combined. "The effectiveness of something like this is vastly increased when it's concentrated," said Steven D. Lydenberg, a principal at Domini Social Investments, which focuses exclusively on socially responsible investing. "That's really making a substantial commitment that more general volunteer programs, while they end up supporting employees, don't have."
HSBC employees who have made the trips cannot quite believe that this is one of their perks. "I had never met people like this before," said Diane Abbott, 36, a branch manager in Rochester who traveled to Brazil in March to help scientists monitor jaguars and conduct a tree census in the Pantanal wetlands. "I felt so far removed from the life I normally lead. Even after a couple of days, it felt like I hadn't sat at a desk, driven a car, run into a store in five years. It really did give me an entirely different perspective." 
Ms. Marshall said she was so taken with her archaeological dig in Spain that she had a hard time pulling herself away. "I'll tell you, I could have stayed there another five or six months," she said.
Darryl Szarpa, 49, who works in facilities administration in Buffalo, related similar feelings. He said his trip in August to Canyonlands National Park in Utah, where he trapped invertebrates and amphibians as part of an ecological survey, inspired thoughts of a second career once he retires.
 EMPLOYEES relished their work, even when the going was rough. "There were just levels of physical discomfort that I wasn't prepared for," said Emily Zahniser, 31, who traveled to central Ontario in July to study the effects of logging and development on ancient forests. Ms. Zahniser, who works as an executive assistant for HSBC in Manhattan and is an avid hiker and camper, battled mosquitoes and heavy rains while bushwalking through dense spruce and brush. "Had I known what I was getting into, I might have been hesitant, but now, having done it, there's no way I would have walked away," she said.
Ms. Zahniser applied for a forestry project because of her interest in Inwood Hill Park, which contains the remnants of primeval forest in Manhattan. For her community project, she would like to bring children to the park's ecology center and share what she has learned. Others have ideas for a mock archaeological dig, an Earth Day fair and plant-identification lessons for schools.
Peter Etu, 62, a senior programmer and technical analyst in Buffalo, returned in August from excavating a bison kill site in Jackson Hole, Wyo. Now he is thinking about his community project -- and is glad it's required. "I think if we didn't have that component, we'd do our fellowships and most of us would stop," Mr. Etu said. "This is an impetus to carry on."

HEADLINE: THE AGE OF DISSONANCE; 
Connoisseurship Runneth Over

BYLINE:  By BOB MORRIS 

 BODY:
The Whiskey Fest at the Marriott Marquis Hotel in Times Square was packed last Wednesday night with 1,000 guests, mostly men, who paid $85 to smell, taste, learn and discuss at length bourbon, Irish whiskey and Scotch. It was not for clubby social drinkers and macho booze swillers. If you like Scotch on the rocks, a tourist bar would have been the place for you.
 Real connoisseurs know that to nose and taste properly you have to add still water to your tulip-shaped glass so that the alcohol doesn't overwhelm you. They use words like "expression" to describe how a bottle from one year might differ from another bottled a year later, and adjectives like "peaty" to denote smokiness. They can tell, they claim, if the stream water used by a distillery had flowed over heather or granite. 
 The fifth floor of the Marriott was filled with 200 distillers, master blenders and the connoisseurs in tweeds who care about them, all trading information fiercely. 
"The only way you'd see this much excitement over Scotch back home in Scotland," said Gregor Cattanach, a kilt-wearing "brand ambassador" for Johnny Walker, looking a little besieged, "would be if you were offering Scotsmen free drinks."
That's Scotland. Here in the land of conspicuous consumption and perpetual self-improvement, we are competitive connoisseurs on a rampage. Not just about bourbon or Scotch but all alcohol, especially in the last five years, according to the Distilled Spirits Council of the United States. Even vodka, which is supposed to be about clarity and purity, and not much else, is getting heavily scrutinized. 
"Honestly, I can't tell the difference between brands," said Kevin Richards, president of Christiania Vodka, a Norwegian company with a regal heritage that's trying to muscle in on Grey Goose, Ketel One and Absolut. "But the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms says we have the right to call ours the world's smoothest vodka."
In an economy where niche markets multiply as rapidly as Internet spam, the capacity for new, competitive connoisseurship is endless. Is that bread artisanal and part of the slow-food movement? Is your television set plasma? Is it a Broad Picture by Loewe from Germany, with a 16.9-inch screen for ultimate movie viewing? Is your perfume custom-blended at a Creed store? Shirts bespoke and by Dunhill? Are the foxgloves from your cuttings garden heirloom? Do you subscribe, at $300 a year, to NB, a travel review "for people looking for better than four or five stars," according to a promoter. 
And please let's not even discuss cigars. 
As a culture, Americans are either suffering from obsessive-consumer disorder or have discovered a puritanical way of making leisure more purposeful. Maybe so many have-it-all Americans say they're overworked because they're making fun into second jobs. "Some connoisseurs are like people making a lot of money," said Colman Andrews, the editor in chief of Saveur, who calls experts "wine bozos" or "fruit bozos" on occasion. "They're so busy making it that they forget the point is to enjoy it."
Katie Brown, a cookbook author and television personality who specializes in simple American cooking, added: "Everything has become so precious. Olive oils have years on them now. Jelly labels announce they're made with river water and berries picked by forest nymphs. You go to buy eggs, and you have to read about how the hens are raised and fed and that they've laid the eggs in a teepee. Where will it end?"
Lew Bryson, the managing editor of Malt Advocate magazine, sponsor of the Whiskey Fest, said that what you can know about whiskey is endless -- until you've consumed enough to not know much of anything.
Halfway through the fest, he announced that a seminar on pot-still bourbon-making was about to begin in a room near the main hall. "Where is it exactly?" asked a well-dressed man in a green blazer. 
"Just outside on the right," Mr. Bryson said, adding, as the man staggered off, "If you can't find it, you're drunk."
And not on knowledge either.

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
Homeowners Drop the New and Go for Improved

BYLINE:  By JULIE FLAHERTY 

 BODY:
EVER since Joe Gardella retired from his engineering job five years ago, he and his wife, Cecile, have been thinking about selling their four-bedroom house in Milford, Mass. They recently checked out the modern condominium units near their home and even considered relocating to Fort Myers Beach, Fla. But they decided to stay put -- and to renovate.
 "We have such equity in this house that it would be foolish to try to sell it, because we would have to put that same amount of money into a much smaller condominium," said Mr. Gardella, 70. "We decided to make our existing home more modern, to keep up with all of our kids." 
 The Gardellas, who paid off their mortgage 10 years ago, chose to remodel their kitchen and dining room; the project, which took two months, cost about $40,000. A local contractor, True T. Davis Building and Remodeling, knocked down walls to make the two rooms flow together and added many extras, like recessed lighting, granite countertops, oak floors and a center island with new appliances. Aside from maintenance on the roof and heating system, the project was the first major renovation of the home since the couple bought it 27 years ago. 
Many homeowners around the country are undertaking similar projects, and for many economic reasons. While stock prices have declined sharply, home values have remained strong in many parts of the country. Interest rates are low, making it cheaper to finance a renovation. And, in contrast to financial assets, a home is an investment that can also be enjoyed.
Prices for most renovations have held steady. While some contractors felt only a dip in business after Sept. 11, others are still trying to recover, which means that they may be willing to get to your project sooner.
The National Association of the Remodeling Industry predicts that Americans will spend $163 billion on renovations this year, up 3.5 percent from 2001 and 8.7 percent from 2000. Much of the money is being spent by people who have moved recently. (This year alone, sales of existing homes are expected to reach 5.4 million units, breaking last year's record of 5.3 million.) 
Renovation demand is strong in high-priced metropolitan markets like Boston, San Francisco and New York. Trading up to a larger house has become prohibitively expensive for many people in such areas, so they are deciding to make changes to their current homes instead.
"The old days of selling a house and moving on up is not happening" for some people, said True Davis, the Gardellas' contractor. Budget-minded homeowners are expanding their living space by converting basements into playrooms or media rooms, he said. Homeowners who are less concerned about money have installed home theaters, wine cellars and even cigar bars with built-in humidors, others say.
Kitchen and bathroom makeovers, though, remain the most popular projects, experts say, mainly because styles are changing constantly. These renovations also have the highest rate of return. On average, homeowners can expect to recoup around 80 percent of their investments in major kitchen and bathroom remodeling, according to Remodeling magazine, though the figures vary around the country. There are also high rates of return for master bedroom, sunroom and family room additions, the magazine says.
Finding a good contractor helps to ensure the best rate of return, not to mention the best results. "You've heard you get what you pay for; that's very true in remodeling," said David Tyson, a designer and remodeling contractor in Charlotte, N.C.
The rule of thumb is to get at least three to five written estimates before signing a contract. But the best way to narrow the pool of candidates may be to ask neighbors. In fact, the remodeling association says that nearly three-quarters of renovation business comes from client referrals or word of mouth.
Mrs. Gardella, 69, a retired nurse, said she saw Mr. Davis's van outside a neighbor's house and asked her neighbor about his work. The neighbor was happy to show her how Mr. Davis had repaired water damage on the first floor.
"You want someone who asks where to place the Dumpster, whether the dog goes out or stays in, when the kids go to school," said Kevin McNulty, executive vice president of the association. "You want a professional."
Of course, you'll also want to set a realistic budget -- and stay within it, though some projects may give you sticker shock. A major kitchen renovation runs about $40,000, on average.
Renovation experts suggest that homeowners leave a 5 to 10 percent cushion for unexpected expenses. In some cases, they add, homeowners may also need to factor in the cost of temporarily renting an apartment or staying in a hotel, plus expenses for meals. Some contractors may provide portable mini-kitchen units that can be set up in a dining room or on a porch.
The Gardellas said they were able to make do without leaving their home. "We have a microwave set up and a toaster, and we have a Wendy's right up the corner," Mr. Gardella said. "And we've got our kids around who are fairly close, so we sponge off them." 
Most people, including the Gardellas, renovate their homes to make them more livable. Others renovate only to improve a resale value. But homeowners need to be careful not to over-improve, experts say. 
"If they are in a neighborhood of flat ranches, there is a limit to what people will pay for a flat ranch, no matter what is in it," said Leslie Brooks, the president of the Massachusetts Board of Real Estate Appraisers in Dedham. The only way to know is by researching prices -- by talking to local real estate agents or by searching the Internet.
WHAT is in style in home renovation, or what will be? Mr. McNulty of the remodeling industry group says he thinks that more homes will be computer-driven. "The cutting edge is in the intelligent appliances and connectivity of the home, in some of the more progressive areas of the country," he said. He also expects more renovation projects to reflect a "green attitude," using recycled materials and alternative energy systems.
Kitchens and bathrooms, in particular, are becoming more high-tech. Some new appliances have several functions, like the refrigerated range, which chills food at 40 degrees and can be programmed to warm it up or start cooking at a certain time. Some sinks can convert into dishwashers. And in bathrooms, showers are often now separate from the tub and might include steam or fiber optics that change the color of the water to suit the bather's mood.
"People are getting very big on the master-bedroom and master-bath concept, and every master bath has to have a whirlpool," said Ms. Brooks, the appraiser.
Of course, none of these appliances and devices are cheap. Whirlpool's new Polara Refrigerated Range has a suggested retail price range of $1,799 to $1,899. 
Color schemes are also changing, experts say, in part to balance all the new technology. Particularly popular are warm and cozy colors with yellow tones that give a sense of security, like terra cotta, or serene colors that convey relaxation, like soft blues and greens, said Melanie Wood, a design consultant at Mannington Mills of Salem, N.J., and the immediate past president of the Color Marketing Group, an industry association that tracks color trends. 
"We see more soothing colors that are easy to live with," she said. "We get enough of a jolt from the world outside."

How to Sort Out the Contractors

THINKING about remodeling? The National Association of the Remodeling Industry (www.remodeltoday.com) recommends interviewing several prospective contractors before hiring one. Here are some questions to ask:
How many similar projects have you completed in the last 12 months?
What percentage of your work comes from repeat business or referrals?
Do you have a list of references (at least three) for similar projects you have completed?
Are the company's employees certified by a trade group like the remodeling industry association?
Does your company carry workers' compensation and liability insurance? Are copies of the insurance certificates available? 
Is the company a full-service or specialty firm? (Homeowners who are planning a small project, say, replacing the bathroom plumbing, may be better off hiring a specialty plumbing firm or a bathroom remodeler.)
Is a permit needed for this project? (A qualified remodeling contractor will know the permit process and ensure that all permits have been received before starting work.)
Can you provide a list of your suppliers? (Suppliers can also help you learn more about the contractor's credit history.)

GRAPHIC: Photos: Cecile and Joe Gardella, top, of Milford, Mass., decided to renovate recently. True Davis, below left, a contractor, remodeled the kitchen and dining room for $40,000. (Photographs by Jodi Hilton for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 14; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 2641 words

HEADLINE: Fading Into History 

BYLINE:  By ALLEN SALKIN 

 BODY:
LINDA Macfarlane, nee Feuer, stood on East Houston Street and looked stunned as she peered south at the sleek bistros and boutiques lining Orchard Street. "It's all gone," she whispered to her husband as she clutched his arm. "What happened?"
 Ms. Macfarlane, 59, left New York more than 25 years ago. Now, on a recent visit to the city, she wanted to show her husband the children's clothing store where she had worked "selling shmattes" as a teenager. But the store, whose name she cannot remember, is gone, as are most of the landmarks and talismans in the neighborhood that was for generations the traditional symbol of the American Jewish experience: the fabric merchants, the ethnic food sellers, the children's furniture stores. 
 "I wanted to smell it, follow my nose, the food, the places," Ms. Macfarlane said wistfully, brushing her blond hair back from her eyes. "But nothing smells the same anymore. The people, everything's gone. The whole ghetto is gone." 
Last month, Ratner's Delicatessen on Delancey Street sold its last onion roll and closed after 97 years. Two years ago, the owners of Schapiro's Kosher Winery on Rivington Street rolled their barrels out of the basement and called it quits, selling the building for $2.3 million. Two weeks ago, H&M Skullcap moved from its home on Hester Street, where it had been for half a century, to 13th Avenue in Borough Park, Brooklyn, a thriving Jewish business thoroughfare. "The Chinese don't want to buy yarmulkes," said Mendel Fefer, a salesman. Some of the remaining small synagogues have so few members that they must import teenagers from Williamsburg, Brooklyn, to help make the minyan of 10 required for daily prayers.
The long-contracting Jewish Lower East Side, the primal homeland for American immigrant Jews, has lost so much of its cultural texture and so many of its living touchstones that it may be time finally to pronounce it dead. Yet paradoxically, even as the traditional neighborhood vanishes, interest in its place in Jewish heritage is exploding, evidenced by the packs of competing walking tours, a spate of new books about its history and increased attendance at the Lower East Side Tenement Museum. 
At its peak, around 1910, the square-mile area bounded by East Third Street, the Bowery, Catherine Street and the East River was home to 373,057 people, a great majority of whom were Eastern European Jews. In the 2000 census, the entire population was only 91,704, nearly half of whom were of Asian descent. Only 17,200 were whites of non-Hispanic descent. 
Despite its changing ethnic and religious makeup, the Lower East Side is hardly suffering economically. Shiny new shops, selling everything from rubber miniskirts to $10 margaritas, have taken over storefronts and brightened blocks that had been abandoned for decades. Clinton Street has become a gourmet destination and Orchard Street a high-fashion strand. The long-shuttered Sunshine Theater on East Houston Street, once a Yiddish vaudeville house, is now a cinema. Moviegoers can fortify themselves with refreshments from the venerable Yonah Schimmel Knishes next door.
Grand Street between Allen and Chrystie Streets bustles with Chinese shops selling vegetables and seafood. Last month, Vanity Fair magazine published a map showing local outposts of trendiness.
Despite such shifts, for countless American Jews like Ms. Macfarlane, the area has remained almost a holy land in memory, an old country to return to. The real old country -- the cities, towns and shtetls of Europe -- has long since disappeared in clouds of war and genocide. But even as recently as a few years ago, a person walking the streets of the Lower East Side could sense the collective memory of a tangible past, helped along by the few Jewish businesses that survived.
Two years ago, the area was designated a state and national historic district. But such a designation does not freeze a neighborhood's appearance and retard change the way landmark designation does.
As a result, what is being lost now are the last images that make it possible to conjure the fantasy of the old days. And a few tenements where Jews once lived, a couple of silver candlestick sellers, Russ & Daughters smoked-fish emporium and Streit's matzo factory are not enough to do the trick for people like Ms. Macfarlane or any of the other mystified visitors seen daily on Orchard Street. To make the dream live, they seem to need the taste of kosher corned beef (Katz's Delicatessen is not kosher), the reek of pickles in brine and the Yiddish-inflected voices of haggling merchants. 
They crave the specters of a vanished culture, said Joyce Mendelsohn, who teaches New York City history at the New School and leads walking tours based on her guidebook, "The Lower East Side Remembered and Revisited" (Lower East Side Press, 2001). "People got upset when Ratner's closed," she said. "They feel an emotional, nostalgic tie to the neighborhood, which is expressed in food in a large way. They are running for the bialys, for the pickles. It's like the heart of the Jewish experience they're hoping to go back to in some way."

Jewish or Not Jewish?
Some people say it is premature to announce the death of the Lower East Side as a Jewish enclave. They point to the recent restoration of a century-old mikvah (ritual bath) on East Broadway, the 270 children who attend local yeshivas and the small synagogues that still dot the streets. Kosher food is still available; Kossar's Bialys on Grand Street sells 500 dozen bialys a day, 30 percent of them to retail customers and the rest to stores like Zabar's.
William Rapfogel, executive director of the Metropolitan Council on Jewish Poverty, says his organization's statistics show that the number of Lower East Side Jews has not changed much over the past decade.
"It may not be as religious, but it's still Jewish," said Debra Engelmeyer, 32, whose family bought Kossar's from the company's founding family four years ago.
But the district is feeling the effects of both an aging population and real estate shifts that have transformed much of the city. Cooperative Village, for example, a 4,500-apartment complex south of the Williamsburg Bridge built as housing for union members, was for decades heavily Orthodox Jewish. Starting in 1997, when restrictions on the selling price of apartments were lifted, many residents began taking generous profits and leaving. A fourth of the units have been sold. The management of the complex says young Orthodox families are moving in, drawn by the opportunity to knock down walls and create large apartments to house large families. But real estate brokers who have handled sales at Cooperative Village say the new buyers represent many different ethnicities.
Almost every night, Rabbi Schmuel Spiegel struggles to gather a minyan at the First Roumanian-American Congregation on Rivington Street. One recent evening, just before services were to start, Rabbi Spiegel had only five men in his sanctuary. Hurrying out the door, he went to Orchard Street.
"You coming to shul?" he asked Sam Weiss, who sat outside his men's shop.
"There's no one else to watch the store," Mr. Weiss replied.
The rabbi bounded into Altman's Luggage. "You're on your minyan roundup?" asked Dan Bettinger, the shopkeeper. But he couldn't make it, either.
Rabbi Spiegel tried Dolce Vita Shoes, and even stuck his head into a car parked on Rivington Street because the driver was wearing a yarmulke. Ten minutes later, he only had eight men, including a tourist from San Diego named Al Krinick who had shown up because he had heard "they were still davening" in the synagogue where his grandfather had prayed more than half a century before. A phone call to Katz Furniture on Essex Street yielded a father-and-son pair. Mission accomplished. 
"Twenty years ago, you would have said there will never be a minyan there in 20 years," Rabbi Spiegel said later. "But we're still here. Ten years from now, I can't say."

Mythmaking and the Museum
While the Lower East Side may not be what it was, in fact, the neighborhood as remembered, idealized and enshrined in popular culture probably never existed. 
The story of life in those precincts is achingly familiar: immigrants jammed into hellish tenements, entire families laboring long hours for meager wages in equally hellish sweatshops, rampant and devastating disease. Most Jewish immigrants wanted nothing more than to get out.
"If it were still a poor neighborhood of Jews selling cheap clothes and other things and struggling to survive, it wouldn't be iconic, it would be a problem," said Hasia R. Diner, a professor of American Jewish history at New York University and the author of "Lower East Side Memories: A Jewish Place in America" (Princeton University Press, 2000), a work exploring why the neighborhood has been remembered fondly over the years. "It's only with the moving on, with the passage of time, that that sort of stuff can be viewed as sweet and lovely."
After World War II, and gaining urgency in the 1960's and 1970's with books like Irving Howe's epic "World of Our Fathers," the Lower East Side became an ever more powerful symbol of the bygone life of the shtetl, where, as Ms. Diner put it, "families got along, neighbors took care of each other and all the food tasted better." 
That impulse is turning the Jewish Lower East Side into a museum piece. Walking-tour guides point to where things used to be, not where they are. The Forward building, home until 1974 of the Yiddish-language newspaper that in the 1920's sold 250,000 copies a day, was converted into expensive loft apartments. The Forsyth Street Synagogue is a Spanish-language Seventh-day Adventist Church. The Garden Cafeteria, where Isaac Bashevis Singer set his short story "The Cabalist of East Broadway," is a Chinese restaurant.
"There is more of a future for tourism than there is for Judaism," said Philip Schoenberg, who has led Jewish Lower East Side Talk and Walk tours since 1992. "I have people who go on my tours, and all I'm saying is: 'This was once a kosher butcher shop. This was this. This was once that.' " 
In addition to the tours conducted by Mr. Schoenberg and Ms. Mendelsohn of the New School, there are others led by the Tenement Museum (every weekend) and Big Onion Walking Tours (which runs a Jewish Lower East Side tour monthly). Ms. Mendelsohn, who books some of her tours through the 92nd Street Y, has been hired by the Lower East Side Conservancy to train docents for tours of historic Lower East Side synagogues. In the last year, more than 12,000 people have taken these tours.
As flesh-and-blood Jews leave, mythmaking becomes ever more powerful.
In 2000, the patch of Orchard Street in front of the Tenement Museum was torn up and replaced by perfectly even rows of unchipped black cobblestone, to give a period feel. The museum, which opened in 1988, takes visitors from around the world into tiny, historically restored apartments at 97 Orchard Street, where 7,000 people lived between 1863 and the 1930's. Annual attendance has soared, from 18,000 in 1992 to 82,000 in the fiscal year ending June 30.
Since 1986, a $10 million restoration has been under way at the Eldridge Street Synagogue. These days, the spectacular stained-glass window on the facade is clear enough for sunlight to flow into the 115-year-old sanctuary. But this space, where 1,000 people once worshiped on the High Holy Days, still needs work. Saturday morning services are held in a small basement room.

Changes, Even in Little Shtetl
If a Jewish equivalent to Little Italy remains in Manhattan -- Little Shtetl, say -- it is probably the two-block stretch of Essex Street between East Broadway and Grand Street, where half a dozen stores carry signs with Hebrew lettering. Yet even here, tides of change are apparent.
At No. 7, an 11-story luxury condominium is rising over neighboring tenements. The sign promises "yards, roof terraces, fireplaces, skyline views -- 1,584 to 3,650 square feet from $825,000." At No. 11 Essex sits the building that until a year ago housed A1, a store that sold Judaica.
Past a Chinese-run store selling cellphones and car parts, at No. 13, is Motty Blumenthal's Judaica shop, named Z & A Kol Torah by his parents, Zelig and Aliza, who opened it 50 years ago. "As long as people come here, I'll stay," Mr. Blumenthal said. "It'll last at least another 5 or 10 years."
At No. 17, next door to Chinese North Dumpling, is Essex Electronics. For many of the store's 35 years, the area was a major destination for Israeli tourists seeking discounted stereo equipment. "There used to be 20 shops here," said Chaim Loeb, the manager. "Now there are three or four, but some people still come." 
Above another storefront at No. 17 is a friendly ghost: the sign Ha-attikos Judaica. The shop closed years ago, neighbors say, and the space is now an apartment. 
At No. 19 is Weinfeld Skull Caps, which has been at the same location for 70 years. Recent customers included Martin and Goldie Sosnick, a San Francisco couple who were ordering 240 black suede yarmulkes for their daughter's wedding. "It's nice to come to where the roots are from," Ms. Sosnick said. But, she added, "it was disappointing to come here wanting to eat in a kosher restaurant, and there wasn't one here."
Soon Weinfeld's will be gone, too; one of the owners said he planned to move the business to Brooklyn within the year, "to be in a Jewish neighborhood."
No. 21 houses T & H Insurance, which has a Chinese-lettered sign, and, until two months ago, Israel Wholesale Import, a Judaica shop, which jumped to 23 Essex, displacing a Chinese printer. Also at No. 23 is Hollywood Video, which sells Chinese-language videos; the sign identifies the address as "23 Exsses St." And so it goes.
Qun Lei, a clerk at Shun Da Sign, a store at 25 Essex Street that manufactures many of the Chinese-language signs that are installed when the Hebrew signs come down, sees the block's future more clearly than its past. "I think it's a Chinese neighborhood," said Ms. Lei, 33, who emigrated from China a year ago and calls herself Maggie."
Ms. Lei hopes to save enough money so she and her family can leave the neighborhood, unconsciously following the path trod by Jews of nearly a century ago. "Uptown Manhattan is good," she said.

Looking at a Cloudy Future
Not every business that might speak to the real or imagined past is gone.
Streit's matzo bakery still makes unleavened bread for a national and international market at the Rivington Street address where the company was founded in 1925.
Russ & Daughters, the smoked-fish and caviar store, occupies the same white-tiled East Houston Street shop where it has been since 1914. Yonah Schimmel Knishes has survived, and Guss's Pickles has found a new lease on life near the Tenement Museum. The owners of Noah's Ark, a kosher restaurant in Teaneck, N.J., will open a branch on Grand Street by year's end.
Perhaps not surprisingly, one of the few merchants who has no intention of moving is the area's last gravestone seller. "We own the building here, and people know where we are," said Murray Silver, the 60-year-old owner of Silver Monuments on Stanton Street, a business dating from the late 30's.
Still, gravestone sellers aside, what kind of real future does the Jewish Lower East Side face? Is there enough left to make Jews feel they can find a link to a Jewish past? Or has too much vanished?
"You can find it at the Lower East Side Tenement Museum, you can find it in walking tours," said Samuel Norich, general manager of the Forward Association, which publishes weekly Jewish newspapers in Yiddish, Russian and English from its home on East 33rd Street. "There are enough remnants of Jewish life on the Lower East Side and life going on now that you can build on and conjure up what used to be there.
"In words at least."

SECTION: Section 9; Column 2; Style Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1597 words

HEADLINE: NOTICED; 
In Hollywood, Rudeness to Make an Oscar Blink

BYLINE:  By HILARY DE VRIES 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES 

 BODY:
IT started as a typical industry evening: a small but select dinner given by Sony Pictures at the Telluride Film Festival in Colorado this year. Invitations went out to a handful of high-profile guests, including Salman Rushdie and Peter O'Toole. Acceptances came in, and a table was reserved at a local restaurant.
 So far so good. But when one agent-turned-manager arrived more than an hour late with an entourage (including uninvited guests) and discovered that the only remaining spaces at the table were next to a clutch of junior publicists, he refused to join the party and demanded a private table. At the end of his meal, he declined to pay his bill, which totaled several hundred dollars, and instead sent it to the Sony executives across the room. 
 "It was unbelievably arrogant," said one of the publicists present. "Even by Hollywood's normal standards for rudeness, it was above and beyond. The studio executives were shaking their heads." 
Far from being an isolated occurrence, displays of selfishly hostile behavior are increasingly common in Hollywood, and increasingly by small fry. Once the sole province of box-office stars and a handful of well-known producers and agents, divalike behavior has filtered down -- sometimes way down -- the chain of command. It is now the reflexive stance of personal assistants, who are obsequious to their bosses but aggressively disdainful toward others; of hairstylists to the stars, who show up an hour late for appointments with regular clients; and of unemployed screenwriters, who cancel dinner plans with old friends because they are suddenly "busy."
"Hollywood has serious entitlement issues these days," said Terry Press, the marketing chief at DreamWorks. "There are so many people now who have that attitude of 'Don't you know who I am?' It's not just celebrities anymore, but everyone -- even the people who service celebrities are arrogant and rude."
Boundless egotism has long characterized those drawn to the film industry, and an abrasive style, not to say boorishness, has been typical of its powerful figures since Louis B. Mayer's day. But insiders say the tendency to blow off anyone not part of your own private movie has gotten worse, and it's more widespread. From showing up late to business meetings or not at all for social engagements, to not returning calls, Hollywood etiquette is all about reminding others that you are more important than they are. The practice of canceling a lunch or a dinner date when a better invitation comes along is so common it is known as B.B.D., for Bigger Better Dealing.
Dawn DaLuise, a Hollywood facialist whose clients include Sarah Michelle Gellar and Christina Ricci, said the arrogance has reached children's birthday parties. Recalling a party she gave for her 11-year-old daughter earlier this year, Ms. DaLuise said, "We sent 23 invitations for a catered party and we didn't get a single response." After follow-up phone calls to the parents elicited 17 acceptances, "we still had only 11 people actually show up," she said, adding, "It's the trickle-down effect of Hollywood rudeness."
THE producer Suzanne Todd, whose credits include the "Austin Powers" films and "Memento," explained that "where you fall in the food chain determines how rude you can be and to whom."
"It all depends on who your agent is, where your production deal is, how your movie opened," she went on. "That determines who you can cancel on and who can cancel on you, who you can have attitude with and who can give you attitude."
Longtimers said that changes in the film and television industries over the last decade have accelerated the level of hostility and the decline in civility. They cited cutbacks in production, increased competition from abroad and the raging cult of celebrity.
"This is a town that used to make 120 pictures a year and now makes 50 or 60, so the pressure is really on," said Robert Evans, who headed Paramount Pictures from the mid-1960's to the mid-70's and was the subject of the documentary "The Kid Stays in the Picture" this year. "People act out of fear, because everyone is so hungry for a deal now. There's no etiquette in Hollywood because there is no peace of mind."
Lynda Obst, a producer whose latest film, the thriller "Abandon," opened on Friday, said the business has changed significantly in the past decade. "People used to be more reckless and more collegial," Ms. Obst said. "But the stakes got too high and the attrition rate got too steep, and you wind up rooting for each other's failures now."
The variety of hostility in Hollywood is often not like it is elsewhere, insiders say. It is passive-aggressive behavior, the donning of a mask of amiability that conceals raw antagonism toward one's competitors, even one's friends.
"Although Hollywood is very competitive, it is not confrontational," said Merle Ginsberg, the entertainment editor of W magazine, who is based in Los Angeles. "It's all about your Prozac and your shrink and your yoga and you're 'happy,' and that behavior can easily be misinterpreted."
One Hollywood manager routinely asserts his position while assessing another's place in the pecking order by asking where the other person lives. "It's not about where you live," a screenwriter who knows him said. "It's about whether you are a winner or a loser this week." 
Catherine Olim, a managing director of PMK/HBH, Hollywood's top publicity agency, remembers receiving "a real wake-up call" when she gave a catered party for her parents shortly after moving to Los Angeles a few years ago. Of her invited guests, "many didn't respond at all," Ms. Olim said, and of those who did accept, "many of them never showed."
To outsiders, the industry's laid-back amiability can be misleading. "There is a very particular game that's played in Los Angeles, but it is an insider's game, and you have to know how to read the signals," said Carol Wolper, a screenwriter and the author of two novels about Hollywood, including "The Cigarette Girl." "There is still a politeness code that exists, but that is not the same thing as actually being nice."
She cites the practice of "spinning your day" -- putting on a happy face no matter how badly work went. In New York you can say you had a bad day, "but in L.A. you better look good and sound happy when you're sipping your cosmopolitan at Ago," Ms. Wolper said. "Even if you're an out-of-work actress or writer, you've got to spin your day to show that you have velocity, that you're a success."
Hollywood's penchant for passive-aggressiveness, insiders say, stems from its being a one-industry town where everyone knows everyone else, coupled with the rampant insecurity inherent in a business where fortunes rise and fall on overnight Nielsen ratings and weekend box-office numbers.
"Hollywood attracts a certain kind of person who is very insecure but also very controlling as a result," said Jennifer Klein, a film producer who is also a popular hostess. She cited unreturned phone calls, lateness and a disregard of R.S.V.P.'s as rampant passive-aggressive acts. "It's all about controlling others," she said.
Linda Kairys, a psychotherapist whose patients include many in the film world, attributes the passive-aggressiveness to the transient nature of the entertainment industry as well as the narcissistic personalities it attracts.
"In Hollywood there is an unwritten social code that everyone is so laid back, but underneath that facade is a huge undercurrent of competitiveness," said Ms. Kairys, a cognitive therapist. "People here are so narcissistic, which means they behave with a great deal of grandiosity, but it's coming from a sense of not feeling valued, so there's lots of jealousy, fear and anger. People are so afraid of rejection that they don't act directly, saying what they really mean, but instead act in very self-protective ways that create incredible amounts of hostility."
The producer Sean Daniel, whose films include "The Scorpion King" and "Down to Earth," said Hollywood today hews to a corporate sensibility that is no different from that of any other industry. "It's a driven, organized, hard-working town," Mr. Daniels said. "There are very few lotus-eaters here anymore."
Lotus-eaters may be in short supply, but celebrities have never been more numerous. Not only has the cult of celebrity become the dominant influence in the entertainment industry, but there is now what can be called the phenomenon of the posse -- ever-larger support staffs for stars who routinely earn $20 million a film. Posses include personal assistants, publicists, managers, trainers, stylists and nutritionists who cater to a star's every need. 
And many of the posse members in turn expect others to cater to their needs, pushing the perquisites of celebrity downward. As Ms. Obst observed, "Everyone in L.A. has an attitude now -- even the valets who park your car have attitude -- because it's all based on celebrity."
But a small group of Hollywood power brokers are starting to resist the spread of divatude.
Ms. Todd, the "Austin Powers" producer, whose sister Jennifer is her partner in making movies and also in giving highly sought-after parties, has thrown down what amounts to a gauntlet.
"We do a lot of parties, and I've made it clear that the rudest thing you can do is not to R.S.V.P.," Ms. Todd said. "Tell me you can't make it. That's fine. But if you don't R.S.V.P. or you don't show, you are off my list for good."
It's a policy that just might change some behavior. At least until Austin Powers's mojo wears down, and the Todd sisters lose a bit of their clout.

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Shopping for Bond Gains, Overseas

BYLINE:  By GERALDINE FABRIKANT 

 BODY:
FOR investors who believe that the rally in domestic bonds is ending, there may be an overseas alternative.
 Many bond managers are recommending that investors shift a portion of their fixed-income holdings into foreign bonds -- a switch that most people can accomplish through global bond funds. But because foreign bonds involve currency risk, they are not favored by all financial advisers. 
 The international bond funds tracked by Morningstar Inc. have turned in the second-best performance in the entire fixed-income sector this year through Thursday, returning 6.92 percent, behind only funds that hold long-term United States government bonds, at 8.39 percent. By contrast, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was down 22.51 percent. 
Foreign bonds, particularly those in Europe, may have more room for a rally than their domestic counterparts. Last week, the 10-year United States Treasury note yielded 4.11 percent, compared with 4.59 percent for 10-year German government notes. The yields on euro-denominated bonds are likely to drop in the months ahead, some analysts say, because European economies have lagged behind that of the United States. Falling yields would mean rising prices, because bond yields and prices move in opposite directions.
"Last year, the Fed was aggressively lowering returns so that you got capital gains and the interest" on investments in American bonds, said Stefan D. Abrams, chief investment officer for asset allocation at the New York office of the Trust Company of the West.
"The European Central bank has lagged badly in cutting interest rates," he said. "They will have to catch up because they need to jump-start their economies." 
Mr. Abrams said he believes that the European bank will cut rates, setting off a rally in European bond markets. An interest rate cut could also mean a strengthening of the euro, which has already gained 11 percent against the dollar over the last year, he added.
He cautioned, however, that investors should expect relatively modest returns and should view investments in foreign bond funds primarily as a way to diversify their fixed-income holdings. "This is not some dot-com stock from 1998 that is going up 100 times the day it comes public," he said. "This is merely a way of improving upon your fixed-income funds."
Many international bond funds have had a terrific year so far. The T. Rowe Price International Bond fund has risen 11.6 percent through Thursday, outperforming the Lehman Brothers aggregate bond index by 5.9 percentage points, according to Morningstar. The fund invests primarily in government and corporate debt in Europe and Japan. So far, the fund, which has a minimum initial investment of $2,500, has benefited not only from higher yields on foreign debt but also from the appreciation of the euro.
The T. Rowe Price fund does not hedge currency risk, and while it has benefited from the euro's strength recently, its performance suffered during the years when the dollar was strong. The fund's annualized three-year return through Thursday was only 0.78 percent and its five-year annualized return was 1.79 percent. 
CHRISTOPHER ROTHERY, a portfolio manager of the T. Rowe Price fund, acknowledged that the fund's assets dropped to about $670 million by late 2000 from $1 billion at the end of 1995. As of last month, however, the fund had rebounded to $1 billion, because of both new money and strong performance this year.
By contrast, a fund that uses currency hedging, BlackRock International Bond, had a return of just 4.1 percent this year through Thursday, well behind the T. Rowe Price fund.
But over the longer term, the BlackRock fund, which has a minimum investment of $5,000, has outperformed the T. Rowe Price portfolio. It posted a three-year annualized return of 7.83 percent and a five-year return of 7.19 percent. By hedging, the fund avoided the impact of the strong dollar in the late 1990's. 
Deciding whether to hedge currency risk is difficult, so some advisers prefer to avoid global bond funds entirely. Philip Cook, of Cook & Associates, a certified financial planner in Torrance, Calif., said he thinks that "the risk is greater than the reward."
However, Jim Keene, a money manager at Bingham, Osborn & Scarborough, a wealth management firm in San Francisco, has used international bond funds to diversify investors' portfolios for the last six or seven years. Mr. Keene, whose firm manages $600 million, said that in light of the plunge in American equity markets this year, many international bond funds have been a great investment. "We have increased our exposure a bit this year," he said. 
He likes unhedged funds like the T. Rowe Price fund, but he recognizes that some investors want to avoid currency risk in fixed-income investing. If those investors are going to take on risk, he said, "they would rather that it be on the equity side."
But, he said, "we feel it is worth it to take that risk with a small percentage -- about 3 percent or 4 percent of an individual's portfolio." This year, he added, "it was our best-performing asset class." 
Even in this bull market for bond funds, some have stumbled. AIM Global Income, for example, was down 3.13 percent through Thursday. Bridget B. Hughes, a senior analyst at Morningstar who follows international funds, said the fund's expense ratio was high, at 1.75 percent, compared with a category average of 1.37 percent. (The T. Rowe Price fund has expenses of 0.95 percent, and the BlackRock fund's are 1.22 percent.) 
For the most part, though, AIM was hurt this year by its American corporate and high-yield bond holdings, she said. Investors looking for global diversification should make sure that the percentage of domestic investments in a particular global fund is relatively small, Ms. Hughes added. She also said that investors seeking overseas diversification should look for unhedged funds. This will help insulate their overall portfolios from fluctuations in the value of the dollar.
FOR these reasons, she prefers the T. Rowe Price fund, even though its longer-term performance has not matched that of hedged competitors like BlackRock. (BlackRock, she said, has also held more United States Treasuries and corporate bonds.)
"People who like the idea of international fixed income and want some strong diversification don't need any U.S. exposure in their global bond fund," Ms. Hughes said. "But when the U.S. is doing well, these kinds of funds will suffer in large part because of the currencies."
A number of experts, including Jim O'Neill, head of global economic research at Goldman, Sachs, say they believe that the euro will continue to strengthen against the dollar, which would be a boon for unhedged global bond funds. The dollar "remains on a downward trend," he said.
"The underlying current account deficit is slowly eroding the dollar's ability to stay stable," he added. "Unless the U.S. economy recovers sharply, it will be increasingly difficult for the U.S. to attract that high-quality investment that can offset the deficit." 
International bond funds are not particularly tax-efficient. Still, last year, many investors in the stock market would have been grateful to show gains that generated any taxable income at all.
Some wealthy investors may prefer to cherry-pick bonds from particular countries. But those decisions can be difficult, and the minimum purchase price of individual securities may be $100,000. That is why many financial advisers suggest that most people venture into international fixed-income investing through a diversified mutual fund.
