 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 9; Column 2; Style Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 1965 words

HEADLINE: Partying Like It's 1999 

BYLINE:  By KATHERINE ROSMAN 

 BODY:
IT was another exhausting night for David Dobkin. Last Wednesday, on the dance floor at Suite 16 in Chelsea, Mr. Dobkin, 23, twirled and dipped various pretty young things with the panache of a man who had charmed women on many previous evenings on many similar dance floors. He was not quite sweating. Rather, he glowed. 
 Ready for a refreshment, he sidled up to the bar next to Neil Fried, also 23, and invited him to join him for a few days in Las Vegas. "Why not?" Mr. Dobkin cajoled excitedly. "I've got the cash." The expression on Mr. Fried's face was troubled. Jetting off to Las Vegas was not so easy; he had a job as an investment banker at Dresdner Kleinwort Wasserstein. 
 Mr. Dobkin, on the other hand, did not. Early last month, he was laid off by the same boutique firm when it dissolved his entire department. But the disappearance of a paycheck has not hindered his social life. "My severance is very good," he said. "I'll probably make more money this year than a lot of people who haven't been laid off." 
Mr. Dobkin is a member of the city's latest downtown subculture, a small, but -- if you happen to be at nightclubs like Lotus, Suite 16 and Bungalow 8 at 3 in the morning -- flamboyant segment of today's unemployed. Laid off in droves by Wall Street in the last 18 months, they are young, mostly single and childless. Coasting on savings and generous severance packages, they use their unemployment checks as pocket change, and pointedly don't look for jobs.
Like the dot-com castoffs who hit the streets two years ago, this group is enjoying its recent liberation from 18-hour work days by staying out late, night after night. And they have an added incentive to slack off: there are no jobs to be had.
Brad Gishen, 30, who lost his investment banking job in February, goes out to clubs and restaurants almost every night, while pouring much of his severance package and savings into the Concept Management Group, which he founded to promote unknown visual artists and fashion designers. "The last thing I wanted to do in February was look for another job, when every other bank was laying people off," he said. 
Jeff Valenty, 32, left his job as a managing director of a leading investment firm during a restructuring one and a half years ago. Since then, he has traveled to Southeast Asia, South America and Europe. "I worked hard for over nine years," he said. "I ran the Wall Street treadmill and didn't have the opportunities to do any of the things I've been able to do." He says he goes out four or five nights a week.
Employment in the securities industry in New York City plummeted by 22,900 jobs in the 13-month period ending in September, according to the New York State Department of Labor. The figure does not reflect more recent announcements, like Wednesday's disclosure by J. P. Morgan that it plans to eliminate 2,000 more investment banking jobs. Though the Labor Department does not tally unemployment by age, conventional wisdom on Wall Street suggests that a vast majority of those laid off are under 40.
Some laid-off Wall Streeters have even adopted a name for themselves: the 405 Club, a reference to an evening last year when a group of unemployed investment bankers jestingly tried to pay an $800 dinner bill at Craft, in the Flatiron district, by signing over their $405 unemployment checks -- the maximum benefit offered by the Labor Department. 
Severance packages for investment bankers, the values of which are influenced by seniority and education, usually consist of about three to six months' paid salary, plus a portion of the bonus the employee would have gotten at the year's end, experts say. In the case of a junior-level banker who missed out on the truly golden year, from 1999 to 2000, the package could still approach $50,000. For others -- especially if they signed employment contracts during the boom, which guaranteed their salaries for years -- a mid-level banker could leave with a $600,000 exit package.
"I've never seen anybody not walk out without a smile on their face," said one banker who yearns to be laid off. "Once they are over the shock, they are some of the happiest people you've ever seen. They dance out of the building."
Which is why, judging by those who observe the nocturnal habits of the young, not all of them are staying home drowning their sorrows in Haagen-Dazs and videos. Far from it. "We have never been busier," said David Rabin, an owner of Lotus, the meatpacking district hot spot. "There is no question that there is a lot of leftover money being spent on Cristal. Someone is still buying the magnums of Belvedere vodka." 
Indeed, an after-hours tour of Manhattan night spots last week turned up dozens of unemployed financial industry workers partying like it's 1999. 
Noah Tepperberg, a co-owner of Suite 16, said that since early July, Monday nights have swelled from attracting 200 revelers to 500. "It's the guys I used to see in clubs in suits on the weekends," he said. "You'll look around and ask, 'Who are these people? Do they work?' The answer is, not many of them do, or they wouldn't be out at 4:30 a.m. on a Monday."
Curt Miller, the chief executive of A-L Associates, a recruiting firm for lawyers and financiers, said he is aware that some laid-off Wall Streeters are out enjoying themselves a little too much. "There are people in their late 20's, early 30's, who are saying, 'I've worked hard for the last couple years, I've saved some money, I'm going to go skiing for the winter,' " he said. " 'If someone wants to call me with a job, they can reach me in Vail.' " 
He added: "I do not think it is a good idea for people to be abusive and to just party. It is inappropriate when you are out of work and in a job market like this."
But one 29-year-old out-of-work banker, who was laid off more than a year ago from the investment banking firm Lazard, is not heeding such advice. Last Monday night, he was at the Church Street Lounge at the Tribeca Grand Hotel, showing off one of the most prized dividends of his unemployment. 
"Feel!" he implored a tall, thin brunette sitting next to him as he sucked in his stomach and jutted his chin forward in an abdominal-muscle flex. Since being let go, the former banker, in addition to traveling to California, Hawaii, Paris, London and Capri, has also been working out two hours a day, paying particular attention to his abdominals. 
Neither the travel nor the physique have come cheap. After less than two years of work, he left Lazard with a package he said totaled nearly $300,000, which he promptly deposited into his checking account. "Unfortunately, it's mostly gone," said the young man, who asked not to be identified (a condition of many Wall Street severance packages is that ex-employees not discuss them publicly). Such economic cruelties forced the banker to accept a new job, which he plans to start soon.
In the meantime, he keeps busy. For the 405-ers, a typical schedule consists of Sundays at Bungalow 8 (for bingo) followed by Pangaea; Mondays at the Tribeca Grand and then Sway; Tuesdays at the Park for karaoke followed by drinks at APT; and Wednesdays at Pangaea, Suite 16 and Lotus. 
"You exhaust yourself during the week," said a 23-year-old woman who was laid off from an investment bank, "and then you have to force yourself to go out on Thursday, Friday and Saturday night if you want to meet people with jobs."
For those who can't be so cavalier with their cash, there's an abbreviated version of the schedule. Derrick Diggs, a member of the crowd who met at the Tribeca Grand last Monday, said, "You scrimp by so that you can be fabulous one or two nights a week." Mr. Diggs, 33, who was laid off by Morgan Stanley a year ago, had been at the company for only a year and received a nominal severance. He is now struggling under the weight of $140,000 in debt he ran up while earning a joint M.B.A. and law degree at the University of Pennsylvania. 
"I'm concerned," he said of his financial situation. Still, he cannot conceive of ignoring the spoils offered in New York. To keep his bar tab reasonably low, Mr. Diggs said, "I pre-party at home" before venturing out. 
"These young people still want to see and be seen," said Steven Hall, owner of a restaurant consulting and publicity company. "They've saved money, they've gotten severance packages, and when you're 25, you're not thinking about saving. When you're 25, you say, 'I've got 10 dollars so I'll spend 15.' " 
In any economy, Manhattan's bar scene revolves around young professionals with money to burn. "These guys, whether they are laid off or just making less money, are going out a lot," agreed John McDonald, owner of Canteen and Merc Bar, and the co-owner of Dos Caminos, a new Gramercy Park bar and restaurant. "If you don't have kids and you're living in Manhattan, you are not going to be a caged animal in your apartment. You drink because things are good, and you drink because things are tough."
Some laid-off bankers are so satisfied with their current status that they have been known to turn down the rare job offer. A laid-off senior investment banker described how a friend at USA Interactive, the new media branch of Barry Diller's USA Networks, asked him to recommend a candidate for a job that paid $125,000. He suggested an unemployed junior investment banker whom he had helped train at Salomon Smith Barney. The young man, however, said he was not interested in a position that paid so little. 
The older banker was horrified. "I said: 'What? Are you crazy? It is a nightmare job market, this is a place to get insurance, to learn, to make a network. I don't think $125,000 is a little amount of money.' "
The young analyst was not swayed. "It was unbelievable," said the older banker. "The guy turned down the introduction." 
In short, a job can just get in the way of enjoying one's unemployment. Consider Vipul Tandon, 28, who said that last summer, as many of his friends lost their jobs and began to go out until the wee hours, he felt left out of the fun because he had to get up in the morning and go to work. So last month, Mr. Tandon said, he quit his job as head of strategic planning for a chemical company to join them. "It just seems like a good time not to be working," he explained. 
Even without a severance package, he said, he has few financial worries. "If you have been in business for the last four or five years, you're stupid if you don't have a lot of money saved," he said.
Some see the hubris of such an attitude as an extension of the recent boom. "The market of the 1990's fostered the arrogance displayed by these young former rainmakers," said Josiah Low, 63, a retired managing director of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette and Merrill Lynch. "We saw youngsters achieve remarkable financial success. They didn't know how to handle the success and now that same group is unwilling to scale back."
One former investment banker, who was laid off twice in the last two years, is appalled by the behavior of his peers. "It just makes us all look so bad," he said. "All of us bankers, all of us New Yorkers."
Mr. Dobkin, the laid-off banker planning a trip to Las Vegas, understands that his severance will support his spending spree for only so long -- perhaps a few more months. He is not overly troubled about finding a new job, and he said that if it came to "beating down doors" to get hired, he would sooner move to Colorado for the winter to ski. 
In general, Mr. Dobkin said, the corporate accounting scandals have left him disillusioned with the business world and his chosen profession in finance. He is trying his hand at writing a television sitcom. He described it as "post-'Seinfeld,' post-'Friends,' post-9/11."
"You know," he said, "the Holden Caulfield of modern-day New York, but not as depressing."

PUB-DATE: October 20, 2002
 Late Edition - Final 

SECTION: Section 3; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 10

LENGTH: 765 words

HEADLINE: PRELUDES; 
Business Plans Without a Dot-Com

BYLINE:  By ABBY ELLIN; Abby Ellin is a Manhattan writer. Her column on starting out in the world of money appears the third Sunday of each month. E-mail: preludes@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
IN the mid- to late 1990's, one of the most fashionable things a young person could do was to start a business, particularly if it involved a high-technology gizmo or the creation of a virtual company.
 Of course, many of those enterprises died after the dot-com bubble burst, but the entrepreneurial spirit lives on. These days, young people are working with more traditional products, using, say, chocolate chips instead of microchips. 
 Jerry F. White, director of the Caruth Institute of Owner-Managed Business, the entrepreneurial center at the Cox School of Business at Southern Methodist University in Dallas, has witnessed the shift. 
In 2000, ideas involving the Internet were in half of all the student business plans that he saw. Not anymore. "I probably had two Internet-related concepts this past spring, and the rest of the students went back to fundamental industries," said Mr. White, who has been teaching for three decades. He expects to find even fewer technology-related plans this year. 
Mr. White said he believed that the years 1994 to 2000 -- from the emergence of the Internet to the start of the stock market collapse -- were anomalies. The current environment is more typical.
"Students are going back to what they were doing before 1994 -- things like food, clothes, basic entertainment," he said. "So what appears to be some kind of radical detox in technology is really a return to the norm."
That is also the view of Jerad Boyd, director of university relations at Students in Free Enterprise, a nonprofit group in Springfield, Mo., that promotes entrepreneurship. He says he believes that young people didn't always feel passionately about the dot-com industry -- it was just where the money happened to be. Now they are motivated by personal interests, not stock options, he said.
"There has to be a mix of passion and desire to starting your own business -- you have to enjoy it," Mr. Boyd said.
Seth Appel, 34, of Manhattan, seems to meet those criteria. He says he has a "certain nostalgia for a time when at the end of the days' labor there was a tangible product, like a desk, a chair, a house." In his case, it's sweets.
Mr. Appel, though, hasn't quit his day job -- yet. He is director of the Jewish Volunteer Corps of the American Jewish World Service. By night, he and two friends gather to cook pralines. He and his partners hope to someday soon start a praline business (tentatively called Pralines for Peace.) In the meantime, they are conducting weekly focus groups about their concoctions. 
"The traditional recipe is too sweet and overpowering, so we're modifying it," he said.
The entrepreneurial bug has also hit Molly Hislop, 28, who works as an analyst for an online market research company in New York. She recently started a jewelry design company called Marlow Designs. While she's not planning to become the next Harry Winston, she says she does want to run a business that is "small in scope, but profitable enough for me to maintain a modest standard of living."
You never know, though, where a small business may take you.
In 1996, D. J. McKie, now 31, left his job as a municipal bond trader in Chicago to start Digital Java, a small company that sold roasted coffee and imported coffee machines to wholesalers. He had always loved coffee (as a child, his mother gave it to him by the spoonful) and after three years at the firm, he realized that he loved coffee beans more than corporate bonds. Two and a half years ago, he crossed paths with an executive from Krispy Kreme Doughnuts.
"I wanted to sell them espresso machines because I'd heard they were upgrading their coffee program," he said. 
As it happened, they were, but they didn't want his espresso machines -- they wanted him. In February 2001, Krispy Kreme bought Digital Java for $389,500 in cash. Seven months later, Mr. McKie, along with his wife, Jennifer, and baby daughter, Madison, moved from Chicago to Winston-Salem, N.C., where he become senior vice president and general manager of Krispy Kreme's coffee and beverages division. 
No one is more surprised than Mr. McKie. "I don't think anyone goes into it and says, 'This is great, I'm going to be a coffee king,' " he said. "I just did what I cared about, and it worked out nicely."
Mr. Appel, meanwhile, says he's not looking to become a praline magnate or to take his company public. Instead, he says, his goal is to "make a great praline recipe that people love to eat and are willing to buy, and to create a business that generates more income than expenses." 
"We're going back to the farm in an urban context," he added.
